cards.summary: Documentation for typedSearchAttributes is incomplete and lacks concrete examples for migrating from the deprecated searchAttributes API in WorkflowOptions.
cards.userImpact: Users attempting to migrate from deprecated searchAttributes to typedSearchAttributes lack clear guidance and concrete examples in the documentation.
cards.proposedFix: Add concrete examples and migration guidance for typedSearchAttributes to the TypeScript documentation at docs.temporal.io/develop/typescript/observability
cards.keyQuote: Documentation still mentions only searchAttributes at https://docs.temporal.io/develop/typescript/observability without the concrete examples how to use typedSearchAttributes

cards.summary: Feature request to add workflow API for creating independent deterministic PRNG sequences to prevent NDEs when plugins and workflow code both use Math.random() or uuid4(), which can disrupt the global PRNG sequence during replay.
cards.userImpact: Workflow plugins that use random number generation or UUID creation can cause non-deterministic errors during workflow replay if the global PRNG sequence is shared with workflow code.
cards.rootCause: Workflow plugins and workflow code share the same PRNG sequence, causing sequence misalignment during replay when plugins are added or removed.
cards.proposedFix: Add API to create distinct deterministic PRNG instances, generate UUIDs from those instances, and activate a PRNG instance as the global one within a given execution scope to isolate plugin PRNG usage.
cards.keyQuote: If the workflow code also use these methods, then the plugin and the workflow code both pull values out of the same PRNG sequence. That may result in NDEs if a workflow is replayed after adding/removing a Plugin.

cards.summary: MCP tools passed to the AI-SDK are missing descriptions and have incorrect input parameter definitions. The tool descriptions are being dropped, and nested jsonSchema structures are causing parsing failures in the model.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot properly use MCP tools with the Temporal AI-SDK because tool descriptions are missing and malformed schemas prevent models from parsing tool definitions correctly.
cards.rootCause: Tool descriptions are being dropped during transformation, and inputSchema contains a nested jsonSchema structure instead of being flattened, which was partially addressed in PR #1890 but not fully applied.
cards.proposedFix: Ensure tool descriptions are preserved in the transformation pipeline and flatten the inputSchema structure to remove the nested jsonSchema wrapper.
cards.resolutionDetails: Issue was addressed through PR #1890 and subsequent releases, though the reporter noted the fix required verification with newer versions.
cards.keyQuote: You still have a nested jsonSchema inside inputSchema which means that #1890 was not applied successfully. That's making ollama fail to parse the tool.

cards.summary: Request to expose per-activity-type counts in WorkerInfo alongside existing aggregate metrics like numInFlightActivities. This would help developers debug worker task slot exhaustion by identifying which activity types are consuming resources.
cards.userImpact: Developers can better diagnose why worker activity task slots are full by identifying which activity types are occupying resources.
cards.proposedFix: Add a Map field to WorkerInfo where keys are activity types and values are in-flight counts for that type, optionally behind an environment variable flag.
cards.keyQuote: when user detects that all worker activity task slots are full, basically worker stops at that point polling for more activity tasks, they can check what activity types are occupying worker

cards.summary: Logging is currently suppressed during queries and update validators because `isReplaying()` returns true. This feature request seeks to allow logging in these live read operations, bringing TypeScript SDK in line with other SDKs.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot log diagnostics during query and update validator execution, limiting debugging and observability for these critical operations.
cards.rootCause: The `isReplaying()` check suppresses logging during all replay scenarios, but queries and update validators are live read operations that should allow logging.
cards.proposedFix: Modify the logging suppression logic to allow logging during queries and update validators while keeping it suppressed during actual workflow replay.
cards.keyQuote: Currently logging is suppressed during queries and update validators because `isReplaying()` returns true. We should allow logging during these live read operations.

cards.summary: The `operatorService` is not accessible on the `ConnectionLike` interface, requiring users to cast the connection to `Connection` type to access operator functionality like listing search attributes.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot directly access operatorService through client.connection without type casting, breaking TypeScript type safety and requiring workarounds.
cards.rootCause: The ConnectionLike interface does not expose operatorService, even though the concrete Connection class has it initialized.
cards.proposedFix: Add operatorService to the ConnectionLike interface so it's accessible on the type-safe connection reference.
cards.workaround: Cast client.connection to Connection type: `(client.connection as Connection).operatorService`
cards.keyQuote: operatorService cannot be available on the ConnectionLike interface... it is initialized on the client

cards.summary: MCP Client connection closes before tool execution completes in callToolActivity. The function needs to await the tool.execute() call instead of returning the promise directly, causing the connection to close prematurely.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot successfully call MCP server tools through Temporal workflows because connections close before tool execution completes.
cards.rootCause: Missing await keyword on tool.execute() call causes the promise to return without waiting for completion, allowing the MCP connection to close prematurely.
cards.proposedFix: Add await keyword before tool.execute(args.input, args.options) on line 66 of @temporalio/ai-sdk/lib/activities.js
cards.keyQuote: It must be return await tool.execute(args.input, args.options);

cards.summary: TypeScript SDK is unable to call tools when using Google as provider with MCP server due to a missing `clientArgs` property on the args object. The code references `args.clientArgs` which does not exist, causing the tool calling functionality to fail.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot use the tool calling feature with Google provider and MCP server due to a code error that prevents argument passing.
cards.rootCause: The code at line 59 references `args.clientArgs` which does not exist on the args object, causing a runtime error when attempting to call tools.
cards.resolutionDetails: Issue was closed, indicating the missing clientArgs property was likely fixed in a subsequent commit.
cards.keyQuote: Line 59 -> args.clientArgs does not exist.

cards.summary: The TypeScript SDK is not reading the default environment configuration TOML file from the correct macOS path ($HOME/Library/Application Support/temporalio/temporal.toml), causing configuration loading to fail.
cards.userImpact: Workers on macOS cannot load default environment configuration files, preventing users from using centralized configuration management on that platform.
cards.rootCause: The TypeScript SDK is not correctly resolving the macOS Application Support directory path for environment configuration files.
cards.resolutionDetails: The issue was confirmed to be a file path resolution problem in the SDK that was fixed to correctly use $HOME/Library/Application Support/temporalio/temporal.toml on macOS.
cards.keyQuote: the SDKs should read the toml config file on a mac from $HOME/Library/Application Support/temporal/temporal.toml. However this path is not being read

cards.summary: Feature request to allow Logger configuration at the Worker level instead of globally via Runtime.install, enabling different logger instances for each Worker in multi-Worker test scenarios for isolation and per-test behavior control.
cards.userImpact: Users running parallel tests with isolated Workers cannot configure different loggers per Worker, preventing per-test logging behavior and assertions on log output.
cards.proposedFix: Allow the Logger to be configured at the Worker level instead of globally through Runtime.install
cards.keyQuote: Allow the Logger to be configured at the Worker level. This would allow us to create a "test logger" instance for each test to enable what we want.

cards.summary: After upgrading to TypeScript SDK 1.14.0, workflows using signals with `condition` are failing with phantom `CancelledFailure` errors. The issue appears to be a race condition introduced in 1.14.0, as downgrading to 1.13.1/1.13.2 resolves the problem and the same code works on the earlier version.
cards.userImpact: Workflows in production fail unexpectedly with CancelledFailure errors when using signals with conditions, disrupting business workflows until versions are downgraded.
cards.rootCause: A race condition was introduced in version 1.14.0 in the signal and condition handling code, specifically in the cancellation scope or workflow signal processing.
cards.proposedFix: Fix #1871 was released in 1.14.1 to address the race condition in signal and condition handling.
cards.workaround: Downgrade to version 1.13.2 or 1.13.1 to avoid the issue; reset affected workflows to the signal event and they will run correctly.
cards.resolutionDetails: The issue was fixed in version 1.14.1 via PR #1871, which addressed the race condition in signal and condition processing.
cards.keyQuote: A race condition seems to have been introduced since we do observe some of our workflows succeeding with a signal and condition.

cards.summary: Feature request to update the TypeScript SDK's AI SDK integration to support v6, as per Vercel's AI SDK 6 release.
cards.userImpact: Users leveraging the AI SDK integration will benefit from the latest v6 features and improvements.
cards.proposedFix: Update the AI SDK integration to v6 following Vercel's release announcement.
cards.resolutionDetails: Resolved by PR #1865 which implements the AI SDK v6 update.
cards.keyQuote: Update AI SDK integration to v6

cards.summary: Feature request to improve error messages when workflow code is imported into activity dependencies or when activities and workflows are mixed in ways that violate sandbox assumptions. Current error message 'Failed to connect before the deadline' is misleading and sends developers down the wrong debugging path.
cards.userImpact: Developers receive misleading error messages when they accidentally mix workflows and activities, wasting time debugging connectivity issues instead of identifying code organization problems.
cards.rootCause: Error messages do not distinguish between actual gRPC connectivity failures and sandbox constraint violations caused by incorrect code placement.
cards.proposedFix: Generate specific error messages that detect and communicate when workflow code appears in activity dependencies or when the sandbox assumptions are violated.
cards.keyQuote: Improve error messages when workflow code ends up in an activity dependency / non-sandboxed side, or activities and workflows end up mixed in a way that breaks the sandbox assumptions.

cards.summary: Performance regression from SDK version 1.13.1 to 1.13.2 causes significant CPU degradation in worker processing despite no obvious changes in the release. A comment suggests a lazy-loaded module added in 1.13.2 may be responsible.
cards.userImpact: Users experience significant CPU usage degradation and performance degradation when upgrading from 1.13.1 to 1.13.2, impacting worker efficiency.
cards.rootCause: A lazy-loaded module that was added in 1.13.2 is suspected to be causing the performance regression.
cards.proposedFix: Try version 1.14.1 where the lazy-loaded module was removed, which may resolve the regression.
cards.workaround: Revert to SDK version 1.13.1 with the patch from PR #1834 to maintain performance.
cards.keyQuote: Updating to `1.13.2` shows a significant degradation in performance. We removed a lazy loaded module that was added in `1.13.2` that might be behind the regression you saw.

cards.summary: After upgrading from v1.11.8 to v1.13.2, OpenTelemetry instrumentation causes excessive CPU usage (up to 100%), which disappears when OTel is disabled. The issue appears related to changes between these versions, possibly involving the reusev8context option or lazy-loaded modules.
cards.userImpact: Users with OpenTelemetry instrumentation enabled experience severe CPU usage spikes (up to 100%) after upgrading to v1.13.x, making production deployments unusable.
cards.rootCause: Likely a lazy-loaded module added in v1.13.2 or interaction between OTel interceptors and reusev8context option, with additional regression in v1.13.2 vs v1.13.1.
cards.proposedFix: Remove the lazy-loaded module added in v1.13.2 or disable reusev8context option as a workaround. Upgrade to v1.14.1 which removed the problematic lazy-loaded module.
cards.workaround: Disable reusev8context option, or downgrade to v1.11.8, or remove OpenTelemetry instrumentation temporarily.
cards.keyQuote: Upon updating from v1.11.8 to v1.13.2, we started to see excessive CPU usage, sometimes up to 100%. Removing all uses of @temporalio/interceptors-opentelemetry resolves the CPU issue.

cards.summary: The TypeScript SDK's `reuseV8Context` feature freezes the global Reflect object, preventing reflect-metadata from patching it with its helpers. This breaks class-based workflows using Inversify decorators, which worked in SDK 1.11.8 but fails in later versions.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot use class-based workflows with decorator libraries like Inversify unless they disable reuseV8Context, incurring significant performance penalties.
cards.rootCause: The SDK freezes the global Reflect object inside reusable workflow isolates, preventing reflect-metadata from adding its patches via Object.defineProperty.
cards.workaround: Disable reuseV8Context by setting it to false, though this increases memory and CPU footprint.
cards.keyQuote: Temporal freezes the global Reflect object inside the reusable workflow isolate, so reflect-metadata cannot add its helpers.

cards.summary: The @temporalio/core-bridge package cannot be built from source in Alpine Linux because bridge-macros files were refactored into a separate top-level folder but were not included in the package.json files list after version 0.12.0.
cards.userImpact: Users building in Alpine/musl environments cannot build the core-bridge Rust binary from source, blocking deployment in containerized environments.
cards.rootCause: After refactoring bridge-macros into a separate top-level folder, the files were not included in the package.json files field, making them unavailable in the installed npm package.
cards.proposedFix: Include bridge-macros files in the core-bridge package.json files field alongside other Rust source files, and optionally add musl target support with strip flag in Cargo.toml.
cards.workaround: Commit the bridge-macros files directly to the repository and apply custom patches for musl support in the build pipeline.
cards.resolutionDetails: PR #1852 was opened to address the missing bridge-macros files in the package distribution.
cards.keyQuote: These files should be included in the `core-bridge` package along with the other rust source files so that we can build them from source.

cards.summary: The docstring for OtelCollectorExporter's url parameter incorrectly states that OTEL_EXPORTER_OTLP_ENDPOINT environment variable will override the provided value, but no such code exists. This documentation is confusing and should be removed.
cards.userImpact: Users reading the documentation are confused about whether environment variables override the url parameter when they actually do not.
cards.rootCause: Inaccurate docstring that references non-existent code for environment variable handling
cards.proposedFix: Remove the note about OTEL_EXPORTER_OTLP_ENDPOINT environment variable override from the docstring
cards.keyQuote: This appears to be incorrect given that there is no code that references the environment variable.

cards.summary: Feature request to enable executing activities outside of workflow context. The SDK must support new server APIs for starting, managing, and retrieving results of standalone activities, and workers must be able to run activities without being part of a workflow.
cards.userImpact: Users will be able to execute activities independently without requiring a workflow context, enabling new use cases for distributed task execution.
cards.proposedFix: Implement support for new server APIs (referenced in temporalio/api#640) for starting, managing, and getting results of activities. Update workers to support running activities outside workflow context.
cards.keyQuote: Allow executing activities without a workflow. The clients must support the new (upcoming) server APIs for starting, managing and getting results of activities.

cards.summary: Feature request to simplify OpenTelemetry interceptor setup in TypeScript SDK by implementing it as a Plugin, allowing users to initialize OTEL with a single plugin object instead of manual configuration.
cards.userImpact: Developers must currently use awkward OTEL interceptor setup when they should be able to use a simple plugin pattern.
cards.proposedFix: Implement OpenTelemetryPlugin class that accepts configuration (resource, traceExporter) and can be passed to both Worker.create() and Client constructor via plugins array.
cards.keyQuote: Setting up OTEL should be as easy as [plugin instantiation] const worker = await Worker.create({...plugins: [plugin]})

cards.summary: The default maxCachedWorkflows calculation uses V8 heap memory limits but doesn't account for the fact that workflow VM isolates allocate native memory outside the heap, causing unexpected OOM errors in containerized environments where heap limits are set high relative to container limits.
cards.userImpact: Users experience unexpected OOMKill events in Kubernetes when running TypeScript SDK workflows with high maxHeapMemory settings, despite appearing to have sufficient memory available.
cards.rootCause: The maxCachedWorkflows calculation formula only considers V8 heap memory (--max-old-space-size) but VM isolates consume native memory outside the heap, making the total memory footprint larger than calculated.
cards.proposedFix: Update default calculation to be more conservative or factor in that VM cache memory is additive to heap usage; add logging to warn when calculated maxCachedWorkflows * ~1MB + maxHeapMemory would exceed available system memory.
cards.keyQuote: VM isolates consume ~2.6GB of NATIVE memory (not heap), Total memory = heap + VM cache + overhead > container limit â†’ OOMKill

cards.summary: The TypeScript SDK's WorkflowExecutionAlreadyStartedError does not include the runId when the server provides it, even though the SDK already has the capability to extract this information from protobuf-encoded error details.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot easily identify which workflow execution is already running when encountering this error, making debugging and recovery more difficult.
cards.rootCause: The TS SDK decodes protobuf error details but does not extract or include the runId field in the WorkflowExecutionAlreadyStartedError exception.
cards.proposedFix: Extract the runId from protobuf-encoded error details and include it in the thrown WorkflowExecutionAlreadyStartedError.
cards.keyQuote: The runId is stored as part of the protobuf-encoded error details, which the TS SDK already knows how to decode.

cards.summary: Worker crashes with 'async hook stack has become corrupted' error when Prometheus metrics are enabled under high concurrency (100+ concurrent tasks). The crash occurs in Node.js worker threads and causes continuous pod restarts in production Kubernetes deployments.
cards.userImpact: Production workers become completely unstable and crash repeatedly when monitoring with Prometheus metrics under moderate-to-high concurrency, breaking observability and service reliability.
cards.rootCause: Async hook stack corruption in Node.js runtime when processing high concurrency with Prometheus metrics enabled, indicating improper async context tracking or stack management in the metrics exporter.
cards.workaround: Disable Prometheus metrics in production or reduce worker concurrency below levels that trigger the bug.
cards.keyQuote: Workers crash repeatedly with Error: `async hook stack has become corrupted` when Prometheus metrics are enabled.

cards.summary: Feature request to allow overriding the Worker Deployment Version when invoking a Child Workflow, similar to the capability available when creating a Workflow from a client. This enables pre-deployment testing scenarios.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot test pre-deployment versions when using child workflows, limiting their testing capabilities before deployment.
cards.proposedFix: Allow overriding the target version on a child workflow invocation using the same mechanism available for client-initiated workflows.
cards.keyQuote: Users want to override the target version on a workflow, especially when doing pre-deployment testing.

cards.summary: Feature request to add native sticky sessions support to the TypeScript SDK to ensure all tasks of a workflow execute on the same worker, enabling workflows with local state. Closed as duplicate of temporalio/features#562 with indication that sessions will be redesigned across all SDKs.
cards.userImpact: Users needing workflows with local state must implement manual sticky execution mechanisms instead of having native SDK support like Go SDK provides.
cards.rootCause: TypeScript SDK lacks native sticky sessions implementation that Go SDK has, forcing users to build custom solutions.
cards.proposedFix: Implement native sticky sessions in TypeScript SDK based on reference implementation using WorkerRegistrationService, HeartbeatService, and WorkflowBalancerService with worker capacity tracking.
cards.workaround: Use Worker Specific Task Queue pattern as mentioned in samples, though it requires complex user-land implementation with limited concurrency control.
cards.resolutionDetails: Closed as duplicate of temporalio/features#562. Team acknowledged the feature's value but declined this specific implementation, indicating sessions will be redesigned holistically across all SDKs when implemented.
cards.keyQuote: So yes, we do intend to add Sessions support at some point. And when we do, we'll add it to _all_ of our official SDKs, not only TypeScript.

cards.summary: Feature request to enable worker heartbeating in the TypeScript SDK by allowing users to specify the worker heartbeat interval when initializing Core Runtime. This capability is already implemented in Core but needs to be exposed to users.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot configure worker heartbeat intervals, limiting their ability to manage worker connection health and responsiveness.
cards.proposedFix: Enable worker heartbeating by allowing users to specify the worker heartbeat interval when initializing Core Runtime
cards.resolutionDetails: Worker heartbeating was enabled in the TypeScript SDK by exposing the heartbeat interval configuration option during Core Runtime initialization
cards.keyQuote: Worker heartbeating is implemented in Core, need to enable worker heartbeating by allowing users to specify the worker heartbeat interval when initializing Core Runtime

cards.summary: Users cannot distinguish error types in TypeScript SDK logs because errors lose type information when passed between Worker and Workflow boundaries, preventing appropriate log level assignment and error categorization.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot determine error origins or apply appropriate logging levels, making production debugging and error handling more difficult.
cards.rootCause: NodeJS/V8 limitation: object prototypes and class information are lost when cloning objects across worker threads, as documented in NodeJS worker_threads API.
cards.proposedFix: Introduce a type indicator field or code field in logged errors to distinguish error sources, potentially as a new non-breaking field alongside the existing failure field.
cards.keyQuote: Currently users cannot distinguish error types in Temporal's TypeScript SDK logs, all logged errors appear as plain Error objects with no type information.

cards.summary: TypeScript SDK 1.12.2 introduced a regression in type inference for activity return types when using proxyActivities, causing 'implicitly has type any' errors in code that previously compiled successfully. The issue is linked to changes in the ActivityInterfaceFor type definition in PR #1657.
cards.userImpact: Users upgrading to SDK 1.12.2+ experience TypeScript compilation failures in previously working code that uses proxyActivities with implicit type inference.
cards.rootCause: Changes to ActivityInterfaceFor type in PR #1657 wrapping activity functions with ActivityFunctionWithOptions introduced circular type references that break TypeScript's type inference.
cards.workaround: Explicitly type variables storing activity return values (e.g., `const result: { pointer: number } = await sampleActivity(...)`) or rearrange code to initialize with destructuring before use in loops.
cards.keyQuote: error TS7022: '...' implicitly has type 'any' because it does not have a type annotation and is referenced directly or indirectly in its own initializer.

cards.summary: Workflow history replay fails with a nondeterminism error when child workflows are present, even though the child workflow IDs are generated fresh from the history. The error indicates a mismatch between scheduled event IDs and command IDs for child workflows during replay.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot run workflow history compatibility tests in CI to prevent nondeterministic changes when workflows contain child workflows.
cards.rootCause: Issue #1744 identified as likely cause; related to child workflow ID generation during replay
cards.keyQuote: Child workflow id of scheduled event does not match child workflow id of command - This means that the workflow code as written is not compatible with the history

cards.summary: Feature request to allow querying the port and address from TestWorkflowEnvironment when using a random free port with createLocal(), enabling manual client creation without needing to pass the address separately to the application.
cards.userImpact: Users must use undocumented APIs or pass port/address separately when creating clients with randomly allocated ports in tests.
cards.rootCause: TestWorkflowEnvironment.createLocal() does not expose a public API to query the allocated port/address when using random free ports.
cards.proposedFix: Add a public method to TestWorkflowEnvironment to query the port/address (similar to the undocumented native.ephemeralServerGetTarget approach).
cards.workaround: Use native.ephemeralServerGetTarget(env["server"]) to access the internal server target.
cards.resolutionDetails: Feature was implemented to expose port/address query capability in TestWorkflowEnvironment.
cards.keyQuote: Allow querying the port/address so it's possible to use a random free port when creating clients manually.

cards.summary: The @temporalio/interceptors-opentelemetry package has peer dependencies on @temporalio/activity, @temporalio/common, @temporalio/worker, and @temporalio/workflow, causing Yarn warnings when consuming only @temporalio/client. The fix is to mark these peer dependencies as optional.
cards.userImpact: Users get Yarn peer dependency warnings when using @temporalio/interceptors-opentelemetry with only @temporalio/client, requiring unnecessary package installations.
cards.rootCause: Peer dependencies in @temporalio/interceptors-opentelemetry are not marked as optional, causing package managers to warn about missing dependencies in projects that don't need all components.
cards.proposedFix: Add peerDependenciesMeta entries with optional: true for all @temporalio/* peer dependencies, and add runtime detection to handle missing optional packages gracefully.
cards.resolutionDetails: Peer dependencies were marked as optional using peerDependenciesMeta configuration with runtime package detection.
cards.keyQuote: The correct thing to do would be to add a `peerDependenciesMeta.*.optional: true` entry for all `@temporalio/*` dependencies.

cards.summary: WorkflowIdReusePolicy.TERMINATE_IF_RUNNING is marked as deprecated in SDK code but still documented as valid in official Temporal.io docs, causing confusion. User needs clarification on whether it's safe to use, especially for child workflows that need to reset with their parent.
cards.userImpact: Users are uncertain whether deprecated TERMINATE_IF_RUNNING policy is safe to use and lack clear guidance on implementing child workflow reset behavior.
cards.rootCause: Deprecation of TERMINATE_IF_RUNNING was not fully communicated across all documentation surfaces, and the server continues to support it despite deprecation.
cards.workaround: Continue using WorkflowIdReusePolicy.TERMINATE_IF_RUNNING for child workflows, as it remains supported by the server despite deprecation.
cards.resolutionDetails: TERMINATE_IF_RUNNING is deprecated but will remain supported indefinitely in the server. Maintainer clarified no exact alternative exists for child workflow reset use case, making continued use acceptable despite deprecation.
cards.keyQuote: Even though that option has been deprecated, the server still accepts terminate as a reuse policy...we have no intent of actually removing that option support in the server at any time.

cards.summary: Feature request to add tests verifying that custom slot supplier implementations properly populate all required slot info fields in the TypeScript SDK.
cards.userImpact: Users implementing custom slot suppliers need assurance that their implementations are correct through comprehensive test coverage.
cards.keyQuote: Ensure tests exist to confirm custom slot supplier slot info has proper fields

cards.summary: The @temporalio/interceptors-opentelemetry library bypasses the required OTEL SpanProcessor, passing spans directly to SpanExporter, which causes errors when accessing resource attributes before they're awaited. The fix requires accepting a SpanProcessor instead of a SpanExporter and calling onEnd() instead of directly exporting.
cards.userImpact: Users encounter frequent OTEL diagnostic errors about accessing resource attributes before they are settled, disrupting observability.
cards.rootCause: The interceptors-opentelemetry library bypasses the SpanProcessor (which handles async resource attribute settlement) and passes spans directly to SpanExporter, violating OTEL SDK requirements.
cards.proposedFix: Accept a SpanProcessor instead of SpanExporter in makeWorkflowExporter(), and call spanProcessor.onEnd(extractReadableSpan(serialized, resource)) instead of directly exporting spans.
cards.keyQuote: @temporalio/interceptors-opentelemetry bypasses the SpanProcessor and passes spans directly to SpanExporter, breaking OTEL SDK requirements.

cards.summary: Feature request to support gRPC binary metadata headers in the TypeScript SDK's native connection. Currently needs to accept Uint8Array as metadata values and transmit them as binary to Tonic for -bin suffixed keys.
cards.userImpact: Users need to pass binary data in gRPC metadata headers but currently lack native support in the TypeScript SDK.
cards.proposedFix: Accept Uint8Array as metadata value type and send as binary to Tonic for -bin suffixed keys
cards.resolutionDetails: Feature was implemented to support Uint8Array metadata values for binary gRPC headers
cards.keyQuote: Probably just need to accept `Uint8Array` as metadata value and send as binary to Tonic for -bin keys

cards.summary: Feature request to reclassify benign application errors in OpenTelemetry spans to prevent noise in monitoring systems. This mirrors a similar request from the Python SDK.
cards.userImpact: Users receive noisy error signals in OpenTelemetry for application errors that don't represent actual problems, complicating monitoring and alerting.
cards.keyQuote: See issue description here: https://github.com/temporalio/sdk-python/issues/1041

cards.summary: Request to add support for generating UUIDv7 in workflow tasks, similar to the existing uuid4() function. Users need this for better indexing and sorting semantics, but cannot use the npm uuid package due to its crypto module dependency.
cards.userImpact: Users need UUID v7 generation capability within workflows for better temporal ordering and indexing of generated identifiers.
cards.proposedFix: Add a uuid7() function with an identical signature to uuid4(), using DataView and ArrayBuffer to generate RFC-compliant UUIDv7 values with timestamp-based components.
cards.workaround: Users have implemented their own uuid7() function in their codebase as a workaround.
cards.keyQuote: We currently use the `uuid4()` function pretty heavily to generate unique ids within Workflow Tasks. For some use cases we want to generate UUIDv7 IDs for better indexing and sorting semantics.

cards.summary: TypeError: (0 , ms_1.default) is not a function error when starting a worker due to incompatible ms package version 3.0.0-canary.1. The issue was resolved by using a proper canary release or clearing npm cache.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot start workers due to runtime TypeError caused by an incompatible transitive dependency version.
cards.rootCause: The ms package version 3.0.0-canary.1 has an incompatible export structure where the default export is not a function, breaking the msWithValidation utility.
cards.proposedFix: Use ms version 2.1.3 or update to a proper canary release (3.0.0-canary.202508261828+). Force package manager to query NPM registry with --prefer-online flag.
cards.workaround: Run npm i --prefer-online (NPM), pnpm install --prefer-online (PNPM), yarn install --update-checksums (Yarn Classic), or yarn install --check-cache (Yarn Berry/3+) to clear cache and install correct version.
cards.resolutionDetails: Resolved by upstream ms package releasing proper canary versions and users clearing npm cache to fetch correct dependency versions.
cards.keyQuote: we're shaking the dust off after many years without a release. if you still want to depend on the canary you can use the release linked here

cards.summary: Source map parsing during worker initialization consumes excessive RAM (2GB+), particularly when running multiple workers on a single machine. The issue is caused by the extractSourceMap function loading entire source maps into memory without optimization.
cards.userImpact: Workers consume excessive memory during boot (2GB+) when running multiple workers on a single machine, making large-scale deployments impractical.
cards.rootCause: The extractSourceMap function and SourceMapConsumer load entire source maps into memory without lazy-loading or memory-efficient parsing strategies.
cards.proposedFix: Add an option to disable source map extraction during bundling via webpackConfigHook, with proper error handling in downstream consumers like addWorkflowBundle.
cards.workaround: Load workers synchronously with global.gc() calls between them to manage memory pressure, or pre-build bundles in CI/CD without source maps.
cards.keyQuote: They sometimes take up over 2GB of RAM simply from parsing the source maps. I am curious if there is a way to optionally allow turning off source maps?

cards.summary: TypeScript SDK v1.12.2 introduces a regression where worker heartbeats fail with permission denied errors when connecting to Temporal Cloud with API keys, causing workers to crash in production despite working in local dev environments.
cards.userImpact: Production workers crash immediately after upgrading to v1.12.2 when using API key authentication with Temporal Cloud.
cards.rootCause: A change to worker heartbeat logic between v1.12.1 and v1.12.2 introduced a regression that causes permission validation failures with API key-based connections.
cards.resolutionDetails: Fixed in TypeScript SDK v1.12.3
cards.keyQuote: Network error while sending worker heartbeat... PermissionDenied, message: "Request unauthorized."

cards.summary: Request for plugin support in the TypeScript SDK to enable extensibility and custom integrations, referencing a cross-SDK features discussion.
cards.userImpact: Users would be able to extend SDK functionality and integrate custom components without forking or modifying core code.
cards.resolutionDetails: Plugin support was implemented in the TypeScript SDK.
cards.keyQuote: See https://github.com/temporalio/features/issues/652

cards.summary: TypeScript SDK hostname validation is overly restrictive and prevents connecting to Temporal instances hosted behind reverse proxies at subpaths. The validation only allows hostname or hostname:port format, rejecting paths like /temporal.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot connect to Temporal instances hosted behind reverse proxies at subpaths, blocking legitimate deployment scenarios that work with the Go SDK and Temporal UI.
cards.rootCause: SDK hostname normalization logic restricts input to hostname or hostname:port format and rejects URLs with path components.
cards.keyQuote: Temporal and Temporal UI allows this just fine and it works as expected, but the typescript SDK attempts to normalize it and only allows hostname or hostname:port

cards.summary: Request for an official Temporal integration with the OpenAI Agents SDK for JavaScript/TypeScript, similar to the existing Python SDK integration. This would enable durable state persistence, fault recovery, observability, and scalable agent execution within Temporal workflows.
cards.userImpact: TypeScript/JavaScript developers cannot leverage Temporal's durability and fault recovery capabilities with the OpenAI Agents SDK, limiting enterprise-grade agent deployments.
cards.proposedFix: Develop and release an official OpenAIAgentsPlugin for the TypeScript SDK with equivalent functionality to the Python integration.
cards.keyQuote: The first AI agents library we're integrating with in TS is ai. The PR is in review, so it should hopefully land soon.

cards.summary: TypeScript SDK client sends versioning override data in a format incompatible with Temporal Server 1.28.0+, which expects either the new v0.32 structure with pinned override behavior or the deprecated v0.31 structure, but not both mixed together. This causes workflow startup to fail with a validation error.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot start workflows with pinned worker versioning overrides on Temporal Server 1.28.0 or later using TypeScript SDK 1.12+.
cards.rootCause: TypeScript SDK sends versioning override data combining both v0.31 and v0.32 API structures simultaneously, while server 1.28.0+ validates and prefers the v0.32 structure exclusively, rejecting the mixed format.
cards.keyQuote: This fails validation, as the server prefers validation of the v0.32 structure over the deprecated v0.31 structure.

cards.summary: Feature request to add Activity support for Worker Versioning, allowing Workflows to specify which version of an Activity to use. Currently, teams must work around this limitation by encoding Activity version into task queue names despite using Worker Versioning for both Workflows and Activities.
cards.userImpact: Teams managing Activities and Workflows on different release cycles cannot reliably specify Activity versions, forcing workarounds like embedding versions in task queue names.
cards.proposedFix: Add `versioningOverride` to `ActivityOptions` and have the Temporal Service use it along with `WorkerDeploymentOptions` to resolve scheduled Activities to Worker Deployments, leveraging existing Workflow Versioning infrastructure.
cards.workaround: Encode the Activity version into the task queue name, though this is suboptimal when Workers already use Deployments and Versioning.
cards.resolutionDetails: Feature was implemented to support Activity versioning through the Worker Versioning system
cards.keyQuote: when a Workflow calls an Activity, even if the Activity Worker uses Worker Versioning, there is no way for the Workflow to specify the version of the Activity to use

cards.summary: Workflow application logs are not displayed unless the telemetry logging filter is set to DEBUG or TRACE, contrary to expected behavior where INFO level logs should appear with an INFO filter setting.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot see workflow application logs at INFO level without enabling DEBUG logging, and this may cause memory leaks as log buffers grow unbounded.
cards.rootCause: Log flushing issue in LogCollector where log entries are buffered but not properly propagated unless core logging filter is set to DEBUG or TRACE.
cards.proposedFix: Fix the log propagation mechanism to respect the configured telemetryOptions.logging.filter level rather than requiring DEBUG/TRACE to display logs.
cards.workaround: Downgrade to SDK version 1.11.8 or set core logging filter to DEBUG/TRACE.
cards.resolutionDetails: Log propagation mechanism was corrected to properly respect configured filter levels.
cards.keyQuote: it would be expected if telemetryOptions.logging.filter is set to INFO, a log.info in workflow code will be reflected in the logs

cards.summary: After upgrading from SDK v1.11.8 to v1.12.1, users experience 'Workflow task not found' errors on long-running workflows. The underlying cause appears to be performance degradation preventing workers from completing tasks within the 10-second timeout window.
cards.userImpact: Users upgrading to newer SDK versions experience workflow failures and significant delays in activity processing, blocking production deployments.
cards.rootCause: A memory leak bug in Worker configuration (fixed in v1.13.0 by PR #1777) causes increased garbage collection overhead, reducing worker performance and preventing task completion within timeout windows.
cards.proposedFix: Upgrade to v1.13.0 or later which contains a fix for the memory leak bug that surfaces as performance degradation in certain Worker configurations.
cards.workaround: Revert to SDK v1.11.8 until the performance regression is resolved in a newer version.
cards.keyQuote: The Workflow task not found error is almost certainly just a secondary symptom; the real problem is that the Worker is not completing task within the allowed time

cards.summary: Worker state logs in the TypeScript SDK cannot be suppressed in test environments, cluttering test output with verbose INFO-level messages. The issue was resolved by using Runtime.install() with DefaultLogger configured to a higher log level.
cards.userImpact: Users running tests with Temporal workers see cluttered test output from worker state logs that cannot be easily suppressed.
cards.rootCause: TypeScript SDK defaults to INFO log level despite documentation claiming WARN is the default, and the Runtime.install() configuration was not prominently documented as the solution.
cards.proposedFix: Runtime.install({ logger: new DefaultLogger('WARN') }) suppresses INFO-level logs including worker state changes.
cards.workaround: Configure the Runtime's logger to a higher log level (WARN or FATAL) using DefaultLogger.
cards.resolutionDetails: User found the solution by using Runtime.install() with DefaultLogger. Documentation and default log level need updating, and documentation should be more prominent about this simple configuration method.
cards.keyQuote: The TS SDK prints out at `INFO` by default... the default in the early days was set to ensure logs would contain key information needed to diagnose basic issues.

cards.summary: Request to add a Summary field to LocalActivityOptions in the TypeScript SDK, similar to what exists in the features repository. This would allow developers to provide descriptive information about local activities.
cards.userImpact: Developers would gain the ability to document and organize local activities with summary information for better code clarity and maintainability.
cards.proposedFix: Add Summary field to LocalActivityOptions
cards.resolutionDetails: Feature implemented by adding Summary field to LocalActivityOptions
cards.keyQuote: Add Summary to LocalActivityOptions

cards.summary: NDE (nondeterminism error) occurs during workflow replay when using nested Promise.all() with multiple activities. The activity execution order differs between initial execution and replay, causing a 'No command scheduled' error.
cards.userImpact: Workflows using nested Promise.all() patterns fail during replay with a nondeterminism error, making this pattern unreliable in production.
cards.rootCause: Promise.all() execution order is not guaranteed to be deterministic across replay when nested - the activity scheduling order differs between the first execution and subsequent replays.
cards.keyQuote: Nondeterminism error: No command scheduled for event HistoryEvent(id: 38, ActivityTaskScheduled)

cards.summary: User asks why a specific implementation approach is used in worker-options.ts without providing context. The maintainer suggests reviewing the worker shutdown documentation.
cards.userImpact: User seeking clarification on worker implementation choices that may affect understanding of worker configuration and shutdown behavior.
cards.resolutionDetails: Issue closed as the question was vague and user was directed to existing documentation without providing specific implementation concerns.
cards.keyQuote: Not sure what your question really is. I'd suggest taking a look at this doc page

cards.summary: The webpackConfigHook doesn't suppress all webpack output despite setting config.stats to 'none'. Webpack logging is still being printed even when users try to minimize logs through bundlerOptions configuration.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot suppress webpack bundler output through bundlerOptions.webpackConfigHook, forcing them to modify SDK source code or use alternative bundling approaches.
cards.rootCause: The webpackConfigHook configuration is ignored for the logger output - webpack stats configuration only affects webpack's internal reporting, not the SDK's logging of webpackOutput in bundler.ts line 270.
cards.proposedFix: Either provide a way to configure logging verbosity through bundlerOptions, or remove the automatic logging of webpackOutput in bundler.ts.
cards.workaround: Call bundleWorkflowCode() directly instead of Worker.create() and pass a custom Logger instance with suppressed output.
cards.keyQuote: Is there another way, preferably through `bundlerOptions.webpackConfigHook` to not show those webpack logs?

cards.summary: Feature request to add `workerShuttingDown` promise and `workerShuttingDownSignal` abort signal to ActivityContext in TypeScript SDK, matching functionality available in other Temporal SDKs (Go, Python, .NET) to detect worker shutdown before grace period expiration.
cards.userImpact: Activities in TypeScript SDK cannot be notified of impending worker shutdown, limiting graceful cleanup capabilities compared to other SDK languages.
cards.proposedFix: Add `workerShuttingDown: Promise<never>` and `workerShuttingDownSignal: AbortSignal` properties to ActivityContext, similar to cancellation handling, with matching top-level exports on activity/index.ts
cards.keyQuote: Other SDKs expose a way on activity context to know that a Worker is shutting down, before expiration of the grace period. TS doesn't.

cards.summary: When using OpenTelemetry with workflow tracing, traceState objects lose their class context during serialization between the workflow isolate and main thread, causing a TypeError when the OTLP exporter tries to call the missing serialize() method.
cards.userImpact: Users enabling OpenTelemetry trace propagation with traceState headers experience worker failures when exporting spans to OTLP collectors.
cards.rootCause: TraceState objects are serialized through V8's serialization protocol when crossing from workflow isolate to main thread, losing class context and methods. When OTLP transformer v0.35.1+ calls traceState.serialize(), the method doesn't exist on the deserialized plain object.
cards.proposedFix: Serialize traceState to string in workflow code, then reconstruct it using TraceState constructor on the host side in makeWorkflowExporter, or drop traceState entirely during serialization.
cards.workaround: Manually reconstruct TraceState objects by copying the private _internalState property to a new TraceState instance before span export.
cards.keyQuote: the trace data are sent from the Workflow Worker thread to the main thread, which goes through V8's serialization protocol. Functions and classes do not survive that serialization

cards.summary: Feature request to mask or sanitize sensitive data in SDK objects to prevent accidental exposure of API keys and authentication credentials when objects are serialized or logged. Proposes implementing custom serialization behaviors and data structure redesigns to mitigate critical security vulnerabilities.
cards.userImpact: Without this feature, developers risk accidentally exposing API keys and authentication credentials through logs, HTTP responses, and error messages when SDK handle objects are inadvertently serialized.
cards.rootCause: SDK objects containing sensitive client references lack protection against accidental serialization, allowing internal fields like API keys to be exposed when objects are passed to JSON.stringify or serialization libraries.
cards.proposedFix: Override toJSON() methods to exclude or mask sensitive fields, redesign data models to prevent serialization of sensitive content, and implement protection mechanisms that work with advanced serialization libraries like superjson.
cards.keyQuote: When a handle object is accidentally passed to serialization layers it exposes the internal client reference which contains unmasked API keys and authentication credentials

cards.summary: RetryPolicy.maximumAttempts === 0 throws an error, but documentation states that 0 should be a valid value for unlimited retries. The TypeScript SDK implementation contradicts the official Temporal documentation regarding this configuration.
cards.userImpact: Developers attempting to use the documented approach of setting maximumAttempts to 0 for unlimited retries encounter runtime errors and must use workarounds.
cards.rootCause: The TypeScript SDK implementation includes validation that rejects maximumAttempts === 0, while the official Temporal documentation states this value should mean unlimited retries. The validation appears to be an overzealous constraint not present in other SDKs.
cards.proposedFix: Either align the TypeScript SDK to accept 0 as a valid value for unlimited retries (per documentation), or align all SDKs and documentation on a single approach such as using undefined or Number.POSITIVE_INFINITY.
cards.workaround: Use undefined or Number.POSITIVE_INFINITY instead of 0 to specify unlimited retries.
cards.keyQuote: Setting the Maximum Attempts value to 0 also means unlimited. [Official Temporal documentation vs. current implementation]

cards.summary: Tests fail to start the Temporal test server on Apple M3 Pro with a CPU features error after a change in the test server build process. The issue was caused by compiler optimizations in GraalVM that depend on AMD64 CPU features not emulated by Rosetta on ARM-based Macs.
cards.userImpact: Users with Apple M-series processors cannot run tests with the Temporal test library, blocking test execution and development workflows.
cards.rootCause: Test Server 1.30.0 added native ARM64 support by rewriting native-build scripts, but the new scripts unintentionally enabled GraalVM compiler optimizations that depend on AMD64 CPU features not emulated by Rosetta on ARM-based Macs.
cards.proposedFix: Fixed in Test Server 1.30.1 by explicitly opting out of GraalVM's default compiler optimizations that require specific AMD64 CPU features.
cards.workaround: Remove cached download files by running `rm $TMPDIR/temporal-test-server-sdk-typescript-*` or `fd temporal /private/var/folders | xargs rm` to force re-download of the fixed executable.
cards.resolutionDetails: Test Server 1.30.1 fixed the native-build process to disable problematic compiler optimizations, allowing proper execution on both AMD64 and ARM64 Macs.
cards.keyQuote: The native-build process for our Test Server has now been fixed, so Test Server 1.30.1 will again run properly on MacOS.

cards.summary: Feature request to implement environment configuration for the TypeScript SDK, following the pattern defined in the external client configuration proposal for all SDKs.
cards.userImpact: Users lack a standardized way to configure the TypeScript SDK through environment variables, making setup and deployment configuration more difficult.
cards.proposedFix: Implement environment configuration following the pattern defined in the external client configuration proposal (temporalio/proposals).
cards.resolutionDetails: Feature was implemented following the cross-SDK external client configuration proposal guidelines.
cards.keyQuote: See https://github.com/temporalio/features/issues/441 and https://github.com/temporalio/proposals/blob/master/all-sdk/external-client-configuration.md

cards.summary: User reported that the `condition()` function's callback doesn't accept async functions returning Promise<boolean>, even though the Promise return type seems implied by the function signature.
cards.userImpact: Users attempting to pass async callback functions to `condition()` encounter TypeScript errors and confusion about expected function signatures.
cards.rootCause: The `condition()` function design intentionally does not support async callbacksâ€”it expects synchronous functions returning boolean values for checking local state, not async operations.
cards.workaround: Use synchronous functions that return boolean values, checking local variables or array states instead of performing async operations.
cards.resolutionDetails: Maintainer clarified that `condition()` is designed to accept only synchronous functions returning boolean values for state checks, not async callbacks. The API documentation correctly reflects this design.
cards.keyQuote: The function argument passed to `condition` can't be asynchronous, and must return a boolean. Typical usage is that `fn` is an inline function that returns the value of a local boolean variable.

cards.summary: Workflow function not found in bundle when using Temporal worker with NestJS. The issue occurs when bundling workflows, with the bundled workflow exports not being properly recognized by importWorkflows(), particularly when combining multiple workflow files and using Bluebird's map() function.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot run workflows with NestJS when using certain bundling patterns or Bluebird utilities, blocking workflow execution.
cards.rootCause: Webpack bundling issue combined with Bluebird's map() function causing incomplete workflow exports to be recognized by importWorkflows().
cards.workaround: Replace Bluebird map() calls with p-map alternative; reduce number of exported workflow files; use Temporal 1.11.3 instead of 1.12.0+.
cards.resolutionDetails: Issue resolved by replacing Bluebird with p-map library, confirming the root cause was an interplay between Bluebird and Webpack that prevented all exported functions from being recognized.
cards.keyQuote: Replacing Bluebird with p-map resolves this issue for me. No changes need to be made to nestjs-temporal.

cards.summary: Feature request to include decoded gRPC error details on all errors thrown from the Client API, not just specific high-level error classes. This would help users diagnose operational issues by providing access to server-provided error metadata, though it requires solving challenges around type checking, error serialization, and recursive protobuf decoding.
cards.userImpact: Users will be able to access detailed error information from gRPC errors for better operational troubleshooting without waiting for specific error classes to be created.
cards.proposedFix: Decode and attach detailed error messages to generic gRPC errors; solve instanceof limitations, JSON serialization of protobuf objects, and recursive protobuf decoding challenges
cards.keyQuote: We should therefore always decode detailed error messages and make them available on the generic grpc errors, even if we don't make specific error classes

cards.summary: When Update-with-Start API errors occur, the error message shown to users displays a generic 'MultiOperation could not be executed' text instead of the actual detailed error message that is available in the error object. This makes debugging difficult for users who rely on standard error printing.
cards.userImpact: Users see generic error messages instead of detailed error reasons when Update-with-Start operations fail, making it difficult to diagnose and fix issues without explicitly accessing the error.message property.
cards.rootCause: The gRPC error's toString() method prints the original generic message rather than the processed detailed message that was extracted from MultiOperationExecutionFailure protobuf and stored in error.message.
cards.proposedFix: Compose a more detailed error message that includes both the operation type and the underlying error details, such as: 'Update-with-Start could not be executed: [actual error]'
cards.keyQuote: a user is left without a clue of what actually went wrong. A better behavior would be for the error to print out with a composed message

cards.summary: Feature request to lazily load webpack in the TypeScript SDK worker package to reduce bundle size and enable stripping webpack from containers. The user has demonstrated a working patch that uses dynamic require for the bundler module instead of eager loading.
cards.userImpact: Users who need to optimize container size or reduce deployment artifacts are currently forced to include webpack even if they don't use the bundling feature.
cards.rootCause: webpack and the bundler module are eagerly imported at the index/worker level, making them impossible to tree-shake or exclude from bundles even when unused.
cards.proposedFix: Export a stub bundleWorkflowCode function that uses dynamic import internally to lazily load the actual implementation, or move bundler to an optional package that can be dynamically imported.
cards.workaround: User demonstrated a patch on build outputs using dynamic require: require("./workflow/bundler").bundleWorkflowCode instead of eager imports. This requires patching compiled JavaScript.
cards.keyQuote: By lazily loading workflow/bundler you can get away with deleting webpack and friends from the bundle

cards.summary: Protobuf Payload Converter is broken after upgrading protobufjs to 7.5.2 due to a new `_fullyQualifiedObjects` property that conflicts with SDK's custom Protobuf Root patching logic.
cards.userImpact: Feature tests fail when using Protobuf Payload converters after upgrading protobufjs to 7.5.2, though actual SDK integration tests and user-facing samples continue to work.
cards.rootCause: The `_fullyQualifiedObjects` property introduced in protobufjs 7.5.2 conflicts with the SDK's custom Protobuf Root patching logic, causing undefined property access errors during type lookup.
cards.keyQuote: The `_fullyQualifiedObjects` property was introduced in protobufjs yesterday. It seems likely that this upstream change may conflict with our "Patch Protobuf Root" logic.

cards.summary: Create a high-level client for control plane operations concerning worker deployments in the TypeScript SDK, following the pattern established in the Go SDK.
cards.userImpact: TypeScript SDK users need a high-level client API to manage worker versioning and deployments, currently unavailable.
cards.proposedFix: Implement a worker versioning control plane client following the Go SDK implementation as a reference.
cards.keyQuote: Create the high-level client for control plane operations concerning worker deployments. See the Go one as an example

cards.summary: SearchAttribute validation should call toJSON() on serializable objects before rejecting them. This enables passing objects like MongoDB ObjectIds that have a toJSON method as search attributes.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot use serializable custom objects (like MongoDB ObjectIds) as SearchAttribute values, limiting interoperability with common database libraries.
cards.proposedFix: Call toJSON() method on objects before validation, allowing serializable objects to be converted to their JSON representation
cards.keyQuote: If an object is passed as a SearchAttribute, and it is not a Date, and it has a `toJSON` method, the `toJSON` method should be called

cards.summary: Feature request to pass webpack object as second parameter to webpackConfigHook so users can access webpack plugins like DefinePlugin without importing webpack separately, avoiding potential version mismatches.
cards.userImpact: Users currently need to import webpack directly to use webpack plugins, which can cause version mismatches with the webpack version used by @temporalio/worker.
cards.proposedFix: Pass webpack object as second parameter to webpackConfigHook callback function alongside the current config parameter.
cards.keyQuote: if we need to use things like `DefinePlugin`, the caller has to import webpack directly. This may cause issues as the caller may wrongly use a webpack version different from the one used by `@temporalio/worker`.

cards.summary: The `MockActivityEnvironment.run` method infers return type as `unknown` instead of the actual function's return type, breaking type safety in strict TypeScript mode. A proposed solution uses better generic type constraints to properly infer the return type.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot use strict TypeScript mode effectively when testing activities with MockActivityEnvironment due to type inference limitations.
cards.rootCause: The current generic signature uses overly broad type constraints that prevent TypeScript from properly inferring the return type through the function parameter.
cards.proposedFix:
Change the signature from `run

>(fn: F, ...args: P): Promise` to `run(fn: F, ...args: Parameters): ReturnType`
cards.keyQuote:
Change the signature of `MockActivityEnvironment.run` from: run

>(fn: F, ...args: P): Promise; to: run(fn: F, ...args: Parameters): ReturnType

cards.summary: MockActivityEnvironment generates non-UUID run IDs for activityInfo().workflowExecution.runId, breaking UUID-based operations that work correctly in real Temporal instances.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot reliably generate UUIDs in activities using the runId during testing, causing tests to fail when activities work correctly in production.
cards.rootCause: MockActivityEnvironment does not generate RFC 4122 compliant UUIDs for the runId field like the real Temporal service does.
cards.proposedFix: Update MockActivityEnvironment to generate valid UUIDs for workflowExecution.runId to match production behavior.
cards.resolutionDetails: MockActivityEnvironment was updated to generate proper UUIDs for the runId field.
cards.keyQuote: I need to know whether the Workflow run ID is always a UUID, and I can depend on that. If so, the MockActivityEnvironment should be updated to match that behaviour.

cards.summary: Complete the implementation of Client over NativeConnection by adding OperatorService and HealthService support, AbortSignal handling, missing Core Client options, and ensuring test coverage for both connection types. This feature is required for supporting Eager Workflow Start.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot fully utilize Client with NativeConnection, limiting support for Eager Workflow Start and affecting DX in certain environments.
cards.proposedFix: Implement: (1) OperatorService and HealthService support, (2) bridge-side AbortSignal acceptance, (3) missing Core Client options (identity, retry_config), (4) dual-connection test coverage
cards.keyQuote: Using `Client` over `NativeConnection` will be required to support Eager Workflow Start, which means that this usage may become dominant in some environments.

cards.summary: Test suite times out on first run when SDK download takes longer than test framework timeout (2s default), with no informational message about the download. On slow/proxied connections, the download can fail or get corrupted, leaving a confusing temp file and timeout error.
cards.userImpact: Users running tests for the first time on slow or proxied connections experience unexplained test timeouts and SDK download failures, blocking their test suite.
cards.rootCause: SDK download happens silently in the background with a 20s timeout, but test frameworks default to 2s timeout, causing tests to fail before download completes. No logging about the download process.
cards.proposedFix: Trigger an informational message when SDK download is required, and potentially increase test timeout handling or improve download progress feedback.
cards.workaround: Increase Jest/Mocha timeout to >20s to allow the download to complete.
cards.keyQuote: Failed to start ephemeral server: Temp download file at /var/folders/3w/4_q0ch0n763141t1zb61z_z80000gn/T/temporal-sdk-typescript-1.11.7.downloading not complete after 20 seconds.

cards.summary: NativeConnection fails to establish TLS connections to Temporal Cloud due to missing root CA certificates, while the client Connection works properly with the same configuration. The error occurs during the TLS handshake phase before API key authentication.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot connect Temporal Workers to Temporal Cloud using NativeConnection with API key authentication in environments where root certificates are not readily accessible.
cards.rootCause: NativeConnection does not properly utilize the system certificate store for TLS certificate validation, unlike Connection which successfully handles the same scenario.
cards.keyQuote: The problem is likely specific to how `NativeConnection` interacts with the TLS certificate store in the environment where it's running.

cards.summary: Feature request to allow executeChild to accept and propagate headers through its options argument. Currently, headers are hardcoded to empty object, preventing context propagation from parent to child workflows when using executeChild, while code client workflows can propagate context via headers and interceptors.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot propagate context headers to child workflows started via executeChild, creating inconsistent behavior between code client-initiated and child workflow-initiated executions.
cards.rootCause: executeChild hardcodes headers to empty object instead of accepting them as a parameter in the options argument.
cards.proposedFix: Modify executeChild to accept headers in the opts argument, allowing headers to be passed through to child workflows.
cards.keyQuote: executeChild to take headers in the `opts` argument

cards.summary: Pure JS client needs a gRPC interceptor that adds a `temporal-namespace` header to all requests when a namespace field is present in the request object. This feature also requires adding a CI test for cloud integration.
cards.userImpact: Users of the pure JS client will have proper namespace header propagation on all requests, enabling correct namespace handling in cloud environments.
cards.proposedFix: Implement a gRPC interceptor that extracts the namespace field from request objects and sets the temporal-namespace header accordingly. Add CI test for cloud workflows.
cards.resolutionDetails: Feature was implemented with gRPC interceptor and cloud CI test added
cards.keyQuote: Pure JS client needs to have a gRPC interceptor that takes the `namespace` field out of the request object if present and set the `temporal-namespace` header

cards.summary: OpenTelemetry exporter errors are silently ignored by the Temporal SDK, making it difficult to debug exporter misconfigurations. The feature request proposes adding an optional callback parameter to `makeWorkflowExporter` to propagate these errors to users.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot detect when the OpenTelemetry exporter fails, leading to silent data loss and difficult debugging of integration issues.
cards.rootCause: The SDK passes errors from the upstream exporter through a callback function but does not expose or handle these errors, resulting in silent failures.
cards.proposedFix: Add an optional callback parameter to `makeWorkflowExporter` that propagates upstream exporter errors, with a default implementation using `globalErrorHandler` similar to `SimpleSpanProcessor`.
cards.keyQuote: Add an optional callback parameter to the `makeWorkflowExporter`, and just pass it to the upstream exporter as its callback.

cards.summary: User requests the ability to record markers from workflows to capture intermediate state in the event history without causing workflow activations. The feature is declined by maintainers as markers are low-level primitives not intended for direct SDK usage.
cards.userImpact: Users building advanced frameworks that need to record intermediate workflow state without triggering activations cannot use markers directly as they are not intended for SDK-level usage.
cards.rootCause: Markers are low-level primitives designed for SDK internal use only, with replay logic that is distinct for each marker type and managed internally by Core SDKs.
cards.workaround: Use alternative features like Memo, Search Attributes, User Data, Local Activity, or Updates depending on the specific use case.
cards.resolutionDetails: Maintainers clarified that markers are not meant for direct SDK usage and a general RecordMarker API is not on the roadmap. Users should use appropriate alternative features based on their use case.
cards.keyQuote: Markers themselves are not meant for direct usage, and a general "Record a Marker" API is simply not on the road map.

cards.summary: Request to add SDK support for activity reset functionality in TypeScript SDK, following the implementation in other SDKs as defined in the features repository.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot reset activities in TypeScript SDK workflows, limiting their ability to handle activity state recovery scenarios.
cards.resolutionDetails: PR was created and merged following server release, implementing activity reset support in TypeScript SDK.
cards.keyQuote: we have this problem at Finch - Let me know how we can be helpful in setting requirements or testing pilot support

cards.summary: Feature request to change eager decoding of static workflow summary/details to lazy loading in the TypeScript client. Currently these are decoded immediately; the request is to defer decoding until the data is actually requested.
cards.userImpact: Users may experience better client performance and reduced memory usage by deferring unnecessary decoding operations until workflow summary/details are actually accessed.
cards.proposedFix: Change the client implementation to defer decoding of static workflow summary and details until they are explicitly requested rather than decoding them eagerly.
cards.resolutionDetails: The issue was closed, indicating the lazy loading feature was implemented.
cards.keyQuote: Today we eagerly decode these, change to be lazy upon request.

cards.summary: Feature request to warn developers when the server-provided task start time differs significantly from when the SDK begins processing the task. This would help identify timing discrepancies in task execution.
cards.userImpact: Developers would receive warnings about timing mismatches between server and SDK task processing, helping identify potential timing issues.
cards.resolutionDetails: Closed as the feature request was deemed too niche for implementation.
cards.keyQuote: We're not gonna do this. Too niche.

cards.summary: Unit tests using TestWorkflowEnvironment.createLocal() fail intermittently with connection timeouts when running multiple test suites together, causing the NativeConnection.connect() call to time out. The issue appears to be resource-related and only manifests when running 10+ test suites sequentially.
cards.userImpact: Developers cannot reliably run local integration tests using TestWorkflowEnvironment when executing multiple test suites sequentially, forcing them to implement retry workarounds.
cards.rootCause: Likely resource exhaustion or port/connection conflicts when running multiple TestWorkflowEnvironment instances across 10+ test suites sequentially, causing TCP connect timeout errors.
cards.workaround: Implement retries until the local env connection succeeds, as suggested by support team.
cards.keyQuote: the test does not fail when runing it singularily. we run the jest tests in band for the service. it smells that the number of tests is the cause for the issue so it might be related to resources issue.

cards.summary: Feature request for adding AbortSignal or timeout support to client.result() to allow cancellation of result polling and prevent resource leaks. The user wanted to wait briefly for workflow completion without blocking indefinitely.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot cleanly cancel result polling, causing potential resource leaks when they need to impose custom timeouts on workflow result waits.
cards.rootCause: The result() function implements an infinite polling loop with no mechanism for caller-initiated cancellation.
cards.proposedFix: Accept an AbortSignal parameter in result() functions (e.g., handle.result({signal: AbortSignal.timeout(10000)})).
cards.workaround: Use client.withTimeout() or client.withAbortSignal() methods to apply timeout/abort constraints to client requests including result().
cards.resolutionDetails: The feature was already implemented via client.withTimeout() and client.withAbortSignal() methods, which the maintainer pointed out as existing solutions.
cards.keyQuote: You can apply a timeout or an abort signal over any client request (including raw gRPC requests) by using the client.withTimeout(...) and client.withAbortSignal(...) methods.

cards.summary: TLS server name override setting in client connection is being overridden by the address parameter due to a grpc-js library issue. The problem was resolved by updating the @grpc/grpc-js dependency to version 1.13.4 or higher.
cards.userImpact: Users unable to connect to Temporal Cloud through Private Link or other scenarios requiring TLS server name override, affecting secure network configurations.
cards.rootCause: The grpc-js library was not properly respecting the serverNameOverride parameter in channel credentials, causing it to be overridden by the address.
cards.proposedFix: Update @grpc/grpc-js dependency to version 1.13.4 or later, or apply the fix in TS SDK 1.12.0 which addresses the issue upstream.
cards.workaround: Pin @grpc/grpc-js to version 1.12.6 or manually update to 1.13.4 by running `npm update @grpc/grpc-js`.
cards.resolutionDetails: Fixed by grpc-node PR #2956 merged in @grpc/grpc-js 1.13.4. Users can update dependency or wait for TS SDK 1.12.0.
cards.keyQuote: We just confirmed that running Temporal TS SDK 1.11.8 with @grpc/grpc-js 1.13.4 works fine and allows connection to Temporal Cloud through Private Link.

cards.summary: Feature request to display retry policy information on the ActivityInfo object, enabling activities to access their configured retry settings at runtime.
cards.userImpact: Activities would be able to inspect their retry policy configuration at runtime for logging, debugging, or conditional logic.
cards.resolutionDetails: Implementation added retry policy information to ActivityInfo
cards.keyQuote: See https://github.com/temporalio/features/issues/615

cards.summary: The OpenTelemetry interceptor lacks support for tracing propagation on inbound update requests. A comprehensive review is needed to identify and implement any other missing hooks in the interceptor.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot properly trace inbound update requests in distributed systems, limiting observability and debugging capabilities.
cards.proposedFix: Implement tracing propagation for inbound update requests and conduct a comprehensive review of the OTel interceptor for other missing hooks.
cards.keyQuote: The OTel interceptor currently does not support tracing propagation on inbound update requests. We need to implement it.

cards.summary: Upgrading to OTel Interceptor 1.11.5+ changes execution order of workflow code, causing signal handlers to execute out of order compared to earlier versions and potentially causing non-determinism errors during replay of older workflows.
cards.userImpact: Workflows using OTel interceptor 1.11.5+ experience incorrect signal handler execution order and risk non-determinism errors when replaying older workflows.
cards.rootCause: Addition of await statements in signal tracing propagation (#1449) and scheduleLocalActivity promise completion (#1577) convert synchronous execution to microtask execution, changing observable order of operations.
cards.proposedFix: SDK interceptors should avoid adding yield points. Document this risk on Workflow Interceptor types to warn user-implemented interceptors of similar issues.
cards.keyQuote: interceptors provided by the SDK itself should as much as possible avoid adding yield points

cards.summary: Two medium severity vulnerabilities (GHSA-4p46-pwfr-66x6 in ring and GHSA-2gh3-rmm4-6rq5 in protobuf) were discovered in Cargo dependencies. These security issues have been resolved in version 1.11.8 and main branch.
cards.userImpact: Users with the affected SDK versions could be exposed to security vulnerabilities through transitive Cargo dependencies.
cards.rootCause: Outdated or vulnerable versions of ring and protobuf Cargo dependencies in core-bridge.
cards.resolutionDetails: Issue was fixed in version 1.11.8 and on the main branch by updating vulnerable dependencies.
cards.keyQuote: This has been fixed in 1.11.8, and also on the main branch.

cards.summary: Feature request to support AggregateError with multiple child errors. Currently the SDK only supports single error causes, but AggregateError allows storing multiple errors with nested causes, which should be extracted and stored or included in stack traces.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot properly capture and serialize multiple errors that occur together in workflows, limiting error reporting and debugging capabilities.
cards.rootCause: SDK currently only supports single child errors via the cause property, not the errors array structure that AggregateError provides.
cards.proposedFix: Extract and store child errors from AggregateError.errors array, or include stack traces of children in the top error's stack trace using util.inspect with proper formatting.
cards.keyQuote: Would be amazing if temporal extracted and stored child errors of the AggregateError, right now it supports only single child in cause.

cards.summary: User requests a batched result retrieval method for workflow executions to improve performance when processing large numbers of results. Currently, sequential retrieval of 1000 executions takes ~1 minute, making 1M executions infeasible (~1000 minutes).
cards.userImpact: Users generating reports from large numbers of workflow execution results face unacceptable processing times that scale linearly with execution count.
