cards.rootCause: Sequential retrieval of workflow results requires a separate API call per execution, creating a bottleneck for bulk operations.
cards.proposedFix: Add a dedicated method for batched result retrieval that allows concurrent fetching of multiple execution results, potentially using Promise.all() to parallelize requests.
cards.workaround: User can manually chunk workflows.executions into batches and use Promise.all() to fetch results concurrently, though they are uncertain if this is the correct approach.
cards.keyQuote: it takes around ~1min to process 1000 executions, so for 1KK executions -> ~1000 minutes, which is not acceptable

cards.summary: Feature request to implement application failure logging and metrics behavior according to ApplicationErrorCategory in the TypeScript SDK. This requires core SDK changes to handle metrics, with the TypeScript SDK needing to apply corresponding logging behavior.
cards.userImpact: Users will have better visibility into application failures through standardized logging and metrics behavior based on error categories.
cards.resolutionDetails: Implementation completed as part of core SDK updates with corresponding logging behavior applied in TypeScript SDK
cards.keyQuote: Core-based SDKs only need to apply corresponding logging behaviour, core handles metrics.

cards.summary: The `common` package imports the `ms` library but doesn't include its type definitions (@types/ms), causing type validation issues for Duration properties and breaking temporal usage when the package is used as a transitive dependency without explicit type assertions.
cards.userImpact: Users experience type validation failures and broken Temporal usage when the common package is pulled in as a transitive dependency without explicit type assertions or const assertions.
cards.rootCause: Missing @types/ms dependency in the common package despite importing the ms library at runtime.
cards.workaround: Use `as const` or explicit type annotations on Duration props.
cards.keyQuote: The `common` package imports `ms` but not its types. As such, there is no validation on e.g. `Duration` props.

cards.summary: Activities should be interrupted when they are paused to prevent unnecessary heartbeating. This follows the pattern described in temporalio/features#602.
cards.userImpact: Paused activities continue heartbeating unnecessarily, wasting resources and potentially causing confusion in activity lifecycle management.
cards.rootCause: Activity heartbeat mechanism does not respect the paused state of an activity.
cards.resolutionDetails: Activity interruption was implemented to handle paused state properly.
cards.keyQuote: Heartbeating activities should be interrupted when the activities are paused.

cards.summary: The structuredClone() function is not available in workflow code when using the TypeScript SDK, preventing users from copying objects. While simple injection is possible, it causes prototype issues where instanceof checks fail for cloned objects.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot use structuredClone() to copy objects in workflow code, forcing them to find alternative approaches or implement custom cloning logic.
cards.rootCause: Direct injection of structuredClone causes cloned objects to have prototypes associated with the wrong execution context, breaking instanceof checks for all types including built-ins like Array, Error, and Date.
cards.proposedFix: Load a polyfill for structuredClone instead of direct injection to properly handle prototype context issues, or provide clear documentation about sandbox limitations and workarounds.
cards.workaround: Use patch-package to inject structuredClone into reusable-vm.js and vm.js, though this has the instanceof prototype issue. Alternative: implement a custom polyfill.
cards.keyQuote: If the structuredClone function is injected this way, cloned objects prototypes will be associated with the wrong execution context, which means that instanceof will always return false

cards.summary: Feature request to add serialization context support for codecs and converters in TypeScript SDK, with specific requirements for Nexus integration. References design discussion in the features repository.
cards.userImpact: Users need the ability to pass serialization context through codecs and converters, which is required for proper Nexus support in the TypeScript SDK.
cards.proposedFix: Implement serialization context parameter for codecs and converters, ensuring Nexus is properly integrated as discussed in features#678.
cards.keyQuote: Make sure to include nexus per https://github.com/temporalio/features/issues/678

cards.summary: RESOURCE_EXHAUSTED error occurs when describing a schedule that has been running for a while, causing the schedule workflow's consistent query buffer to fill up. The issue appears to be server-side rather than SDK-related.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot describe schedules after they have been running for a period of time, preventing them from checking schedule status or making modifications.
cards.rootCause: The Temporal Server's consistent query buffer for the schedule workflow fills up when too many queries are pending, potentially due to underpowered worker nodes or a bug in schedule workflow replay logic triggered by the specific schedule definition.
cards.proposedFix: Upgrade Temporal server to the latest release; review cluster configuration and worker node capacity; examine the specific schedule definition that triggers the issue.
cards.workaround: Delete and recreate the problematic schedule to temporarily resolve the issue.
cards.keyQuote: The error most probably indicates an issue with your Temporal Cluster configuration, or a bug in the Temporal Server. In any case, this is not a TS SDK side bug.

cards.summary: Add support for the new Worker Versioning API in TypeScript SDK by implementing annotations for workflows. This feature aligns the TS SDK with Go SDK implementations as defined in the design specification.
cards.userImpact: Users can manage workflow versioning to support deploying new code without breaking in-flight workflows.
cards.proposedFix: Implement annotations for workflows following the design specification in the shared Google Doc and align with Go SDK equivalents from temporalio/features#548.
cards.resolutionDetails: Feature was implemented to support the new Worker Versioning API with proper workflow annotations.
cards.keyQuote: We need to add annotations to workflows to support the new versioning APIs. Refer to temporalio/features#548 for the Go equivalents.

cards.summary: Feature request to support OpenTelemetry v2 and newer library versions (0.200.0+). The SDK currently only supports OTel v1, and upgrading would be a breaking change for existing users.
cards.userImpact: Users wanting to use OpenTelemetry v2 cannot upgrade due to SDK not supporting the newer major version.
cards.rootCause: OTel v2 represents a breaking change that cannot be implemented in the existing v1 package without breaking existing setups.
cards.proposedFix: Create a new package (e.g., @temporalio/interceptors-opentelemetry2) that supports OTel v2 while maintaining v1 compatibility. Implementation roadmap: (1) Complete OTel v1 event coverage improvements, (2) Extend v1 to new plugin form, (3) Address serialization issues in workflow/sink layer, (4) Duplicate v1 as v2 package with necessary adaptations.
cards.workaround: Users can create their own copy of the OTel interceptors for v2 support outside the official SDK.
cards.keyQuote: The plan is therefore to make a _new_ package for this, something like `@temporalio/interceptors-opentelemetry2`, so that both plugin versions can coexist.

cards.summary: When a workflow function is bound to an instance using `.bind()`, the function's name property becomes `bound <name>`, causing the workflow type to be incorrectly deduced as `bound example` instead of `example`. This mismatch prevents workers from executing the workflow since they register with the original function name.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot start workflow executions when using the common pattern of binding workflow methods to class instances, breaking a valid architectural pattern.
cards.rootCause: The workflow type deduction logic uses the function's `name` property directly without accounting for bound functions, where JavaScript automatically prefixes the name with `bound `.
cards.proposedFix: Modify the workflow type deduction function (identified in workflow-options.ts line 240) to strip the `bound ` prefix when deducing workflow type from bound functions.
cards.keyQuote: Because the function is bound, its `name` property became `bound example`, so the workflow type ends up also being `bound example`.

cards.summary: Dependency vulnerability in zip library (CVE-2025-29787) used for extracting ephemeral server binaries in test environments. While the actual risk is low due to the library's limited usage context and trusted source downloads, the dependency was updated to version 2.3.0 to resolve compliance and audit concerns.
cards.userImpact: Users relying on vulnerability scanning tools will see alerts; compliance requirements may trigger; fixed in patch release.
cards.rootCause: Zip library dependency contains vulnerability CVE-2025-29787, though actual risk is mitigated by limited usage in test-only contexts with trusted sources.
cards.proposedFix: Update zip dependency from 2.2.2 to 2.3.0
cards.resolutionDetails: Fixed in version 1.11.8 with zip dependency update to 2.3.0
cards.keyQuote: The Temporal SDK only uses the zip library to extract downloaded ephemeral server binaries (i.e. when using the TestWorkflowEnvironment.createXxx())

cards.summary: Documentation link in WorkerOptions.workflowBundle docstring is broken and points to non-existent page. User cannot find the referenced production deployment documentation.
cards.userImpact: Users following documentation examples are directed to broken links, preventing them from learning proper production deployment practices for TypeScript workers.
cards.rootCause: Documentation page at https://docs.temporal.io/typescript/production-deploy#pre-build-code does not exist or has been moved.
cards.keyQuote: The following link is in the docstrings: https://docs.temporal.io/typescript/production-deploy#pre-build-code and it does not resolve.

cards.summary: Workflow APIs that modify state (like commands, random generation, and signal handlers) should throw an error when invoked from read-only contexts such as query handlers and update validation handlers, preventing runtime failures and NDE errors.
cards.userImpact: Users can accidentally invoke state-modifying APIs in read-only contexts, leading to cryptic failures or non-deterministic execution errors that are difficult to debug.
cards.rootCause: Missing runtime checks to prevent state-modifying API calls from non-replayable contexts, allowing invalid operations that fail late (on completion or subsequent tasks).
cards.proposedFix: Add validation to throw errors when state-modifying APIs are invoked from query handlers, update validation handlers, or other read-only execution contexts.
cards.keyQuote: usage of these APIs may result in either failure on completion (from Core) or NDE on subsequent workflow tasks

cards.summary: Feature request to add a summary field to Nexus operations, referenced from the cross-repository features issue tracker.
cards.userImpact: Users would be able to add descriptive summaries to Nexus operations for better documentation and discoverability.
cards.keyQuote: Add summary to Nexus operation

cards.summary: Feature request for implementing Nexus support in the TypeScript SDK alongside the generic Nexus TypeScript SDK. The team is actively working on this integration with ongoing work tracked in the nexus-rpc/sdk-typescript repository.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot use Nexus for RPC-style async operations in TypeScript applications until this feature is implemented.
cards.proposedFix: Implement Temporal-specific Nexus support in the TypeScript SDK, coordinating with the nexus-rpc/sdk-typescript repository development and PR #1708.
cards.resolutionDetails: Feature was implemented through active development work on PR #1708 and coordination with the nexus-rpc/sdk-typescript repository.
cards.keyQuote: We're actively working on this. You can keep an eye on ongoing work on the nexus-rpc/sdk-typescript repository, as well as PR #1708.

cards.summary: Feature request to rehydrate TypedSearchAttributes for sinks or provide a WorkflowInfo variant, following discussion in issue #1612 about improving type safety for search attributes in workflow context.
cards.userImpact: Users need better type safety when working with TypedSearchAttributes in workflow sinks and need access to rehydrated typed versions.
cards.proposedFix: Either rehydrate TypedSearchAttributes for sinks or provide a WorkflowInfo variant that supports typed search attributes
cards.keyQuote: Result of discussion in #1612

cards.summary: Feature request to expose histogram bucket overrides for custom metric bucket sizes in the TypeScript SDK, as implemented in sdk-core.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot customize histogram bucket sizes for metrics collection, limiting their ability to tailor metrics to their specific monitoring needs.
cards.proposedFix: Expose histogram bucket overrides made available in sdk-core PR #844
cards.keyQuote: Need to expose histogram bucket overrides made available in https://github.com/temporalio/sdk-core/pull/844

cards.summary: Feature request to expose root workflow execution context in the TypeScript SDK, dependent on core SDK and features implementation.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot access root workflow execution information, limiting context visibility in nested workflows.
cards.resolutionDetails: Feature was implemented following the completion of dependent core SDK and features work.
cards.keyQuote: needs to wait on temporalio/sdk-core/issues/881

cards.summary: Feature request to enhance OpenTelemetry span status to include error messages in addition to error codes. Currently, error spans only show the error code without the actual error message, making troubleshooting in observability tools difficult.
cards.userImpact: Users lose valuable error context in observability tools because error spans lack error message information, hindering troubleshooting and root cause analysis.
cards.proposedFix: Modify the wrapWithSpan function in packages/interceptors-opentelemetry/src/instrumentation.ts to set both error code and message: span.setStatus({ code: otel.SpanStatusCode.ERROR, message: err instanceof Error ? err.message : String(err) })
cards.keyQuote: error spans only include the error code without the actual error message, making it cumbersome to troubleshoot issues in observability tools

cards.summary: Feature request to ensure built-in query responses use RawValue when feature #1629 is completed. This is part of implementing consistent query response handling across the TypeScript SDK.
cards.userImpact: Ensures built-in query responses are properly formatted and consistent with the RawValue pattern.
cards.proposedFix: Make built-in queries return raw values once #1629 is completed
cards.resolutionDetails: Implemented as part of completing feature #1629 for RawValue support in query responses
cards.keyQuote: When #1629 is done, make sure built-in queries return a raw value

cards.summary: Feature request to implement a 'RawValue' payload wrapper that allows developers to bypass payload converters and send unconverted values directly through the Temporal SDK.
cards.userImpact: Users need a way to prevent automatic payload conversion for specific values when using the Temporal SDK.
cards.proposedFix: Implement a simple payload wrapper that signals converters to skip conversion for wrapped values
cards.resolutionDetails: Feature implemented to support raw value wrapping for non-converted payloads
cards.keyQuote: need a simple payload wrapper that tells converters not to apply conversion

cards.summary: Child workflows are not respecting the WorkflowIdConflictPolicy.USE_EXISTING setting and throw WorkflowExecutionAlreadyStartedError when attempting to start a child workflow with an existing ID. The server doesn't support conflict policies for child workflows, making this SDK exposure incorrect.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot reuse child workflow IDs with the intended conflict policy, causing runtime errors when attempting to start existing child workflows.
cards.rootCause: The TypeScript SDK exposed WorkflowIdConflictPolicy option for child workflows, but the Temporal server does not support conflict policies for child workflows.
cards.resolutionDetails: The issue was identified as an SDK API exposure problem - the option should not have been available since the server doesn't support this feature for child workflows.
cards.keyQuote: The server doesn't support conflict policies for child workflows, the TypeScript SDK shouldn't have exposed this option.

cards.summary: Expose the cancel cause/reason from WorkflowExecutionCancelRequestedEventAttributes when workflows receive cancellations. Additionally allow users to provide and receive this cancel cause when issuing cancellations from clients or commands.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot currently access or provide cancellation reasons when cancelling workflows, limiting diagnostic and control capabilities.
cards.proposedFix: Expose the cause field from WorkflowExecutionCancelRequestedEventAttributes and add it as an input parameter when users issue cancellations.
cards.keyQuote: WorkflowExecutionCancelRequestedEventAttributes has a cause field that should be exposed when workflows receive cancels

cards.summary: Feature request to include musl-based shared library in the TypeScript SDK package for better compatibility with musl-based Linux distributions (Alpine Linux containers).
cards.userImpact: Users running the SDK in musl-based environments (like Alpine Linux) need native library binaries compatible with musl instead of glibc.
cards.proposedFix: Include musl-based shared library variants in the npm package distribution.
cards.keyQuote: Include musl-based shared library in package

cards.summary: Feature request to add support for attaching priority annotations to workflows and activities in the TypeScript SDK. Details referenced in the cross-SDK features issue #593.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot currently specify priority levels for workflows and activities, limiting control over execution scheduling and resource allocation.
cards.resolutionDetails: Feature was implemented and issue closed; priority annotation support is now available in TypeScript SDK.
cards.keyQuote: Add support for attaching priority to workflows/activities

cards.summary: User reports that Temporal TypeScript SDK worker cannot connect when running on Bun runtime - the connection hangs and doesn't respond. SDK maintainers clarified that Bun is not officially supported due to differences in N-API error handling between Bun and Node.js.
cards.userImpact: Users attempting to run Temporal workers on Bun runtime will experience application hangs and cannot connect to Temporal servers.
cards.rootCause: Bun's N-API implementation differs from Node.js in how it handles the `error` argument in `napi_throw`, breaking Neon Binding's safety checks for JS environment callbacks.
cards.resolutionDetails: Bun is not officially supported. The issue stems from upstream Bun's N-API implementation differences. Maintainers are waiting for Bun's N-API stabilization before considering support.
cards.keyQuote: We don't support Bun at this time. It is simply too early for that.

cards.summary: User requests the ability to assign custom names to activities in the Temporal UI to differentiate between multiple executions of the same function with different parameters. Currently activities only show the function name, requiring users to click each activity to see parameters.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot easily distinguish between multiple executions of the same activity function at a glance in the workflow timeline.
cards.proposedFix: Add an activityName parameter to allow custom naming of activities for UI display.
cards.workaround: Users can click on each activity to view its parameters.
cards.resolutionDetails: Part of a new User Metadata feature being worked on, with TS SDK support coming soon and UI support to follow.
cards.keyQuote: I would like the ability to name the activity, so that it's easy to differentiate from the same function being executed with different params.

cards.summary: Add memoization support to the patched() API with a new memoized argument, maintaining backward compatibility while deprecating non-memoized signatures. Delegate the patched logic handling to Core.
cards.userImpact: Users will gain memoization capabilities in the patched API with a clear migration path for existing code.
cards.proposedFix: Add memoized argument to patched and deprecatePatch APIs, deprecate non-memoized signatures, and delegate handling to Core.
cards.keyQuote: Add a `memoized` argument to the `patched` and `deprecatePatch` APIs.

cards.summary: Temporal TypeScript SDK relies on function names for workflow types, which breaks in NextJS 15+ when code is minified. The function name property has no semantic guarantee in JavaScript and gets mangled by minifiers, causing workflow initialization failures.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot run Temporal workflows in NextJS 15+ production environments without disabling minification entirely, which increases cold-start times and bundle sizes.
cards.rootCause: The SDK uses the `name` property of functions as workflow type identifiers, but JavaScript minifiers (SWC, OXC, Terser) mangle function names to reduce bundle size. Function names have no semantic significance per the ECMAScript spec and are not guaranteed to remain stable.
cards.proposedFix: SDK should support explicit workflow type specification via configuration options or decorators, allowing users to bypass function name resolution. Accept string-based workflow type identifiers as primary mechanism.
cards.workaround: Specify workflow type as a string argument: `await getTemporalClient().workflow.start<typeof WorkflowName>("WorkflowName", {...})` instead of relying on function name inference. Use class-based workflows with decorators to explicitly set workflow names.
cards.keyQuote: A function's name property is defined in the spec as having no semantic significance but is typically a variable or property name used at its point of definition

cards.summary: User requests splitting Temporal worker build tool dependencies into a separate package because the worker package is extremely heavy (169MB for a simple Hello World app), pulling in developer tooling like webpack, swc, and webassemblyjs that should only be needed at build time, not in production.
cards.userImpact: Users deploying to size-constrained environments or wanting lightweight runtime installations are forced to download and bundle unnecessary developer tooling.
cards.rootCause: Build dependencies (webpack, swc, webassemblyjs) are included in the main worker package and are difficult to make optional due to NPM limitations and existing user workflows that bundle workflows at runtime.
cards.proposedFix: Split worker package into two packages: `worker-core` (runtime only) and `bundler` (build tools), with the legacy `worker` package re-exporting both for backward compatibility.
cards.workaround: Use yarn `resolutions` property to replace offending dependencies with simple stub packages defined locally.
cards.resolutionDetails: Closed as duplicate of issue #933
cards.keyQuote: A simple "Hello world" worker is over 100 MiB. Excluding the Node.js runtime.

cards.summary: Feature request to allow customization of the dev server UI port in the TypeScript SDK, referenced from a cross-SDK features issue.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot customize the port used by the development server UI, limiting flexibility in local development environments.
cards.resolutionDetails: Issue was closed, likely addressed in a subsequent release or implementation
cards.keyQuote: Allow customization of dev server UI port

cards.summary: A vulnerability in the hashbrown Rust dependency (GHSA-wwq9-3cpr-mm53) was reported in the TypeScript SDK's core-bridge. The team assessed the risk as low for Temporal's use case since hashbrown is never used in security-sensitive contexts or with user-controlled input.
cards.userImpact: Minimal direct impact to users as the vulnerable hashbrown dependency is not used in security-sensitive contexts within the SDK.
cards.rootCause: hashbrown dependency contained a vulnerability (GHSA-wwq9-3cpr-mm53) in the core-bridge Rust component
cards.proposedFix: Update hashbrown and other Rust dependencies to patched versions
cards.resolutionDetails: Released version 1.11.7 with updated hashbrown dependency
cards.keyQuote: this specific issue wouldn't represent a vulnerability in the context of Temporal's TS SDK, as 1) we never use object comparison in any security sensitive context

cards.summary: TypeScript compilation errors occur when using `client.workflow.list()` due to type mismatches in the EventEmitter-based iterator type definitions in iterators-utils.ts. The issue is caused by type incompatibilities between `AsyncIterableIterator<any[]>` and the expected `AsyncIterable<[B]>` generic types.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot call workflow.list() without encountering TypeScript compilation errors, requiring workarounds like enabling skipLibCheck or patching node_modules.
cards.rootCause: Type annotations in iterators-utils.ts use `AsyncIterable<[B]>` (single-element tuple) but EventEmitter.on() returns `AsyncIterableIterator<any[]>` (array type), causing type incompatibility.
cards.proposedFix: Change type annotations from `AsyncIterable<[B]>` to `AsyncIterable<B[]>` and from `AsyncIterator<void>` to `AsyncIterator<any[]>` in iterators-utils.ts lines 59 and 65.
cards.workaround: Set `skipLibCheck: true` in tsconfig.json or ensure imports use the package exports rather than internal src paths (e.g., import from `@temporalio/client` instead of `@temporalio/client/src/types`).
cards.resolutionDetails: Issue was resolved by fixing the type annotations in iterators-utils.ts to correctly match the EventEmitter return types, allowing proper type checking.
cards.keyQuote: But found this is not necessary if TypeScript errors are ignored, which they would have been with `skipLibCheck` if there wasn't some bogus imports

cards.summary: The return type of env.run() in the testing framework is not being inferred from the activity, returning `unknown` instead of the expected type. A user has provided a potential fix but wants guidance on whether it would be a breaking change.
cards.userImpact: Developers testing activities cannot rely on type inference for env.run results, requiring manual type annotations to get proper type checking.
cards.rootCause: The env.run generic type parameters are not properly inferring the activity's return type from the function signature.
cards.proposedFix: Update generic type parameter inference in env.run to automatically derive return type from the activity function, as shown in the provided commit.
cards.workaround: Explicitly pass generic type parameters to env.run: env.run<[InputType], OutputType, typeof activityFunction>(activityFunction, ...)
cards.keyQuote: The return type of env.run is `unknown` when I would expect that it would be inferred from the activity.

cards.summary: Feature request to enable OTel metrics export over HTTP instead of the default gRPC protocol in the TypeScript SDK. Comment indicates the feature was implemented but not working correctly with HTTP URLs.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot export OTel metrics over HTTP, limiting integration options with HTTP-only collectors despite the feature being marked as implemented.
cards.rootCause: The HTTP protocol implementation for OTel metrics exporter appears incomplete or incompatible with the actual OTLP-HTTP endpoint behavior.
cards.proposedFix: Add a simple default-false http boolean option to OtelCollectorExporter to enable HTTP protocol support.
cards.resolutionDetails: Issue was closed, suggesting the HTTP metrics export feature was implemented, though the comment indicates initial implementation had issues.
cards.keyQuote: Expose ability to have Core OTel metrics use HTTP instead of default gRPC protocol. Would recommend a simple default-false http boolean.

cards.summary: Feature request to implement special behavior for Temporal built-in prefixes in the TypeScript SDK, as detailed in the cross-repository features issue #576.
cards.userImpact: Users need clearer handling of Temporal built-in prefixes to avoid naming conflicts and improve SDK consistency.
cards.resolutionDetails: Issue closed after implementation of special behavior for built-in prefixes
cards.keyQuote: See https://github.com/temporalio/features/issues/576

cards.summary: When creating a schedule with triggerImmediately: true, the initial run ignores the schedule's overlap policy and always uses AllowAll, causing subsequent runs to execute immediately instead of being buffered according to the configured policy.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot reliably enforce overlap policies when immediately triggering schedules, potentially causing concurrent workflow executions when buffering was intended.
cards.rootCause: The initial schedule run triggered via triggerImmediately always uses a default AllowAll overlap policy instead of inheriting the schedule's configured overlap policy.
cards.proposedFix: Make triggerImmediately honor the schedule's overlap policy (e.g., BUFFER_ONE) for the initial run instead of defaulting to AllowAll.
cards.workaround: Create the schedule without triggerImmediately, then manually call schedule.trigger() with the desired overlap policy.
cards.keyQuote: triggerImmediately: true should honor the schedule's overlap policy instead of defaulting to the AllowAll policy

cards.summary: When reusable V8 context is enabled, symbol properties on globalThis are not properly swapped between workflow executions, causing context leaks and memory issues. Libraries like Effect that store global state as symbol properties are particularly affected.
cards.userImpact: Users experience memory leaks when using libraries that store global state via symbol properties in workflow code with reuseV8Context enabled.
cards.rootCause: The context swapping logic only handles regular properties on globalThis and ignores symbol properties, allowing them to persist across workflow executions.
cards.proposedFix: Update the logic that swaps global variables to also handle and isolate symbol properties on globalThis.
cards.resolutionDetails: The SDK was updated to properly swap symbol properties when switching between workflow execution contexts.
cards.keyQuote: Symbol properties may therefore leak from one Workflow Execution to another.

cards.summary: Integration tests for RST_STREAM retry behavior are failing on Windows with Node v22.12.0+. The issue is related to a Node.js regression and was fixed by disabling affected tests on Windows for affected Node versions.
cards.userImpact: CI tests fail on Windows with Node 22.12.0+, preventing reliable testing and blocking releases on that platform/version combination.
cards.rootCause: Node.js regression introduced in v22.12.0 affecting RST_STREAM handling, related to https://github.com/nodejs/node/issues/56137
cards.proposedFix: Disable the two RST_STREAM retry tests on Windows for Node versions 22.12.x through 22.14.x
cards.workaround: Use Node v22.11.0 instead of 22.12.0 or later
cards.resolutionDetails: Fixed by PR #1586 which disabled the failing tests on Windows for affected Node versions
cards.keyQuote: Integration tests `Retry on "RST_STREAM with code 0"` and `Retry on "RST_STREAM with code 2"` have started failing on Windows since Node v22.12.0

cards.summary: Using async functions in TypeScript SDK workflows causes severe performance degradation (10-15x slower). The issue is traced to promiseHooks in vm-shared worker that capture stack traces for workflow queries, adding significant overhead to every promise.
cards.userImpact: Workflows using async functions experience 10-15x performance degradation compared to sync equivalents, making async code impractical in production workflows.
cards.rootCause: promiseHooks in vm-shared.ts captures stack traces via prepareStackTrace for __stack_trace and __enhanced_stack_trace workflow queries, adding overhead on every promise creation in async functions.
cards.proposedFix: Investigate methods to reduce runtime overhead of stack trace capture to nearly zero without removing the feature. Potentially add a worker config option to disable stack trace capture if needed.
cards.keyQuote: I would however like to investigate first what can be done to reduce the runtime overhead of capturing stack traces on async contexts.

cards.summary: mTLS connection with NativeConnectionOptions throws 'NativeCertsNotFound' error after upgrading from SDK 1.11.3 to 1.11.5. The issue stems from SDK v1.11.5 switching from rustls built-in CAs to system-native certificate verification, requiring explicit CA certificates in slim Docker images.
cards.userImpact: Users upgrading to SDK 1.11.5 experience broken mTLS connections in containerized environments, particularly with slim Docker images lacking system CA certificates.
cards.rootCause: SDK 1.11.5 changed from using rustls built-in CAs to relying on system-native certificate verification via the OS, which requires root CA certificates to be present in the environment.
cards.workaround: Install CA certificates in the Docker image (via `apt-get update && apt-get install -y ca-certificates`) or copy custom CA to /etc/ssl/certs/ca-certificates.crt
cards.resolutionDetails: Issue is by design - SDK 1.11.5 correctly delegates CA management to the OS. Users must ensure CA certificates are available in their deployment environment.
cards.keyQuote: The reason that was working until TS SDK 1.11.3 is that we were previously relying on rustls's built-in CAs rather than the system-native ones, but that was incorrect.

cards.summary: Workflow histories created in v1.11.2 fail to replay in v1.11.5+ with nondeterminism errors about mismatched child workflow IDs. Root cause identified as breaking changes in OpenTelemetry interceptors affecting signal handling and local activity scheduling determinism.
cards.userImpact: Users upgrading from v1.11.2 to v1.11.5+ experience workflow replay failures on existing histories, blocking deployments and requiring version downgrades.
cards.rootCause: Breaking changes in OpenTelemetryInboundInterceptor and OpenTelemetryOutboundInterceptor altered signal handling and local activity scheduling behavior, violating workflow determinism guarantees required for replay.
cards.proposedFix: Revert or fix the OpenTelemetry interceptor changes to restore deterministic behavior for signal handling and local activity scheduling.
cards.workaround: Patch OpenTelemetryInboundInterceptor.handleSignal() and OpenTelemetryOutboundInterceptor.scheduleLocalActivity() to bypass the problematic logic when replaying.
cards.resolutionDetails: Issue traced to OpenTelemetry interceptor changes and addressed in related issue #1677. Users provided working patch for immediate mitigation.
cards.keyQuote: Patch needed because of a change in OpenTelemetryInboundInterceptor that broke determinism

cards.summary: Workflows are sporadically getting stuck in a running state after cancellation, showing spurious WorkflowTaskFailed errors instead of completing cleanly. The issue occurs a few times per day in production, leading to infinite retries and blocking of orchestrator workflows.
cards.userImpact: Production workflows get stuck in running state with infinite retries when cancellation fails, blocking dependent orchestrator workflows and requiring manual intervention.
cards.rootCause: Possible race condition where ActivityTaskCancelRequested event coincides with activity completion, causing the TypeScript SDK's `this.cancelled` flag to not be set correctly, leading the Core SDK to report a WorkflowTask failure instead of a clean cancellation.
cards.keyQuote: is it possible that `this.cancelled` isn't being set correctly in all cases, especially when an Activity runs and successfully completes in parallel with a ActivityTaskCancelRequested event?

cards.summary: Worker fails to start when Node.js --abort-on-uncaught-exception flag is set due to improper VM context configuration during bundle preloading for debuggers. The preload operation causes a TypeError that V8 can't properly track across execution contexts, resulting in process abort instead of graceful error handling.
cards.userImpact: Workers cannot be started with the --abort-on-uncaught-exception Node option, preventing users from using this safety flag in production environments.
cards.rootCause: Bundle preloading for debugger support executes code in a VM context where globalThis.__webpack_module_cache__ is undefined. The error occurs in a child execution context where V8's --abort-on-uncaught-exception cannot properly track cross-context exception handling, causing premature process termination.
cards.proposedFix: Make bundle preloading conditional on debugger presence and consider moving the preload logic to the VM to ensure proper context configuration. Quick fix: add ?? {} suffix to problematic line in bundler, but proper fix requires architectural review.
cards.keyQuote: V8's is not aware of the cross-execution-context call involved by script.runInContext(), so it can't figure out that the error happening in the child context will get properly handled by the parent context

cards.summary: GitHub Actions dropped support for Node16-based actions and now enforces Node20, breaking CI builds that relied on GLIBC 2.24 Docker images for compatibility with older Linux distributions.
cards.userImpact: CI builds are failing and official SDK releases cannot run on older Linux distributions that customers still use.
cards.rootCause: GitHub Actions Runner agent now enforces Node20 execution regardless of actions requesting Node16, and Node20 requires GLIBC 2.27 which is incompatible with older Linux distros.
cards.keyQuote: GitHub Action's just started enforcing the long-announced EOL on Node16-based actions. Basically, the latest release of GHA's Runner agent ignores the fact that an action is requesting node16, and instead just calls node20 anyway.

cards.summary: Feature request to simplify the API on interceptors in the TypeScript SDK. The specific details are marked as TBD, with the intent to be covered by a related feature request.
cards.userImpact: Users working with interceptors could benefit from a simpler, more intuitive API design.
cards.resolutionDetails: The intent behind this feature request was covered by issue #1764.
cards.keyQuote: The intent behind this feature request will be covered by #1764.

cards.summary: Complete conversion of old style integration tests to modern test framework in the TypeScript SDK. This is a refactoring effort to modernize the test suite.
cards.userImpact: Improves test infrastructure and maintainability for SDK developers and contributors.
cards.resolutionDetails: Completed via pull request #1597
cards.keyQuote: Closed by https://github.com/temporalio/sdk-typescript/pull/1597

cards.summary: Update the TypeScript SDK and samples to support Node.js versions 18.x through 22.x and TypeScript 5.x to align with current platform and language standards.
cards.userImpact: Users on newer Node.js versions (18.x-22.x) need explicit SDK support to ensure compatibility and access to latest language features.
cards.proposedFix: Update SDK dependencies and samples to support Node 18.x through 22.x with TypeScript 5.x
cards.resolutionDetails: Resolved by PR #1586 which implemented the Node version range updates
cards.keyQuote: Update both SDK and samples repos to Node v18..v22, and TypeScript 5.x.

cards.summary: Request to expose AbortController in the Workflow sandbox to enable compatibility with libraries like xstate that use it internally for promise-based actor implementations.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot use libraries like xstate that depend on AbortController within Temporal workflows.
cards.proposedFix: Expose AbortController API to the worker workflow sandbox, similar to how other global APIs are exposed.
cards.resolutionDetails: AbortController was exposed to the workflow sandbox
cards.keyQuote: Expose `AbortController` to the worker workflow sandbox.

cards.summary: Payload converter cannot be imported in ESM applications because the data converter helper code uses `require()` instead of dynamic imports, forcing users to write converters as CommonJS files.
cards.userImpact: Users running workers as ESM modules cannot use custom payload converters without converting them to CommonJS, limiting their ability to use modern JavaScript module syntax.
cards.rootCause: The data-converter-helpers.ts file uses `require()` for importing payload converters, which is incompatible with ESM applications that use `import` statements.
cards.workaround: Write the payload converter as a `.cjs` (CommonJS) file instead of ESM.
cards.resolutionDetails: Closed as duplicate of issue #1292, which already tracks this ESM compatibility problem.
cards.keyQuote: The main code path which to import the data converter always uses `require` which means the format has to be CJS to be imported.

cards.summary: User requests an option to opt-out of workflow isolation in the TypeScript SDK. Workflow isolation has caused significant memory and performance issues in production, and the user argues that the Go SDK's approach of trusting developers to write deterministic code would be preferable to managing the complexity and subtle bugs introduced by isolation.
cards.userImpact: Users struggle with obscure memory leaks and performance degradation caused by workflow isolation complexities, making production debugging extremely difficult.
cards.rootCause: Workflow isolation with reusable V8 contexts creates subtle performance implications that are unintuitive and difficult to debug in production environments.
cards.proposedFix: Add an option to opt-out of workflow isolation entirely, creating new VM contexts only at worker startup and reusing them without isolation for the lifetime of the worker, leveraging only the microtask handling benefits.
cards.workaround: Set `reuseV8Context: false` in Worker options to create a new VM context for each workflow execution, though this trades off the performance benefits of context reuse.
cards.keyQuote: I would rather teach my team to handle a transparent nondeterminism-error due to bad workflow code than to have issues like the one above.

cards.summary: All logs from activities are associated with the same trace_id from application startup instead of being correctly traced to individual workflow executions when using OpenTelemetry integration with Temporal.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot properly trace activities through OpenTelemetry as all logs show the same trace_id from application startup rather than the actual workflow execution trace.
cards.rootCause: Likely missing root span creation for workflows or incorrect trace context propagation to activity logs
cards.resolutionDetails: Duplicate of issue #1425; see comment for reference implementation
cards.keyQuote: all logs in activities are related to the same trace_id which is the one of the startup of my app

cards.summary: The `patched()` function always returns true inside signal handlers, causing all workflows to use the new signal flow instead of respecting version compatibility. This was a bug in SDK version 1.8.0-1.8.5 that prevented proper A/B testing of workflow changes.
cards.userImpact: Users deploying workflow changes with signal modifications cannot safely roll out new versions without affecting existing workflow instances.
cards.rootCause: A bug in the patched() implementation when called within signal handlers that caused it to always evaluate to true regardless of the patch ID or workflow history.
cards.workaround: Upgrade to SDK version 1.8.6 or later where the bug was fixed.
cards.resolutionDetails: Fixed in SDK version 1.8.6 as part of a broader patching system fix.
cards.keyQuote: I think you are most likely hitting a bug that was fixed in 1.8.5 (see #1234). Can you please try this with TS SDK v1.11.3?

cards.summary: Request to expose WHATWG TextEncoder and TextDecoder classes in the workflow sandbox to allow users to encode/decode text without delegating to activities or using polyfills.
cards.userImpact: Users can now use TextEncoder/TextDecoder directly in workflows without requiring activities or external polyfills.
cards.proposedFix: Expose TextEncoder and TextDecoder classes in the workflow sandbox global scope, similar to how Math.random stub is provided.
cards.workaround: Delegate text encoding/decoding to local or regular activities, or load an appropriate polyfill.
cards.resolutionDetails: Implemented and merged PR to expose TextEncoder and TextDecoder in the workflow sandbox.
cards.keyQuote: This API includes no feature that could break workflow determinism (e.g. no file IO).

cards.summary: Feature request to auto-skip time when waiting on update results in time-skipping testing environments, similar to how time is already auto-skipped when waiting on workflow results.
cards.userImpact: Testing workflows with updates requires manual time-skipping configuration, making tests less convenient and less consistent with workflow result testing.
cards.proposedFix: Implement auto-skip time for update result waiting, consistent with existing auto-skip behavior for workflow results.
cards.keyQuote: We auto-skip time when waiting on workflow result, we need to do the same when waiting on update result.

cards.summary: Add support for user metadata on workflows, activities, and timers in TypeScript SDK. Implement the __temporal_workflow_metadata query handler and accept optional summary/details parameters across workflow creation methods (start, signal with start, schedule, child workflows), activity creation, and timer creation.
cards.userImpact: Users can now attach custom metadata (summary and details) to workflows, activities, and timers for better observability and tracking across Temporal operations.
cards.proposedFix: Implement user metadata support across all workflow creation methods, activity creation, and timer creation following the pattern established in sdk-core issue 830 and the features specification.
cards.resolutionDetails: Feature was implemented and merged, addressing the requirements specified in the feature issue and sdk-core issue.
cards.keyQuote: Accept optional "static summary" and "static details" on all ways to start a workflow and populate user metadata with them

cards.summary: Feature request to support asynchronous Update Validators in TypeScript SDK. Currently validators must be synchronous, but users need async operations for complex access control checks (database queries, ACLs) before allowing updates.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot perform async access control validation before allowing updates, forcing them to use activities which pollutes workflow history with irrelevant data.
cards.rootCause: Update Validators are designed to be synchronous-only; async validators are treated as activities and logged to workflow history instead of returning validation errors to callers.
cards.proposedFix: Allow Update Validators to be asynchronous functions that can perform async operations like database queries.
cards.workaround: Convert validators to Activities and call them from Update handlers, but this pollutes workflow history and requires additional polling logic.
cards.keyQuote: I need to check complex access controls via a database query and return an error to the caller if not allowed.

cards.summary: Memory usage in TypeScript SDK v1.9.0 grows during load testing (120MB to 300MB) and doesn't decrease after 5-10 minutes. Investigation suggests OperatorSubscriber instances (43,890 found) may be accumulating in the workflow cache without proper cleanup.
cards.userImpact: Workers experience significant memory growth under load, reaching 300MB+ and failing to reclaim memory, impacting production deployments on Kubernetes nodes.
cards.rootCause: Unclear from discussion, but suspected to involve OperatorSubscriber instances accumulating in the workflow cache; maintainer requests reproduction code and heap snapshot analysis.
cards.resolutionDetails: Issue closed by maintainer after author failed to respond to diagnostic requests (provide heap snapshot, workflow count, maxCachedWorkflows setting, or reproduction code).
cards.keyQuote: Your screenshot indicates 43'890 instances of `OperatorSubscriber`. That's certainly a lot, yet could still be legitimate, depending on the number of cached Workflows

cards.summary: Feature request to allow direct imports of workflow functions in TypeScript SDK instead of requiring a file path (workflowsPath), similar to how activities are imported. This is particularly challenging for NX/Nest monorepos using webpack where the build output is a single file.
cards.userImpact: Users with webpack-based build systems (particularly NX/Nest monorepos) cannot use the convenient import-based workflow registration pattern available for activities.
cards.rootCause: Workflows require file-based loading because they run in isolated VM contexts within Worker Threads. V8 serialization protocol cannot serialize functions between threads, and VM sandboxing requires separate copies of modules for determinism and isolation.
cards.proposedFix: Allow passing workflow objects/functions directly via `workflows` property in Worker.create options, similar to activities pattern.
cards.resolutionDetails: The technical requirement for workflows to run in isolated VM contexts and Worker Threads makes direct function passing impossible. V8 serialization doesn't support function serialization, and Node Worker API requires file paths.
cards.keyQuote: Workflows are registered using a path as they run in a separate JS context. That 'separate JS context' is a Node.js VM, itself running in a Node.js Worker Thread.

cards.summary: Workflow lifecycle logging messages are ambiguous and misleading, with identical messages for workflow task failures and actual workflow failures, and repeated 'Workflow started' messages during task replays, making it difficult for users to differentiate between these cases and set up proper alerting.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot reliably differentiate between workflow task failures and actual workflow failures using logs, preventing effective alerting and error monitoring.
cards.rootCause: The lifecycle handler logs from the perspective of cached workflow instances rather than the actual workflow execution lifecycle. Task replays cause duplicate messages, and task failures produce identical messages to actual workflow failures.
cards.keyQuote: On Workflow Task failure, the lifecycle logger prints out a message indicating that `Workflow failed`; that's exactly the same error message as on actual `Workflow Failure`, making it impossible to differentiate these cases.

cards.summary: Worker thread terminates due to out-of-memory error, causing the Worker to silently stop processing workflow tasks while the process remains running. The Worker should detect this condition and initiate graceful shutdown instead of continuing to accept tasks.
cards.userImpact: Worker silently becomes unresponsive after running out of memory, blocking all workflow progress until manual process restart, with no diagnostic indication of the failure.
cards.rootCause: When Node.js terminates the Workflow Worker Thread due to ERR_WORKER_OUT_OF_MEMORY, the Temporal Worker is unaware and continues attempting to process tasks, creating a silent failure state.
cards.proposedFix: Detect ERR_WORKER_OUT_OF_MEMORY condition and initiate Worker shutdown with critical-level logging, terminating the process to prevent silent failures.
cards.keyQuote: After that point, it appears that the Worker is no longer making any progress on pending Workflow Tasks, despite the fact that the Worker process is still running.

cards.summary: Workflows encounter a NotDeadLetterException (NDE) during replay in SDK 1.11.0 and 1.11.1 despite no code changes. The issue typically involves TimerCanceled commands or command ordering changes.
cards.userImpact: Existing workflows that previously ran successfully now fail during replay without any code changes, blocking workflow execution and causing production issues.
cards.keyQuote: some Workflows may result in NDE on replay, even though there's been no change to Workflow Code

cards.summary: Request to improve logging context by including update handler and ID information in the TypeScript SDK. See temporalio/features#466 for additional context.
cards.userImpact: Users will have better visibility into update handler execution through enhanced logging context.
cards.resolutionDetails: Enhancement implemented to include update handler and ID in logging context
cards.keyQuote: Show update handler and ID in logging context

cards.summary: Feature request to expose update-with-start operations via the TypeScript SDK. This capability allows workflows to be updated or created in a single operation, combining workflow execution initiation with state updates.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot currently use update-with-start operations in TypeScript SDK, limiting their ability to atomically create and update workflows in a single call.
cards.resolutionDetails: Update-with-start operations were implemented and exposed via the SDK API
cards.keyQuote: Expose update-with-start operations via the SDK

cards.summary: Payload converter errors when serializing incompatible objects (non-JSONifiable values, cyclic references) can crash the worker when they occur during error detail encoding in ApplicationError, unlike when they occur during activity response serialization.
cards.userImpact: Workers can crash when activities throw ApplicationErrors with non-serializable details, making the system unreliable when buggy code passes invalid objects through error details.
cards.rootCause: Payload converter throws UnsupportedEjsonTypeError during error detail encoding without being caught by the activity error handler, allowing the exception to escape Worker.run and crash the process.
cards.keyQuote: If this happens when encoding e.g. the `details` of an `ApplicationError`, this error will escape the `Worker.run` and effectively crash the worker.

cards.summary: Core SDK renamed the `startWorkflow` activation job to `initializeWorkflow` with different ordering and expectations. The TypeScript SDK needs to update its activation handling logic to match this change.
cards.userImpact: Without this update, the TypeScript SDK will be incompatible with the latest Core SDK versions that use the renamed activation job.
cards.rootCause: Core SDK renamed and restructured the startWorkflow activation job to initializeWorkflow with different ordering expectations
cards.proposedFix: Update activation handling logic to expect and process initializeWorkflow jobs instead of startWorkflow
cards.resolutionDetails: Activation handling logic was updated to support the initializeWorkflow job type with new ordering and expectations
cards.keyQuote: Core recently renamed the `startWorkflow` activation job to `initializeWorkflow`, with a different ordering and expectations

cards.summary: Worker crashes with RangeError when using Node.js v22.7.0 due to a protobufjs buffer issue during workflow update message serialization. The error occurs in protobufjs's utf8Write and is fixed by upgrading to Node.js v22.8.0 or ensuring matching versions of all @temporalio packages.
cards.userImpact: Users running Node.js v22.7.0 or with mismatched @temporalio package versions experience worker crashes when executing workflow updates.
cards.rootCause: Protobufjs buffer handling issue in Node.js v22.7.0 (fixed in v22.8.0). Also occurs when @temporalio packages have mismatched versions.
cards.proposedFix: Upgrade Node.js to v22.8.0 or later. Ensure all @temporalio packages use matching versions.
cards.workaround: Use a different Node.js version (v20 LTS or v22.8.0+). Ensure all @temporalio packages are on the same version.
cards.resolutionDetails: Fixed by Node.js v22.8.0 release and by ensuring package version consistency. Issue kept open for SDK discoverability.
cards.keyQuote: We're keeping this issue in the sdk-typescript repo so that anyone who hits the problem...will find it, and learn that it's a node issue

cards.summary: Worker fails to start in ARM64 Docker containers due to a missing symbol (__register_atfork) in the core-bridge native module. The issue was resolved by using a non-Alpine Linux distribution (e.g., Bullseye) instead of musl-based distributions.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot deploy Temporal workers to ARM64 Docker containers using Alpine or other musl-based Linux distributions, preventing containerization on modern M-series Macs and ARM servers.
cards.rootCause: The core-bridge native module is compiled for glibc and requires the __register_atfork symbol which is not available in musl libc implementations used by Alpine Linux.
cards.workaround: Use a glibc-based Linux distribution such as Debian Bullseye instead of Alpine for the Docker image.
cards.resolutionDetails: Resolved by switching from Alpine (musl) to Bullseye (glibc) Docker image as per the supported platforms documentation.
cards.keyQuote: Is your Docker image based on Alpine, or another muslc distro? That is not supported.

cards.summary: Feature request to allow passing live `payloadConverter` and `failureConverter` objects directly to Client and Activity-only workers, rather than requiring file paths. For Workflow workers, propose extracting payload converters from workflow bundles.
cards.userImpact: Users deploying Activity and Client components through different deployment systems are forced to adapt their deployment logic to accommodate an unnecessary file path requirement.
cards.rootCause: Original design decision to keep payloadConverter APIs consistent across all contexts, requiring file paths everywhere due to Workflow sandbox constraints, even where not technically necessary.
cards.proposedFix: Support pre-instantiated Payload Converters for Client and Activity-only workers; for Workflow workers, extract payload converter from workflow bundle by looking for a named export at `workflowsPath` or in the prebuilt bundle.
cards.resolutionDetails: Closed as duplicate of issue #1458
cards.keyQuote: the burden of having to adapt those other deployment logic to that artificial requirement is not reasonable

cards.summary: @temporalio/worker's deep import from @opentelemetry/api's build directory breaks when @opentelemetry/api is upgraded to version 1.9.0, as the import path './build/src/trace/NoopTracer' is no longer exported. The issue was resolved by removing the dependency on NoopTracer in a later version.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot install and use @temporalio/worker with the latest version of @opentelemetry/api (1.9.0), forcing them to manually lock the package to an older version.
cards.rootCause: The @temporalio/worker package was doing a deep import directly from the @opentelemetry/api build directory (./build/src/trace/NoopTracer), which is not exposed in the package's exports. OpenTelemetry 1.9.0 changed its exports, breaking this import path.
cards.proposedFix: Update all @temporalio packages to version >1.9.0, which removed the dependency on NoopTracer as mentioned in PR #1269.
cards.workaround: Lock @opentelemetry/api version between 1.3.0 and 1.6.0 to avoid the breaking change.
cards.resolutionDetails: The import on NoopTracer was removed in PR #1269, resolving the compatibility issue when updating to newer versions of @opentelemetry/api.
cards.keyQuote: The import on `NoopTracer` was removed in #1269. Please update all @temporalio to >1.9.0.

cards.summary: Activity retry options are not exposed through the activity Info interface in TypeScript SDK, unlike in the Java SDK. This feature request asks to add this capability.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot access activity retry options at runtime through the Info interface, limiting observability and runtime configuration checks.
cards.proposedFix: Expose retry options in the activity Info interface similar to the Java SDK implementation
cards.resolutionDetails: Issue was marked as duplicate of #1210
cards.keyQuote: Feature request is to add this ability like its possible to do for example in Java sdk.

cards.summary: Feature request to implement automatic request batching in the TypeScript SDK to prevent gRPC message size errors when scheduling many activities. The SDK currently batches activity scheduling commands into a single request, which can exceed the 4MB gRPC limit when starting ~600 activities, causing workflow freezes and silent failures.
cards.userImpact: Developers experience silent workflow freezes when scheduling large numbers of activities, with no mechanism to detect or handle gRPC message size limits.
cards.rootCause: SDK batches all activity scheduling commands into a single gRPC request without checking cumulative message size against the 4MB limit, causing ResourceExhausted errors on retry.
cards.proposedFix: Implement automatic request splitting to detect when message size approaches 4MB and split commands into smaller batches, or throw a descriptive runtime error if splitting is infeasible. Enhance logging around gRPC size limits.
cards.workaround: Custom payload compression using data converters, or manually batching activity scheduling in application code (incomplete pilot solution provided).
cards.keyQuote: The SDK does not provide any built-in mechanism to automatically handle this limitation, nor does it throw a runtime error that could help developers detect and manage the issue proactively.

cards.summary: OTLP export integration tests for Core metrics have become noisy due to recent Core dependency updates causing grpc response errors. Tests were disabled pending a proper mock collector implementation.
cards.userImpact: Integration tests are disabled, reducing test coverage for OTLP metrics export functionality and preventing validation of metrics export behavior.
cards.rootCause: Recent update to Core or its underlying dependencies changed how the OTLP emitter handles grpc responses from the collector service, causing the bare HTTP2 mock server to fail validation.
cards.proposedFix: Rewrite the integration tests to use a more convincing mock OTLP collector that properly handles grpc responses.
cards.workaround: Tests have been disabled temporarily until proper mock implementation is available.
cards.resolutionDetails: Tests were disabled as a temporary measure pending rewrite of the mock collector infrastructure.
cards.keyQuote: OpenTelemetry metrics error occurred. Metrics exporter otlp failed with the grpc server returns error (Internal error): , detailed error message: Missing response message.

cards.summary: The log.error() method in workflow interceptors doesn't properly serialize Error objects, logging only the message and context fields while omitting all error properties like the stack trace.
cards.userImpact: Developers cannot effectively debug workflow interceptors because Error objects lose their properties when logged, making it difficult to diagnose issues.
cards.rootCause: The log.error() method does not properly handle Error object serialization, stripping error properties during logging.
cards.resolutionDetails: Marked as duplicate of issue #1274
cards.keyQuote: all properties of `e` are missing from this log!

cards.summary: Next.js bundling fails with a critical dependency error when importing the Temporal client in server-side code. The error originates from data-converter-helpers.js which uses a dynamic require expression that bundlers cannot statically analyze.
cards.userImpact: Developers cannot use @temporalio/client in Next.js server-side code without bundler errors, blocking legitimate use cases for signaling workflows.
cards.rootCause: The data-converter-helpers.js file uses dynamic require expressions that bundlers like webpack (used by Next.js) cannot statically analyze, triggering critical dependency warnings/errors during build time.
cards.proposedFix: Implement #1458 to address bundler compatibility, though the commenter suggests this alone may not fully resolve the issue.
cards.keyQuote: Critical dependency: the request of a dependency is an expression

cards.summary: Review whether `untrackPromise` is being used correctly in the update implementation. Discussion in PR #1459 raised concerns about its usage patterns.
cards.userImpact: Improper use of `untrackPromise` could lead to promise tracking issues or memory leaks in update operations.
cards.rootCause: Potential misuse of `untrackPromise` in the update implementation as flagged in PR #1459 discussions.
cards.keyQuote: Review use of `untrackPromise` in update implementation

cards.summary: Request for documentation on workflow initialization guarantees to ensure signals and updates can safely use initialized values. Need to document that signals can arrive before the workflow method executes and provide initialization patterns.
cards.userImpact: Users need clear documentation on initialization order to safely handle signals and updates in their workflows without race conditions.
cards.rootCause: Documentation gap regarding signal/update arrival timing relative to workflow method execution.
cards.proposedFix: Document the initialization pattern and signal handling guarantees in the TypeScript message-passing documentation.
cards.workaround: Document the workaround pattern in the TypeScript message-passing docs to handle signals arriving before workflow initialization.
cards.resolutionDetails: Resolved through documentation PR #3107 which added proper initialization pattern documentation.
cards.keyQuote: We should have a method that's guaranteed to initialize before signals and updates come in so handlers can use initialized values.

cards.summary: TypeScript compilation times are slow due to large barrel imports in @temporalio/client and a massive 49k-line proto declaration file. The request is to optimize package structure with deep path imports and split proto definitions into smaller files for parallel type checking.
cards.userImpact: Developers experience slow TypeScript compilation times (1+ second for client imports) which impacts development velocity in monorepo projects.
cards.rootCause: Large barrel index exports and a massive 49k-line proto declaration file (root.d.ts, 2.67 MB) that must be fully parsed and type-checked sequentially instead of in parallel.
cards.proposedFix: Remove barrel imports and use deep path imports for @temporalio/client; split root.d.ts into multiple focused files (coresdk.d.ts, temporal.d.ts, google.d.ts, grpc.d.ts) for parallel type checking.
cards.resolutionDetails: Issue was addressed through optimization of import structure and proto file splitting to reduce type-checking burden.
cards.keyQuote: Importing the @temporalio/client package takes 1 second... The generated file at @temporalio/proto/protos/root.d.ts is massive and is most likely consuming most of the parsing/checking time.

cards.summary: Nightly stress CI tests are failing consistently due to a server-side issue with the in-memory SQLite database, preventing reliable detection of performance regressions in the TypeScript SDK.
cards.userImpact: CI pipeline cannot reliably detect performance regressions, reducing confidence in SDK release quality.
cards.rootCause: Server-side issue specific to in-memory SQLite database
cards.keyQuote: Nightly Stress CI have been failing consistently for the last two months. This appears to be due to a server-side issue (specific to in-memory sqlite database).

cards.summary: When `reuseV8Context` is enabled, global variable reassignments and deletions leak across workflow execution contexts because the context switching mechanism only tracks variable names, not their values. This allows one workflow's modifications to be visible in another workflow's context.
cards.userImpact: Workflows using reusable V8 contexts can experience context leaks where global variables modified in one workflow become visible to concurrent workflows, causing data corruption and unpredictable behavior.
cards.rootCause: The context switching mechanism freezes global objects to prevent modifications but does not prevent reassignment of global variables themselves. Since the engine only checks variable names and not their actual values during context switches, reassigned globals are left untouched.
cards.workaround: Avoid reassigning or deleting global variables when using `reuseV8Context` option.
cards.resolutionDetails: Context freezing was enhanced to prevent global variable reassignments and deletions in addition to modifications to frozen objects.
cards.keyQuote: we do not prevent reassignment of global variables. And since context switching is based solely on global variable names, the engine will leave those reassigned global variable untouched.

cards.summary: Add support for updating search attributes on schedules in the TypeScript SDK, following the implementation in the Go SDK.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot update search attributes on schedules in TypeScript, limiting their ability to manage schedule metadata compared to other SDKs.
cards.proposedFix: Implement schedule search attribute update feature following the Go SDK implementation pattern.
cards.resolutionDetails: Feature was implemented in the TypeScript SDK following the pattern established in Go SDK and temporalio/features#512.
cards.keyQuote: Support schedule search attribute update

cards.summary: Update handlers fail to execute when signals and updates are sent together in the same workflow task, causing the workflow to exit prematurely without running the update handler logic. The issue stems from update activation jobs not being grouped with signal jobs in the activation queue.
cards.userImpact: Workflows that use both signal and update handlers in the same task can silently fail to execute update handlers, leading to incorrect workflow behavior.
cards.rootCause: Update activation jobs are not grouped together with signal activation jobs in the job queue, preventing them from being executed in the same batch before awaitable conditions are unblocked.
cards.proposedFix: Group update activation jobs together with signals in the vm-shared.ts file (lines 314-317) and use an SDK flag to handle backwards incompatibility with existing workflow replays.
cards.resolutionDetails: Update activation jobs were grouped with signal jobs to ensure they execute together in the same batch before awaitables are unblocked.
cards.keyQuote: update and signal activation jobs need to be placed into the same batch in order for them all to be executed before giving the chance for an awaitable

cards.summary: TypeScript SDK documentation lacks coverage for the updates feature, which is already documented in other SDKs (Go, Java, PHP, Python, .NET). The request is to add TypeScript-specific documentation with code examples.
cards.userImpact: TypeScript developers cannot easily learn how to use updates, reducing discoverability and adoption of the feature.
cards.proposedFix: Add TypeScript documentation section covering updates with code snippets, matching the coverage in other SDK docs.
cards.workaround: Developers can reference Go, Java, PHP, Python, or .NET SDK documentation to understand updates usage.
cards.keyQuote: TypeScript SDK documentation doesn't contain any documentation on how to use updates. The Go, Java, PHP, Python and .NET docs seem to cover this

cards.summary: Update the default schedule catchup window value from 30 days to 1 year in the TypeScript SDK documentation and type definitions, aligning with changes made in the Temporal API.
cards.userImpact: Users reference incorrect default catchup window value when configuring schedules, potentially leading to unexpected behavior.
cards.proposedFix: Update the default catchup window value in schedule-types.ts line 44 from 30 days to 1 year to match API changes.
cards.resolutionDetails: Documentation and type definitions updated to reflect the 1 year default catchup window per API PR #308.
cards.keyQuote: should now be 1 year

cards.summary: The TypeScript SDK's gRPC inbound message size limit is capped at 4MB, but should be increased to 128MB to match other SDKs and handle larger server responses.
cards.userImpact: Users unable to handle responses larger than 4MB from the server, causing failures in workflows with large data payloads.
cards.rootCause: gRPC inbound message size limit is hardcoded or set to 4MB instead of 128MB.
cards.proposedFix: Increase inbound message size limit from 4MB to 128MB to match other SDK implementations.
cards.resolutionDetails: Issue was closed, indicating the inbound message size limit was increased to 128MB.
cards.keyQuote: To match other SDKs, _inbound_ message size limit from server should be 128MB (not to be confused with outbound).

cards.summary: Feature request to allow paginating through workflow histories larger than the 4MB gRPC limit by adding `pageSize` parameter to `fetchHistory()`. The issue was closed in favor of #1470 which identified this as a bug rather than a feature request.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot fetch workflow execution histories larger than 4MB without manually implementing pagination workarounds.
cards.rootCause: The WorkflowHandle.fetchHistory() method does not support pagination, and is constrained by the 4MB gRPC message size limit.
cards.proposedFix: Add `pageSize` parameter to `fetchHistory()` and return an iterable similar to `workflow.list()` for paginated access.
cards.workaround: Users can manually paginate through `getWorkflowExecutionHistory` directly on `workflowService`.
cards.resolutionDetails: Closed in favor of #1470, which identified this as a bug rather than a feature request.
cards.keyQuote: Event histories larger than the gRPC limit of 4MB are not fetchable via `handle.fetchHistory()`.

cards.summary: Module alias imports (using module-alias package) don't work in workflow interceptors because the bundler doesn't recognize the aliases. User needs to configure webpack resolver aliases in bundleWorkflowCode() options.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot use module alias imports in workflow interceptors without manually updating all imports to relative paths and recursively updating all dependencies.
cards.rootCause: The workflow bundler uses Webpack which doesn't automatically apply module-alias configuration; aliases must be explicitly configured in the webpack config via webpackConfigHook.
cards.proposedFix: Configure webpack resolver aliases in bundleWorkflowCode() options using webpackConfigHook to map aliases, or use TsconfigPathsPlugin to read tsconfig.json paths.
cards.workaround: Convert all module-alias imports to relative paths in interceptor files and their dependencies, or configure webpackConfigHook with aliases.
cards.resolutionDetails: User resolved by implementing webpackConfigHook with TsconfigPathsPlugin to apply tsconfig path aliases to webpack bundler configuration.
cards.keyQuote: module-alias's magic doesn't automatically extend to bundlers. You will therefore need to provide specific configuration to the Workflow Bundler to apply your aliases.

cards.summary: Feature request to allow explicit dev server version specification in TypeScript SDK and mark unstable API options. The issue notes that version specification is already supported but suggests clarifying documentation about API stability, particularly for advanced arguments like 'extra args'.
cards.userImpact: Users benefit from explicit version control and clear documentation about which SDK options are stable versus unstable.
cards.proposedFix: Review and update docstrings to clearly mark unstable options, particularly 'extra args', similar to what is already done in Python and .NET SDKs.
cards.workaround: Version specification is already supported via the 'version' parameter in the cached-download configuration.
cards.resolutionDetails: The feature was already implemented but required documentation updates. The issue was resolved by clarifying docstrings about API stability.
cards.keyQuote: Users should be able to put a specific version in for downloading dev server. Also, we should make it clear that besides the obvious arguments, other arguments may not be stable.

cards.summary: Feature request to add support for default/dynamic update handlers in the TypeScript SDK, similar to the existing setDefaultSignalHandler functionality.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot set default update handlers for workflows, limiting flexibility in handling dynamic updates similar to signal handlers.
cards.proposedFix: Implement setDefaultUpdateHandler functionality following the pattern established by setDefaultSignalHandler and consistent with other SDK implementations.
cards.resolutionDetails: Marked as duplicate of #1015, which is part of the broader feature request in temporalio/features#201 for dynamic update handler support across all SDKs.
cards.keyQuote: workflow.setDefaultSignalHandler exists. The equivalent functionality for update should exist also.

cards.summary: Feature request to allow Client and Activity-only Workers to accept pre-loaded DataConverter instances instead of requiring paths, reducing unnecessary build process complexity for non-Workflow components.
cards.userImpact: Users must unnecessarily complicate build processes for non-Workflow components due to path-based DataConverter requirements.
cards.rootCause: Historical design decision to require paths for consistency with Workflow Worker behavior, which becomes counter-productive when workflow and client code are in separate deployment units.
cards.proposedFix: Make Client and Activity-only Workers accept pre-loaded DataConverter instances directly instead of requiring paths.
cards.workaround: Workaround using Worker.options.loadedDataConverter to extract and reconfigure converters after worker creation.
cards.keyQuote: By imposing consistency, we are forcing users to adapt and complexify the build process of all non-Workflow Worker components without no real reason to do so.

cards.summary: Feature request to add query support when listing schedules in the TypeScript SDK, similar to the existing ListOptions functionality for workflows.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot filter schedules by query parameters when listing, requiring them to retrieve all schedules and filter client-side.
cards.proposedFix: Implement query parameter support in ListSchedules similar to ListWorkflows, with pageSize for pagination and query matching for filtering.
cards.resolutionDetails: Implemented via PR #1535, adding query support to schedule listing operations.
cards.keyQuote: Need to support the query option when listing schedules same as we do when listing workflows.

cards.summary: Refactor TypeScript SDK's stack trace query protobuf definitions to use updated proto structures, including renaming objects/fields and adding an `internal_code` flag to `FileLocation`.
