cards.userImpact: Ensures the TypeScript SDK uses the latest protobuf definitions for stack trace queries, improving compatibility with updated Temporal API.
cards.rootCause: Proto definitions in temporalio/api were updated but TypeScript SDK proto code was not yet refactored to match.
cards.proposedFix: Rename affected objects and fields in stack trace query protos, add `internal_code` flag to `FileLocation` structures in packages/workflow/src/internals.ts
cards.resolutionDetails: Proto definitions were refactored to align with updated temporalio/api specifications.
cards.keyQuote: Small reminder to refactor TS query protos regarding stack traces -- we have to rename a few objects and fields + add the `internal_code` flag

cards.summary: Feature request to allow users to set search attributes in the dev server startup options, which would translate to --search-attribute command-line flags. This follows the CLI implementation in temporalio/cli#593.
cards.userImpact: Users can configure search attributes directly in dev server startup options instead of manually passing command-line flags.
cards.proposedFix: Implement search attributes parameter in dev server options that translates to --search-attribute calls, matching the CLI implementation.
cards.resolutionDetails: Feature was implemented to support search attributes configuration in dev server startup options.
cards.keyQuote: users should be allowed to set search attributes in dev server option that translate to `--search-attribute` calls

cards.summary: Need a workflow-friendly concurrency control mechanism (mutex/semaphore) that is reentrant and deterministic for use within signal handlers, update handlers, and workflow coroutines.
cards.userImpact: Users lack a safe, deterministic way to control concurrency within workflow logic, limiting ability to manage resource access in signal and update handlers.
cards.keyQuote: We need a mechanism for concurrency control (mutex/semaphore) that fits with the language but is reentrant and deterministic within workflow coroutines.

cards.summary: Placeholder issue with minimal content containing only the word 'testing'.
cards.userImpact: No clear user impact - this appears to be a test or placeholder issue.
cards.resolutionDetails: Issue was closed as invalid due to insufficient content and unclear purpose.
cards.keyQuote: testing

cards.summary: A minimal testing issue reported by the SDK team. The issue title and body both simply state 'testing' with no description, suggesting this may be a placeholder or incomplete report.
cards.userImpact: Unclear impact due to minimal issue description; appears to be an incomplete or placeholder issue.
cards.resolutionDetails: Issue was closed, likely due to being incomplete or not requiring action.
cards.keyQuote: testing

cards.summary: Failure to start an ephemeral server (e.g., due to unsupported architecture) leaves the server in a failed state, preventing proper test cleanup and causing the process to hang during shutdown.
cards.userImpact: Tests fail with unhandled promise rejections and the process never completes shutdown, requiring manual intervention.
cards.rootCause: When ephemeral server startup fails, the teardown function is not properly initialized, causing a TypeError when cleanup is attempted and blocking process exit.
cards.keyQuote: Failure to start ephemeral server prevents shutdown of the process

cards.summary: Client metrics emitted by the TypeScript SDK are missing the 'temporal_' prefix that should be added by default. This regression was introduced in version 1.10.1, affecting metrics like request_failure and long_request_failure.
cards.userImpact: Users lose observability into client behavior as metrics lack the expected temporal_ prefix, breaking monitoring dashboards and alerting rules.
cards.rootCause: Regression in version 1.10.1 where the default metric name prefix logic was removed or broken.
cards.resolutionDetails: The temporal_ prefix was restored to client metrics in a subsequent release.
cards.keyQuote: looks like client metrics like request_failure, long_request_failure etc are missing the default temporal_ prefix in the metric name

cards.summary: NestJS integration with Temporal SDK fails to restart the worker after code changes during hot reload due to port already in use error (3000). The issue occurs when using nest start worker --watch with nestjs-temporal package.
cards.userImpact: Developers cannot use hot reload during development and must manually restart the application after code changes.
cards.rootCause: Proper shutdown hooks not being called before worker restart, leaving the port bound.
cards.proposedFix: Add app.enableShutdownHooks() to NestJS application configuration to ensure proper cleanup on reload.
cards.workaround: Split NestJS app into separate entry point with standalone context and separate app registered in nest-cli.json, or manually restart the application.
cards.resolutionDetails: Issue reporter confirmed it was resolved using the shutdown hooks tip or other solutions mentioned, and indicated it was a development-time issue that could be closed.
cards.keyQuote: Adding `app.enableShutdownHooks()` fixes this problem for me.

cards.summary: Request for methods to wait for all workflow handlers to finish before continuing as new or exiting the workflow. Users need to explicitly specify whether they want to await or ignore remaining handlers.
cards.userImpact: Users can now easily manage workflow handlers when continuing as new or exiting, improving control over cleanup behavior.
cards.resolutionDetails: Implemented via PR #1459 which added methods to wait for all handlers to finish
cards.keyQuote: Users want to easily await (or ignore) all their remaining handlers when they continue as new or exit the workflow.

cards.summary: SDK should warn or error when update handlers are not awaited before workflow completion (cancellation, failure, or success). This prevents silent handler abandonment and encourages best practices like using await-all-handlers or drop-all-handlers methods.
cards.userImpact: Users may unknowingly abandon update handlers at workflow exit, leading to incomplete request processing without explicit notification.
cards.rootCause: Update handlers can dangle across CAN (cancellation) or workflow exit without explicit warning or policy enforcement.
cards.proposedFix: Implement HandlerUnfinishedPolicy with WARN_AND_ABANDON as default, provide all_handlers_finished() method, and emit UnfinishedUpdateHandlersWarning when handlers are incomplete at exit.
cards.workaround: Call await-all-handlers or drop-all-handlers methods explicitly before workflow completion.
cards.resolutionDetails: Implemented in Python SDK via PR #556 with HandlerUnfinishedPolicy enum, all_handlers_finished() method, and warning system. Spec provided for other SDK implementations.
cards.keyQuote: Workflow code can wait on a method named similarly to workflow.all_handlers_finished(). By default, the worker will emit UnfinishedUpdateHandlersWarning if any handlers are unfinished when the workflow completes.

cards.summary: AsyncLocalStorage in Workflow context retains memory and adds performance overhead when not properly disposed. The SDK should track and automatically cleanup ALS instances when workflows are evicted from cache, and investigate providing a workflow-aware ALS implementation that scales better.
cards.userImpact: Users using AsyncLocalStorage for tracing or context propagation in workflows may experience memory leaks and performance degradation under high workflow caching scenarios.
cards.rootCause: AsyncLocalStorage tags every AsyncResource created in the worker thread regardless of which VM created it, adding 48-byte overhead per resource without automatic cleanup when workflows are evicted.
cards.proposedFix: SDK should automatically track and dispose AsyncLocalStorage instances when execution context is destroyed, and provide a custom workflow-aware ALS implementation.
cards.workaround: Users must manually dispose AsyncLocalStorage instances before workflow execution ends to prevent heap retention.
cards.resolutionDetails: Issue was marked as duplicate of #1557
cards.keyQuote: ALS must be 'disabled' when they are no longer required otherwise they do retain heap and still get called for every single AsyncResource creation.

cards.summary: Error messages when connecting to Temporal Cloud with an invalid serverRootCACertificate are cryptic, showing 'Failed to connect before the deadline' instead of a TLS-related error. User requests improved diagnostics to help troubleshoot certificate configuration issues.
cards.userImpact: Users troubleshooting connection failures to Temporal Cloud with invalid TLS certificates receive misleading error messages that point them in the wrong direction, making diagnosis slow and frustrating.
cards.rootCause: gRPC treats connection-level TLS failures as transient errors and retries transparently, masking the actual certificate validation error with a generic 'deadline exceeded' message. TLS libraries close connections without detailed error information on handshake failure.
cards.proposedFix: Improve error messaging to indicate TLS validation or certificate-related issues when connecting to Temporal Cloud, possibly by detecting and surfacing certificate validation failures before they become generic timeout errors.
cards.keyQuote: I had expected the message to be something related to TLS validation or similar, not a failed connection before the deadline...

cards.summary: Feature request to call the Core worker.validate method on worker start/run, added in sdk-core PR #750, and propagate any validation errors to the user.
cards.userImpact: Users need validation errors from the Core worker to be surfaced during worker startup to catch configuration issues early.
cards.proposedFix: Call worker.validate() on worker start/run and propagate any errors to the user
cards.resolutionDetails: Feature was implemented to call Core worker.validate method and handle validation errors
cards.keyQuote: validate added in sdk-core PR #750, make sure to call it on worker start/run and if it errors, error to the user

cards.summary: TypeScript SDK v1.10.0 build fails with GLIBC_2.29 version error on Linux systems with older glibc versions (e.g., glibc 2.28). The core-bridge native module compiled for a newer glibc is incompatible with deployment environments using older glibc versions.
cards.userImpact: Users upgrading to v1.10.0 experience build failures in deployment environments with glibc 2.28, preventing successful deployments on platforms like Render.
cards.rootCause: The v1.10.0 core-bridge native module was compiled against glibc 2.29, but many deployment environments use glibc 2.28, causing dynamic loader failures when requiring the native .node module.
cards.proposedFix: Rebuild the core-bridge native module to be compatible with glibc 2.28 instead of requiring glibc 2.29, as implemented in PR #1428.
cards.workaround: Downgrade to v1.9.0 or earlier until the fix is released.
cards.resolutionDetails: Fixed in v1.10.1 by rebuilding core-bridge to support glibc 2.28 via PR #1428.
cards.keyQuote: version `GLIBC_2.29' not found (required by /opt/render/project/src/node_modules/.pnpm/@temporalio+core-bridge@1.10.0

cards.summary: Feature request to add OpenTelemetry trace_id and span_id attributes to workflow log messages. Currently these attributes appear in activity and client logs but are missing from workflow logs due to the sandboxed execution environment.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot correlate workflow logs with distributed traces in OpenTelemetry-instrumented applications, making it harder to troubleshoot workflow execution issues.
cards.rootCause: Workflow code executes in a sandboxed environment that is decoupled from OpenTelemetry's call scope by the time log messages reach the runtime logger through the Workflow Sink and MessagePort.
cards.proposedFix: Register a WorkflowOutboundInterceptor that intercepts getLogAttributes function and injects trace_id and span_id attributes from the OpenTelemetry context.
cards.workaround: Use a custom logger that manually injects trace and span IDs by emitting structured logs via OpenTelemetry's logging API instead of relying on auto-instrumentation.
cards.resolutionDetails: Community member provided working implementation using WorkflowOutboundInterceptor to inject trace IDs into log attributes, and created a sample PR demonstrating the solution.
cards.keyQuote: What you can do instead is to register a WorkflowOutboundInterceptor on your Workflow Worker that intercepts the getLogAttributes function and injects the trace_id and span_id attributes from there.

cards.summary: CancellationScope.nonCancellable does not prevent cancellation when a condition has a timeout, allowing CancelledFailure to propagate into the nonCancellable scope. The root issue is that timeouts are implemented via a cancellable CancellationScope that inherits cancellation from parent scopes even when nested inside a nonCancellable scope.
cards.userImpact: Developers cannot reliably use conditions with timeouts inside nonCancellable scopes, breaking expected behavior during cleanup operations and preventing proper cancellation control.
cards.rootCause: The timeout feature in condition is implemented through a cancellable CancellationScope that inherits cancellation from parent scopes, bypassing the nonCancellable boundary. The root scope propagates cancellation to all cancellable scopes even when nested inside nonCancellable scopes.
cards.proposedFix: Add an option to disable automatic cancellation propagation from parent scopes, or ensure nonCancellable scopes properly isolate their children from parent cancellation.
cards.workaround: Use Promise.race with a sleep timer instead of condition timeout, combined with checking parent scope cancellability.
cards.keyQuote: a cancellable CancellationScope cancels when any of its parent scope cancels, even when the parent is nonCancellable

cards.summary: Wrap GRPC CANCELED and DEADLINE_EXCEEDED errors in a unified SDK Timeout exception for the Update feature, allowing users to catch a single predictable exception instead of handling multiple gRPC error types.
cards.userImpact: Users must currently catch multiple gRPC error types for timeout scenarios in Updates; wrapping them in a single SDK exception simplifies error handling.
cards.proposedFix: Create an SDK-level Timeout exception that wraps GRPC::CANCELED and DEADLINE_EXCEEDED errors for Update operations.
cards.resolutionDetails: Implementation details referenced in the features repository issue #483.
cards.keyQuote: So that users only have to catch one predictable exception

cards.summary: Delay workflow completion until all coroutines have settled in the task queue to prevent dropping post-terminal commands. This aligns with core SDK requirements and follows patterns implemented in Python and .NET SDKs.
cards.userImpact: Prevents loss of post-terminal commands and ensures consistent workflow behavior across SDKs by deferring completion until all coroutines are settled.
cards.rootCause: Workflow completion is currently set before all coroutines in the task have settled, causing post-terminal commands to be dropped.
cards.proposedFix: Change workflow completion logic to wait until all coroutines have settled, similar to the approach implemented in sdk-python and sdk-dotnet after sdk-core PR #776.
cards.resolutionDetails: Unblocked by sdk-core PR #776 merge, allowing implementation in sdk-python and sdk-dotnet by removing post-terminal command dropping.
cards.keyQuote: https://github.com/temporalio/sdk-core/pull/776 has been merged, and so this is unblocked.

cards.summary: Request for a clean API to intentionally fail activities in long-polling patterns without generating excessive WARN-level logs. The activity should support retryable failures when no new data is available.
cards.userImpact: Users polling external services experience noisy WARN-level logs for intentional activity failures, making error monitoring less effective.
cards.proposedFix: Add a specific API for activities to intentionally fail: could be a special exception type (similar to CompleteAsyncError), special return value, or context function (similar to continueAsNew())
cards.keyQuote: It would be nice to have a specific API for activities to "intentionally fail so that the activity task is retried", which would not cause extra logging.

cards.summary: Feature request to allow ApplicationFailure exceptions thrown from within update handlers to fail the workflow directly, instead of requiring a workaround with flags and conditional logic in the workflow code.
cards.userImpact: Users must implement awkward workarounds with flags to fail workflows from update handlers, making the API less intuitive.
cards.proposedFix: throw ApplicationFailure should return WorkflowFailedError instead of WorkflowUpdateFailedError when called from an update handler.
cards.workaround: Set a flag in the update handler and check for it in the workflow code to throw the failure.
cards.keyQuote: throw ApplicationFailure should return (or at least have the option to return) WorkflowFailedError instead of WorkflowUpdateFailedError.

cards.summary: Add a separate Cloud Operations API client for the TypeScript SDK using cloud protos, marked as experimental. This aligns with similar implementations in other SDKs like Go.
cards.userImpact: Users will have a dedicated cloud operations client available in TypeScript SDK for managing Temporal Cloud workflows and operations.
cards.proposedFix: Create a separate cloud client using cloud protos, following the pattern established in the Go SDK (PR #1426).
cards.resolutionDetails: Cloud operations API client was implemented in the TypeScript SDK following the Go SDK pattern.
cards.keyQuote: We need a separate cloud client using the cloud protos (they are separate today). The client should be marked experimental.

cards.summary: Update the TypeScript SDK repository to use native NPM 7 workspaces instead of Lerna, now that Node 14 support was dropped. This issue became obsolete as the repository was later transitioned to PNPM.
cards.userImpact: Developers contributing to the repository would benefit from simplified workspace tooling and updated build processes.
cards.proposedFix: Migrate from Lerna to native NPM 7 workspaces and update to Lerna 7
cards.resolutionDetails: Issue became inapplicable as the repository was transitioned to PNPM instead of implementing NPM 7 workspaces.
cards.keyQuote: This is no longer applicable, as the repository has been transitioned to PNPM.

cards.summary: Request to emit warning messages when NativeConnection objects are left open after their associated Worker completes, helping users identify forgotten close() calls that prevent process shutdown.
cards.userImpact: Users may struggle to debug why their process hangs when they forget to close NativeConnection objects, leading to frustrating debugging sessions.
cards.proposedFix: Emit warning messages when a NativeConnection remains open for a few seconds after completion of the last associated Worker.
cards.resolutionDetails: Issue was closed, indicating the feature was likely implemented.
cards.keyQuote: It is however too easy to forget doing so, and be left wondering why the process isn't completing as expected.

cards.summary: Feature request to enable runtime replacement of the worker client with a new client instance that may be configured with different options (e.g., updated TLS certificates). This allows workers to reconnect with new credentials without restarting.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot update worker client credentials or connection options at runtime without completely restarting the worker process.
cards.keyQuote: Need to be able to replace the worker client with a new client that may be connected with different options (e.g. a new TLS cert).

cards.summary: User unable to build TypeScript SDK application with Worker due to unresolved module '__temporal_custom_payload_converter'. The issue stems from bundling the Worker and requires clarification on setup and bundling approach.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot build applications with Workers due to missing module resolution, blocking workflow execution with Worker infrastructure.
cards.rootCause: Unclear bundling configuration or missing dependencies when bundling the Worker component in the application build process.
cards.resolutionDetails: Issue closed as invalid - determined to be a configuration/usage issue rather than a SDK bug. User needed to provide more details about their bundling setup.
cards.keyQuote: Can you please give more details? Why and how are you bundling the Worker itself?

cards.summary: Review and validate all type assertions in the TypeScript SDK where protobuf fields are assumed to be non-null despite not being technically guaranteed by the type system. Fix any unsafe assertions that could cause unexpected errors if server behavior changes.
cards.userImpact: Unsafe type assertions could cause runtime errors if the server's protobuf message behavior changes, leading to unexpected crashes.
cards.rootCause: SDK code uses type assertions that rely on undocumented server guarantees rather than proper type validation.
cards.keyQuote: There are some places in the SDK where we expect some protobuf fields to be non-null (because the server effectively never return a null value for that field), even though the field isn't technically _guaranteed_ to be non-null.

cards.summary: Unexpected errors during Activity Task processing in TypeScript Worker can cause complete Worker failure due to null values and TypeErrors not being caught. This requires proper error handling on the TypeScript side since Core cannot handle these exceptions.
cards.userImpact: Workers can completely fail when encountering unexpected errors during Activity Task processing, causing service disruption.
cards.rootCause: TypeScript Worker does not properly catch and handle unexpected errors (such as TypeError from null ActivityInfo.startTime) that occur during task processing, causing them to propagate and crash the entire worker.
cards.proposedFix: Implement proper error catching and handling on the TypeScript side to gracefully handle unexpected errors during Activity Task processing.
cards.keyQuote: This kind of unexpected errors must be caught and handled on TS side, as Core can't properly handle them.

cards.summary: Feature request to make startUpdate API users aware that it's synchronous with the worker. The API parameter should not be optional and users need clarity on synchronous behavior.
cards.userImpact: Users may be unaware that startUpdate is synchronous with the worker, potentially leading to unexpected blocking behavior.
cards.proposedFix: Make the API parameter required (not optional) to force users to explicitly specify what they wait for
cards.keyQuote: Shouldn't be optional to pass what you'll wait for.

cards.summary: Feature request to support updating search attributes on schedules in the TypeScript SDK. The SDK was not exposing this capability in the schedule update operation, limiting users' ability to manage schedule-level search attributes.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot update search attributes on existing schedules, preventing them from managing schedule-level metadata and searchability after creation.
cards.rootCause: SearchAttributes was not included in the ScheduleUpdate type definition in the TypeScript SDK's schedule-types.ts file.
cards.proposedFix: Add searchAttributes field to the schedule update operation, with optional naming consideration of scheduleSearchAttributes to distinguish from workflow-level searchAttributes.
cards.resolutionDetails: Implemented in PR #1625 and released as part of v1.12.0
cards.keyQuote: The typescript SDK seems to ignore search attributes in the update operation. I'd like to update some existing schedules to set search attributes on the schedule itself and on the workflow.

cards.summary: User encountered "Workflow referenced an unregistered external sink" errors when using OpenTelemetry interceptors with bundled workflow code. The issue was resolved by ensuring proper `sinks` configuration on the Worker, but documentation lacked clear guidance on this requirement.
cards.userImpact: Users integrating OpenTelemetry interceptors encounter noisy error logs that are resolved by proper configuration, but the requirement is not well documented.
cards.rootCause: Missing or disabled `sinks` configuration on the Worker when using OpenTelemetryOutboundInterceptor
cards.proposedFix: Add `sinks` configuration to Worker.create() with `exporter: makeWorkflowExporter(exporter, resource)`
cards.workaround: Enable the `sinks` configuration block when using OpenTelemetry interceptors
cards.resolutionDetails: Issue was user configuration error - missing required sinks configuration. User noted feedback about improving documentation clarity.
cards.keyQuote: it would be useful to make note of them in the readme, or make more explicit note of them in the sample since its easy to miss the need for it

cards.summary: User requested a way to await multiple signals in a workflow, similar to JVM SDK's Workflow.await(). Their current workaround using a polling loop with sleep is causing OutOfMemory issues due to unbounded loop caching.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot efficiently wait for multiple signals in workflows, forcing them to use problematic polling loops that cause memory issues in production.
cards.rootCause: TypeScript SDK lacked a direct equivalent to JVM's Workflow.await for coordinating multiple signals, leading users to implement inefficient polling patterns.
cards.proposedFix: Implement a workflow.condition or workflow.await method that allows waiting for multiple signals without memory overhead.
cards.workaround: Use a while loop polling with workflow.sleep, though this causes OutOfMemory issues on workers due to loop iteration caching.
cards.resolutionDetails: Issue author discovered workflow.condition already exists for this exact purpose, providing the needed functionality.
cards.keyQuote: turns out there is `workflow.condition` for this exact purpose already!

cards.summary: Ephemeral test server startup failures in CI provide no error details about why the server failed to start. Users only see a generic timeout error after 5 seconds with no indication of the root cause.
cards.userImpact: Developers debugging random CI test failures cannot determine why the ephemeral test server failed to start, making it impossible to fix underlying issues.
cards.rootCause: On POSIX platforms, stdout and stderr were not properly inherited by ephemeral servers spawned from native code because NodeJS was setting FD_CLOEXEC on file descriptors, which prevented their inheritance in child processes.
cards.proposedFix: Ensure stdout and stderr from the ephemeral test server subprocess are properly captured and logged to provide users with detailed error information about startup failures.
cards.workaround: Set the server logging level to 'debug' instead of 'warn' to get more detailed output, though this may not capture subprocess stderr properly.
cards.resolutionDetails: Fixed by ensuring stdout and stderr file descriptors are properly inherited by child processes on POSIX platforms, allowing server startup errors to be visible to users.
cards.keyQuote: nodejs is setting FD_CLOEXEC on all of its standard file descriptors, which means that these file descriptors are not inherited by child processes

cards.summary: Request to expose a defaultConnection() method that can switch between localhost and cloud-based Temporal connections based on environment variables. This would enable sample repositories to easily run in cloud environments without code changes.
cards.userImpact: Developers can more easily switch between localhost and cloud Temporal instances in sample code without manual modifications.
cards.proposedFix: Expose a defaultConnection() method or similar utility that reads an environment variable to determine whether to connect to localhost or cloud.
cards.resolutionDetails: Feature was implemented to provide a connection configuration method that supports environment-based switching.
cards.keyQuote: Expose a defaultConnection() method or similar that switches between localhost (default) and cloud based on some environment variable

cards.summary: Add support for WorkflowIdConflictPolicy in TypeScript SDK to handle workflow ID conflicts consistently with other Temporal SDKs. This feature request includes implementation of the policy for the SignalWithStart API as well.
cards.userImpact: TypeScript SDK users cannot handle workflow ID conflicts with a configurable policy, while other SDKs support this feature.
cards.resolutionDetails: Feature was implemented and merged via PR #1490, addressing the gap between TypeScript SDK and other SDK implementations.
cards.keyQuote: TS sdk is the only one missing this feature

cards.summary: User encountered `crypto.getRandomValues() not supported` error when using the uuid npm package in workflow code. The issue was resolved by explaining that workflow code must be deterministic and recommending the use of `uuid4` from `@temporalio/workflow` package or moving UUID generation to activities.
cards.userImpact: Users attempting to generate UUIDs in workflow code using standard npm packages encounter runtime failures and need to refactor their code.
cards.rootCause: The `uuid` npm package uses the built-in `crypto.getRandomValues()` which cannot be imported in workflow code due to non-determinism requirements. Workflow code bundler did not catch this dependency early enough.
cards.proposedFix: Use the `uuid4` function from `@temporalio/workflow` package which implements a replay-safe random number generator, or move UUID generation logic to activities.
cards.workaround: Use the `uuid4` function exported by the `@temporalio/workflow` package instead of the npm uuid package.
cards.resolutionDetails: User acknowledged the solution and understood that non-deterministic logic should be moved to activities or use the provided uuid4 function.
cards.keyQuote: Workflow code must be deterministic. Use the uuid4 function exported by the @temporalio/workflow package which internally uses a replay-safe random number generator.

cards.summary: Type definition of workflow arguments is inconsistent between the `Workflow` type (using `any[]`) and `WithWorkflowArgs` type (using `[any, ...any[]]`), making it impossible to create generic types that extend `Workflow` while satisfying `WorkflowStartOptions`.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot create reusable generic types that extend Workflow and work with WorkflowStartOptions due to type incompatibility.
cards.rootCause: `any[]` type on Workflow interface is not assignable to `[any, ...any[]]` required by WithWorkflowArgs, causing type checking failures in generic scenarios.
cards.proposedFix: Align the type definition of workflow arguments between Workflow and WithWorkflowArgs to use consistent tuple representation.
cards.workaround: Define custom type extending `(...args: [any, ...any[]]) => Promise<any>` instead of extending Workflow type directly.
cards.keyQuote: Due to `any[]` not being equal to `[any, ...any[]]`, the following example function will not pass type checking.

cards.summary: Add HTTP CONNECT proxy support to the TypeScript SDK for both workers and gRPC clients, following implementation patterns from sdk-core and sdk-python.
cards.userImpact: Users behind HTTP CONNECT proxies cannot use the TypeScript SDK without proxy support.
cards.proposedFix: Implement HTTP CONNECT proxy options similar to sdk-core PR #714 and sdk-python PR #501; leverage grpc-js http_proxy environment variable support
cards.workaround: Use http_proxy environment variable directly (grpc-js native support)
cards.resolutionDetails: HTTP CONNECT proxy support was implemented following the pattern from sdk-core and sdk-python, with grpc-js supporting it via http_proxy environment variable
cards.keyQuote: Client/grpc-js supports HTTP CONNECT through setting the `http_proxy` environment variable.

cards.summary: The pageSize parameter in temporalClient.list() doesn't work as expectedâ€”returning thousands of results instead of the specified page size of 1. User cannot test pagination functionality and needs clarification on proper usage.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot effectively paginate through workflow query results, blocking large-scale data retrieval use cases.
cards.resolutionDetails: Issue marked as completed, though commenter questions if fix was actually applied or if user discovered a workaround/misuse of the API.
cards.keyQuote: I'm calling temporalClient.list({pageSize: 1, query: 'randomQuery'}) but it seems to just returns thousands of results

cards.summary: Feature request to use macOS M1/ARM runners for all SDK CI/CD pipelines to improve build performance and reduce costs on Apple Silicon hardware.
cards.userImpact: Enables faster CI builds and reduces infrastructure costs for the TypeScript SDK project.
cards.resolutionDetails: Completed and implemented in PR #1003
cards.keyQuote: See: https://github.com/temporalio/features/issues/396

cards.summary: Add support for Prometheus metric option to use seconds for duration measurements in TypeScript SDK, following recent core metric changes from sdk-core PR #706.
cards.userImpact: Users need the ability to configure Prometheus metrics to report durations in seconds instead of the default unit.
cards.proposedFix: Expose the `use_seconds_for_duration` option from sdk-core PR #706 in the TypeScript SDK Prometheus metrics configuration.
cards.resolutionDetails: Feature was implemented to expose the use_seconds_for_duration option for Prometheus metrics.
cards.keyQuote: Need to at least expose `use_seconds_for_duration` option on Prometheus metrics from https://github.com/temporalio/sdk-core/pull/706

cards.summary: Feature request to add native workflow queueing/buffering capability similar to executeChild, allowing workflows to queue subsequent executions without creating schedules or clients. Current workaround uses schedules with BUFFER_ONE policy but has limitations like inability to pass arguments.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot efficiently queue workflows from within a workflow without creating schedules and clients, requiring boilerplate code to implement buffering patterns.
cards.proposedFix: Add native workflow queueing capability similar to executeChild that allows workflows to queue subsequent executions from within the workflow without requiring schedule creation or client instantiation.
cards.workaround: Use entity workflow pattern with signals and continueAsNew to buffer requests in-memory, maintaining a queue that processes items sequentially while managing history growth.
cards.keyQuote: The ability to queue a workflow after the completion of a currently running workflow, similar to the BUFFER_ONE schedule overlap policy.

cards.summary: Feature request to prevent the SDK from returning an update handle when the update has not reached the desired state, addressing consistency in update state handling.
cards.userImpact: Users may receive update handles in unexpected or incorrect states, leading to confusion and potential errors in update workflows.
cards.keyQuote: SDK should not return an update handle if the update has not reached the desired state

cards.summary: Feature request to ensure SDK clients automatically set an UpdateID on update requests even when users don't explicitly specify one. The issue was resolved as the functionality was already implemented in the codebase.
cards.userImpact: Users may not need to manually specify UpdateID values when calling update operations, simplifying the API usage.
cards.resolutionDetails: The functionality was already implemented in the codebase as confirmed by the maintainer, with UpdateID being automatically set on update requests.
cards.keyQuote: This appears to be already working this way just fine

cards.summary: Error messages from FailureConverters incorrectly identify themselves as PayloadConverters. The error messages need to be made more generic using template variables and use failure converter-specific methods where needed.
cards.userImpact: Users see confusing error messages that misidentify which type of converter encountered an error, making debugging more difficult.
cards.rootCause: Error messages hardcode 'payloadConverter' instead of using generic type variables, causing FailureConverters to be mislabeled.
cards.proposedFix: Use ${type} template variable in error messages instead of hardcoding 'payloadConverter', and implement failure converter-specific error reporting methods.
cards.resolutionDetails: Resolved by PR #1373
cards.keyQuote: The errors thrown by data converters should be made more generic by using ${type} instead of hardcoding payloadConverter

cards.summary: Feature request to add API key client option to the TypeScript SDK, following the feature specification outlined in the cross-repo features issue.
cards.userImpact: Users need a standardized way to configure API key authentication when initializing Temporal clients.
cards.proposedFix: Implement API key client option as specified in the cross-repo features specification
cards.resolutionDetails: API key support was implemented in the TypeScript SDK following the cross-repo features specification
cards.keyQuote: See https://github.com/temporalio/features/issues/426

cards.summary: Feature request to support weighted random polling of multiple task queues in the TypeScript SDK to implement priority-like functionality and prevent starvation, similar to Faktory workers. The maintainer indicated this requires platform-level support from the Temporal server.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot implement priority-based task processing without complex workarounds, limiting ability to handle critical tasks before bulk processing.
cards.rootCause: Temporal server does not support priority queues at the platform level, preventing SDK-level implementation.
cards.proposedFix: Add support for taskQueue as either an array of queue names, an object with weighted queues (e.g., {critical: 10, default: 1}), or a function to select the next queue dynamically.
cards.workaround: Create multiple workers with different configurations and use maxConcurrentActivityTaskPolls to manage concurrency per worker.
cards.resolutionDetails: Platform-level feature that requires Temporal server support. Implementation deferred pending server-side priority queue support (temporal/temporal#1507).
cards.keyQuote: Priority queues is a platform level feature that is not currently supported. Once Temporal server adds support for this, we can add it to the SDK.

cards.summary: Worker.runReplayHistory() doesn't automatically handle serialized History objects from fetchHistory(). Users must manually convert with History.fromObject(), creating confusion since the method already handles Web UI/CLI JSON formats differently.
cards.userImpact: Users attempting to serialize and replay workflow histories from fetchHistory() encounter confusing proto serialization errors and must manually convert using History.fromObject().
cards.rootCause: runReplayHistory() detects and auto-converts Web UI/CLI JSON format but doesn't recognize History objects serialized via JSON.stringify(), requiring manual History.fromObject() conversion.
cards.proposedFix: Enhance runReplayHistory() to automatically detect and convert History objects serialized as JSON using History.fromObject(), similar to existing Web UI/CLI format handling.
cards.workaround: Use History.fromObject(JSON.parse(serializedHistory)) to manually convert serialized History objects before passing to runReplayHistory().
cards.keyQuote: What would be nice is if it could also detect where it's being passed a History object serialized into a JSON object

cards.summary: User requests a custom workflow name resolver for the TypeScript SDK Worker to support prefixed workflow names (e.g., 'slack.postMessage') for better organization when multiple teams contribute workflows, similar to the existing activity mapping capability.
cards.userImpact: Users managing multi-team workflow repositories cannot easily namespace workflows with prefixes like activities, limiting organization in the Temporal Web UI.
cards.rootCause: The Worker.create API supports custom activity mapping but lacks equivalent workflow name resolver functionality.
cards.proposedFix: Add a workflowNameResolver option to Worker.create configuration that accepts a function to transform workflow names.
cards.workaround: Build a default export wrapper function in workflows.generated.ts that uses workflowInfo() to intercept and route workflow types manually.
cards.resolutionDetails: Feature is already supported by leveraging the default export pattern with workflowInfo() to implement custom name resolution without API changes.
cards.keyQuote: You can build this yourself by leveraging the `default` export... Note that if you want to use the typed client interface, you'll need to specify both the workflow name and the function type via generics.

cards.summary: WorkerStatus API lacks visibility into the number of concurrent local activities, making it impossible to monitor load across all three task slot types (workflows, activities, and local activities). The user requests a numInFlightLocalActivities field similar to the existing numInFlightActivities.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot accurately monitor worker load and determine how close they are to local activity concurrency limits.
cards.proposedFix: Add numInFlightLocalActivities field to WorkerStatus, similar to the existing numInFlightActivities field
cards.resolutionDetails: The numInFlightLocalActivities field was added to WorkerStatus to provide visibility into concurrent local activity count
cards.keyQuote: We have 3 types of task slots (workflow / activities / local activities) in the worker each with a concurrency limit. However, I have no way of finding out how many concurrent local activities are running.

cards.summary: Feature request to make workflow failure exception types configurable in the TypeScript SDK. The request references a cross-SDK features issue for implementation guidance.
cards.userImpact: Users want more control over how workflow failures are represented and handled in exception types.
cards.keyQuote: See https://github.com/temporalio/features/issues/322

cards.summary: The `reuseV8Context` feature in v1.9.0 breaks workflow isolation by allowing global variables and module state to leak between workflow runs. Users discovered that cleanup steps and signal handlers persisted across different workflow executions when using a shared V8 context.
cards.userImpact: Users' workflow code breaks in production when using global variables or module-level state due to isolation violations between different workflow executions.
cards.rootCause: The reuseV8Context feature shares V8 contexts across workflow runs, causing global variables and module cache state to persist and leak between executions. The Webpack module cache is not discarded during workflow replay.
cards.proposedFix: Make AsyncLocalStorage available to workflow code for safe state management, or properly isolate module caches between workflow executions during replay.
cards.workaround: Use bundleWorkflowCode with the provided Webpack hook to isolate code; avoid global variables and use AsyncLocalStorage instead.
cards.resolutionDetails: Issue was addressed by recommending bundleWorkflowCode and proper isolation patterns. Documentation was updated to warn against global state.
cards.keyQuote: With reuseV8Context however it caused the cleanup steps to leak into other workflow runs. If workflow run X added a cleanup step and went to sleep and then another workflow run Y got executed with the same V8 context, then Y would also invoke the cleanup steps of X.

cards.summary: Some metrics emitted by the TypeScript SDK are not prefixed with 'temporal_' (specifically 'request' and 'long_request'), a regression introduced in v1.9.0. The issue appears to stem from unprefixed metrics coming from the Rust client.
cards.userImpact: Users see inconsistently prefixed metrics in Prometheus output, breaking naming conventions and making metric collection and monitoring inconsistent.
cards.rootCause: Metrics that don't have the temporal_ prefix come from the Rust client, likely due to a metrics refactor around 6 months prior to the issue.
cards.resolutionDetails: Fixed by #1441
cards.keyQuote: Some metrics emited by the sdk are not prefixed with "temporal_", concretely `request` and `long_request`

cards.summary: Feature request to support Pino as a logging framework alongside Winston in the TypeScript SDK. The issue was ultimately closed as the team decided the SDK should remain logger-framework agnostic, but maintainers provided guidance on implementing custom logging adapters.
cards.userImpact: Users who prefer Pino logging must create custom adapters instead of having native SDK support for both Winston and Pino logging frameworks.
cards.rootCause: SDK Logger interface was designed to be framework-agnostic but appears Winston-like, making it inconvenient for Pino users who need to implement workarounds.
cards.proposedFix: The team suggested creating an adaptor class that exposes Pino-style log methods internally using the SDK's Logger signature, leveraging Runtime.logger for all log message funneling.
cards.workaround: Create a custom logger adaptor class that wraps Pino with the SDK's Logger interface; use ActivityInboundLogInterceptor for activity logging (though deprecated); register custom logger sink for workflow logging.
cards.resolutionDetails: Team decided SDK must remain logger-framework agnostic. Provided architectural guidance on implementing custom Pino adapters instead of adding native Pino support.
cards.keyQuote: the SDK itself must remain logger-framework agnostic...there's not that much we can do within the SDK itself to simplify usage of alternate logging APIs

cards.summary: TypeScript SDK lacks support for updating schedules by cronExpression alone, causing issues with duplicate intervals and upcoming runs when attempting to update only the cron expression.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot reliably update schedule cron expressions without manually managing intervals and calendars, requiring workarounds.
cards.rootCause: Temporal Server applies cron expressions to existing intervals instead of replacing them during update operations.
cards.proposedFix: Add support for updating schedules by cronExpression, ensuring existing intervals and calendars are properly cleared during the update.
cards.workaround: Manually delete intervals and calendars from ScheduleUpdateOptions when updating cronExpression.
cards.keyQuote: temporal is not wiping the existing intervals out as part of the update, but it's applying the cron expressions to those intervals

cards.summary: The @temporalio/interceptors-opentelemetry package v1.9.0 has a peer dependency conflict with @temporalio/activity, requiring file:// references instead of version numbers. This prevents installation even though other packages can be updated to v1.9.0 successfully.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot install or upgrade @temporalio/interceptors-opentelemetry v1.9.0 due to unresolvable peer dependency conflicts, blocking their ability to use OpenTelemetry integration with the updated SDK.
cards.rootCause: The interceptors-opentelemetry package was published with peer dependency declarations using file:// references instead of version number ranges, making it incompatible with npm's dependency resolver when other packages were upgraded to v1.9.0.
cards.proposedFix: Update the peer dependency declarations in the package to use proper version ranges instead of file references, as fixed in v1.9.1.
cards.workaround: Use npm install with --force or --legacy-peer-deps flags to bypass the dependency check.
cards.resolutionDetails: Published version 1.9.1 which corrects the peer dependency declarations, allowing normal installation without workarounds.
cards.keyQuote: peer @temporalio/activity@"file:../activity" from @temporalio/interceptors-opentelemetry@1.9.0 - unable to resolve dependency tree

cards.summary: Expose the next retry delay field (recently added to the API) on ApplicationFailure across all SDKs. This field allows activities to specify custom retry delays on failure and needs to be surfaced in the SDK.
cards.userImpact: Activities cannot currently leverage the next retry delay capability that was added to the API, limiting retry behavior customization.
cards.proposedFix: Expose the next retry delay field from the API failure message in the SDK's ApplicationFailure class.
cards.resolutionDetails: The feature was implemented to expose the next retry delay field on ApplicationFailure in the SDK.
cards.keyQuote: We recently added the ability for an activity to specify the next retry delay on failure via a field on ApplicationFailure. Expose this in the SDK.

cards.summary: Add support for Eager Workflow Start (EWS) in the TypeScript SDK, a feature that reduces workflow start latency by allowing clients to schedule the first workflow task directly to a local worker. This feature is already supported in Java, Python, Core, and Go SDKs and depends on another TypeScript SDK issue.
cards.userImpact: Users can achieve lower latency when starting workflows by leveraging eager workflow start capability available in other SDKs.
cards.proposedFix: Implement Eager Workflow Start support in the TypeScript SDK, dependent on issue #3776
cards.resolutionDetails: Feature was implemented and merged into the TypeScript SDK
cards.keyQuote: Support for Eager Workflow Start (EWS) was added in the server in 1.20, and is currently supported in Java, Python, Core, and Go SDKs.

cards.summary: listWorkflowExecutions API call throws 'Namespace is empty' error when namespace parameter is omitted. The namespace should be marked as mandatory in the API to provide better developer guidance.
cards.userImpact: Developers receive confusing gRPC error messages instead of clear API documentation indicating namespace is required.
cards.rootCause: The low-level gRPC API (auto-generated from protobuf) does not enforce required properties, and protobuf 3 lacks a concept of required fields.
cards.proposedFix: Mark namespace as mandatory in API documentation or add runtime validation in the client library.
cards.workaround: Use the high-level client.workflow.list() API instead, which handles namespace requirements internally and provides better developer experience.
cards.resolutionDetails: Issue resolved by recommending users use the high-level client.workflow.list() API instead of the low-level gRPC connection.workflowService API, which provides better error handling and required parameter validation.
cards.keyQuote: I strongly recommend you use client.workflow.list instead, which is the high level API to list workflows. It provides a more intuitive API, and handle pagination internally.

cards.summary: Feature request to prevent application code from modifying built-in query handlers that start with `__temporal` prefix, ensuring that core functionality like the Temporal UI continues to work correctly.
cards.userImpact: Users could accidentally override critical built-in query handlers, breaking Temporal UI and other core functionality.
cards.proposedFix: Disable changes to handlers with names starting by `__temporal` and other well-known built-in names.
cards.resolutionDetails: Built-in query handlers are now protected from being overridden by application code.
cards.keyQuote: Built-in query handlers should not be modified by application code to ensure that, e.g., the temporal UI still works.

cards.summary: Runtime fails to start with OtelCollectorExporter configured in SDK 1.9.0 due to missing required 'headers' field that should be optional. The telemetry options crash during Runtime.install() unless an empty headers map is explicitly provided.
cards.userImpact: Users upgrading to SDK 1.9.0 with OtelCollectorExporter enabled cannot start their workers without manually adding an empty headers object.
cards.rootCause: The headers field in OTLP exporter options was made required when it should remain optional, breaking backwards compatibility with configurations that don't specify headers.
cards.workaround: Add an empty headers map to the OtelCollectorExporter configuration: headers: {}
cards.resolutionDetails: Acknowledged as an easy fix by maintainers; the required headers field was corrected to be optional.
cards.keyQuote: Failed to build otlp exporter options: UninitializedField("headers") - the parameter is labeled optional and was not required in the previous SDK version

cards.summary: The API reference page for `workflow.Trigger` displays malformed content with raw markdown syntax visible to users instead of being properly rendered. The example code section shows an HTML comment and markdown fence markers as literal text rather than being interpreted correctly.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot properly learn how to use the workflow.Trigger API because the documentation page displays raw markdown and HTML instead of rendered content.
cards.rootCause: Markdown source code is not being properly processed or rendered in the TypeScript SDK API reference documentation generation pipeline, likely a typedoc configuration or template issue.
cards.resolutionDetails: Issue was closed, indicating the documentation rendering problem was resolved in a subsequent update.
cards.keyQuote: The code shown below the **Example** heading contains invalid content (an HTML comment, followed by three backticks and `ts` which is markdown being displayed as a literal string instead of being interpreted as a rendering instruction).

cards.summary: The workflow update feature was added to the TypeScript SDK but lacks comprehensive stress testing in the nightly CI suite. This request is to add workflow update tests to the nightly test suite to ensure the feature is robust under various conditions.
cards.userImpact: Without comprehensive stress testing in CI, workflow update feature reliability may not be thoroughly validated before release.
cards.proposedFix: Add workflow update tests to the nightly test suite
cards.keyQuote: We added the feature without running stress tests for it in CI

cards.summary: Request to support Bun runtime for Temporal workers. User encountered multiple issues when attempting to run Temporal workers with Bun: hook initialization failures and core-bridge panics due to hash table capacity overflow in the native bindings.
cards.userImpact: Developers cannot use Temporal workers with Bun runtime despite Bun's performance advantages and HTTP2/gRPC support being available.
cards.rootCause: Core-bridge native bindings have compatibility issues with Bun's v8 sandbox environment, causing hash table capacity overflow and worker initialization failures when hooks are enabled.
cards.workaround: Commenting out the createHook code block temporarily resolves the initial error but breaks core-bridge functionality entirely.
cards.keyQuote: Since bun provide many out-of-box features and better performance than node.js, It would be great if temporal sdk can support bun worker.

cards.summary: TestWorkflowEnvironment should support connecting to already-running servers instead of always spawning new ones, allowing developers to run integration tests against persistent servers with UI and history.
cards.userImpact: Developers cannot easily run integration tests against existing servers, limiting their ability to leverage UI features and maintain test run history during development.
cards.proposedFix: Support instantiation from a Connection object and use the same connection for both client and worker to avoid translating between NativeConnection and pure JS Connection classes.
cards.keyQuote: We should support instantiation from a `Connection`. I would rather also have the worker be powered by the same connection to avoid translating between the objects

cards.summary: Feature request to automatically create tracing spans for schedule creation when the tracing interceptor is active, with workflow header integration and opt-out capability for users.
cards.userImpact: Users relying on tracing instrumentation must manually handle span creation for schedules, leading to incomplete observability when schedules trigger workflows.
cards.proposedFix: Implement automatic span creation in the tracing interceptor when schedules are created, with span propagation to workflow headers and configurable opt-out mechanism.
cards.keyQuote: When the tracing interceptor is in use, by default creating a schedule should create a span for the schedule and set it on the workflow header if the action is starting a workflow.

cards.summary: Dependency security vulnerability report for nyc-test-coverage package with 2 transitive vulnerabilities: CVE-2023-45133 in traverse (CVSS 8.8) and CVE-2022-25883 in semver (CVSS 7.5). Issue was automatically closed as the vulnerable library is no longer part of the Mend inventory.
cards.userImpact: Users of the SDK are exposed to potential arbitrary code execution attacks and denial of service vulnerabilities through transitive dependencies used in testing and build processes.
cards.rootCause: Vulnerable transitive dependencies in nyc-test-coverage: @babel/traverse before 7.23.2 allows arbitrary code execution during compilation, and semver before 7.5.2 is vulnerable to ReDoS attacks via Range validation.
cards.proposedFix: Upgrade @babel/traverse to 7.23.2 or later and semver to 7.5.2 or later. Update affected packages: @babel/plugin-transform-runtime, @babel/preset-env, and babel polyfill plugins to their latest versions.
cards.resolutionDetails: Automatically closed by Mend as the vulnerable library was marked as ignored or is no longer part of the Mend inventory. The transitive vulnerabilities could not be remediated at the direct dependency level.
cards.keyQuote: using Babel to compile code that was specifically crafted by an attacker can lead to arbitrary code execution during compilation, when using plugins that rely on the path.evaluate() or path.evaluateTruthy() internal Babel methods

cards.summary: Feature request to improve error messages when invalid arguments are passed to client.workflow.start(). Currently shows opaque error for incorrect args format (object instead of array).
cards.userImpact: Users receive confusing error messages when passing incorrectly formatted arguments to workflow.start(), making debugging difficult.
cards.proposedFix: Throw a clear error message like 'args must be an array' when invalid argument types are passed.
cards.resolutionDetails: Marked as no longer pertinent by maintainer - likely resolved in subsequent updates or determined to be out of scope.
cards.keyQuote: Throw an error like `args must be an array`

cards.summary: Throwing non-Error objects with non-serializable properties from workflows causes DataCloneError and activation failure. The error message obscures the original exception, making debugging difficult. The issue requests better error handling or earlier serialization to provide context about non-serializable objects.
cards.userImpact: Users receive confusing 'Failed to activate workflow' errors when throwing custom exceptions with non-serializable properties, making it difficult to identify the root cause of failures.
cards.rootCause: V8 Serialization cannot serialize non-serializable objects (like functions), and failure to encode objects in the sink calls list causes the entire operation to fail with a DataCloneError that masks the original exception.
cards.proposedFix: Serialize sink arguments immediately at call site instead of delaying until activation completion, or use a custom Serializer to intercept serialization errors and replace problematic objects with safe alternatives (JSON representation or warning message).
cards.workaround: Intercept exceptions and throw something serializable like ApplicationFailure or a class extending Error instead of throwing custom non-serializable objects.
cards.keyQuote: Even though a `Failed to activate workflow` error message mentioning `DataCloneError` is visible in the log, the original exception is not accessible, making it difficult to figure out the origin of the failure.

cards.summary: Prometheus metrics server is broken in v1.9.0-rc.0 when configured with Runtime.install(). Tests are missing to catch this regression.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot use Prometheus metrics collection in v1.9.0-rc.0, breaking observability and monitoring capabilities.
cards.rootCause: Regression introduced between v1.8.6 and v1.9.0-rc.0 in Prometheus server initialization
cards.proposedFix: Add test coverage to verify Prometheus server starts correctly on the configured bind address
cards.resolutionDetails: Fixed by PR #1324
cards.keyQuote: A worker started with Runtime.install({ telemetryOptions: { metrics: { prometheus: { bindAddress: '0.0.0.0:9090' } } } }) should bring up a server listening for metrics requests on 9090. This works on v1.8.6 but is broken in v1.9.0-rc.0.

cards.summary: Feature request to expose `updateId` to Update handlers in the TypeScript SDK for deduplication across continue-as-new boundaries. Currently, updateId is only available to workflow interceptors, not to the update handler itself.
cards.userImpact: Workflow implementers need access to updateId to implement deduplication guarantees across continue-as-new boundaries, which is currently not possible without using workarounds.
cards.rootCause: The updateId field is passed to interceptors but not exposed through a dedicated API to update handlers.
cards.proposedFix: Expose an `updateInfo()` function that provides access to updateId and other update execution context, potentially leveraging asyncLocalStorage to make it generally available for queries and signals as well.
cards.workaround: Capture the updateId from a workflow interceptor and make it accessible to the update handler code using async local storage.
cards.resolutionDetails: The feature was implemented to expose updateId through an updateInfo() function to update handlers.
cards.keyQuote: Workflow implementers may have legitimate reasons to extend that guarantee across continue-as-new boundary. Doing that effectively require access to the `updateId`

cards.summary: Two transitive dependency vulnerabilities were detected in the TypeScript SDK test coverage package: @babel/traverse (CVE-2023-45133, CVSS 8.8) allowing arbitrary code execution during compilation, and semver (CVE-2022-25883, CVSS 7.5) vulnerable to ReDoS attacks. The issue was automatically closed as the vulnerable libraries were no longer part of the inventory.
cards.userImpact: Users could be exposed to arbitrary code execution during compilation when using affected Babel plugins or to denial-of-service attacks if untrusted semver ranges are processed.
cards.rootCause: Outdated versions of transitive dependencies @babel/traverse-7.21.4 and semver-7.5.0 containing known security vulnerabilities in the dependency chain.
cards.proposedFix: Upgrade @babel/traverse to 7.23.2 or later and semver to 7.5.2 or later, or update dependent packages to their latest versions.
cards.resolutionDetails: Automatically closed by Mend as the vulnerable library was no longer part of the inventory or was marked as ignored in the specific branch.
cards.keyQuote: The vulnerability has been fixed in @babel/traverse@7.23.2 and @babel/traverse@8.0.0-alpha.4.

cards.summary: The comment in the Worker.shutdown() method should clarify that activities are cancelled after the shutdownGraceTime expires, not immediately when shutdown is called.
cards.userImpact: Developers may misunderstand when their running activities are actually cancelled during worker shutdown, leading to incorrect assumptions about cleanup timing.
cards.rootCause: The existing comment in the source code at line 733 does not mention that activity cancellation occurs after shutdownGraceTime has elapsed.
cards.proposedFix: Edit the comment in the Worker.shutdown() method to clarify that activities are cancelled after shutdownGraceTime expires.
cards.keyQuote: It should mention that the activities are cancelled after `shutdownGraceTime`.

cards.summary: Add comprehensive type safety tests for user-defined function APIs across signals, updates, queries, workflows, activities, and schedules to catch type coherency deficiencies that could allow incorrect user code to compile.
cards.userImpact: Users could write type-unsafe code that compiles but fails at runtime because type assertions don't catch all invalid argument patterns and function signatures.
cards.rootCause: Inconsistent and incomplete type-safety test coverage across APIs that accept user-defined functions, allowing type coherency deficiencies to be introduced and persist undetected.
cards.proposedFix: Assess current typing test coverage and add missing tests for all user-defined function APIs, following patterns already established in test-interface-type-safety.ts.
cards.keyQuote: deficiencies that affect incorrect user code (i.e. some code that should not compile does due to improper typing rules)

cards.summary: Add a getUpdateHandle() method to workflowHandle to obtain an UpdateHandle given update and workflow execution identifiers.
cards.userImpact: Users can retrieve an UpdateHandle for an existing workflow execution to interact with pending or completed updates.
cards.proposedFix: Implement workflowHandle.getUpdateHandle(...) method accepting update and workflow execution identifiers
cards.resolutionDetails: Feature was implemented in the TypeScript SDK
cards.keyQuote: Add `workflowHandle.getUpdateHandle(...)` method to obtain an `UpdateHandle` given update and workflow execution identifiers.

cards.summary: Node.js discards promises created by the bridge-to-rust layer when callbacks are passed to non-node threads (e.g., Tokio runtime), causing unexpected process exits with code 13. The issue occurs because callbacks aren't marked as "referenced" by native code, and Neon doesn't expose the Thread Safe Functions API needed to fix it.
cards.userImpact: Applications may crash unexpectedly with exit code 13 when using ESM or worker threads, making the SDK unreliable in these environments.
cards.rootCause: Callback functions passed to non-node threads (Tokio runtime) are not marked as "referenced" by native code, causing Node.js to discard the associated promises as non-resolving and exit prematurely.
cards.proposedFix: Expose the Thread Safe Functions API in Neon to properly mark callbacks as referenced when they're passed to non-node threads.
cards.workaround: Wrap the promise with an additional timeout promise to keep the event loop alive (e.g., `Promise.all([runtime.shutdown(), setTimeout(2000)])`)
cards.keyQuote: callback functions are not marked as "referenced" by the native code when they get passed to non-node threads

cards.summary: The test framework is using an outdated version of the CLI for creating ephemeral test servers, which prevents testing of the latest features like those introduced in #1300.
cards.userImpact: Developers cannot test new features during development due to outdated test server capabilities.
cards.rootCause: Test framework is using an old version of the CLI that lacks support for latest features
cards.proposedFix: Upgrade the CLI to the latest version in the test framework
cards.resolutionDetails: CLI version in test framework was upgraded to support the latest features
cards.keyQuote: The test framework is using an old version of the cli to create ephemeral servers during testing, and these servers do not support the latest features

cards.summary: Support using the pure JavaScript Connection class to power Workers instead of requiring NativeConnection. This would unify the two separate connection implementations, enable exposing the worker's connection to activities, and support eager workflow start.
cards.userImpact: Users would have a unified connection interface, slimmer deployments in FaaS environments, and access to worker connections in activity implementations.
cards.rootCause: The architecture maintains two separate connection implementations (NativeConnection for workers, Connection for clients) causing confusion and architectural limitations.
cards.proposedFix: Merge the two connection classes, use Connection as the base implementation since it supports gRPC interceptors and requires no native code, and add metrics recording to Connection.
cards.keyQuote: Connection is the preferred implementation as it supports grpc interceptors and does not require any native code making it slimmer

cards.summary: The `this` context becomes undefined when destructuring methods from Context.current() and calling them from a new async context, because arrow functions weren't used. This breaks the pattern of importing sleep/other context methods before use.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot destructure context methods like sleep from Context.current() and call them later from different async contexts, limiting code organization patterns.
cards.rootCause: Methods in Context were not defined as arrow functions, so `this` binding was lost when methods were destructured and called from a new async context.
cards.proposedFix: Convert context methods to arrow functions to preserve `this` binding regardless of call site.
cards.workaround: Users must keep the reference to Context.current() and call methods through it: `const context = Context.current(); await context.sleep(3000);` instead of destructuring.
cards.resolutionDetails: Resolved in PR #1249 by making context methods arrow functions to fix `this` binding in async contexts.
cards.keyQuote: you can't import it before const { sleep } = Context.current(); ... await sleep(3000); and then call it from a new async context.

cards.summary: ESM custom payload converters fail to load because the SDK uses `require()` instead of dynamic `import()` to load them. Users get an ERR_REQUIRE_ESM error when trying to use ESM modules as custom payload converters.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot use ESM modules as custom payload converters without manually bundling them to CommonJS, creating a developer experience barrier.
cards.rootCause: The SDK uses synchronous `require()` in data-converter-helpers.ts to load payload converters, which doesn't support ESM modules. Node.js requires dynamic `import()` for ESM compatibility.
cards.proposedFix: Replace `require()` with dynamic `import()` for loading payload converters to support both CommonJS and ESM modules.
cards.workaround: Manually bundle ESM payload converters to CommonJS using esbuild or tsup with appropriate external dependencies, then use `require.resolve()` to reference them.
cards.keyQuote: Instead change the require of payload-converter.js to a dynamic import() which is available in all CommonJS modules.

cards.summary: Custom payload converter works for encoding but fails during activity resolution with 'Unknown encoding' error. Issue stems from ESM bundling of the custom converter - the converter is passed correctly for initial workflow activation but fails when activities complete.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot use custom payload converters with ESM bundling in TypeScript workers as activities fail to resolve with encoding errors.
cards.rootCause: Issue with how ESM TypeScript is transformed into CommonJS bundle for custom payload converters - the converter works for toPayload but fails for fromPayload during activity completion
cards.proposedFix: Provide guidelines or fix for properly bundling ESM payload converters to CommonJS format that works correctly in both encoding and decoding phases
cards.workaround: Pass a raw TS file directly to payloadConverterPath instead of a bundled version
cards.resolutionDetails: Reporter determined the root cause was their own bundling configuration (ESM to CommonJS transformation), not an SDK bug. Related issue #1292 opened to track ESM converter support separately.
cards.keyQuote: I think it is indeed an issue with how I transformed my ESM ts into a commonjs bundle, but it is weird that it works to create the payload and start the activity, but not when the activity completes.

cards.summary: Users need the ability to manually control pagination when listing workflows in the TypeScript SDK. The request is for the SDK to return pagination tokens and allow users to provide those tokens on subsequent calls, similar to how the Python SDK implements this feature.
cards.userImpact: Users building UIs around workflow listing cannot implement manual pagination controls, limiting their ability to create flexible pagination interfaces.
cards.proposedFix: Accept pagination token parameter on list call and return token and page information in response, following the pattern already implemented in the Python SDK.
cards.keyQuote: Some users are using this list to power a UI, but we are hiding the pagination.

cards.summary: Feature request to reduce boilerplate code in the TypeScript SDK by allowing direct imports and calls to workflows and activities as regular functions, and passing them directly to Worker configuration instead of using proxy functions and path specifications.
cards.userImpact: Developers would write less boilerplate code and have a more natural TypeScript experience when wiring workflows and activities.
cards.rootCause: The architectural requirement to compose workflows and activities across different execution contexts (deterministic VM, worker threads, etc.) necessitates proxy patterns and explicit configuration.
cards.proposedFix: Allow importing workflow/activity functions directly and passing them as first argument with configuration at call time, similar to Rust's implicit self parameter pattern. Pass workflow/activity modules directly to Worker.create instead of path specifications.
cards.resolutionDetails: Maintainers determined the proposal was not actionable without more concrete suggestions and noted that JavaScript/TypeScript language design constraints make eliminating glue code impractical.
cards.keyQuote: I honestly don't see how it would be possible to "magically" avoid any form of glue code.

cards.summary: Feature request to add Deno support to the TypeScript SDK. The request would enable developers to write Temporal code using Deno's native Web APIs and run TypeScript without a build step.
cards.userImpact: Developers wanting to use Temporal workflows in Deno environments cannot currently do so, limiting the SDK's compatibility with the Deno runtime.
cards.rootCause: TypeScript SDK relies heavily on Node.js-specific APIs (Worker Threads, VMs, async hooks, native libraries) that are not fully compatible or available in Deno, requiring significant architectural redesign.
cards.proposedFix: Redesign key SDK components and potentially the Core SDK to work as a WASM module instead of NAPI library, with compatibility abstractions for Deno's implementations.
cards.resolutionDetails: Closed as a long-term objective that would require considerable rewriting of multiple components. The project uses a different system to track and prioritize large-scale objectives.
cards.keyQuote: In practice, I expect that we'll probably need to rewrite/redesign several key components of the TypeScript SDK to get it to run reliably and efficiently on Deno.

cards.summary: Activity logger does not serialize Error objects passed as metadata arguments, only showing the Context object instead. The issue occurs when passing Error objects as the second argument to log.error(), but works correctly for uncaught errors.
cards.userImpact: Developers cannot properly log Error objects in activities, making debugging more difficult as stack traces are lost.
cards.rootCause: The second argument to log.error() is treated as a metadata object rather than an error object, and the logging implementation does not serialize Error objects in metadata.
cards.proposedFix: Wrap Error objects in a metadata object with an 'error' key: { error: new Error('...') }
cards.workaround: Pass the Error object wrapped in a metadata object: Context.current().log.error('Kablamo!', { error: new Error('THIS IS AN ERROR!!!') })
cards.resolutionDetails: Marked as resolved through documentation/clarification - the API is working as designed, and the correct usage pattern was provided.
cards.keyQuote: The second argument of `log.error` is a metadata object, not an error.

cards.summary: Request to support Vite as a bundler for TypeScript SDK instead of Webpack, which is slow (10+ second builds). Community members suggest esbuild as a faster alternative, with one user reporting 0.6s production builds.
cards.userImpact: Users experience slow development and production builds with Webpack, reducing developer productivity during iterative development.
cards.rootCause: Webpack bundler integrated into SDK is slow compared to modern alternatives like Vite and esbuild.
cards.proposedFix: Replace Webpack with Vite or esbuild for faster bundling. esbuild achieves 0.6s production builds compared to 10+ seconds with Webpack.
cards.workaround: Users can use external bundlers like esbuild with custom build scripts (as demonstrated in shared gist), though integration with SDK worker instantiation remains a consideration.
cards.keyQuote: Webpack is great, but it is pretty slow and waiting 10 seconds for bundle to complete can become a nuisance.

cards.summary: Feature request to expose NativeClient keep-alive options that are already enabled by default in SDK core. The request was closed as the team determined that long polls used by the worker are a suitable replacement for keep-alive functionality.
cards.userImpact: Users requesting keep-alive support for NativeClient connections would not have direct access to this feature.
cards.rootCause: Long polls in the worker provide equivalent functionality to keep-alive, making the feature request unnecessary.
cards.proposedFix: Expose keep-alive options from sdk-core issue #585 (though ultimately not implemented).
cards.workaround: Use long polling mechanism already available in the worker.
cards.resolutionDetails: Team determined that long polls used by workers are a sufficient replacement for keep-alive support, so the feature was not implemented.
cards.keyQuote: This doesn't apply to the worker imho as the long polls are a replacement for keep alive.

cards.summary: Error objects sent to Sink functions lose important fields (type, details, custom ApplicationFailure properties) due to structured clone serialization limitations in postMessage. When errors are transferred from worker threads to the main thread, only basic Error properties (name, message, stack) are preserved.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot access custom error attributes (type, details, nonRetryable flag) in sink functions, limiting error handling and observability in workflows.
cards.rootCause: Node.js structured clone algorithm used by postMessage does not serialize custom properties on Error objects or complex nested structures like ApplicationFailure.
cards.proposedFix: Extend the error serialization format to manually preserve custom fields before postMessage transfer and reconstruct them on the receiving end.
cards.workaround: Documentation should clearly document this limitation and advise users on what fields are available in sinks.
