cards.keyQuote: This is a known limitation of sinks...the data is transferred over postMessage from a worker thread to the main Node.js thread which uses the structured clone algorithm.

cards.summary: Docker worker fails with TCP connection error (Cannot assign requested address) when started via docker run, but works when manually running the same command inside the container. The issue appears to be an environment or networking configuration problem specific to the container startup context.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot deploy Temporal TypeScript workers in Docker containers using standard docker run commands without manual intervention.
cards.rootCause: Network binding issue specific to how Docker initializes the container environment - likely related to host address resolution or network interface availability at container startup time versus manual execution.
cards.workaround: Manually shell into the container and run the worker initialization command directly (e.g., shell exec form in Dockerfile or manual docker exec).
cards.resolutionDetails: Issue closed due to lack of response from original poster and insufficient debugging information. Maintainers requested more context (NativeConnection options, Worker options, Dockerfile) to diagnose.
cards.keyQuote: It works when I manually shell into the container and manually run `node worker.js`.

cards.summary: The TypeScript SDK's core-bridge native library doesn't support musl-based systems (like Alpine Linux). Users need the ability to build musl-compatible native libraries to run workers in Alpine containers.
cards.userImpact: Users requiring Alpine Docker images cannot run TypeScript SDK workers without self-building the native library.
cards.rootCause: The target environment detection logic in core-bridge cannot recognize musl-based systems because Node.js provides no direct indication of the C library in use.
cards.proposedFix: Modify the target environment detection logic in packages/core-bridge/common.js to recognize musl environments by inspecting process or os APIs, and add musl build targets to the CI test matrix.
cards.workaround: Users can manually build the native library by installing build tools, setting RUSTFLAGS and BUILD_CORE_RELEASE environment variables, and copying the compiled artifact.
cards.resolutionDetails: Superseded by #1621, indicating the feature was implemented through a more comprehensive solution.
cards.keyQuote: the TS logic that identify the current target can't recognize the fact that it is running on a musl-based system

cards.summary: Webpack's log output is being called repeatedly with ANSI color sequences, making logs difficult to parse when captured by external logging systems like GitHub Actions or Datadog. The issue requests gathering Webpack log output into single, structured log entries.
cards.userImpact: Users who integrate worker logging with external logging systems experience unreadable, fragmented logs with ANSI escape sequences.
cards.rootCause: Webpack's logger is called multiple times per bundle operation, each call including ANSI color escape sequences that don't display well in non-terminal environments.
cards.proposedFix: Gather Webpack log output into a single, structured log entry instead of multiple calls with raw output.
cards.workaround: Implement a custom bundle with a custom Webpack logger that collects all logs and removes ANSI styling before outputting to external systems.
cards.resolutionDetails: Resolved in #1414 with changes to how Webpack logging is handled during bundling.
cards.keyQuote: Webpack calls `log()` repeatedly, and include lot of ANSI-color escape sequences. This is fine and nice when logs are going straight to console, but horrible and hard to understand when logs are captured into some external system

cards.summary: Add support for `StartWorkflowOptions.workflowStartDelay` that was recently introduced in the server. The API should expose this option to allow workflows to start with a specified delay.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot currently use the server's workflow start delay feature from the TypeScript SDK, limiting scheduling capabilities.
cards.proposedFix: Expose `workflowStartDelay` (or `startDelay` as recommended) in the `StartWorkflowOptions` interface
cards.resolutionDetails: Feature was implemented, with naming feedback suggesting `startDelay` as the API name
cards.keyQuote: workflowStartDelay was introduced recently in server. Need to expose it in StartWorkflowOptions

cards.summary: Mend security vulnerability report for nyc-test-coverage package with 2 high-severity vulnerabilities in transitive dependencies: CVE-2023-45133 in @babel/traverse (CVSS 8.8) and CVE-2022-25883 in semver (CVSS 7.5). Issue was automatically closed as the vulnerable library was removed from the project inventory.
cards.userImpact: Users could be exposed to arbitrary code execution during compilation when using affected Babel plugins, though actual impact depends on whether untrusted code is compiled.
cards.rootCause: Vulnerable transitive dependencies (traverse-7.21.4 and semver-7.5.0) in the test coverage configuration package nyc-test-coverage-1.8.6.
cards.proposedFix: Upgrade @babel/traverse to 7.23.2 or later, and semver to 7.5.2 or later.
cards.workaround: Upgrade affected Babel-related packages to patched versions: @babel/plugin-transform-runtime v7.23.2, @babel/preset-env v7.23.2, or other affected packages listed in the vulnerability details.
cards.resolutionDetails: Automatically closed by Mend as the vulnerable library was removed from the project or marked as ignored in the Mend inventory.
cards.keyQuote: This issue was automatically closed by Mend because the vulnerable library in the specific branch(es) was either marked as ignored or it is no longer part of the Mend inventory.

cards.summary: MockActivityEnvironment instantiation holds open a neon threadsafe function handle that prevents Jest from exiting cleanly. The issue occurs even if the environment is never used to run activities.
cards.userImpact: Testing with MockActivityEnvironment fails because Jest cannot exit due to an open native handle, blocking test suite completion.
cards.rootCause: The core-bridge native binding creates a neon threadsafe function handle during runtime initialization that is not properly cleaned up when MockActivityEnvironment is instantiated.
cards.resolutionDetails: Marked as duplicate of issue #928 which addresses the same MockActivityEnvironment handle cleanup problem.
cards.keyQuote: Jest can't exit after instantiating MockActivityEnvironment, even if I don't actually use the MockActivityEnvironment to run an activity.

cards.summary: Users encounter cryptic and inconsistent TLS CA certificate error messages when running in slim Docker images without root CA certificates. The error message lacks clarity on what users need to do to resolve the issue.
cards.userImpact: Users running in minimal environments receive unhelpful error messages that obscure the root cause and solution path for missing TLS certificates.
cards.rootCause: Error messages from underlying transport layers (tonic/hyper) are not being wrapped with user-friendly context about missing CA certificates.
cards.proposedFix: Provide nicer, more informative error messages that clearly indicate missing CA certificates and guide users toward solutions.
cards.workaround: Install ca-certificates package (though this is not always sufficient in all environments).
cards.keyQuote: if root CA certificates are not available locally (ie. running with `-slim` docker images), then the error message is cryptic and inconsistent

cards.summary: The `appendDefaultInterceptors()` function is easy to miss and causes poor developer experience. This feature request asks to make workflow and activity logging work by default without requiring this explicit call, then deprecate the function.
cards.userImpact: Users will have a better developer experience by not needing to remember to call `appendDefaultInterceptors()` for logging to work.
cards.rootCause: The `appendDefaultInterceptors()` function is required for workflow and activity logging but is not intuitive or automatic, requiring developers to explicitly call it.
cards.proposedFix: Move log calls out of the interceptor into the activator or forcibly inject the interceptor so it works by default, making `appendDefaultInterceptors()` a noop that can be deprecated.
cards.resolutionDetails: Fixed in PR #1290
cards.keyQuote: appendDefaultInterceptors() is quite easy to miss => Bad developer experience. Since 1.8, prepending defaultSink() is no longer required => Better DX

cards.summary: ESBuild-compiled CommonJS workflow bundles fail with 'module is not defined' error when executed in the Temporal workflow VM. The issue occurs because the VM context doesn't provide CommonJS globals like `module` and `exports`.
cards.userImpact: Users building workflows with ESBuild in CommonJS format cannot run them with the Temporal TypeScript SDK, blocking adoption for projects unable to switch to ESM.
cards.rootCause: The VM context used to execute workflows does not provide CommonJS globals (`module`, `exports`) required by ESBuild-generated CommonJS bundles.
cards.resolutionDetails: The SDK was updated to properly support CommonJS workflows in the VM context, allowing ESBuild CommonJS bundles to execute without requiring ESM migration.
cards.keyQuote: ReferenceError: module is not defined at ../src/entrypoint.ts:1:0 at Script.runInContext (node:vm:141:12)

cards.summary: CallCredentials and ChannelCredentials are not being applied to gRPC connections, preventing users from sending Authorization headers for secured Temporal clusters. The issue stems from credentials being dropped during connection setup when TLS is not used.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot authenticate with secured Temporal clusters that require JWT bearer tokens, blocking production deployments with Azure AD or similar auth systems.
cards.rootCause: The connection setup code destructures and discards the credentials parameter when TLS is not configured, preventing call credentials from being applied to the gRPC channel.
cards.proposedFix: Ensure credentials are preserved and applied to the gRPC channel configuration regardless of TLS status, similar to how metadata is handled.
cards.workaround: Use static metadata with Authorization header in connection options and override it per-call via an interceptor that refreshes the token on each request.
cards.resolutionDetails: The credentials handling was corrected in the connection setup to properly apply CallCredentials regardless of TLS configuration.
cards.keyQuote: I believe the issue comes from this line... In essence I believe that this removes credentials from the resolved options.

cards.summary: WorkflowInfo and Activity.Context objects returned by user code can be mutated, including dangerous mutations like flipping isReplaying which breaks the patched() API. Objects should be immutable to prevent unintended side effects.
cards.userImpact: Users can accidentally mutate critical context properties, breaking workflow replay detection and other runtime behavior.
cards.rootCause: WorkflowInfo and Activity.Context objects are not frozen/immutable, allowing direct property mutations that affect SDK behavior.
cards.keyQuote: workflow code can actually flip the value of wf.workflowInfo().unsafe.isReplaying, which results in the wf.patched() API function to misbehave

cards.summary: A ReDoS vulnerability (CVE-2022-25883) was detected in the semver dependency (version 7.5.0) transitive through ts-loader. The issue was automatically closed after the vulnerable library was removed from the inventory.
cards.userImpact: Users could be affected by a Regular Expression Denial of Service attack if untrusted user data is provided to semver's Range function.
cards.rootCause: semver library versions before 7.5.2 contain a ReDoS vulnerability in the Range function when processing untrusted input.
cards.proposedFix: Upgrade semver to version 7.5.2 or later (also available: 5.7.2, 6.3.1).
cards.resolutionDetails: Issue was automatically closed by Mend because the vulnerable library was either ignored or removed from the inventory.
cards.keyQuote: Versions of the package semver before 7.5.2 are vulnerable to Regular Expression Denial of Service (ReDoS) via the function new Range

cards.summary: Transitive dependency vulnerability in semver package (CVE-2022-25883) used by ts-loader, causing a Regular Expression Denial of Service vulnerability with CVSS score 7.5. Issue was automatically closed when the vulnerable library was removed from the project's dependency tree.
cards.userImpact: Users may experience denial of service if untrusted semver range data is processed during the build process.
cards.rootCause: semver package versions before 7.5.2 contain a Regular Expression Denial of Service vulnerability in the Range function when processing untrusted user input.
cards.proposedFix: Upgrade semver to version 7.5.2 or later, or remove/update ts-loader dependency.
cards.resolutionDetails: Vulnerability was resolved when the vulnerable library was removed from the project dependencies and is no longer part of the inventory.
cards.keyQuote: Versions of the package semver before 7.5.2 are vulnerable to Regular Expression Denial of Service (ReDoS) via the function new Range

cards.summary: The @temporalio/nyc-test-coverage package is difficult to use correctly and fragile, causing users to encounter various errors (invalid coverage objects, incorrect coverage reports) despite following documentation. The issue requires both tool improvements for resilience and better usage documentation.
cards.userImpact: Users struggle to set up test coverage for workflow tests and encounter errors or incorrect coverage reports, making it difficult to measure test quality.
cards.rootCause: FileCoverage constructor receives CoverageMap instances when expecting FileCoverage instances; mergeIntoGlobalCoverage function doesn't correctly handle coverage merging with different source maps from different transpilers (ts-jest vs webpack).
cards.proposedFix: Improve tool resilience to runtime environment variations; patch FileCoverage constructor to handle CoverageMap instances; fix mergeIntoGlobalCoverage function to properly merge coverage data regardless of source map differences.
cards.workaround: Bypass mergeIntoGlobalCoverage and manually write coverage data to .nyc_output using createCoverageMap().merge() for each coverage map; patch istanbul-lib-coverage FileCoverage constructor locally.
cards.keyQuote: using the `@temporalio/nyc-test-coverage` package to collect coverage data for Workflow tests is quite difficult and generally fragile

cards.summary: Feature request to implement typed search attributes for the TypeScript SDK, as defined in the cross-SDK proposal. This would provide type-safe access to search attributes in workflows and activities.
cards.userImpact: Enables developers to define and use search attributes with full type safety, reducing runtime errors and improving developer experience.
cards.proposedFix: Implement typed search attributes following the SDK proposal specification
cards.resolutionDetails: Feature was implemented and completed
cards.keyQuote: Implementation of typed search attributes

cards.summary: TypeScript compiler error in deprecated-time.ts due to unfamiliar syntax that requires TypeScript 5.1 or later to properly recognize.
cards.userImpact: Users with TypeScript versions below 5.1 may encounter compiler errors when building the SDK.
cards.rootCause: The syntax in deprecated-time.ts is not recognized by TypeScript versions below 5.1.
cards.proposedFix: Upgrade to TypeScript 5.1 or later to recognize the syntax.
cards.resolutionDetails: Issue was resolved by supporting TypeScript 5.1 which properly recognizes the syntax.
cards.keyQuote: Using typescript > 5.1 helps to recognise this syntax.

cards.summary: User requested a `registerSearchAttribute` method on `TestWorkflowEnvironment` to register custom search attributes for testing, similar to the Java SDK. The issue was self-resolved when the user discovered the functionality already exists via `connection.operatorService.addSearchAttributes()`, but the API is poorly documented.
cards.userImpact: Users struggle to register custom search attributes in test environments due to undiscovered or undocumented API.
cards.rootCause: The `operatorService.addSearchAttributes()` method exists but is not exposed on `TestWorkflowEnvironment` interface or documented, making it difficult for users to discover.
cards.proposedFix: Add `registerSearchAttribute` method to `TestWorkflowEnvironment` interface as a convenience method, or improve documentation to reference the existing `operatorService.addSearchAttributes()` approach.
cards.workaround: Use `temporalTestEnv.connection.operatorService.addSearchAttributes()` to register custom search attributes directly.
cards.resolutionDetails: Resolved by improving documentation and exposing the existing operatorService.addSearchAttributes() API. User discovered the solution exists but is hidden.
cards.keyQuote: It's quite hidden though. Would be good if it could be documented somewhere.

cards.summary: Add support for custom metrics in the TypeScript SDK following the pattern established by DotNET and Python SDKs. This includes updating to the latest Core SDK, ensuring existing Prometheus and OpenTelemetry options work correctly, adding user-facing metrics APIs, and removing Tracing support.
cards.userImpact: Users can now record custom metrics in their Temporal TypeScript applications, improving observability and alignment with other SDK implementations.
cards.proposedFix: Follow the API patterns established by DotNET SDK PR #129 and Python SDK PR #380 for adding custom metrics support
cards.resolutionDetails: Implemented custom metrics support following established patterns from other SDKs
cards.keyQuote: With https://github.com/temporalio/sdk-core/pull/544 landed, we need to: Add support for users to add/record metrics

cards.summary: A Regular Expression Denial of Service (ReDoS) vulnerability was discovered in semver 7.5.0, a transitive dependency through ts-loader in the nyc-test-coverage package. The vulnerability allows untrusted user data to cause high availability impact, and was resolved when the vulnerable library was removed from the project.
cards.userImpact: Users' builds and CI/CD pipelines could experience denial of service through malicious or untrusted semver range inputs.
cards.rootCause: Regular Expression Denial of Service (ReDoS) in semver versions before 7.5.2 when parsing untrusted range data.
cards.proposedFix: Upgrade semver to version 7.5.2 or later, or remove the vulnerable dependency chain.
cards.resolutionDetails: The issue was automatically closed when the vulnerable library was removed from the Mend inventory for the specific branch.
cards.keyQuote: Versions of the package semver before 7.5.2 are vulnerable to Regular Expression Denial of Service (ReDoS) via the function new Range

cards.summary: User seeks clarification on signalWithStart behavior after release notes mentioned throwing WorkflowExecutionAlreadyStartedError. The official documentation suggests it should signal without error if workflow is running, creating confusion about whether this is a regression.
cards.userImpact: Users are confused about the expected behavior of signalWithStart and whether throwing an error on running workflows is intended or a regression.
cards.rootCause: Unclear release notes wording combined with documentation that describes different behavior than what was implemented in v1.8.3.
cards.workaround: Use workflowIdReusePolicy: WORKFLOW_ID_REUSE_POLICY_ALLOW_DUPLICATE (the default) to avoid the error case.
cards.resolutionDetails: Clarified that signalWithStart should not throw WorkflowExecutionAlreadyStartedError when workflow is running. The error only occurs in rare cases with specific workflowIdReusePolicy settings and non-running workflows.
cards.keyQuote: In general `signalWithStart` should not throw `WorkflowExecutionAlreadyStartedError`.

cards.summary: Worker crashes with RangeError during shutdown when log forwarding is enabled due to infinite recursion in RxJS repeat operator. The issue only occurs with log forwarding configuration and doesn't happen with alternative logging filter options.
cards.userImpact: Worker process crashes during shutdown when log forwarding is configured, affecting graceful termination.
cards.rootCause: RxJS repeat operator enters infinite recursion when handling completion during worker shutdown with log forwarding enabled.
cards.proposedFix: Refactor the log polling mechanism to avoid triggering repeat operator recursion, possibly by moving log processing logic to a separate function or restructuring the subscription chain.
cards.workaround: Switch logging configuration from log forwarding to filter-based logging: use makeTelemetryFilterString() instead of forward option.
cards.resolutionDetails: Original fix attempt was reverted due to memory leak, but the issue was later restored/fixed in PR #1225.
cards.keyQuote: This only happens if using log forwarding... No error is thrown if logging options are changed to filter option

cards.summary: Feature request to expose `originalExecutionRunId` in `workflowInfo()` to enable deterministic PRNG seeding that remains stable through Resets but changes on Continue-As-New/Cron operations.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot currently seed PRNGs deterministically in workflows with a value that changes on Continue-As-New/Cron but persists through Resets.
cards.proposedFix: Expose `originalExecutionRunId` through the `workflowInfo()` API
cards.workaround: Math.random() is already deterministic and seeded using originalRunId, updated when run ID changes
cards.keyQuote: Can we get this `originalExecutionRunId` exposed in `workflowInfo()`?

cards.summary: Transitive dependency semver 7.5.0 has a ReDoS vulnerability (CVE-2022-25883) with CVSS score 7.5. The vulnerable package is pulled in through ts-loader, affecting the test coverage build artifact.
cards.userImpact: Users could experience denial of service attacks if untrusted data is provided to the vulnerable semver Range function in test artifacts.
cards.rootCause: semver package before version 7.5.2 contains a ReDoS vulnerability in the Range function when processing untrusted input
cards.proposedFix: Upgrade semver to version 7.5.2 or later, or upgrade ts-loader which is the direct dependency bringing in the vulnerable semver version
cards.resolutionDetails: Issue was automatically closed when the vulnerable library was removed from the inventory or marked as ignored in the Mend system
cards.keyQuote: Versions of the package semver before 7.5.2 are vulnerable to Regular Expression Denial of Service (ReDoS) via the function new Range

cards.summary: Critical prototype pollution vulnerability (CVE-2023-36665) in protobufjs 7.2.3, a transitive dependency of @temporalio/client. The vulnerability allows attackers to pollute Object.prototype through malicious protobuf messages, with a CVSS score of 9.8.
cards.userImpact: Users of @temporalio/client are exposed to critical prototype pollution attacks through the vulnerable protobufjs transitive dependency.
cards.rootCause: protobufjs versions 6.10.0 through 7.x before 7.2.4 contain a prototype pollution vulnerability allowing Object.prototype to be modified through user-controlled protobuf messages.
cards.proposedFix: Upgrade protobufjs to version 7.2.4 or later
cards.resolutionDetails: Issue was closed, likely by upgrading protobufjs to a patched version (7.2.4+)
cards.keyQuote: protobuf.js (aka protobufjs) 6.10.0 through 7.x before 7.2.4 allows Prototype Pollution... A user-controlled protobuf message can be used by an attacker to pollute the prototype of Object.prototype

cards.summary: Semver 7.5.0 contains a ReDoS vulnerability (CVE-2022-25883) with CVSS score 7.5, affecting nyc-test-coverage as a transitive dependency through ts-loader. The issue was automatically closed after the vulnerable library was no longer part of the inventory.
cards.userImpact: Dependency contains a ReDoS vulnerability that could cause denial of service through maliciously crafted semver ranges.
cards.rootCause: semver library before version 7.5.2 is vulnerable to Regular Expression Denial of Service (ReDoS) via the Range function when processing untrusted user data.
cards.proposedFix: Upgrade semver to version 7.5.2 or later (fix available since 2023-06-21).
cards.resolutionDetails: Automatically closed by Mend after the vulnerable library was marked as ignored or removed from the Mend inventory, not through explicit remediation.
cards.keyQuote: Versions of the package semver before 7.5.2 are vulnerable to Regular Expression Denial of Service (ReDoS) via the function new Range

cards.summary: Prototype Pollution vulnerability (CVE-2023-36665) in protobufjs 7.2.3 with CVSS score of 9.8, allowing attackers to pollute Object.prototype through untrusted protobuf messages. The issue was automatically closed after the vulnerable library was removed from the dependency inventory.
cards.userImpact: Applications using the affected version of protobufjs are vulnerable to prototype pollution attacks that could compromise confidentiality, integrity, and availability.
cards.rootCause: protobufjs versions 6.10.0 through 7.2.3 fail to properly sanitize user-controlled protobuf messages, allowing modification of Object.prototype through parse(), load/loadSync(), or untrusted input to ReflectionObject.setParsedOption.
cards.proposedFix: Upgrade protobufjs to version 7.2.4 or later to fix the prototype pollution vulnerability.
cards.resolutionDetails: The issue was automatically closed by Mend because the vulnerable library was either ignored or removed from the dependency inventory in the branch.
cards.keyQuote: protobuf.js 6.10.0 through 7.x before 7.2.4 allows Prototype Pollution... A user-controlled protobuf message can be used by an attacker to pollute the prototype of Object.prototype

cards.summary: Activity interceptors need access to retry configuration to determine if an activity is on its final attempt, enabling selective error reporting to monitoring services.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot distinguish between transient failures and final failures in activity interceptors, causing unnecessary error reports to monitoring services.
cards.rootCause: ActivityInfo does not expose retry configuration or remaining attempt count, even though this data is available in the PollActivityTaskQueueResponse proto and known to the server.
cards.proposedFix: Expose retry options or remaining attempt count in the ActivityInfo interface to allow interceptors to conditionally report errors.
cards.workaround: None identified in discussion.
cards.resolutionDetails: Closed as duplicate of a cross-SDK issue. Blocking issue is server-side: server is not populating retry policy field in PollActivityTaskQueueResponse (temporal#6502).
cards.keyQuote: We'd like to only report exceptions that are thrown on the final attempt, but ActivityInboundExceptionInterceptor only knows which attempt the activity threw the exception on, it doesn't know how many attempts the activity has left.

cards.summary: The defaultWorkerLogger sink fails to register automatically when using @temporalio/nyc-test-coverage's augmentWorkerOptions without explicitly setting WorkerOptions.sinks. Users must manually specify sinks: defaultSinks() as a workaround.
cards.userImpact: Users testing with nyc-test-coverage cannot use workflow.log without manually configuring sinks, breaking the default logging experience.
cards.rootCause: The defaultWorkerLogger sink registration is not automatically applied when augmentWorkerOptions is called without explicit sinks configuration.
cards.workaround: Explicitly specify sinks: defaultSinks() in WorkerOptions before calling augmentWorkerOptions
cards.resolutionDetails: Fixed by PR #1283
cards.keyQuote: The defaultWorkerLogger sink doesn't get automatically registered if WorkerOptions.sinks is not explicitly set before passing the WorkerOptions through @temporalio/nyc-test-coverage's augmentWorkerOptions.

cards.summary: Type definitions for proxyActivities incorrectly return type `symbol` when wrapping synchronous (non-Promise-returning) activity functions, causing TypeScript errors and requiring manual type casting.
cards.userImpact: Developers using synchronous activity functions cannot use proxyActivities without manual type casting, reducing type safety.
cards.rootCause: ActivityFunction interface type definition missing union type for non-Promise return values, filtering out synchronous functions
cards.proposedFix: Add `| R` to line 69 of packages/common/src/interfaces.ts to include non-Promise return types in the ActivityFunction interface
cards.workaround: Manually type cast the result of proxyActivities to the correct function signature
cards.resolutionDetails: Closed as not planned - the design intentionally requires async activities. Authors confirmed no legitimate use case.
cards.keyQuote: This is actually by design, thought that's something that we could reconsider if there's a strong use case for explicitly non-async activities.

cards.summary: Cron job workflow gets terminated automatically shortly after deployment, either immediately after scheduling or mid-execution. User experiencing issues with cron job reliability on AWS ECS despite setting workflowRunTimeout and workflowTaskTimeout.
cards.userImpact: Production cron jobs fail to execute reliably after deployment, causing scheduled work to be lost or interrupted.
cards.rootCause: Possible causes identified in discussion: (1) workflow terminated by client before task scheduling, (2) workflow exceeding operational limits (too many buffered events or large gRPC message size), or (3) deployment/worker configuration issue
cards.proposedFix: Migrate to Schedules API which is more powerful and reliable than legacy cron workflows
cards.resolutionDetails: Maintainer closed ticket indicating no action needed on SDK side; recommended using Schedules API instead and suggested community channels for support
cards.keyQuote: This happens when a workflow somehow exceeds some operational limit, for example if there are too many buffered events for that workflow, or if buffered events exceeds the maximum gRPC message size.

cards.summary: The metric `workflow_task_execution_failed` is missing the `workflow_type` tag after upgrading from SDK 1.6.0 to 1.8.2, making it difficult to route alerts by workflow type. The `task_queue` tag works correctly.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot monitor workflow task execution failures per workflow type, limiting their ability to route alerts to the correct teams.
cards.rootCause: Change in sdk-core PR #481 stopped emitting the `workflow_type` tag on the `workflow_task_execution_failed` metric
cards.resolutionDetails: Post-upgrade metrics to 1.8.2 are now tagged correctly with workflow_type; the issue was likely resolved by the sdk-core change that reintroduced proper tagging
cards.keyQuote: the metric for `workflow_task_execution_failed` stopped being emitted... we used to get some tags on the metric for the `workflow_type`, but that's no longer coming through

cards.summary: User requests a programmatic way to roll back workflow execution step-by-step by reverting the event history, rather than just resetting to the beginning. They want workflow logic to undo previous steps.
cards.userImpact: Users seeking step-by-step rollback capability would need to implement their own compensating transactions or use the CLI reset command instead.
cards.proposedFix: Possible programmatic reset API like `workflowHandle.reset(eventId)` was suggested but not endorsed as a solution.
cards.workaround: Use try/catch blocks with compensating activities in workflow code, or use the CLI `workflow reset` command for full resets.
cards.resolutionDetails: Maintainers recommended existing approaches: implementing rollback logic in workflow code via try/catch with compensating activities, or using the CLI reset command. Closed as unresolved but with suggested workarounds.
cards.keyQuote: It is much more preferable coding and handling rollback in workflow code where you have access to the full execution context.

cards.summary: Typo in the `defaultWorflowInterceptorModules` API name in the TypeScript SDK documentation and/or code. The API name should be `defaultWorkflowInterceptorModules` (with correct spelling of 'Workflow').
cards.userImpact: Users encountering the misspelled API name may face confusion when trying to use the worker interceptor modules feature.
cards.rootCause: Typo in the API name 'defaultWorflowInterceptorModules' should be 'defaultWorkflowInterceptorModules'
cards.resolutionDetails: Fixed by PR #1204
cards.keyQuote: Typo in `defaultWorflowInterceptorModules` API

cards.summary: Log entries forwarded from the core runtime lack metadata fields like workflow ID and run ID, making them non-actionable. The core has these fields available but they're not being extracted and passed to the TypeScript logger.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot effectively debug or monitor workflows because forwarded core logs lack essential metadata like workflow ID and run ID needed to correlate logs with workflow executions.
cards.rootCause: The SDK currently ships pre-formatted logs from Core without extracting individual attributes/metadata fields that are available in the Core API's telemetry structures.
cards.proposedFix: Extract log attributes from the Core telemetry API and pass them to the lang logger, with field name casing normalization (e.g., workflow_type to workflowType).
cards.resolutionDetails: Core telemetry fields were made available for extraction by the TypeScript SDK.
cards.keyQuote: Especially log entries like `Failing workflow task` need to include the workflow id and run id for them to be actionable.

cards.summary: Workflow bundle size increased by approximately 1.5MB in version 1.8.1 due to an unintended dependency on the protobuf package being imported in workflow.ts, causing bundle bloat.
cards.userImpact: Users experience significantly larger workflow bundles in production, increasing deployment size and latency by over 200%.
cards.rootCause: Unintended dependency on the protobuf package was added to workflow.ts in version 1.8.1
cards.resolutionDetails: Fixed by PR #1203
cards.keyQuote: The workflow bundle size increased by ~1.5 MB between TS SDK 1.8.0 and 1.8.1.

cards.summary: Memory occupied by worker instances on AWS ECS Linux environments is not being released after load testing, while the same code works properly on Windows. Setting maxCachedWorkflows to 0 releases memory but causes performance degradation.
cards.userImpact: Production deployments on AWS ECS Linux may experience uncontrolled memory growth leading to potential out-of-memory crashes, requiring configuration workarounds that harm performance.
cards.rootCause: Platform-specific memory release behavior in workflow caching mechanism differs between Linux and Windows; default maxCachedWorkflows calculation results in different cache sizes (158 on Linux vs 914 on Windows), preventing proper garbage collection on Linux under sustained load.
cards.proposedFix: Upgrade to SDK version 1.8.2 or later and enable reuseV8Context option; explicitly configure maxCachedWorkflows based on performance testing in production environments rather than relying on defaults.
cards.workaround: Set maxCachedWorkflows to 0 to disable workflow caching (not recommended for production due to performance impact) or explicitly tune maxCachedWorkflows to an appropriate value and enable reuseV8Context.
cards.resolutionDetails: Maintainer determined this is expected behavior and the solution requires proper configuration (upgrading to 1.8.2, enabling reuseV8Context, and tuning maxCachedWorkflows) rather than a code fix. The issue was a configuration and understanding problem, not a bug.
cards.keyQuote: Correctly tuning this involves performance testing. Explicitly setting maxCachedWorkflows to 0 disable workflow caching. This can be very detrimental for the performance of both your workers and your Temporal cluster.

cards.summary: Critical prototype pollution vulnerability (CVE-2023-36665) in protobufjs 7.2.3 transitive dependency with CVSS score of 9.8. The vulnerability allows attackers to pollute Object.prototype through untrusted protobuf messages.
cards.userImpact: Users of @temporalio/client are exposed to a critical prototype pollution vulnerability that could lead to unauthorized code execution or data manipulation.
cards.rootCause: protobufjs library (7.2.3) contains a prototype pollution vulnerability allowing attackers to pollute Object.prototype through untrusted protobuf messages via parse(), load(), or setParsedOption() functions.
cards.proposedFix: Upgrade protobufjs to version 7.2.4 or later where the vulnerability is fixed.
cards.resolutionDetails: Issue was automatically closed by Mend because the vulnerable library was either marked as ignored or is no longer part of the Mend inventory in the specific branch.
cards.keyQuote: protobufjs 6.10.0 through 7.x before 7.2.4 allows Prototype Pollution...A user-controlled protobuf message can be used by an attacker to pollute the prototype of Object.prototype

cards.summary: Transitive dependency vulnerability in semver 7.5.0 (CVE-2022-25883) causing Regular Expression Denial of Service. The vulnerability was resolved by updating the dependency chain through ts-loader.
cards.userImpact: Applications using this SDK version are vulnerable to Denial of Service attacks via specially crafted semantic version ranges.
cards.rootCause: semver library versions before 7.5.2 have a Regular Expression Denial of Service vulnerability in the Range function when processing untrusted input.
cards.proposedFix: Upgrade semver to version 7.5.2 or later; upgrade ts-loader which transitively depends on semver.
cards.resolutionDetails: The issue was automatically closed by Mend after the vulnerable library was either ignored or removed from the inventory, indicating the dependency was updated or removed from the build.
cards.keyQuote: Versions of the package semver before 7.5.2 are vulnerable to Regular Expression Denial of Service (ReDoS) via the function new Range

cards.summary: Worker.create fails to bundle ESM written in TypeScript when imports use .js extensions for .ts files. The bundler cannot resolve the modules because the physical .ts files don't have .js extensions, causing webpack resolution errors.
cards.userImpact: Users writing TypeScript workflows with ESM imports cannot use Worker.create with bundling without manually configuring webpack extension aliases.
cards.rootCause: Webpack's module resolver expects either actual .js files or a configuration to treat .js imports as .ts files, but Worker.create doesn't provide this by default for TypeScript ESM projects.
cards.workaround: Use bundlerOptions with a webpackConfigHook to set config.resolve.extensionAlias = { ".js": [".ts", ".js"] }
cards.resolutionDetails: Issue was closed, indicating the bundling TypeScript ESM support was implemented or resolved in a subsequent version.
cards.keyQuote: Worker.create does not support bundling ESM written in TypeScript (imports of `.ts` files with `.js`)

cards.summary: Worker shutdown in v1.8.1 causes a ShutdownError exception that terminates Jest with exit code 1, breaking test suites. Downgrading to v1.7.4 resolves the issue.
cards.userImpact: Tests fail entirely when using worker.shutdown() in v1.8.1, preventing developers from running test suites.
cards.rootCause: Regression introduced in v1.8.1 related to shutdown error handling
cards.proposedFix: PR #1166 fixes the issue
cards.workaround: Downgrade to v1.7.4
cards.resolutionDetails: Fixed in PR #1166, included in v1.8.2 release
cards.keyQuote: [ERROR] Worker failed { error: [Error [ShutdownError]: ShutDown] }

cards.summary: The `Context.current().info.heartbeatTimeoutMs` property is undefined in the TypeScript SDK, while it should contain the heartbeat timeout value for activities.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot access the heartbeat timeout value during activity execution, limiting visibility into timeout configurations.
cards.rootCause: The heartbeatTimeoutMs property is not being populated in the Context info object.
cards.resolutionDetails: The property was added to the Context info object in the SDK.
cards.keyQuote: Context.current().info.heartbeatTimeoutMs is undefined

cards.summary: Forward metrics from Core SDK to TypeScript SDK to enable custom metrics handling, filtering, and export to external collectors. This requires implementing support for accepting and handling metrics from Core.
cards.userImpact: Enables users to customize metrics handling, filter metrics for cost reduction, and export to unsupported external collectors.
cards.proposedFix: Implement TypeScript SDK support for Core's metrics export API, with separate interfaces for custom collector implementation and metric emission on existing collectors.
cards.keyQuote: expose both the ability to impl a custom collector _and_ to emit metrics on the existing one as separate unrelated things

cards.summary: Worker fails with "Automatic publicPath is not supported in this browser" error when running compiled JavaScript via node, but works with ts-node. Root cause identified as third-party packages importing browser-specific modules into the workflow bundle.
cards.userImpact: Workers fail to activate workflows in production Node.js environments when the workflow bundle contains browser-targeting dependencies.
cards.rootCause: Third-party packages (e.g., @supabase/supabase-js) importing browser-specific modules that use Webpack's automatic publicPath feature, which is incompatible with Node.js VM execution context.
cards.proposedFix: Use bundlerOptions.ignoreModules to exclude problematic packages from the workflow bundle.
cards.workaround: Run workers with ts-node instead of compiled JavaScript, or exclude the offending NPM package using ignoreModules configuration.
cards.resolutionDetails: Issue determined to be caused by user's workflow importing incompatible third-party packages. SDK behavior is correct; users must review and filter their workflow imports.
cards.keyQuote: Your Workflow code is somehow importing an NPM package that uses Webpack's automatic publicPath feature. That feature only makes sense in a web app

cards.summary: TypeScript SDK should drop signals with unparseable payloads instead of failing, matching behavior in Go and Java SDKs. This prevents runtime errors when signal arguments cannot be deserialized.
cards.userImpact: Currently, signals with unparseable payloads cause failures in the TypeScript SDK, whereas Go and Java SDKs gracefully drop them.
cards.rootCause: TypeScript SDK does not implement signal payload deserialization failure handling that exists in Go and Java implementations.
cards.proposedFix: Implement signal dropping behavior for failed payload deserialization to match Go and Java SDK behavior.
cards.keyQuote: In Go and Java we drop signals whose args can't be deserialized, we should here too.

cards.summary: Feature request for out-of-the-box Sentry integration to simplify error logging in TypeScript SDK activities. Currently requires implementing a custom ActivityInboundCallsInterceptor.
cards.userImpact: Users must implement custom ActivityInboundCallsInterceptor to integrate Sentry, reducing ease of error tracking setup.
cards.proposedFix: Implement a Sentry integration module within the SDK that simplifies error logging to Sentry.
cards.workaround: Users can implement a custom ActivityInboundCallsInterceptor or register a custom logger to achieve Sentry integration.
cards.resolutionDetails: Team decided not to provide out-of-the-box Sentry support, as users can easily implement this themselves using custom logger registration.
cards.keyQuote: We have no plan to add out-of-the-box support for Sentry in the foreseeable future, and users can easily do that themselves by registering a custom logger.

cards.summary: The ProtobufJSONPayloadConverter cannot handle binary protobuf fields because it requires Node.js Buffer class which is not accessible in workflow context. This prevents workflows from encoding/decoding protobufs with binary data using this converter.
cards.userImpact: Workflows cannot serialize or deserialize Protocol Buffer messages containing binary fields when using the ProtobufJSONPayloadConverter.
cards.rootCause: The proto3-json-serializer library requires Node.js Buffer class for binary field encoding/decoding, but Buffer is not available in the workflow execution context.
cards.resolutionDetails: Issue was closed, indicating a fix was implemented to provide Buffer access or alternative binary handling in workflow context.
cards.keyQuote: workflows cannot encode/decode protobufs that contain binary data by using this converter

cards.summary: Transitive dependency vulnerability in semver (CVE-2022-25883) affecting the test coverage library. A Regular Expression Denial of Service (ReDoS) vulnerability was identified in semver-7.5.0 with a CVSS score of 7.5.
cards.userImpact: Users' applications are potentially vulnerable to ReDoS attacks through untrusted semver range input in test dependencies.
cards.rootCause: semver versions before 7.5.2 contain a ReDoS vulnerability in the Range function when processing untrusted user data.
cards.proposedFix: Upgrade semver to version 7.5.2 or later.
cards.resolutionDetails: Issue was automatically closed by Mend as the vulnerable library was either marked as ignored or no longer part of inventory.
cards.keyQuote: Versions of the package semver before 7.5.2 are vulnerable to Regular Expression Denial of Service (ReDoS) via the function new Range

cards.summary: Critical prototype pollution vulnerability (CVE-2023-36665) in protobufjs 7.2.3 transitive dependency with CVSS score of 9.8. Vulnerability allows attackers to pollute Object.prototype through untrusted protobuf message processing.
cards.userImpact: Applications using the SDK are vulnerable to prototype pollution attacks that could lead to arbitrary code execution or data manipulation through specially crafted protobuf messages.
cards.rootCause: protobufjs versions 6.10.0 through 7.2.3 allow prototype pollution via Object.constructor.prototype manipulation when parsing untrusted protobuf messages or loading external .proto files.
cards.proposedFix: Upgrade protobufjs to version 7.2.4 or later to patch CVE-2023-36665.
cards.resolutionDetails: Issue was autoclosed by Mend after the vulnerable library was either marked as ignored or removed from the Mend inventory, indicating the vulnerability was addressed.
cards.keyQuote: protobuf.js (aka protobufjs) 6.10.0 through 7.x before 7.2.4 allows Prototype Pollution...A user-controlled protobuf message can be used by an attacker to pollute the prototype of Object.prototype

cards.summary: Prototype pollution vulnerability (CVE-2023-36665) in protobufjs transitive dependency with CVSS 5.5 score. The issue was automatically closed as the vulnerable library was no longer part of the inventory.
cards.userImpact: Applications using client-1.8.0 may be vulnerable to prototype pollution attacks through protobufjs, potentially affecting availability.
cards.rootCause: protobufjs versions 6.10.0 through 7.2.3 allow prototype pollution via untrusted protobuf messages or .proto files, enabling attackers to modify Object.prototype.
cards.proposedFix: Upgrade protobufjs to version 7.2.4 or later
cards.resolutionDetails: Automatically closed by Mend because the vulnerable library was no longer part of the inventory or was marked as ignored
cards.keyQuote: protobufjs 6.10.0 through 7.x before 7.2.4 allows Prototype Pollution via user-controlled protobuf messages

cards.summary: Transitive dependency vulnerability in semver (CVE-2022-25883) detected in nyc test coverage package, causing a Regular Expression Denial of Service (ReDoS) vulnerability. Issue was automatically closed when the vulnerable library was removed from the inventory.
cards.userImpact: Users could be affected by a denial of service vulnerability in the test coverage tool if untrusted semver range data is processed.
cards.rootCause: semver versions before 7.5.2 contain a Regular Expression Denial of Service vulnerability in the Range function when processing untrusted input.
cards.proposedFix: Upgrade semver to version 7.5.2 or later.
cards.resolutionDetails: Issue was automatically closed by Mend when the vulnerable library was removed from the project inventory or marked as ignored.
cards.keyQuote: Versions of the package semver before 7.5.2 are vulnerable to Regular Expression Denial of Service (ReDoS) via the function new Range

cards.summary: Request to add workflow update support to the TypeScript SDK, allowing workflows to be updated without losing state.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot update workflow code without losing in-flight workflow state, limiting deployment flexibility.
cards.resolutionDetails: Workflow update support was implemented in the TypeScript SDK

cards.summary: A ReDoS vulnerability (CVE-2022-25883) was detected in the semver dependency (version 7.5.0) used transitively through ts-loader. The issue was automatically closed as the vulnerable library is no longer part of the inventory.
cards.userImpact: Users could experience denial of service if untrusted user data is provided as a semver range, potentially affecting availability.
cards.rootCause: Regular Expression Denial of Service (ReDoS) in semver package versions before 7.5.2 when processing untrusted range data.
cards.proposedFix: Upgrade semver to version 7.5.2 or later.
cards.resolutionDetails: Issue was automatically closed by Mend as the vulnerable library was marked as ignored or removed from the Mend inventory.
cards.keyQuote: Versions of the package semver before 7.5.2 are vulnerable to Regular Expression Denial of Service (ReDoS) via the function new Range

cards.summary: User asks how to cache data (like authentication headers) between multiple interceptors in the workflow context, similar to thread-local storage in Java. The issue involves using local activities in interceptors to authenticate values and pass them to other interceptors.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot easily share cached data like authentication headers across multiple interceptors in workflow context, requiring workarounds or complex context management.
cards.rootCause: AsyncLocalStorage from @temporalio/workflow may not work properly when instantiated outside the standard SDK patterns, causing errors when used across multiple interceptors.
cards.proposedFix: SDK could provide built-in support for context-local caching in interceptors, or clarify the proper pattern for sharing state across interceptors similar to Java's thread-local storage.
cards.workaround: Copy and export a custom ContextManager instance based on SDK's internal context-manager.ts, using AsyncLocalStorage from @temporalio/workflow to manage context.
cards.resolutionDetails: Discussion indicates continuation-local-storage is outdated and AsyncLocalStorage has limitations in workflow context. Users are directed to implement custom solutions based on SDK patterns.
cards.keyQuote: continuation-local-storage is outdated so I would not use it at all and in any case it will not work from the workflow context.

cards.summary: Client.schedule.create() returns incorrect 'Schedule not found' error when using a non-existent namespace, instead of reporting that the namespace itself doesn't exist. Similar error handling issues likely affect other ScheduleClient and WorkflowClient methods.
cards.userImpact: Users receive misleading error messages when configuring clients with incorrect namespaces, making it harder to diagnose configuration issues.
cards.rootCause: Error handling in ScheduleClient likely masks underlying namespace-not-found errors with generic schedule-not-found responses
cards.proposedFix: See issue #976 and its comments for suggested error handling fix approach
cards.resolutionDetails: Issue was resolved through error handling improvements referenced in #976
cards.keyQuote: trying to create a new schedule results in a "Schedule not found" exception, rather than something like "Namespace not found"

cards.summary: Jest doesn't work well with the existing @temporalio/nyc-test-coverage package for capturing workflow test coverage data due to Jest's deep integration with Node internals and custom code transformers. A new approach is needed to support Jest alongside the existing Mocha and AVA support.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot reliably capture workflow test coverage data when using Jest, forcing them to switch testing frameworks or use unreliable workarounds.
cards.rootCause: Jest heavily hooks into Node internals and adds its own source code transformers that cannot be injected into the webpack-based workflow bundler, making it impossible for the nyc-test-coverage module to detect and match Jest's transformation pipeline.
cards.proposedFix: Design a new approach to support test coverage capture in workflow context with Jest, potentially by customizing the workflow bundler's Webpack configuration to match Jest's transformation pipeline or using pre-transformation CLI commands.
cards.workaround: Run Jest on pre-compiled JS files (transpile with tsc first), apply transformations via CLI before tests, avoid importing workflow files in tests, or customize the workflow bundler's Webpack configuration to match Jest's pipeline.
cards.keyQuote: Jest heavily hooks into Node's internals, making it very difficult to detect these code transformers at runtime; more over, Jest itself sometime add source code transformers, which can't be injected into our webpack-based Workflow bundler.

cards.summary: Payload converters in the workflow context return objects (like Uint8Array) that use constructors from the node context, breaking instanceof checks and third-party libraries. Additionally, some converters rely on the Buffer class which is not visible in the workflow context.
cards.userImpact: Third-party libraries that rely on instanceof checks for Uint8Array and similar types fail when using binary and protobuf payload converters.
cards.rootCause: Payload converters execute in the workflow context but return objects constructed with node context constructors, causing type identity mismatches. Some converters depend on the Buffer class which is not available in the workflow context.
cards.resolutionDetails: Issue was resolved by addressing the context isolation problem in payload converters.
cards.keyQuote: Payload converters run in the workflow context but sometimes return objects, e.g., Uint8Array, that use constructors defined in the node context.

cards.summary: Transitive dependency vulnerability in semver 7.5.0 (ReDoS) found via nyc-test-coverage dependency chain. The issue was automatically resolved when the vulnerable library was removed from the inventory.
cards.userImpact: Potential denial of service attack via malformed semantic version ranges if untrusted user data reaches the semver parser.
cards.rootCause: Versions of semver before 7.5.2 contain a ReDoS vulnerability in the Range function when processing untrusted user input.
cards.proposedFix: Upgrade semver dependency to version 7.5.2 or later.
cards.resolutionDetails: Automatic closure by Mend when the vulnerable library was removed from the dependency tree or marked as ignored.
cards.keyQuote: Versions of the package semver before 7.5.2 are vulnerable to Regular Expression Denial of Service (ReDoS) via the function new Range

cards.summary: Feature request to allow TemporalFailure instances from converters and codecs to fail the entire workflow, not just individual tasks. Currently, failures in these components only fail the task, but users need the ability to propagate critical failures to the workflow level.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot fail an entire workflow when converters or codecs encounter critical errors, limiting error handling flexibility.

cards.summary: User asks how to implement authorization in a workflow inbound interceptor that validates headers via a remote authentication service in different environments, given that the 'process' API is forbidden in workflow interceptors for determinism.
cards.userImpact: Users need guidance on securely implementing authentication workflows when external service URLs differ by environment while maintaining workflow determinism.
cards.rootCause: Workflow inbound interceptors restrict process API access for determinism, preventing direct environment variable access or external service calls needed for dynamic authentication.
cards.proposedFix: Use local activities to access environment variables and call the authentication service from within the workflow, with careful header encoding to prevent history pollution and replay attacks.
cards.workaround: Encode authentication headers before workflow start and decode in a local activity; embed workflow execution details (ID, checksum, timestamp) in the header to prevent replay.
cards.resolutionDetails: Community member provided detailed guidance on using local activities for authentication, explaining the trade-offs between local and regular activities, and recommending header encoding strategies.
cards.keyQuote: One possibility would be to call a local activity from your Workflow inbound interceptor. From that activity, you will be able to access environment variables and make calls to your external auth service.

cards.summary: A bug in the unionfs dependency caused a company-wide outage for users of @temporalio/worker due to an unpinned transitive dependency. The discussion explores whether pinning dependencies is the right approach to prevent similar issues.
cards.userImpact: Users experienced production outages when indirect dependencies introduced breaking changes, making the SDK unusable.
cards.rootCause: Unpinned transitive dependency (unionfs ^4.4.0) allowed broken releases to be installed, causing module resolution failures.
cards.proposedFix: Consider pinning all direct dependencies to exact versions, though this may not prevent transitive dependency issues; alternatively, users can vendor the SDK using package-lock.json.
cards.workaround: Users can vendor the Temporal SDK and its dependencies locally by pointing to packages in a local directory, or use package-lock.json to lock transitive dependencies.
cards.resolutionDetails: Determined that pinning dependencies would cause more harm than benefit to the community. Recommended solution is for users to vendor the SDK if they need strict dependency control.
cards.keyQuote: This sdk is a core piece of infrastructure and should not suddenly break when indirect dependencies are updated.

cards.summary: User expects activity errors to be caught in workflow try-catch blocks, but Temporal automatically retries failed activities instead. The user wants to decide retry policy at the workflow level rather than in the activity itself.
cards.userImpact: Users confused about activity failure behavior may implement incorrect error handling patterns, expecting standard JavaScript promise rejection behavior.
cards.rootCause: Temporal activities are retried indefinitely by default unless they throw non-retryable errors, which differs from standard JavaScript promise behavior and can be counterintuitive.
cards.proposedFix: Use ApplicationFailure.create({ message: 'foo', nonRetryable: true }) to throw non-retryable errors from activities, allowing workflow-level control over retry decisions.
cards.workaround: Throw ApplicationFailure with nonRetryable flag set to true from the activity to prevent automatic retries and allow workflow-level exception handling.
cards.resolutionDetails: This is expected Temporal behavior, not a bug. Users should throw non-retryable ApplicationFailure from activities if they want workflow-level retry control.
cards.keyQuote: Activities are retired indefinitely by default unless they throw an error that's specified in the non retryable types in the retry policy

cards.summary: TypeScript compilation fails in projects created with `npx @temporalio/create` on Node 20 because the `es2023` library definitions are not available in the pinned TypeScript 4.x version. The create tool updates `@tsconfig/node16` to `@tsconfig/node20`, which references `es2023`, but the project still uses TypeScript 4.x which doesn't support that library.
cards.userImpact: New users following the official documentation cannot successfully create and run projects on Node 20 without manual fixes.
cards.rootCause: The create-project tool automatically updates @tsconfig/nodeXX based on the user's Node version, but the pinned TypeScript version (4.x) doesn't support the es2023 library definitions that node20 tsconfig requires.
cards.proposedFix: Either bump TypeScript version to 5.x in all samples, or stop automatically updating @tsconfig/nodeXX and use a version-agnostic config instead.
cards.workaround: Manually downgrade @tsconfig/node20 to @tsconfig/node16 or upgrade TypeScript to 5.x.
cards.resolutionDetails: The issue was fixed by updating TypeScript and related dependencies to version 5.x.
cards.keyQuote: TypeScript compilation fails in an unmodified new project, based on the `child-workflow` sample, because the `es2023` library definitions are not included with the version of TypeScript used in the sample project

cards.summary: Add `upsertMemo` command to the TypeScript Workflow API. The underlying support already exists in the Core SDK and just needs to be exposed.
cards.userImpact: Users can update workflow memos directly from the TypeScript SDK without workarounds.
cards.proposedFix: Expose the existing Core SDK upsertMemo support in the TypeScript Workflow API
cards.resolutionDetails: Feature implemented and exposed in the Workflow API
cards.keyQuote: Underlying support already exists in Core SDK.

cards.summary: Temporal TypeScript worker fails to start when workflow code imports classes or libraries with non-deterministic dependencies like NestJS. The workflow bundler cannot include modules with I/O, network calls, or environment variable access due to sandbox constraints.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot use common utility classes or NestJS-integrated code in workflows, preventing normal development patterns.
cards.rootCause: Workflow code transitively imports @nestjs/core through DTO classes, which contains non-deterministic operations that violate the workflow sandbox's determinism requirements.
cards.proposedFix: Separate workflow-safe DTO definitions from NestJS dependencies; use type-only imports; or add problematic modules to ignoredModules option.
cards.workaround: Avoid instantiating classes in workflows; use plain objects instead; use 'import type' for type definitions only; exclude non-deterministic modules via WorkflowBundlingOptions.ignoredModules.
cards.resolutionDetails: The behavior is by design - workflows must be deterministic and cannot execute non-deterministic code. Users must restructure code to isolate workflow logic from external dependencies.
cards.keyQuote: That doesn't mean you can't use NestJS in your project, but simply that your Workflow code may not pull anything that relates to NestJS, not even transitively.

cards.summary: The @temporalio/create scaffolding tool generates a hello-world project with TypeScript ^4.4.2, but this version is incompatible with tsconfig/node20 which requires TypeScript >= 5 due to es2023 lib configuration.
cards.userImpact: Users following the getting started guide cannot build the generated hello-world project on Node 20.
cards.rootCause: TypeScript 4.4.2 does not support es2023 in the lib configuration, which is required by tsconfig/node20.
cards.resolutionDetails: Closed in favor of issue #1125 which tracks Node 20 support.
cards.keyQuote: Project fails to build. The created hello-world project is configured to use TypeScript ^4.4.2 but this is incompatible with the supplied version of tsconfig/node20

cards.summary: Workflow tasks fail with unspecified cause when activities started in parallel lack proper error handling, causing the workflow to remain in running state instead of failing properly and preventing catch blocks from executing.
cards.userImpact: Users encounter confusing workflow failures with unspecified causes when running parallel activities without proper error handling, requiring workarounds to manually catch and propagate errors.
cards.rootCause: Activities started in parallel without await result in promises without proper error handling, causing unhandled rejections that manifest as WorkflowTaskFailed with unspecified cause instead of proper workflow failure.
cards.proposedFix: Make unhandled rejection clearer to users to reduce confusion around error handling in parallel activity execution.
cards.workaround: Add catch blocks to each activity promise, save errors, and manually check for errors in the main workflow function before throwing an ApplicationFailure.
cards.resolutionDetails: Marked as duplicate of issue #1039; root cause identified as unhandled promise rejections in parallel activity execution requiring explicit error handling.
cards.keyQuote: I managed to solve the problem. The issue was that activities that were started in parallel (without `await`) resulted in promises without proper error handling.

cards.summary: ChildWorkflowHandle lacks a `.cancel()` method despite JSDoc claiming it can cancel workflow execution. Users must work around this limitation when needing to cancel child workflows created with `startChild()`.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot cancel child workflows using the expected `.cancel()` method, forcing them to find alternative approaches or workarounds.
cards.rootCause: The ChildWorkflowHandle type definition does not include the cancel() method implementation, despite the JSDoc documentation claiming this capability.
cards.resolutionDetails: Tracking issue #740 created to address the missing cancel() method on ChildWorkflowHandle.
cards.keyQuote: there is no `cancel()` method on the `ChildWorkflowHandle` like there is for a `WorkflowHandle<T>`

cards.summary: Create a `@temporalio/doctor` CLI tool that can be executed via `npx` to diagnose and fix common configuration issues in Temporal TypeScript SDK projects, such as version mismatches, unexpected package hoisting, deprecated dependencies, and known bugs.
cards.userImpact: Users struggling with configuration issues would be able to quickly diagnose and fix common problems with their Temporal SDK setup.
cards.proposedFix: Develop a @temporalio/doctor CLI program that can scan package.json, lock files, and node_modules directories to detect version mismatches, hoisting issues, deprecated packages, and known bugs, while also providing functionality to update/set version numbers on all @temporalio/* dependencies.
cards.keyQuote: We could develop a `@temporalio/doctor` CLI program, meant to be executed using `npx` or similar, that provides various commands to diagnose and fix some common configuration issues

cards.summary: The Workflow Bundler does not prevent usage of the `process` global variable in workflow code, which is not available in the workflow sandbox environment, causing ReferenceError at execution time. The issue requires implementing a custom Webpack target that matches the sandbox's capabilities while maintaining compatibility with external libraries using conditional package.json exports.
cards.userImpact: Developers can write workflow code that compiles successfully but fails at runtime with ReferenceError when the bundler does not catch usage of unavailable globals like `process`.
cards.rootCause: Webpack defaults to 'web' target which does not forbid 'process' global usage, but the workflow sandbox environment does not provide this global. Setting target to 'false' would match the sandbox but breaks libraries with conditional package.json exports.
cards.proposedFix: Define a custom Webpack target that closely matches the workflow sandbox environment and enables 'browser' conditional exports to maintain compatibility with external libraries.
cards.keyQuote: Setting target to `false` would be closest to the sandbox, but breaks libraries using conditional package.json exports. A custom Webpack target matching the sandbox with browser conditionals is the most appropriate solution.

cards.summary: npm install fails in Docker when building with TypeScript SDK 1.7.3 due to missing prebuilt binaries for the core-bridge native module, requiring Rust/Cargo to compile from source.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot build Docker containers with the TypeScript SDK 1.7.3 unless Rust/Cargo is installed in the image.
cards.rootCause: The 1.7.3 release was published without prebuilt binaries for the @temporalio/core-bridge native module, forcing npm install to attempt compilation with cargo.
cards.workaround: Lock the SDK version to 1.7.2 in package.json until 1.7.4 is released with prebuilt binaries.
cards.resolutionDetails: Version 1.7.4 was published with prebuilt binaries included, resolving the compilation requirement.
cards.keyQuote: I just published 1.7.4 that includes the prebuilt binaries.

cards.summary: Feature request to allow importing Node's built-in `buffer` module in workflows. Currently all builtin modules are blocked; user needs buffer for domain type conversion logic and believes it's deterministic and safe.
cards.userImpact: Users who need Node's buffer module for domain type conversion in workflows are blocked and must find workarounds.
cards.rootCause: All builtin modules are disallowed to maintain determinism and support multi-runtime compatibility (Deno, browser, etc).
cards.proposedFix: Provide an exemption for buffer module similar to the existing exemption for assert, or allow users to load polyfills from Webpack bundler.
cards.workaround: Load appropriate polyfills from Webpack bundler instead of using Node's native buffer.
cards.resolutionDetails: Team decided not to support Node's Buffer API out-of-the-box to maintain compatibility with other JavaScript runtimes (Deno, browser). Users should use polyfills instead.
cards.keyQuote: It's preferable not to provide out-of-the-box support for Node's Buffer API...we encourage users to load appropriate polyfills from their Webpack bundler.

cards.summary: CalendarSpec components for hour and dayOfMonth are encoded with incorrect validation ranges, rejecting valid values. Hour field accepts 0-59 instead of 0-23, and dayOfMonth accepts 0-6 instead of 1-31.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot create temporal schedules with valid calendar specifications, as legitimate dayOfMonth and hour values are rejected with validation errors.
cards.rootCause: Validation range checks in makeCalendarSpecFieldCoders use incorrect upper bounds: hour field checks x <= 59 instead of x <= 23, and dayOfMonth field checks x <= 6 instead of x <= 31.
cards.proposedFix: Change hour validation from (x >= 0 && x <= 59) to (x >= 0 && x <= 23) and dayOfMonth validation from (x >= 0 && x <= 6) to (x >= 0 && x <= 31).
cards.workaround: Patch node_modules/@temporalio/client/src/schedule-helpers.ts with the provided diff to correct the validation ranges.
cards.resolutionDetails: Issue was fixed by correcting the validation range checks for hour (0-23) and dayOfMonth (1-31) fields in schedule-helpers.ts
cards.keyQuote: Error: Invalid CalendarSpec component for field dayOfMonth: '21' of type 'number'

cards.summary: Workflow worker hangs when starting on NodeJS 18.14.2 in production Linux containers, but works fine on NodeJS 16.17.0. Investigation revealed the root cause was incorrectly configured Node heap options.
cards.userImpact: Users experience workflow worker hangs in production, requiring manual intervention or environment downgrade to resolve.
cards.rootCause: Incorrectly configured Node heap options causing worker thread creation to hang on NodeJS 18.14.2
cards.workaround: Downgrade to NodeJS 16.17.0 or reconfigure Node heap options correctly
cards.resolutionDetails: Issue was resolved by correcting the Node heap configuration, allowing worker to start properly on NodeJS 18.14.2
cards.keyQuote: Investigation revealed that issue was caused by incorrectly configured Node heap options

cards.summary: Duplicate name error occurs when @temporalio/worker and @temporalio/testing are both installed, causing a protobufjs namespace conflict with the ActivityHeartbeat type in the coresdk namespace.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot use @temporalio/testing with @temporalio/worker due to protobuf namespace conflicts preventing tests from running.
cards.rootCause: Different versions of @temporalio/proto in worker and testing packages contain duplicate protobuf definitions that conflict when loaded simultaneously.
cards.proposedFix: Ensure all @temporalio/* packages use the same version
cards.workaround: Use matching versions across all @temporalio packages
cards.resolutionDetails: User confirmed that using the same version of all @temporalio packages resolved the duplicate name error.
cards.keyQuote: Please use the same version of of the `@temporalio/*` packages, it should prevent this from happening.

cards.summary: Webpack stats are being automatically logged with color codes and multiline formatting, making logs difficult to read in third-party logging systems and wasting money on per-line charges. User requests the ability to configure or disable these stats via Webpack's existing stats configuration.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot control Webpack stats logging, leading to cluttered logs with color codes and multiline output that increases costs in pay-per-line logging systems.
cards.rootCause: The SDK hardcodes Webpack stats configuration in bundler.ts without providing user control over the stats output.
cards.proposedFix: Allow stats to be controlled via Webpack's existing stats configuration options, similar to how webpackConfigHook works.
cards.workaround: Pass a custom logger to bundleWorkflowCode to replace the default logging behavior.
cards.resolutionDetails: Issue was resolved by allowing users to control logging through a custom logger parameter in bundleWorkflowCode.
cards.keyQuote: Allow stats to be controlled via Webpack's existing stats configuration. At a minimum, document the fact that these log lines cannot be toggled.

cards.summary: The `workflowId` field in `ScheduleUpdateOptions.action` should be optional, matching the behavior in `ScheduleOptionsStartWorkflowAction` where it is already optional.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot update schedules without providing a workflowId even when it should remain unchanged, creating unnecessary friction in the API.
cards.rootCause: Type definition inconsistency between ScheduleOptionsStartWorkflowAction and ScheduleUpdateOptions.action
cards.proposedFix: Make workflowId optional in ScheduleUpdateOptions.action to match ScheduleOptionsStartWorkflowAction
cards.resolutionDetails: workflowId was made optional in ScheduleUpdateOptions.action
cards.keyQuote: Right now it's optional in `ScheduleOptionsStartWorkflowAction` but not in `ScheduleUpdateOptions`

cards.summary: Request to expose URL and URLSearchParams APIs to the workflow sandbox. These are deterministic APIs available in all major JS runtimes and would enable more flexible URL handling within workflows.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot use URL and URLSearchParams APIs within workflows, limiting their ability to parse and manipulate URLs in a deterministic manner.
cards.resolutionDetails: Duplicate of issue #981
cards.keyQuote: Both APIs are available in every major JS runtime and are deterministic.

cards.summary: The create-project CLI tool fails to update tsconfig.json and package.json files correctly when creating projects with subdirectories (like monorepo examples) on Node 18. The tool doesn't properly replace Node version references in nested directory structures.
cards.userImpact: Users creating monorepo projects with the CLI tool get misconfigured tsconfig and package.json files, requiring manual fixes.
cards.rootCause: The CLI tool's file replacement logic does not account for or traverse subdirectories when searching for and updating configuration files.
cards.keyQuote: If you create a sample project with node 18 that has subdirectory packages, like the monorepo example, it doesn't update tsconfig or package.json files properly.

cards.summary: User encountered 'too many filter conditions specified' error when querying active workflows using WorkflowClient.list() with a two-condition filter, while the same query works with direct gRPC calls to listWorkflowExecutions(). The issue was identified as a server limitation related to visibility database configuration, not an SDK bug.
cards.userImpact: Users attempting to query workflows with reasonable filter conditions receive a server error and cannot list filtered workflow executions through the client API.
cards.rootCause: Server-side limitation: the visibility database (Cassandra/ScyllaDB without ElasticSearch) does not support the enhanced visibility queries that the SDK attempts to construct.
cards.workaround: Use the direct gRPC connection's listWorkflowExecutions() method instead of WorkflowClient.list(). Alternatively, enable ElasticSearch as the visibility database to support enhanced queries.
cards.resolutionDetails: Closed as not planned - determined to be a server configuration issue rather than an SDK bug. User's persistence layer (Cassandra/ScyllaDB) does not support enhanced visibility without ElasticSearch.
cards.keyQuote: It's not an SDK bug, it's a server limitation.

cards.summary: User reports that `instanceof` checks fail for ActivityError in workflows, even though the activity returns the error object. The error type checking only works when performed inside the activity before returning.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot reliably use instanceof to check for activity errors in workflows, forcing them to implement workarounds or move type checking into activities.
cards.rootCause: Activity errors are wrapped on the workflow side, so instanceof checks against the original error type fail because the error is wrapped in ActivityFailure/ApplicationFailure.
cards.workaround: Catch ActivityFailure with cause set to ApplicationFailure and check the type property instead of using instanceof.
cards.resolutionDetails: Not a bug but expected behavior - activity errors are wrapped in ActivityFailure/ApplicationFailure on the workflow side. Users should follow the documented pattern for handling activity failures.
cards.keyQuote: Activity errors are wrapped on the workflow side. You should be able to catch an ActivityFailure with cause set to ApplicationFailure with the type of the original exception thrown in the activity.

cards.summary: Proposal for a built-in query mechanism to track which handlers (queries and signals) are currently registered in a workflow, enabling clients to determine which operations are legal to send at any given moment.
cards.userImpact: Allows developers to discover available handlers at runtime and implement dynamic UX that only permits currently legal operations without manual tracking.
cards.proposedFix: Implement a built-in metadata query that returns currently registered handlers, potentially as a cross-SDK feature using protobuf definitions in the temporal/api repository.
