cards.proposedFix: Patch Runtime to only add listener to process signal when there is a callback registered, or add a listener that always exits for development scenarios.
cards.workaround: Manually manage process signal listeners or use development tooling workarounds to ensure workers properly terminate.
cards.resolutionDetails: Issue was resolved by improving signal handling in the Runtime to properly register and manage shutdown signal callbacks.
cards.keyQuote: When a listener to a process signal is added, the signal no longer causes the default behavior, so the signal is ignored.

cards.summary: The `npx @temporalio/create@latest` command fails with a 'DownloadError: Premature close' error when using Node 18. The issue is related to a known problem with the npm node-tar package and is resolved by clearing the npx cache.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot create new Temporal TypeScript projects using the standard initialization command on Node 18.
cards.rootCause: npm node-tar package issue causing premature close during file downloads; npx maintains a separate cache that can become corrupted.
cards.workaround: Clear the npx cache using `npx clear-npx-cache` before running the create command.
cards.resolutionDetails: Issue was resolved by clearing the npx cache, which resolves the corrupted tar extraction state.
cards.keyQuote: Fixed by `npx clear-npx-cache` (npx has a separate cache).

cards.summary: Dependency vulnerability in ajv 5.5.2 (transitive dependency) with CVSS score 5.6 allows prototype pollution through crafted JSON schemas. Issue was automatically closed after the vulnerable library was removed or ignored.
cards.userImpact: Users may be at risk if untrusted JSON schemas are validated using the vulnerable ajv library version.
cards.rootCause: Ajv 5.5.2 is vulnerable to prototype pollution attacks through carefully crafted JSON schemas in the validate() function.
cards.proposedFix: Upgrade ajv to version 6.12.3 or later
cards.resolutionDetails: The vulnerable library was removed from the Mend inventory or marked as ignored in the project dependencies.
cards.keyQuote: A carefully crafted JSON schema could be provided that allows execution of other code by prototype pollution.

cards.summary: Installing an older version of @temporalio/worker pulls in the latest minor version of @temporalio/common due to caret (^) version constraints, causing breaking changes. Version 1.3.0 fails when @temporalio/common 1.4.0 unexports the errorMessage function.
cards.userImpact: Users installing specific older versions of the SDK encounter runtime errors due to incompatible dependency versions being automatically pulled in.
cards.rootCause: Package dependencies use caret (^) version constraints allowing minor version updates, but breaking changes were introduced in minor releases without proper version pinning.
cards.proposedFix: Pin exact versions of Temporal SDK dependencies across all packages instead of using caret constraints.
cards.resolutionDetails: Fixed in version 1.3.1 by switching to tilde (~) constraints for patch-only updates. Issue remained in 1.4.x versions which continued using caret constraints.
cards.keyQuote: Since @temporalio/workflow depends on "@temporalio/common": "^1.3.0" instead of "@temporalio/common": "1.3.0", it installs the latest minor version.

cards.summary: Webpack bundling errors in the TypeScript SDK worker produce an opaque error message that doesn't help users diagnose the actual problem. Request to include more detailed error information from Webpack in the error output.
cards.userImpact: Users encounter vague Webpack errors that don't indicate the root cause, forcing them to dig into Webpack internals or troubleshooting docs without actionable guidance.
cards.rootCause: Webpack errors are caught and re-thrown with a generic message that hides the actual compilation errors from webpack output.
cards.proposedFix: Include webpack compilation error details in the Temporal error message so users can understand what went wrong without manual investigation.
cards.resolutionDetails: Error messages were enhanced to include detailed webpack compilation errors.
cards.keyQuote: if you're unsure what went wrong, visit our troubleshooting page at https://docs.temporal.io/typescript/troubleshooting#webpack-errors

cards.summary: Transitive dependency vulnerability in ajv 5.5.2 (CVE-2020-15366) affecting the nyc-test-coverage package. A specially crafted JSON schema could enable code execution through prototype pollution in Ajv's validate() function.
cards.userImpact: Users may be exposed to code execution risk if untrusted JSON schemas are validated using the affected transitive dependency.
cards.rootCause: Prototype pollution vulnerability in ajv 5.5.2 allows arbitrary code execution when processing specially crafted JSON schemas.
cards.proposedFix: Upgrade ajv to version 6.12.3 or later
cards.resolutionDetails: The vulnerable library was removed from the Mend inventory or marked as ignored in the specific branch, resolving the security concern.
cards.keyQuote: A carefully crafted JSON schema could be provided that allows execution of other code by prototype pollution.

cards.summary: TypeScript SDK has multiple deprecated npm dependencies causing warnings during installation. Includes outdated packages like source-map tools, uuid v3, request, and core-js v2 that need upgrades.
cards.userImpact: Users see numerous npm warnings during installation, creating noise and potential security concerns from using outdated packages.
cards.rootCause: Dependencies have not been updated to their latest versions; transitive dependencies include packages no longer actively maintained or recommended.
cards.proposedFix: Upgrade all deprecated dependencies to their current versions, particularly fsevents (v2), chokidar (v3), uuid (v7+), and replace request with alternatives.
cards.resolutionDetails: Dependencies were pruned and updated as part of issue #1330.
cards.keyQuote: Pruned all dependencies as part of #1330.

cards.summary: Users receive a confusing warning message when running Worker.runReplayHistory without activities registered, making them think something is wrong. The request is to suppress this warning during replay history operations since it's expected behavior.
cards.userImpact: Users are confused by warning messages during normal replay operations, leading them to believe there's a problem when there isn't one.
cards.proposedFix: Suppress the 'No activities registered' warning when Worker.runReplayHistory is active
cards.resolutionDetails: Warning was suppressed or modified to not appear during replay history operations
cards.keyQuote: Users see this in output and think something is wrong: [WARN] No activities registered, not polling for activity tasks

cards.summary: Documentation search index was returning a deprecated `workflowClient` interface reference that led to a 404 page. The interface was replaced with `TestWorkflowEnvironment.workflowClient` but the search index hadn't been updated.
cards.userImpact: Users following search results encounter 404 errors when trying to access deprecated API documentation.
cards.rootCause: Documentation indexing delay - the search index included references to deprecated APIs that were replaced but not yet reflected in the index.
cards.proposedFix: Either remove deprecated entries from search index or implement redirects from old API references to their replacements.
cards.resolutionDetails: Issue was resolved by waiting for the next manual documentation index rebuild which removed the stale references.
cards.keyQuote: Indexing is once/week or manual. Last one was 3h ago, and this issue was fixed.

cards.summary: Version 1.3.0 of @temporalio/protos has a duplicate const declaration for 'Long' that causes build failures. This was caused by protobufjs recently adding the 'long' import, but the Temporal generation script was already compensating for its absence.
cards.userImpact: Users upgrading to @temporalio/client 1.3.0 experience build failures in their applications until they downgrade to 1.1.0 or upgrade to 1.4.0.
cards.rootCause: The proto generation script was compensating for the fact that protobufjs's pbts tool didn't add the 'long' import. When protobufjs fixed this and started adding the import, the script's compensation caused a duplicate 'Long' identifier.
cards.proposedFix: Remove the manual 'long' import compensation from the proto generation script since protobufjs now handles it correctly.
cards.workaround: Override all @temporalio libraries to version 1.1.0 in package.json.
cards.resolutionDetails: Fixed in version 1.4.0 by updating the proto generation script to remove the duplicate 'Long' identifier compensation.
cards.keyQuote: We were compensating for the fact that `pbts` didn't add the `long` import in our proto generation script and just recently this was fixed

cards.summary: Add support for OpenTelemetry (OTel) temporality configuration in the TypeScript SDK by exposing the temporality configuration from sdk-core PR #402.
cards.userImpact: Users can configure OpenTelemetry temporality settings to control how metrics are aggregated and exported.
cards.proposedFix: Expose the temporality configuration parameter that was implemented in sdk-core PR #402
cards.resolutionDetails: Feature was implemented and merged
cards.keyQuote: Expose temporality configuration from https://github.com/temporalio/sdk-core/pull/402

cards.summary: Client doesn't retry the 'sticky worker unavailable' error from the server, but should treat it as a retryable server error like other similar errors.
cards.userImpact: Users experience failures when sticky workers become unavailable instead of having the client automatically retry the request.
cards.rootCause: The client's list of retryable server errors does not include the 'UNAVAILABLE: sticky worker unavailable' error code.
cards.proposedFix: Add 'sticky worker unavailable' error to the list of retryable server errors in the gRPC retry logic.
cards.resolutionDetails: Server now handles this error in recent versions; SDK already retries configured retryable server errors.
cards.keyQuote: Error: 14 UNAVAILABLE: sticky worker unavailable, please use original task queue

cards.summary: Error "failed to downcast any" occurs when creating a Worker without passing a required NativeConnection parameter. The error message from the Rust bridge is unclear and lacks context about what input was invalid.
cards.userImpact: Users deploying to Render or similar environments get cryptic error messages when misconfiguring Worker initialization, making it difficult to debug.
cards.rootCause: Missing required NativeConnection parameter passed to Worker.create; the Rust bridge's downcast error doesn't indicate what was wrong or what was expected.
cards.proposedFix: Upgrade downcast error messages in the bridge to include context about what type was expected and what was received. Add input validation to Worker.create and related methods.
cards.workaround: Ensure NativeConnection is properly instantiated and passed to Worker.create as shown in corrected examples.
cards.resolutionDetails: Issue was user error (missing NativeConnection parameter). Commenter suggested the downcast error is fundamentally input validation and that IDEs should catch type errors.
cards.keyQuote: Failed to downcast is input validation, it's a type error. We can add more input validation at worker creation time but I think that's overkill, an IDE should catch this.

cards.summary: WebAssembly memory errors and threading issues when running Temporal SDK TypeScript tests with vitest instead of jest, causing crashes and unhandled rejections. Resolved in version 1.5.0.
cards.userImpact: Users migrating from jest to vitest for testing cannot run tests with multi-threading enabled, requiring them to disable parallelization or stay on jest.
cards.rootCause: Incompatibility between Temporal SDK's native core-bridge module and vitest's threading model for WebAssembly memory isolation across worker threads.
cards.workaround: Disable multi-threading in vitest configuration or continue using jest for testing.
cards.resolutionDetails: Fixed in version 1.5.0, presumably by PR #983. Users confirmed the issue is resolved and can now use vitest.
cards.keyQuote: Apparently resolved as of 1.5.0 (presumably by #983). I can no longer reproduce any of the reported errors.

cards.summary: The test-npm-init workflow on macOS intermittently hangs during the 'Test run a workflow' step, sometimes taking over 2 hours instead of completing in ~9 seconds. The issue was closed after monitoring showed it hadn't occurred recently in tracked CI flakes.
cards.userImpact: CI builds intermittently hang on macOS, blocking development workflows and delaying releases.
cards.resolutionDetails: Issue was not observed in tracked CI flakes for a long time, suggesting it may have been fixed in a recent update or no longer occurs.
cards.keyQuote: We recently started tracking CI flakes in a private document, to help identify and triage recurring CI issues, and there's no trace of anything similar to this one.

cards.summary: Dependency vulnerability in ajv-5.5.2 (CVE-2020-15366) transitively included via istanbul-instrumenter-loader and schema-utils. The vulnerability allows prototype pollution through carefully crafted JSON schemas, though the direct dependency has no available fix.
cards.userImpact: Users are exposed to a prototype pollution vulnerability through a transitive dependency that could potentially lead to code execution if untrusted schemas are processed.
cards.rootCause: ajv-5.5.2 contains CVE-2020-15366 which allows prototype pollution via specially crafted JSON schemas; included transitively through istanbul-instrumenter-loader -> schema-utils -> ajv
cards.proposedFix: Upgrade ajv to version 6.12.3 or later, though this requires upgrading the direct dependencies that use it
cards.resolutionDetails: Issue was automatically closed/reopened by Mend automation; marked as resolved when vulnerable library was removed from inventory or marked as ignored
cards.keyQuote: CVE-2020-15366: A carefully crafted JSON schema could be provided that allows execution of other code by prototype pollution

cards.summary: CVE-2018-16875 vulnerability detected in webpki-0.22.0 transitive dependency through reqwest, causing potential CPU denial of service in X.509 certificate verification. Issue was automatically closed and reopened multiple times as the dependency was toggled in inventory.
cards.userImpact: Users running temporal-sdk-core could be vulnerable to CPU denial of service attacks through crafted X.509 certificate chains.
cards.rootCause: webpki-0.22.0 (transitive dependency via reqwest) contains CVE-2018-16875, which allows CPU exhaustion during X.509 chain verification with pathological inputs.
cards.proposedFix: Upgrade webpki to version 0.22.2 or higher, or use rustls-webpki versions 0.100.2 or 0.101.4.
cards.resolutionDetails: Issue was automatically closed by Mend as the vulnerable library was marked as ignored or removed from inventory, despite the CVSS 7.5 vulnerability persisting.
cards.keyQuote: This issue was automatically closed by Mend because the vulnerable library in the specific branch(es) was either marked as ignored or it is no longer part of the Mend inventory.

cards.summary: Add an ESLint rule to prevent Query handlers from mutating state, which is a gap in TypeScript's enforced determinism. Multiple implementation approaches were explored but the feature was deprioritized due to complexity in handling various code patterns.
cards.userImpact: Without this lint rule, developers can accidentally introduce non-deterministic behavior in Query handlers that violates Temporal's execution guarantees.
cards.rootCause: TypeScript's VM enforcement of determinism has a gap allowing mutations in Query handlers, which can lead to subtle bugs in distributed workflows.
cards.proposedFix: Implement an ESLint rule based on eslint-plugin-fp's no-mutation rule, potentially forked to work specifically with Query handlers and Temporal's APIs.
cards.keyQuote: The only hole in TS's enforced determinism (besides intentionally escaping the vm) is mutating state in Query handlers.

cards.summary: The `instanceof WorkflowNotFoundError` check fails to catch the error thrown when a workflow doesn't exist. The issue is caused by multiple versions of `@temporalio/common` being installed, and the workaround is to check `err.name === 'WorkflowNotFoundError'` or import from `@temporalio/client` instead.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot reliably catch WorkflowNotFoundError using instanceof, making it difficult to distinguish between missing workflows and other errors.
cards.rootCause: Multiple versions of @temporalio/common installed, causing instanceof checks to fail due to different class instances in the prototype chain.
cards.proposedFix: Import WorkflowNotFoundError from '@temporalio/client' instead of '@temporalio/workflow', or check err.name === 'WorkflowNotFoundError'.
cards.workaround: Use err.name === 'WorkflowNotFoundError' instead of instanceof, or change import source to '@temporalio/client'.
cards.resolutionDetails: Issue was identified as caused by dependency duplication and resolved by recommending correct import source.
cards.keyQuote: This is likely due to multiple versions of `@temporalio/common` installed. Try changing the import to: `import { WorkflowNotFoundError } from '@temporalio/client`

cards.summary: Stress tests failed to complete in CI with unclear cause. Investigation was blocked by infrastructure limitations but resolved after migrating to GitHub-hosted runners.
cards.userImpact: Unreliable CI stress tests prevent validation of SDK stability and reliability.
cards.rootCause: Infrastructure limitations in the CI runner environment causing test timeouts or incomplete execution.
cards.proposedFix: Migrate to GitHub-hosted runners with better resource availability and stability.
cards.resolutionDetails: Issue resolved by migrating to GitHub-hosted runners which provide more reliable infrastructure.
cards.keyQuote: Closing this as it should not happen anymore now that we have GH hosted runner.

cards.summary: NYC test coverage instrumentation for Jest tests is not generating coverage reports despite following the package documentation. When manually instrumented with NYC, the workflow function body is not being marked as covered even though tests execute successfully.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot obtain accurate code coverage reports for their TypeScript Temporal workflows when using Jest with the NYC test coverage tool.
cards.rootCause: Possible issue with how NYC instrument and coverage reporting interacts with the workflow testing setup, or rebuild occurring after instrumentation that overwrites instrumented code.
cards.workaround: Use mocha test runner instead of Jest for coverage reporting, though workflow body coverage may still not be captured correctly.
cards.resolutionDetails: Investigator was unable to reproduce the issue in the test suite and coverage appeared to be working correctly in their testing, suggesting the root cause was likely user error (rebuilding after instrumentation) rather than a framework bug.
cards.keyQuote: My best guess is that you're somehow re-building after manually instrumenting.

cards.summary: Jest test runner fails to exit cleanly due to an open handle in the native Temporal module, preventing proper code coverage collection with nyc. The issue occurs when registering native errors during module initialization.
cards.userImpact: Users testing TypeScript Temporal code cannot properly exit Jest tests or collect code coverage due to hanging processes.
cards.rootCause: A neon threadsafe function created during native error registration keeps the process open
cards.keyQuote: Jest has detected the following 1 open handle potentially keeping Jest from exiting: neon threadsafe function

cards.summary: Error running Temporal TypeScript SDK in Linux Docker containers without glibc (GNU libc). The core-bridge module fails to load because it only provides x86_64-unknown-linux-gnu binaries, not musl/Alpine-compatible versions, causing missing shared library errors.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot run the TypeScript SDK in lightweight Alpine/musl-based Docker containers, limiting deployment options.
cards.rootCause: The core-bridge native module is compiled only for glibc (linux-gnu), not for musl. Alpine and other musl-based distributions lack the required glibc shared libraries.
cards.proposedFix: Build and distribute core-bridge binaries for musl targets (e.g., x86_64-unknown-linux-musl) similar to how other Node.js native libraries like SWC handle it.
cards.workaround: Use glibc-based Docker images (e.g., node, node-slim) instead of Alpine. Add ca-certificates package if needed for lightweight deployment.
cards.resolutionDetails: Maintainers documented that musl/Alpine is not supported. Issue closed as a documented limitation, though they noted musl support might be considered in the future.
cards.keyQuote: Using musl based images (such as Alpine) is not supported. Can you try with a glibc based image, such as node?

cards.summary: Feature request to access workflow/activity execution metadata (workflowId, activityId, runId, etc.) within PayloadCodec for logging purposes. Currently, this context is only partially accessible during activity decoding via Context.current(), limiting the ability to correlate codec failures with specific workflow/activity executions.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot reliably log codec failures with workflow/activity identifiers, making it difficult to correlate encoding/decoding issues with specific executions in production logs.
cards.rootCause: PayloadCodec lacks access to workflow/activity execution context that contains necessary metadata for correlation and logging.
cards.proposedFix: Provide a trimmed-down context object accessible to PayloadCodec containing execution metadata (workflowId, activityId, etc.) and potentially request headers and a logger.
cards.workaround: Pass context through payload metadata from a PayloadConverter and read it in PayloadCodec, though this approach has limitations.
cards.resolutionDetails: Closed in favor of cross-SDK ticket #1661 addressing the same feature across multiple SDKs.
cards.keyQuote: A way to access the activity/workflow execution metadata, so it can be added to logs. Information like: workflowType, workflowId, runId, activityType, activityId, attempt

cards.summary: Feature request for a catch-all signal handler in TypeScript workflows to ensure in-order delivery of all signals regardless of type. Currently requires either a single signal type or multiple individual handlers, making it difficult to guarantee ordering across different signal types.
cards.userImpact: Developers must use workarounds (single signal type or fat handler) to guarantee in-order signal processing across multiple signal types.
cards.proposedFix: Add a setGlobalSignalHandler API that acts as a catch-all for any signal type not handled by specific handlers, with catch-all only triggering when no more specific handler is defined.
cards.workaround: Use a single 'fat handler' signal type or only define one signal handler to process all signals in order.
cards.resolutionDetails: Feature was implemented with catch-all handler API added to SDK.
cards.keyQuote: Easy to add, has been brought up before, API TBD. For the behavior, I'd recommend this being a catch all, meaning it doesn't get triggered if a more specific handler is set.

cards.summary: The @types/long stub types definition is unnecessarily listed as a dependency in @temporalio/client's package.json. Since long v5 includes its own types, this @types package should be removed from dependencies and moved to devDependencies if needed.
cards.userImpact: Users installing @temporalio/client unnecessarily receive an obsolete type definition package, increasing bundle size and causing deprecation warnings.
cards.rootCause: The @types/long stub was required for type definitions in earlier versions of the long library, but long v5 includes native type definitions making the stub unnecessary.
cards.proposedFix: Remove @types/long from dependencies in packages/client/package.json since long v5 provides its own types.
cards.resolutionDetails: The deprecated @types/long dependency was removed from the client package as long v5 includes native type definitions.
cards.keyQuote: it can be removed since v5 of `long`

cards.summary: AsyncLocalStorage-based CancellationScopes may leak scope state in Node.js 18, potentially affecting code that uses condition() with timeouts which internally create and cancel scopes.
cards.userImpact: Users may experience unexpected scope state persistence or context leakage when using condition() or CancellationScopes in Node.js 18.
cards.resolutionDetails: Could not be reproduced; issue closed due to inability to confirm problem.
cards.keyQuote: Cannot reproduce this, closing.

cards.summary: Feature request to add a meta client to the TypeScript SDK, as described in the Schedules proposal for higher-level client functionality.
cards.userImpact: Users would have access to a higher-level meta client for enhanced functionality in the TypeScript SDK.
cards.proposedFix: Implementation as described in the Schedules proposal for TypeScript SDK.
cards.resolutionDetails: Already implemented by bergundy a couple weeks prior to the feature request.
cards.keyQuote: I already did this a couple weeks ago.

cards.summary: The @temporalio/nyc-test-coverage npm package version 1.1.0 only contains the src directory but is missing the compiled lib directory, making it unusable when installed via npm.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot use the @temporalio/nyc-test-coverage package after installing it via npm because the compiled lib directory is missing.
cards.rootCause: The lib directory is included in the package.json files field but is not being built or packaged during the npm publish process.
cards.proposedFix: Ensure the lib directory is built and included in the npm package by verifying the build process runs before publishing.
cards.resolutionDetails: The issue was resolved by ensuring the lib directory is properly built and included in the npm package distribution.
cards.keyQuote: You'll see that there's only an `src` directory, no `lib`

cards.summary: The default `WorkerOptions.maxCachedWorkflows` value was significantly reduced in a recent change, causing a substantial decrease in workflow cache capacity (e.g., from 12600 to 761 on 64GB machines). The default needs to be increased to be more reasonable for typical deployments.
cards.userImpact: Users experience significantly reduced workflow cache capacity by default, potentially impacting performance and causing unnecessary cache misses on adequately-sized machines.
cards.rootCause: PR #802 reduced the default maxCachedWorkflows value without accounting for the impact on different machine sizes.
cards.proposedFix: Increase the default maxCachedWorkflows value; potentially implement dynamic calculation based on available memory in the future.
cards.resolutionDetails: Default maxCachedWorkflows value was increased to be more reasonable for typical deployments.
cards.keyQuote: For example on a 64GB machine it went down from 12600 to 761 and on a 16GB machine (nightly CI) from 2853 to 261.

cards.summary: CI test-npm-init job is rate limited when downloading from api.github.com. The issue persists despite a previous PR attempt to fix it. Suggested solution is to use a Cloudflare CDN in front of api.github.com for both package creation and testing.
cards.userImpact: CI builds fail intermittently due to GitHub API rate limiting when running npm-init tests, blocking PR validation and releases.
cards.rootCause: Missing or insufficient authentication headers in GitHub API requests during npm package initialization in CI environment, causing requests to be rate limited more aggressively.
cards.proposedFix: Add Cloudflare CDN proxy in front of api.github.com and update both package creation and test scripts to use the CDN domain instead of direct API calls.
cards.resolutionDetails: Fixed by ensuring auth headers are sent in all requests to GitHub API. PR #865 addresses the missing authentication header that was causing the rate limit issue.
cards.keyQuote: Looks like we weren't sending the auth header in one of the requests, I'm fixing this.

cards.summary: Remove deprecated `sourceMap` and `sourceMapPath` configuration options that were made irrelevant by PR #819 and formally deprecated in PR #827.
cards.userImpact: Removes deprecated configuration options from the SDK to simplify the API surface and reduce maintenance burden.
cards.proposedFix: Remove the `sourceMap` and `sourceMapPath` options from the SDK configuration.
cards.keyQuote: Made irrelevant in #819. Deprecated in #827

cards.summary: Request to remove the Long type from the TypeScript client SDK. The feature was originally implemented in PR #818 but was subsequently reverted in PR #827, indicating it should be removed from the codebase.
cards.userImpact: Simplifies the TypeScript client API by removing an unnecessary type, reducing API surface and potential confusion.
cards.resolutionDetails: The Long type was removed from the client following the reversion in PR #827.
cards.keyQuote: Originally implemented here: https://github.com/temporalio/sdk-typescript/pull/818 Reverted here: https://github.com/temporalio/sdk-typescript/pull/827

cards.summary: Feature request to throw an error when heartbeat() is called from Local Activities, aligning with Python SDK behavior. This would signal to users that heartbeats are unnecessary and ignored in local activities.
cards.userImpact: Users will receive a clear error message instead of silently ignored heartbeat calls, preventing confusion about whether their code is working correctly.
cards.proposedFix: Throw an error when heartbeat() is invoked from within a local activity execution context.
cards.keyQuote: This is what Python does. It's a way to indicate to users that they don't need that line of code (which currently is ignored / has no effect).

cards.summary: Users encountered TypeError when using console.warn() in workflows. Request to add missing console methods (warn, error, info, debug) to the workflow VM, which currently only supports console.log().
cards.userImpact: Users cannot use standard console methods beyond console.log() within workflows, forcing workarounds or incomplete logging capabilities.
cards.rootCause: The workflow VM sandbox only exposes console.log() function, missing other standard console methods.
cards.proposedFix: Add console.warn(), console.error(), console.info(), and console.debug() functions to the workflow VM environment alongside the existing console.log().
cards.resolutionDetails: The missing console methods were added to the workflow VM.
cards.keyQuote: Add some common functions like `console.warn`, `.error`, `.info`, `.debug`.

cards.summary: CI test suite experiences intermittent timeouts during script execution with ERR_SCRIPT_EXECUTION_TIMEOUT errors. The issue was partially mitigated by increasing isolateExecutionTimeout from 100ms to 400ms, but rare flakes still occur under resource constraints.
cards.userImpact: Developers experience intermittent CI failures that are not related to actual code quality, causing unreliable test results and build delays.
cards.rootCause: Script execution timeout due to test concurrency and machine resource constraints. 5-second limit with individual script timeout threshold too aggressive.
cards.proposedFix: Increase isolateExecutionTimeout threshold and potentially reduce test concurrency or allocate stronger CI machines.
cards.workaround: Increased isolateExecutionTimeout from 100ms to 400ms to reduce frequency of timeouts.
cards.resolutionDetails: Partially resolved by increasing isolateExecutionTimeout to 400ms. Rare flakes may still occur but deemed acceptable with current infrastructure limitations.
cards.keyQuote: Script execution timed out after 100ms

cards.summary: The TypeScript SDK docs reference a deprecated `nodeModulesPaths` option that was removed from WorkerOptions, causing type errors when developers follow the documentation. The option is no longer needed as the SDK now automatically detects node_modules correctly.
cards.userImpact: Developers following the official documentation receive TypeScript compilation errors when trying to use the outdated nodeModulesPaths option.
cards.rootCause: The nodeModulesPaths option was removed from WorkerOptions because the SDK now automatically detects node_modules, but the documentation was not updated to reflect this change.
cards.proposedFix: Update the documentation to remove references to nodeModulesPaths and explain that the SDK now handles node_modules detection automatically.
cards.workaround: Remove the nodeModulesPaths option from Worker.create() configuration.
cards.resolutionDetails: Documentation was updated in temporalio/documentation PR #1425 to remove references to the deprecated nodeModulesPaths option.
cards.keyQuote: We removed it, as we should now always detect it correctly. If you remove the option, does it work?

cards.summary: Request to upsert TemporalChangeVersion on patch updates. This feature was implemented in PR #1072 with the latest Core and requires server version 1.20 or later to take effect.
cards.userImpact: Users can now automatically update TemporalChangeVersion when applying patches, improving version management workflows.
cards.proposedFix: Implemented via PR #1072 with latest Core
cards.resolutionDetails: Feature implemented in PR #1072 with latest Core, requires server version 1.20+
cards.keyQuote: This will now happen as of #1072 with latest Core. Requires server version 1.20 to take effect.

cards.summary: User requests significant API simplification and less boilerplate for workflow and activity setup, comparing current experience to React class components and requesting more functional patterns with colocated definitions and default options.
cards.userImpact: Users must write extensive boilerplate code across multiple files to set up workflows and activities, creating friction for adoption and migration from other systems.
cards.proposedFix: Implement default activity options system-wide, allow direct activity invocation without proxies, colocate workflow implementations with activities, and provide simplified worker creation patterns similar to functional React components.
cards.workaround: Set up single Worker with all workflows/activities in organized directories, reuse existing non-temporal code by having activities call it, use existing compile-time type checking.
cards.keyQuote: it really is like React for the Backend...Right now it feels like React Classes, I want React Functions.

cards.summary: Test server download breaks when Java releases are broken or missing assets, affecting users' automated testing and npm installation. The issue discusses coupling to a fixed working version, fallback logic, or CDN-based distribution.
cards.userImpact: Users experience broken automated testing when Java test server releases are broken or lack assets, causing npm install failures.
cards.rootCause: Test server download script depends on latest Java SDK release having properly built test server assets, with no fallback mechanism.
cards.proposedFix: Point @temporalio/testing package to a fixed test server version for consistency, use temporal.download service to cache requests and control version serving, or add fallback logic to try previous versions.
cards.resolutionDetails: Resolved by leveraging temporal.download service to cache requests and control which test server version is served, eliminating rate-limiting issues and providing version control.
cards.keyQuote: point the @temporalio/testing package to a fixed test server version, that way there are no surprises

cards.summary: The `long` package is incorrectly listed as a devDependency instead of a dependency in the TypeScript SDK, causing worker failures in production Docker containers that only install production dependencies with `yarn workspaces focus --production`.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot deploy workers in production Docker containers using yarn with `--production` flag, resulting in runtime errors when workers try to execute workflows.
cards.rootCause: @protobufjs/inquire delegates loading of `long` to protobufjs/light but doesn't declare `long` as a dependency. Yarn 3 PnP and PNPM enforce strict dependency resolution, unlike traditional node_modules layout.
cards.proposedFix: Add `long` as a proper dependency (not devDependency) in the internal-workflow-common package.json, or configure Yarn with packageExtensions to declare the dependency in @protobufjs/inquire.
cards.workaround: Add the following to .yarnrc.yml file: packageExtensions: "@protobufjs/inquire@*": dependencies: long: "5.2.0"
cards.resolutionDetails: Fixed in a subsequent release by properly declaring the `long` dependency.
cards.keyQuote: The problem is that `protobufjs/light` delegates loading of `long` to the `@protobufjs/inquire` package... Yarn 3's PnP is essentially the strictest of all.

cards.summary: Stress tests intermittently fail when a dynamically created namespace becomes unavailable before tests complete, causing TonicError with 'Namespace not found' message. The issue appears to be a race condition during namespace initialization or availability.
cards.userImpact: Stress tests fail sporadically, reducing test reliability and making it difficult to detect real performance issues or regressions.
cards.rootCause: Namespace may not be fully ready when stress test attempts to use it, or namespace becomes unavailable during test execution
cards.proposedFix: Add 'wait for namespace ready' function before running tests; consider using Temporalite as an alternative
cards.workaround: Add sleep delay before running stress tests to allow namespace initialization; use Temporalite for more stable test environment
cards.resolutionDetails: Resolved by adding 'wait for namespace ready' function before running tests, eliminating the race condition
cards.keyQuote: No recent occurrence of this one, and I believe this has been resolved a long time ago by adding a "wait for namespace ready" function

cards.summary: Stress test CI workflow exits with timeout error (exit code 124). The worker fails to pick up new tasks, possibly related to Docker Compose setup or artifact loss during reruns.
cards.userImpact: CI stress tests fail intermittently, preventing validation of SDK stability under load.
cards.rootCause: Worker not picking up new tasks, potentially due to Docker Compose setup or lost artifacts during test reruns
cards.resolutionDetails: Issue was resolved at some point, though exact cause and fix are not documented in the discussion
cards.keyQuote: 124 looks due to timeout. I think this is related to #804 where for some reason the worker isn't picking up new tasks.

cards.summary: Nightly tests were failing because no workflow tasks were being returned to the worker, with the logs full of poll timeout messages. The issue resolved itself without clear explanation of what changed.
cards.userImpact: Nightly test suite was broken, preventing validation of SDK changes and regressions.
cards.rootCause: Unknown - possibly related to Docker Compose environment or infrastructure changes.
cards.resolutionDetails: Tests became green again after the issue was reported, suggesting an environmental or transient issue that self-resolved.
cards.keyQuote: Poll wft timeout

cards.summary: Transitive dependency vulnerability in node-fetch (CVE-2022-2596) with CVSS score 5.9 affecting the documentation build process through docusaurus-plugin-snipsync. The vulnerability is a denial of service issue in node-fetch prior to version 3.2.10.
cards.userImpact: Users building the documentation are exposed to a potential denial of service vulnerability through a transitive dependency.
cards.rootCause: node-fetch version 2.6.7 contains CVE-2022-2596, a DoS vulnerability that could be exploited via network requests under specific conditions.
cards.proposedFix: Upgrade node-fetch to version 3.2.10 or later to resolve CVE-2022-2596.
cards.resolutionDetails: The issue was automatically closed by Mend after the vulnerable library was either marked as ignored or removed from the dependency tree.
cards.keyQuote: Denial of Service in GitHub repository node-fetch/node-fetch prior to 3.2.10

cards.summary: A panic occurs in the Neon bridge when a workflow fails nondeterministic replay validation. The error manifests as a Rust panic about improper Root handle cleanup followed by a channel closed error, preventing proper error handling.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot properly catch and handle errors from nondeterministic workflow replay, causing uncaught panics that crash the application.
cards.rootCause: Bug in the TypeScript-Rust bridge code (Neon) where the Root handle is not properly cleaned up when a workflow replay fails, violating Neon's drop safety requirements.
cards.resolutionDetails: Fixed by recent changes to Runtime; reporter indicated the issue was no longer reproducible after runtime modifications.
cards.keyQuote: Must call `into_inner` or `drop` on `Root` ... thread '<unnamed>' panicked

cards.summary: Node.js fatal error occurs when signalWithStart is used to create a new workflow and send a signal to it. The worker crashes with a V8 internal check failure. The root cause was identified as a missing await on the sleep promise in the workflow code.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot reliably use signalWithStart to create workflows and send signals, causing worker crashes with V8 fatal errors.
cards.rootCause: Missing await on sleep('1 year') promise in the workflow handler caused improper async state management during signal processing.
cards.proposedFix: Await the sleep promise, and use await CancellationScope.current().cancelRequested or await condition(() => false) for indefinite workflow blocking.
cards.workaround: Ensure all promises in workflows are properly awaited; add ESLint rules to catch missing awaits.
cards.resolutionDetails: User identified the issue was a missing await on sleep() in their workflow code. The issue was not a framework bug but a user error in async handling.
cards.keyQuote: Turns out, the issue was just a missing `await` in the workflow's `while(true) { sleep('1 year') }` loop.

cards.summary: Queries that use Date.now() are calculated once and cached rather than recalculated on each query invocation, causing issues like returning stale time values for timers. The request is to add WorkflowInfo.unsafe.now() to access the current workflow time for query handlers.
cards.userImpact: Query handlers cannot reliably return time-dependent values like elapsed time or time-to-deadline without receiving stale cached results.
cards.rootCause: Query handlers cache the result of Date.now() on first evaluation rather than recalculating it on each query invocation.
cards.proposedFix: Add WorkflowInfo.unsafe.now() API to allow query handlers to access the current workflow time.
cards.resolutionDetails: Trivialized and marked for inclusion in next release per maintainer comment.
cards.keyQuote: If I query this, I keep getting the same number back even though I would expect to keep getting smaller numbers.

cards.summary: Breakpoints cannot be set on workflow code due to bundling, making debugging impossible. The proposed solution is to run an HTTP server in debug mode to serve source maps so the debugger can map back to original source.
cards.userImpact: Developers cannot debug workflow code effectively, significantly hindering development and troubleshooting of TypeScript workflows.
cards.rootCause: Workflow code bundling and lack of inlined source maps prevent debuggers from mapping bundled code back to original source for breakpoint setting.
cards.proposedFix: Start an HTTP server in the worker when running in debug mode to serve source maps, with configurable port for remote debugging scenarios.
cards.workaround: Previously could use debugger statements at top of workflow functions, but this no longer works after stack trace query implementation.
cards.keyQuote: by setting a file name on the vm script we use to compile the code and having the file and source map available the debugger can map back to the source

cards.summary: Request to implement a ScheduleClient API for the TypeScript SDK, following the feature specification defined in the SDK features repository.
cards.userImpact: Users can programmatically create, update, and manage recurring workflow schedules through a dedicated API.
cards.resolutionDetails: Implemented in pull request #937
cards.keyQuote: Implemented in #937

cards.summary: Documentation for bundleWorkflowCode is insufficient, lacking guidance on passing interceptors through the function to prevent non-determinism errors when replaying workflows. Users are unclear how to pass the bundled code to Worker.create.
cards.userImpact: Developers cannot correctly implement workflow code bundling and interceptors, leading to non-determinism errors during workflow replay.
cards.proposedFix: Add documentation to bundleWorkflowCode API reference explaining that interceptors must be passed through this function and is necessary for replay to work correctly.
cards.resolutionDetails: Documentation was improved to clarify bundleWorkflowCode usage and interceptor handling.
cards.keyQuote: Better documentation around bundleWorkflowCode to indicate that interceptors should be passed in through bundleWorkflowCode and is necessary if used with replaying

cards.summary: The TypeScript SDK currently depends on protobufjs@6 while the latest proto3-json-serializer requires protobufjs@7, causing users to have both versions installed. This feature request proposes upgrading to protobufjs@7 to resolve the dependency conflict.
cards.userImpact: Users experience duplicate protobufjs versions in their dependency tree, increasing bundle size and potential compatibility issues.
cards.rootCause: SDK pins protobufjs@6 while proto3-json-serializer requires protobufjs@7, creating version mismatch.
cards.proposedFix: Upgrade the SDK to use protobufjs@7 and migrate CLI usage to the new protobufjs-cli package.
cards.resolutionDetails: The SDK was upgraded to protobufjs@7, resolving the dependency conflict and aligning with proto3-json-serializer requirements.
cards.keyQuote: Latest proto3-json-serializer depends on protobufjs@7, and we curently depend on 6, which means users get both versions.

cards.summary: User requests better support for using the Temporal TypeScript SDK within Nx monorepos, including a dedicated executor or working sample configuration to simplify bundling and command execution.
cards.userImpact: Developers using Nx monorepos struggle with complex configuration and bundling when integrating Temporal SDK.
cards.proposedFix: Create a dedicated Temporal executor for Nx that handles bundling and command execution, or provide a working sample configuration.
cards.keyQuote: It's currently very hard to use temporal inside an Nx monorepo

cards.summary: Test server downloads are rate-limited when fetching directly from GitHub. The solution is to serve test server binaries through a CDN to avoid GitHub's rate limiting.
cards.userImpact: Users running tests with the testing package encounter rate limit errors when downloading the test server binary from GitHub.
cards.rootCause: Direct downloads from GitHub API hit rate limits under repeated or concurrent access patterns.
cards.proposedFix: Implement CDN-based distribution for test server binaries instead of direct GitHub downloads.
cards.resolutionDetails: Issue was resolved by moving test server distribution behind a CDN to handle rate limiting.
cards.keyQuote: Users using testing package may get: `HTTPError: Response code 403 (rate limit exceeded)` from: `node ./scripts/download-test-server.mjs`

cards.summary: OpenTelemetry spans are being ended twice in the TypeScript SDK worker, causing error messages about attempting to end an already-ended span. The issue occurs because the `instrument` function already ends the span, but an additional `.end()` call is made in the worker code.
cards.userImpact: Users see repeated error messages in logs about span operations on ended spans, creating noise and confusion in observability data.
cards.rootCause: The worker code calls `.end()` on a span that has already been ended by the `instrument` wrapper function.
cards.proposedFix: Remove the `.end()` call from the worker code since `instrument` already handles span termination.
cards.resolutionDetails: The duplicate .end() call was removed from the worker code to let the instrument function handle span lifecycle management.
cards.keyQuote: Easy fix, should just require dropping the `.end()` on â˜ï¸ since `instrument` takes care of it

cards.summary: Feature request to include string representations of enums in failure objects for better debuggability. Currently, enum values appear as numbers (e.g., `retryState: 4`), making it difficult for users to understand what the values mean.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot easily understand enum values in failure objects without looking up the enum definitions, reducing debugging efficiency.
cards.proposedFix: Add string enum representations alongside numeric values in failure objects (e.g., `retryStateString: 'MAXIMUM_ATTEMPTS_REACHED'`), or provide a helper function like `logFriendly(failure)` or `failure.pretty()`.
cards.workaround: Users can manually look up enum names and implement their own conversion function.
cards.resolutionDetails: The maintainers decided not to implement this feature, determining that users can easily look up enum names and implement custom functions if needed. Suggested users could create their own helper.
cards.keyQuote: Users can easily look up the enum names and implement this function. Let's close for now and revisit if there's demand.

cards.summary: Feature request to expose internal-non-workflow-common functionality to users, either by adding it to the API reference or restructuring internal packages to provide a non-workflow public entry point.
cards.userImpact: Users currently need to reference internal package files directly, making it difficult to use non-workflow common functionality without relying on implementation details.
cards.rootCause: Non-workflow common utilities are in internal packages without a stable public API or documented entry point.
cards.proposedFix: Either add the internal-non-workflow-common package to the API reference or restructure internal packages into a 'common' folder with a separate '@temporalio/common/non-workflow' entry point.
cards.workaround: Users can import directly from the GitHub repository: `import { encodeToPayload, loadDataConverter } from '@temporalio/internal-non-workflow-common'`
cards.keyQuote: Either: Add to API ref - Combine internal* packages into `common`, using a separate folder & entry point for any non-workflow APIs

cards.summary: User requests batched replay functionality to replay multiple workflows in parallel, which would improve test performance by allowing concurrent worker initialization instead of sequential replays.
cards.userImpact: Users must replay workflows sequentially, causing slow test execution when validating determinism across multiple workflows.
cards.rootCause: Worker registration and initialization is not parallelizable in current implementation; each replay requires sequential setup.
cards.proposedFix: Add a batched replay feature that accepts a list of workflow IDs and replays them in parallel, returning results and failures.
cards.workaround: Use Promise.allSettled to parallelize runReplayHistory calls manually, though this provides limited speedup due to serialized worker initialization.
cards.resolutionDetails: Support added in sdk-core which enables batched replay functionality.
cards.keyQuote: It would be useful to have a feature that allows you to kick off a replay that takes in a list of workflow IDs and replays all of them in parallel

cards.summary: Enable the ESLint `import/no-deprecated` rule to catch usage of deprecated APIs. The rule was added but commented out due to many RxJS deprecation warnings. After dependency pruning, determine if it's now feasible to enable.
cards.userImpact: Enabling this rule would help developers catch usage of deprecated APIs earlier and encourage proactive upgrades to avoid future breaking changes.
cards.rootCause: RxJS deprecations (scheduler parameter, resultSelector, thisArg, subscribe-arguments) were causing numerous import/no-deprecated lint errors when the rule was enabled.
cards.proposedFix: After pruning dependencies in #1330, re-evaluate whether enabling import/no-deprecated is feasible. Determine if false-positives remain beyond what the deprecation/deprecation rule already provides.
cards.resolutionDetails: Attempted enabling import/no-deprecated but found it caused too many false-positives with no additional benefit over the existing deprecation/deprecation rule.
cards.keyQuote: Also tried enabling import/no-deprecated, but it caused a lot of false-positives, with nothing pertinent over what deprecation/deprecation already provides.

cards.summary: The payloadToJSON function from @temporalio/common/lib/proto-utils does not properly encode metadata fields as base64 strings, failing to generate valid proto JSON. The issue stems from proto3-json-serializer's inability to properly handle maps of bytes.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot properly serialize Temporal payloads with metadata to valid proto JSON format.
cards.rootCause: proto3-json-serializer does not properly handle maps of bytes, causing metadata fields to not be base64 encoded
cards.proposedFix: Manually encode metadata fields as base64 strings: Object.entries(metadata).map(([k, v]): [string, string] => [k, Buffer.from(v).toString('base64')])
cards.workaround: Manually implement the base64 encoding for metadata fields as shown in the issue comment
cards.keyQuote: Metadata fields are not turned into base64 encoded strings

cards.summary: User experiencing timeout on the last workflow during runReplayHistory when replaying multiple workflows in parallel using Promise.all(). The final replay fails with 'Timed out waiting for task result' error while others succeed.
cards.userImpact: Users replaying multiple workflows in parallel may experience unexpected timeouts on the final replay, preventing batch replay operations from completing successfully.
cards.rootCause: The workflow bundle was not created with the same interceptors that were passed into the worker, causing a mismatch in replay configuration.
cards.proposedFix: Ensure that when creating a workflowBundle for runReplayHistory, the same interceptors used in the worker are included in the bundle configuration.
cards.resolutionDetails: Issue was resolved by identifying that the workflow bundle must be created with the same interceptors passed to the worker.
cards.keyQuote: We figured out that the cause was that the bundle wasn't created with the same interceptors that were passed in to the worker.

cards.summary: Remove terser dependency from worker package.json once webpack is updated to a version that no longer requires it as a separate dependency.
cards.userImpact: Reduces build dependencies and maintenance overhead for the TypeScript SDK worker package.
cards.rootCause: Terser was added as a workaround dependency in #760 pending webpack version updates.
cards.proposedFix: Remove terser from packages/worker/package.json once webpack is updated.
cards.resolutionDetails: Terser dependency was removed after webpack was updated to a version that handles it automatically.
cards.keyQuote: Once webpack updates and we update our webpack version, we can remove terser from packages/worker/package.json

cards.summary: Worker client experiences OOM errors in Kubernetes containers because maxCachedWorkflows is calculated using os.totalmem() which returns host machine memory instead of container resource limits. Recommendation to use v8.getHeapStatistics().total_available_size instead for accurate memory calculation.
cards.userImpact: Workers crash with OOM errors in Kubernetes environments even when memory limits are properly configured via NODE_OPTIONS.
cards.rootCause: maxCachedWorkflows default calculation uses os.totalmem() which returns host machine memory, not container cgroup limits, causing incorrect memory estimates and excessive workflow caching.
cards.proposedFix: Calculate default maxCachedWorkflows using v8.getHeapStatistics().total_available_size instead of os.totalmem() to respect container memory constraints.
cards.workaround: Manually set maxCachedWorkflows to a lower value in worker options.
cards.resolutionDetails: Agreed to use total_available_size from v8.getHeapStatistics() as the default instead of os.totalmem().
cards.keyQuote: os.totalmem() will get the host machine memory not container resource setting. Could we calculate default maxCachedWorkflows with v8.getHeapStatistics().total_available_size

cards.summary: A regular expression denial of service (ReDoS) vulnerability was detected in terser 5.14.1, a transitive dependency used via webpack for build tooling. The vulnerability has a CVSS score of 5.3 and is fixed in terser versions 4.8.1 and 5.14.2 or later.
cards.userImpact: Users of the SDK are exposed to a potential denial of service vulnerability through a transitive dependency in the build pipeline.
cards.rootCause: Insecure usage of regular expressions in terser library versions before 5.14.2 causing ReDoS vulnerability (CVE-2022-25858).
cards.proposedFix: Upgrade terser to version 4.8.1 or 5.14.2 or later.
cards.resolutionDetails: The issue was resolved by upgrading the terser dependency to a patched version that addresses CVE-2022-25858.
cards.keyQuote: The package terser before 4.8.1, from 5.0.0 and before 5.14.2 are vulnerable to Regular Expression Denial of Service (ReDoS)

cards.summary: Worker crashes with 'Invalid regular expression flags' error when using workflowBundle with inline code and sourceMap properties instead of codePath and sourceMapPath. The user was passing file paths instead of actual code content to the code property.
cards.userImpact: Users upgrading to 1.0.0-rc.1 may encounter cryptic crashes if they misuse the workflowBundle API by passing file paths instead of actual code content.
cards.rootCause: User passed file paths to the 'code' property instead of the actual bundled code content, causing the worker to interpret the path string as invalid regex flags.
cards.workaround: Use codePath and sourceMapPath properties instead of inline code and sourceMap properties.
cards.resolutionDetails: Closed as invalid - the issue was user error/misunderstanding of the API documentation rather than a bug in the SDK.
cards.keyQuote: If I just change my workflowBundle bundle to use the codePath and sourceMapPath properties, the worker does not crash.

cards.summary: The `patched()` API doesn't work correctly inside `condition()` calls because the patch ID is cached and returns the same value on subsequent evaluations. Users need to support updating workflow conditions after deployment without manually creating unique patch IDs for each call.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot safely use patched() inside condition() to update workflow logic after deployment without creating unique patch IDs for each evaluation.
cards.rootCause: The patched() API caches its result, returning the same value on subsequent condition evaluations rather than re-evaluating on each call.
cards.proposedFix: The SDK should internally generate different patch IDs on every condition call or handle re-evaluation transparently to avoid manual workarounds.
cards.workaround: Use different patch IDs for each condition evaluation by incrementing a counter: `patched("patchId" + (i++))`
cards.resolutionDetails: Discussion revealed that patch() already works as intended - it evaluates to false during replay and returns true once the marker is seen or workflow exits replay mode. The reported issue appears to be a misunderstanding of the intended behavior.
cards.keyQuote: patched already works this way today. It evaluates to false during replay and once the marker is seen or workflow is no longer replaying it starts returning true.

cards.summary: Yarn PnP (Plug'n'Play) package manager breaks workflow tests in TypeScript SDK due to ESM module resolution issues and missing pnpapi dependency. The testing framework fails with VM module errors and require stack issues when using yarn workspaces.
cards.userImpact: Users with yarn PnP package managers cannot run workflow tests without manual patches or workarounds, blocking testing capabilities.
cards.rootCause: The @temporalio/testing library and dependencies like get-port use ESM syntax which is incompatible with yarn PnP's module resolution; enhanced-resolve cannot find pnpapi in the require stack.
cards.proposedFix: Vendor and port get-port package to CommonJS to eliminate ESM dependency issues; update @temporalio/testing to handle both ESM and CommonJS module systems.
cards.workaround: Use patch-package to manually convert ESM imports to require statements; set NODE_OPTIONS=--experimental-vm-modules when running tests.
cards.resolutionDetails: Resolved by removing dependency on get-port package, eliminating the ESM compatibility issues with yarn PnP.
cards.keyQuote: Closing, we don't depend on `get-port` anymore.

cards.summary: Feature request to add a user-friendly `listWorkflows()` method to the workflow client that simplifies pagination and provides type-safe query filtering, replacing the lower-level protobuf-based `listWorkflowExecutions` API.
cards.userImpact: Developers currently need to work with low-level protobuf APIs and manual pagination for listing workflows, making the API harder to use.
cards.proposedFix: Add `workflowClient.listWorkflows()` method that returns an async iterator, includes type-safe query builder for filter expressions, and handles pagination internally.
cards.keyQuote: Proposed: `workflowClient.listWorkflows()` that maybe makes pagination easier and converts types of returned executions

cards.summary: The test framework causes segmentation faults when run with Jest on macOS M1, though it works consistently with Mocha. The issue appears related to Jest's handling of the SDK rather than the test server itself.
cards.userImpact: Developers cannot reliably run SDK tests with Jest, forcing them to switch to alternative test runners like Mocha.
cards.rootCause: Issue with Jest handling of the SDK, likely related to ESM module loading and vm contexts created in the main nodejs thread, exacerbated by get-port ESM version.
cards.proposedFix: Downgrade get-port to non-ESM version to resolve module loading issues.
cards.workaround: Use Mocha or other test runners instead of Jest for running tests with the SDK.
cards.resolutionDetails: Fixed by downgrading get-port to the non-ESM version, which resolved Jest compatibility issues with the SDK.
cards.keyQuote: This is probably the 4th jest related issue we've gotten.

cards.summary: Add a static `create` method to `ApplicationFailure` for convenient instantiation with message, type, nonRetryable flag, and cause parameters.
cards.userImpact: Users can more conveniently construct ApplicationFailure instances with a fluent static method instead of direct constructor calls.
cards.proposedFix: Add a static `create` method to ApplicationFailure class that accepts an object with message, type, nonRetryable, and cause properties.
cards.resolutionDetails: The feature was implemented, as indicated by the closed status and positive review from maintainer.
cards.keyQuote: Add `create` static method to ApplicationFailure

cards.summary: Security advisory for 8 vulnerabilities (CVSS up to 9.8) detected in transitive dependencies of the documentation package, including high-severity prototype pollution and ReDoS issues in minimist, terser, and other libraries. Issue was auto-closed after marking as ignored in Mend inventory.
cards.userImpact: Users of the TypeScript SDK documentation may be exposed to high-severity security vulnerabilities in nested dependencies of the docs build system.
cards.rootCause: Outdated transitive dependencies in the @docusaurus/core dependency chain include vulnerable versions of minimist (CVE-2021-44906: prototype pollution), terser (CVE-2022-25858: ReDoS), and other libraries with known security issues.
cards.proposedFix: Update @docusaurus/core to a version that includes patched transitive dependencies with minimist >=1.2.6, terser >=5.14.2, and other fixed versions.
cards.workaround: Mark vulnerabilities as ignored in Mend until docusaurus updates their dependencies.
cards.resolutionDetails: Issue was auto-closed by Mend after being marked as ignored in the Mend inventory. The vulnerabilities were determined to not affect the deployed documentation site and would be addressed by updating docusaurus when they update their transitive dependencies.
cards.keyQuote: This report is coming from the docs package, not the SDK itself, and it does not affect our deployed docs site

cards.summary: Feature request to add a convenient `cancel()` method directly on `ChildWorkflowHandle` for canceling child workflows, instead of requiring users to cancel a scope or use external workflow handles.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot directly cancel child workflows via handle and must resort to workarounds like cancellation scopes or external workflow handles.
cards.proposedFix: Add a `cancel()` method to the `ChildWorkflowHandle` interface for direct child workflow cancellation.
cards.workaround: Use `getExternalWorkflowHandle()` to get a regular `WorkflowHandle` for the child workflow and call cancel on that, or start the child in a cancellation scope and cancel the scope.
cards.keyQuote: Would be convenient to be able to do `childHandle.cancel()`

cards.summary: Search results on the TypeScript SDK documentation site do not rank function/method API pages highly enough. When searching for specific functions like 'continueAsNew' or 'heartbeat', the relevant API documentation pages appear near the end of results instead of at the top.
cards.userImpact: Developers searching for specific Temporal API functions in documentation have difficulty finding them because relevant pages are ranked too low in search results.
cards.rootCause: Documentation search ranking algorithm does not prioritize function/method API pages using Algolia's ranking mechanisms (recordProps.lvl or pageRank).
cards.proposedFix: Use Algolia's recordProps.lvl parameter to boost function pages, or implement pageRank-based ranking to prioritize `/api/namespaces/*` pages or move functions to dedicated `/api/functions/` directory.
cards.keyQuote: It would be nice if it were first. It looks like the two ways to rank things higher are `recordProps.lvl*` or `pageRank`

cards.summary: Prototype Pollution vulnerability (CVE-2022-25878) in protobufjs 6.11.2 dependency with CVSS 7.5 severity. Vulnerability allows attackers to modify Object.prototype properties through untrusted input or .proto file parsing.
cards.userImpact: Users of the TypeScript SDK may be exposed to prototype pollution attacks if protobufjs dependency is not upgraded.
cards.rootCause: Prototype Pollution vulnerability in protobufjs versions before 6.11.3 allows modification of Object.prototype through untrusted input or .proto file parsing.
cards.proposedFix: Upgrade protobufjs to version 6.11.3 or 6.10.3
cards.resolutionDetails: Issue was automatically closed by Mend after the vulnerable library was marked as ignored or removed from the Mend inventory.
cards.keyQuote: The package protobufjs before 6.11.3 are vulnerable to Prototype Pollution which can allow an attacker to add/modify properties of the Object.prototype.

cards.summary: Feature request to enhance OpenTelemetry span instrumentation to include workflow and activity inputs/outputs as span attributes for better observability and analysis in tools like Datadog.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot currently include activity/workflow input and output data in OpenTelemetry spans, limiting observability and analysis capabilities in monitoring platforms.
cards.proposedFix: Add optional `attributes` field to `InstrumentOptions` to allow passing `SpanAttributes` to span creation, with optional global `includeAttributes` configuration flag in interceptor initialization.
cards.workaround: Manually set span attributes in custom interceptor implementations using `span?.setAttributes()` method as shown in community responses.
cards.resolutionDetails: Community provided workaround through interceptor implementation pattern; issue appears resolved through documentation/sample updates.
cards.keyQuote: Looking at the opentelemetry sdk, `tracer.startActiveSpan` has another available signature where you can pass in a `SpanOptions` object and this has a field called `attributes`

cards.summary: Local activity machine throws a nondeterminism error when a TimerStarted event occurs, preventing workflows from properly handling timer operations with local activities and condition checks.
cards.userImpact: Workflows using local activities with condition checks fail with nondeterminism errors, preventing them from completing successfully.
cards.rootCause: The local activity machine does not properly handle TimerStarted events in the event history, causing a RunUpdateErr when the workflow state machine encounters a timer event it cannot process.
cards.resolutionDetails: The issue was resolved through fixes to the local activity machine and workflow state machine to properly handle TimerStarted events during workflow execution.
cards.keyQuote: Local activity machine cannot handle this event: HistoryEvent(id: 5, Some(TimerStarted))

cards.summary: Documentation doesn't clearly indicate when TypeScript SDK methods have multiple overloads. Users struggle to discover alternative function signatures because overloads aren't visually distinguished or listed together.
cards.userImpact: Users may miss available method signatures and overloads, leading to incomplete understanding of the API capabilities and potentially implementing less optimal solutions.
cards.proposedFix: Add visual distinction for overloaded methods and display a list of all available overload signatures under the method header with links to each variant's detailed documentation.
cards.keyQuote: Some visual change, and maybe a list of options (preferably linked) under the header

cards.summary: Code coverage reports show all workflow lines as uncovered in TestWorkflowEnvironment even though tests do execute signals and queries. This is due to workflow code executing in a sandbox environment which makes coverage tracking difficult.
cards.userImpact: Developers cannot accurately measure code coverage for workflow unit tests, making it difficult to assess test completeness.
cards.rootCause: Workflow code executes in a sandbox environment which prevents standard code coverage instrumentation from working correctly.
cards.resolutionDetails: Resolved by creating the @temporalio/nyc-test-coverage package to handle code coverage specifically for sandboxed workflow code.
cards.keyQuote: This is probably going to be tricky with the way workflow code executes in the sandbox

cards.summary: Jest times out on the first run of TestWorkflowEnvironment in the TypeScript SDK, but subsequent runs pass. The issue appears to be a race condition or initialization delay in the test framework rather than a fundamental bug.
cards.userImpact: Users writing unit tests with TestWorkflowEnvironment experience intermittent timeout failures on first test run, forcing them to rerun tests.
cards.proposedFix: Increase jest timeout using jest.setTimeout(15000) in jest.config.js
cards.workaround: Rerun the tests; they typically pass on subsequent runs. Increase jest timeout configuration.
cards.resolutionDetails: Issue was addressed in SDK version 1.3.0 with a redesigned test framework. Could not be reproduced after the redesign.
cards.keyQuote: We've redone the test framework in 1.3.0. And haven't been able to reproduce this, closing until this is reproducible.

cards.summary: The `temporalio` meta package doesn't work with strict dependency resolution package managers like pnpm and yarn3. The team decided to deprecate it and recommend installing individual packages (@temporalio/client, @temporalio/worker, @temporalio/workflow, @temporalio/activity, @temporalio/common) directly instead.
cards.userImpact: Users of pnpm and yarn3 cannot use the simplified `npm install temporalio` command and must install individual packages instead, creating confusion and inconsistent documentation.
cards.rootCause: Package managers like pnpm and yarn3 enforce strict dependency resolution and don't support transitive dependencies without explicit installation, making the umbrella package non-functional for these users.
cards.proposedFix: Deprecate the `temporalio` meta package and update all setup instructions and samples to recommend installing individual packages: `npm install @temporalio/{client,worker,workflow,activity,common}`
cards.workaround: Install individual packages directly instead of using the meta package, as most utilities are re-exported from relevant client/activity/workflow packages.
cards.resolutionDetails: The meta package was deprecated and documentation was updated to recommend installing individual packages for all users, providing a consistent approach across package managers.
cards.keyQuote: I'd rather steer users in the right direction... it seems like the node ecosystem is going towards the more strict package layout scheme

cards.summary: The TypeScript SDK README is outdated and doesn't accurately reflect the current 1.0.0 capabilities. For example, it incorrectly states that Upsert on search attributes is not implemented when it actually is supported.
cards.userImpact: Users may be misled about SDK capabilities when consulting the README, potentially leading them to believe certain features are unavailable.
cards.rootCause: The README was not updated to reflect the changes introduced in the 1.0.0 release.
cards.resolutionDetails: The issue reported the outdated README, and the maintainer acknowledged the need to update it.
cards.keyQuote: The SDK README is out of date with the current capabilities of the SDK

cards.summary: WorkflowNotFoundError is currently exported from an internal module (@temporalio/internal-workflow-common) while other common errors like WorkflowExecutionAlreadyStartedError are exported from @temporalio/client. The request is to re-export WorkflowNotFoundError from @temporalio/client for API consistency.
cards.userImpact: Users must import WorkflowNotFoundError from an internal module instead of the public client module, creating an inconsistent and confusing API.
cards.rootCause: WorkflowNotFoundError was not included in the public @temporalio/client exports alongside other common errors.
cards.proposedFix: Re-export WorkflowNotFoundError from @temporalio/client to make it available alongside other error exports.
cards.workaround: Import WorkflowNotFoundError from @temporalio/internal-workflow-common
cards.resolutionDetails: The maintainer acknowledged the issue and agreed to re-export the error from the client module.
cards.keyQuote: I think it would be nice to have one place that re-exports all possible errors, so there is no need to import from "internal-workflow-common" at all.

cards.summary: The @temporalio/interceptors-opentelemetry package.json references non-existent entry points (lib/index.js and lib/index.d.ts), causing import failures. Users must import from specific subpaths like lib/worker instead.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot import from the @temporalio/interceptors-opentelemetry package root and receive TypeScript compilation errors.
cards.rootCause: package.json main and types fields point to lib/index.js and lib/index.d.ts which don't exist in the published package
cards.proposedFix: Update package.json to reference correct entry points (lib/worker, lib/client, lib/workflow) or provide a proper root index file
cards.workaround: Import from specific subpaths: @temporalio/interceptors-opentelemetry/lib/worker instead of root package
cards.resolutionDetails: Author committed to fixing package.json and provided guidance to import from specific subpaths
cards.keyQuote: There's nothing to import at the root of this package, you should import from `lib/client`, `lib/worker` and `lib/workflow`

cards.summary: Dependency security vulnerability in got-10.7.0 library (CVE-2022-33987) that allows redirects to UNIX sockets. The issue was automatically resolved by Mend when the vulnerable library was removed from the project inventory.
cards.userImpact: Users of the SDK could be exposed to potential integrity attacks through malicious redirects to UNIX sockets if using the vulnerable got library version.
cards.rootCause: got library version 10.7.0 lacked validation for UNIX socket redirects in HTTP requests
cards.proposedFix: Upgrade got library to version 12.0.0-beta.1 or later (11.8.5+ for 11.x branch)
cards.resolutionDetails: The vulnerable dependency was automatically removed or updated in the project, and the issue was auto-closed by Mend when got was no longer part of the dependency inventory.
cards.keyQuote: The got package before 12.1.0 (also fixed in 11.8.5) for Node.js allows a redirect to a UNIX socket.

cards.summary: Dependency vulnerability in got 12.0.3 package (CVE-2022-33987) allowing redirect to UNIX socket. This medium severity issue was automatically resolved by removing the vulnerable library from the project inventory.
cards.userImpact: Users could be vulnerable to attacks exploiting the redirect behavior in the got HTTP library if they depend on affected versions of the testing package.
cards.rootCause: The got package before version 12.1.0 (or 11.8.5) allows HTTP redirects to UNIX sockets, potentially enabling exploitation.
cards.proposedFix: Upgrade got library to version 12.1.0 or 11.8.5 or later
cards.resolutionDetails: Automatically closed by Mend as the vulnerable library was removed from the project dependency inventory or marked as ignored
cards.keyQuote: The got package before 12.1.0 (also fixed in 11.8.5) for Node.js allows a redirect to a UNIX socket.

cards.summary: Prototype Pollution vulnerability (CVE-2022-25878) in protobufjs 6.11.2 transitive dependency of @temporalio/client-1.0.0-rc.0 with CVSS score 7.5. The issue was automatically closed when the vulnerable library was removed from the Mend inventory.
cards.userImpact: Users of @temporalio/client-1.0.0-rc.0 were exposed to a prototype pollution vulnerability that could allow attackers to modify object properties.
cards.rootCause: Protobufjs version 6.11.2 contained a prototype pollution flaw that could be triggered via untrusted user input to util.setProperty or ReflectionObject.setParsedOption functions or by parsing untrusted .proto files.
cards.proposedFix: Upgrade protobufjs to version 6.10.3 or 6.11.3 or later.
cards.resolutionDetails: Issue automatically closed by Mend as the vulnerable library was removed from the inventory, indicating the dependency was updated or removed.
cards.keyQuote: protobufjs before 6.11.3 are vulnerable to Prototype Pollution which can allow an attacker to add/modify properties of the Object.prototype.
