cards.summary: Documentation for the `maxCachedWorkflows` config option incorrectly references a non-existent option `maxIsolateMemoryMB`, creating a broken link in the API documentation.
cards.userImpact: Users viewing the API documentation encounter broken links and references to options that do not exist.
cards.rootCause: The option `maxIsolateMemoryMB` was removed from the codebase but the documentation referencing it was not updated.
cards.proposedFix: Update the documentation to remove the reference to the non-existent `maxIsolateMemoryMB` option.
cards.resolutionDetails: The documentation was corrected to remove the reference to the removed option.
cards.keyQuote: Thanks, we removed this option and forgot to update the docs.

cards.summary: Move NativeConnectionOptions fields (identity and workerBinaryId) from connection-level to worker-level configuration. This requires coordination with Core-side changes.
cards.userImpact: Users need to reconfigure where these connection options are specified, moving them from connection to worker setup.
cards.rootCause: Fields are currently at the wrong API level (connection instead of worker)
cards.proposedFix: Move NativeConnectionOptions.identity and NativeConnectionOptions.workerBinaryId to Worker configuration
cards.resolutionDetails: Fields were moved to worker-level configuration in coordination with Core-side changes
cards.keyQuote: Move these to Worker: NativeConnectionOptions.identity NativeConnectionOptions.workerBinaryId

cards.summary: Feature request to add WorkflowInfo.historySizeInBytes property to the TypeScript SDK. This allows workflows to access the size of their execution history, which was blocked pending server support.
cards.userImpact: Users can now monitor and optimize workflow memory usage by accessing history size information.
cards.proposedFix: Add historySizeInBytes field to WorkflowInfo class once server support is available.
cards.resolutionDetails: Feature was implemented after server support became available and related suggestion (isContinueAsNewSuggested) was also added.
cards.keyQuote: Ready â˜ºï¸

cards.summary: Add WorkflowInfo.runStartTime property to TypeScript SDK to match functionality available in Go and Java SDKs. This provides access to the workflow run start timestamp.
cards.userImpact: TypeScript SDK users cannot access the workflow run start time, limiting visibility into workflow execution timing information available in other SDKs.
cards.proposedFix: Add runStartTime property to WorkflowInfo class, matching the existing getRunStartedTimestampMillis() method in Java SDK.
cards.resolutionDetails: Feature was implemented and merged into the TypeScript SDK.
cards.keyQuote: Add `WorkflowInfo.runStartTime` to match Go and Java SDK functionality

cards.summary: Feature request to implement Rust dependency caching in CI using the rust-cache GitHub Action to improve build times by reducing redundant dependency compilation across builds.
cards.userImpact: Reduces CI build times, enabling faster iteration and deployment cycles for SDK development.
cards.proposedFix: Integrate Swatinem/rust-cache GitHub Action into CI workflow with working-directory option configured.
cards.resolutionDetails: Implemented via PR #864 which integrated the rust-cache action, saving several minutes per build.
cards.keyQuote: I just merged a PR (#864) that uses the action, save a few minutes. Wish we'd done this a while ago..

cards.summary: Module import error in v0.23 where @temporalio/workflow imports from @temporalio/common but @temporalio/common is not declared as a dependency in workflow/package.json, causing 'Cannot find module' errors during builds.
cards.userImpact: Users upgrading from v0.21 to v0.23 encounter build failures when the workflow package cannot locate the required common module.
cards.rootCause: @temporalio/workflow depends on @temporalio/common in its source code but @temporalio/common is not listed as a dependency in workflow/package.json
cards.proposedFix: Add @temporalio/common as a dependency to @temporalio/workflow/package.json
cards.resolutionDetails: Issue #688 was opened to fix the dependency declarations between workflow and common packages
cards.keyQuote: @temporalio/workflow/lib/internals depends on @temporalio/common, but @temporalio/common is not defined as a dependency in workflow/package.json

cards.summary: Worker logs a warning when workflow code imports built-in Node modules instead of failing loudly, making it difficult to detect and debug determinism violations. The issue should fail fast rather than silently continuing.
cards.userImpact: Users may unknowingly deploy workflows that import forbidden modules, only discovering the issue at runtime rather than during startup validation.
cards.rootCause: The bundler detects built-in module imports but only logs a warning instead of throwing an error, allowing the worker to start normally.
cards.proposedFix: Change the warning to a loud failure (throw an error) that prevents worker startup when built-in modules are imported, unless explicitly listed in ignoreModules.
cards.workaround: Add the module names to WorkerOptions.bundlerOptions.ignoreModules if the modules are not actually used at runtime.
cards.resolutionDetails: Worker now fails loudly when workflow code imports built-in Node modules, unless they are explicitly whitelisted in bundlerOptions.ignoreModules.
cards.keyQuote: Workflow code doesn't have access to built-in Node modules (in order to help enforce determinism).

cards.summary: The TypeScript SDK client connection does not send client-name and client-version HTTP headers, unlike the worker connection. This header information is needed for proper client identification and tracking.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot be properly identified and tracked through HTTP headers when using the TypeScript SDK client, limiting observability and debugging capabilities.
cards.rootCause: The client connection implementation is missing the code that sends client-name and client-version headers, which is already implemented in the worker connection.
cards.resolutionDetails: The headers were added to the client connection to match the worker connection implementation.
cards.keyQuote: Only the worker connection does, needs to be applied to the client connection too.

cards.summary: Prototype Pollution vulnerability (CVE-2022-25878) in protobufjs 6.11.2, a transitive dependency of the TypeScript SDK client. The vulnerability allows attackers to modify Object.prototype through untrusted input or .proto file parsing.
cards.userImpact: Users of SDK client 0.23.0 are exposed to a prototype pollution attack via transitive protobufjs dependency.
cards.rootCause: protobufjs version 6.11.2 contains unpatched prototype pollution vulnerability affecting Object.prototype manipulation
cards.proposedFix: Upgrade protobufjs to version 6.10.3 or 6.11.3
cards.resolutionDetails: Automatically closed by Mend as the vulnerable library was resolved or removed from the dependency inventory
cards.keyQuote: protobufjs before 6.11.3 are vulnerable to Prototype Pollution which can allow an attacker to add/modify properties of the Object.prototype

cards.summary: protobufjs dependency version 6.11.2 contains CVE-2022-25878, a prototype pollution vulnerability with CVSS 7.5. The TypeScript SDK shipped with this vulnerable version, but the SDK's usage patterns mitigate the actual risk since it doesn't accept untrusted user input to the affected functions.
cards.userImpact: Users may face security scanning failures and compliance issues due to the flagged vulnerable dependency, despite minimal actual runtime risk in the SDK.
cards.rootCause: protobufjs 6.11.2 is vulnerable to prototype pollution attacks through util.setProperty or ReflectionObject.setParsedOption functions, or by parsing untrusted .proto files.
cards.proposedFix: Upgrade protobufjs to version 6.11.3 or later which contains the fix for CVE-2022-25878.
cards.resolutionDetails: Issue was resolved by upgrading the protobufjs dependency to a patched version, as referenced in PR #789.
cards.keyQuote: This vulnerability can occur...by providing untrusted user input to util.setProperty or to ReflectionObject.setParsedOption functions

cards.summary: Feature request to expose the Initiator enum through WorkflowInfo, allowing workflows to determine whether execution was triggered by retry, continue-as-new, cron, or other mechanisms.
cards.userImpact: Users need visibility into why a workflow execution was initiated to implement conditional logic based on restart cause.
cards.proposedFix: Expose startWorkflow.continueInitiator as WorkflowInfo.more.initiator with the Initiator enum values
cards.keyQuote: One possible use case is determining whether the current Execution was initiated due to retry vs continue as new.

cards.summary: The isReplaying flag needs to be updated to reflect the current execution context in the main thread during workflow replay. This is a follow-up to PR #657 addressing how replay state is communicated.
cards.userImpact: Users may receive incorrect isReplaying values during workflow execution, leading to unexpected behavior in replay detection logic.
cards.rootCause: The isReplaying flag is not properly synchronized with the main thread execution state during workflow replay.
cards.resolutionDetails: Issue was resolved through updates to the replay mechanism to properly track isReplaying state in the main thread context.
cards.keyQuote: Update isReplaying in main thread

cards.summary: Neon 0.8.3 dependency has a use-after-free vulnerability (CVE WS-2022-0133) with CVSS score 7.8. The issue was automatically closed as the vulnerability was either ignored or removed from the Mend inventory.
cards.userImpact: Users of the TypeScript SDK with neon 0.8.3 are exposed to a potential memory safety vulnerability that could be exploited locally to read/write memory.
cards.rootCause: Neon 0.8.3's JsArrayBuffer::external and JsBuffer::external did not require T: 'static, allowing creation of externally backed buffers from types that may be freed while referenced by JavaScript.
cards.proposedFix: Upgrade neon to version 0.10.1 or later
cards.resolutionDetails: Issue was automatically closed by Mend as the vulnerable library was either marked as ignored or removed from inventory, indicating the dependency was addressed or is no longer used.
cards.keyQuote: Use after free in Neon external buffers between 0.8.0 and before 0.10.1

cards.summary: Users find it difficult to mock SDK functions in tests. Current mocking approaches (Jest, Sinon) don't work well with the SDK's export structure, and testing workflows requires setting up a full Worker and test client, which is cumbersome for unit testing.
cards.userImpact: Developers struggle to write simple unit tests for workflows and helper functions without setting up complex Worker infrastructure, leading to slower test iteration and lower test coverage.
cards.rootCause: SDK doesn't provide built-in mocking utilities and the architectural design (no default exports, complex internal state management) makes standard mocking libraries ineffective.
cards.proposedFix: Add built-in mocking support, possibly: 1) allow mocks to be passed directly to Worker.create(), 2) create first-class mocking utilities that work with standard mocking frameworks, 3) support local activities that don't produce markers for mocking child workflows.
cards.workaround: Use a Worker with test connection and mock activities, or register helper functions as workflows and execute them via workflowClient.
cards.keyQuote: Mocking an SDK function is difficult...we'll be working on improving this experience in the future

cards.summary: User encountered a WorkflowNotFoundError when attempting to create a new workflow with the same workflowId as a completed one, even after specifying ALLOW_DUPLICATE policy. The error was ultimately traced to signal() calls rather than workflow creation.
cards.userImpact: Users are unable to reuse workflow IDs for new executions and receive confusing error messages that don't point to the actual root cause.
cards.rootCause: The error was not from starting a new workflow with a duplicate ID, but from calling signal() on a completed workflow execution. The error message was misleading about the actual source.
cards.workaround: Verify that signal() is not being called on completed workflows; the ALLOW_DUPLICATE policy works correctly for starting new workflows.
cards.resolutionDetails: Issue was not a bug in the SDK but user error - the error originated from calling signal() on a completed workflow, not from workflow creation with duplicate IDs.
cards.keyQuote: From `at Object.signal` in the trace, it looks like the error is actually coming from calling `handle.signal()`?

cards.summary: instanceof checks fail on WorkflowInfo fields because the info object is created outside the VM context, causing type checks like `searchAttributes.CustomIntField instanceof Array` to return false.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot reliably determine types of WorkflowInfo fields using instanceof checks, making type-safe code patterns impossible.
cards.rootCause: WorkflowInfo object is created outside the VM context, so instanceof checks against built-in types fail due to different prototype chains.
cards.proposedFix: Serialize WorkflowInfo to JSON and deserialize it within the VM context to ensure proper prototype chains, or provide type-safe accessors.
cards.workaround: Dump to JSON and reconstruct the object within the workflow VM context.
cards.resolutionDetails: The issue was resolved by ensuring WorkflowInfo objects are properly contextualized within the VM so instanceof checks work correctly.
cards.keyQuote: workflowInfo().searchAttributes.CustomIntField instanceof Array returns false since the info object is created outside the vm

cards.summary: Feature request to add validation for retry policy `maxAttempts` parameter to ensure it's an integer and not `Infinity` or other invalid values.
cards.userImpact: Users may accidentally pass invalid values like `Infinity` to `maxAttempts`, which should be caught early with clear validation.
cards.resolutionDetails: Validation was implemented to ensure maxAttempts is a valid integer

cards.summary: ActivityInterface adds a string index signature to any interface that extends it, allowing TypeScript to accept any method call on proxy objects without type checking. This creates a mismatch between compile-time and runtime behavior where invalid method calls compile but fail at runtime.
cards.userImpact: Developers lose type safety when using proxyActivities with custom activity interfaces, allowing invalid method calls to compile and only fail at runtime.
cards.rootCause: ActivityInterface includes a string index signature that gets inherited by any interface extending it, allowing TypeScript to accept arbitrary property access on proxy objects.
cards.proposedFix: Change proxyActivities to return a mapped type that only includes valid ActivityFunction methods, such as using Pick<T, KeysWhere<T, ActivityFunction>> to filter to conforming methods only.
cards.workaround: Use a utility type like ActivityInterfaceFor<T> = Pick<T, keyof {[K in keyof T as T[K] extends ActivityFunction<any[], any> ? K : never]: T[K]}> to wrap the proxy result and provide proper type filtering.
cards.resolutionDetails: Changed the type signature to use a mapped type that filters activities to only those conforming to ActivityFunction, improving type safety and preventing invalid method calls from compiling.
cards.keyQuote: You won't get any completions from the TS language server for undeclared properties but compilation still passes so that's not great

cards.summary: Memory leak caused by accumulation of OperatorSubscriber objects that are not properly cleaned up in the temporal TypeScript worker, leading to out-of-memory container kills. Issue was resolved in an earlier SDK version, though similar symptoms may occur in user code with incorrect AsyncLocalStorage cleanup.
cards.userImpact: Worker containers are killed due to out-of-memory errors caused by accumulating OperatorSubscriber objects that are never cleaned up.
cards.rootCause: OperatorSubscriber objects created on the temporal-worker side were not being properly cleaned up, causing memory accumulation over time.
cards.resolutionDetails: The actual SDK bug from May 2022 was resolved in an earlier version. Similar symptoms reported later were traced to incorrect cleanup of AsyncLocalStorage in user code, leading to issue #1432.
cards.keyQuote: a lot of 'OperatorSubscriber' objects create on temporal-worker side, but it never clean, and it make memory leak problem

cards.summary: Feature request to make documentation breadcrumbs clickable for easier navigation. Currently only the house emoji icon is clickable, but other breadcrumb elements should be interactive.
cards.userImpact: Users must click only the home icon to navigate in docs instead of any breadcrumb element, reducing navigation efficiency.
cards.resolutionDetails: Issue was closed, likely implemented as the feature request was accepted.
cards.keyQuote: Currently only the house emoji is clickable

cards.summary: Expose gRPC static headers support in NativeConnection to match core client capabilities. This feature is already implemented in the core client but needs to be exposed through the NativeConnection API and integrated in the bridge.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot currently set static gRPC headers when using NativeConnection, limiting their ability to customize connection behavior.
cards.proposedFix: Expose the gRPC static headers support that already exists in the core client through the NativeConnection API and hook it up in the bridge.
cards.resolutionDetails: Feature was implemented to expose gRPC static headers through NativeConnection.
cards.keyQuote: This is already supported by the core client, need to expose in NativeConnection and hook it up in the bridge

cards.summary: Feature request to disable GitHub's "require branches to be up to date before merging" requirement for faster PR merging. Currently, every time a PR is merged, all other PRs are blocked and require manual updating and rerunning of checks.
cards.userImpact: Reduces developer friction and PR merge time by eliminating the requirement to update and re-run checks on every PR after another PR is merged.
cards.rootCause: GitHub branch protection rule requiring PRs to be up to date with main before merging causes cascading delays when multiple PRs exist.
cards.proposedFix: Disable the branch protection rule that requires branches to be up to date before merging, accepting the trade-off of potentially discovering test failures on main rather than before merge.
cards.workaround: Manually click 'Update branch' and use 'Enable auto-merge', though this still requires manual intervention for failed checks and can fail if another PR is merged concurrently.
cards.resolutionDetails: The repository maintainer (bergundy) disabled the GitHub branch protection setting as requested.
cards.keyQuote: We uncheck this box... Pro: takes much less time to merge PRs. Con: slightly less safe: delayed knowledge of failure.

cards.summary: The failure type for non-TemporalFailure exceptions is incorrectly set to 'Error' instead of the actual exception class name. When throwing a custom error that extends Error (but not TemporalFailure), the type should reflect the actual class name like 'MyFailure' rather than the parent 'Error' class.
cards.userImpact: Users debugging failures see incorrect type information, making it harder to identify which custom error was thrown in workflows.
cards.rootCause: The code likely uses a method that returns the parent class name (Error) instead of accessing the actual constructor name through the prototype chain.
cards.proposedFix: Use `err.__proto__.constructor.name` to get the actual exception class name instead of the parent class name.
cards.resolutionDetails: The issue was identified as occurring in failure.ts at line 360, with a proposed fix to use the prototype constructor name.
cards.keyQuote: We could take `err.__proto__.constructor.name`

cards.summary: When non-Error objects are thrown in workflows (e.g., `throw {a: 'test'}`), the error message shows `[object Object]` instead of the serialized object value. The issue involves proper serialization and safe handling of non-Error values thrown from user code.
cards.userImpact: Users who throw non-Error objects receive unclear error messages that don't help them debug issues.
cards.rootCause: JSON.stringify() was being used for serialization, but can fail with certain object types (e.g., BigInt) and doesn't provide clear output for plain objects.
cards.proposedFix: Wrap JSON.stringify with error handling or use a safer serialization method that handles edge cases like BigInt without throwing.
cards.resolutionDetails: Fixed with PR #467, which properly serializes non-Error objects and includes a helpful message recommending throwing Error objects.
cards.keyQuote: It should be `{a: "test"} [A non-Error value was thrown from your code. We recommend throwing Error objects so that we can provide a stack trace.]`

cards.summary: Feature request to support loading workflow execution history from tctl/web JSON exports in the replayer by leveraging proto JSON serialization with json-module output.
cards.userImpact: Users can replay workflow histories exported from tctl/web UI without manual conversion, improving testing and debugging workflows.
cards.proposedFix: Use proto JSON serialization to load history from tctl/web JSON exports directly in the replayer
cards.resolutionDetails: Feature was implemented and marked as done
cards.keyQuote: Now that we're compiling our protos using `json-module` output we should be able to use proper proto json serialization.

cards.summary: OpenTelemetry interceptors package modifies the global object to add a `window` property when imported, affecting code outside the workflow isolate that depends on `typeof window === "undefined"` checks. This breaks existing Node.js projects that use this common pattern to detect browser vs server environments.
cards.userImpact: Existing Node.js projects that rely on `typeof window === "undefined"` for environment detection break when using OpenTelemetry interceptors, as the global `window` property is added outside the workflow isolate.
cards.rootCause: The OpenTelemetry interceptors modify the global object to add a `window` property for workflow isolate compatibility, but this modification happens during import and affects the entire Node.js process rather than being scoped to the workflow isolate.
cards.proposedFix: Scope the global modifications to only affect code inside the workflow isolate, or avoid modifying globals altogether.
cards.keyQuote: This modification may be necessary within the workflow isolate, but this code is also required outside the workflow isolate when just booting the worker

cards.summary: Tests cannot run from GitHub forks due to a regression in the test infrastructure. This breaks CI/CD pipelines for external contributors.
cards.userImpact: External contributors cannot run tests on their forks, blocking pull request validation.
cards.resolutionDetails: Issue was fixed by lorensr before this issue was closed.
cards.keyQuote: We have a regression in our tests where we can no longer run tests from forks

cards.summary: Jest test isolation causes `ShutdownError: Core is shut down` errors when running multiple Temporal test files simultaneously in the same process. The root cause is module duplication where different test files get separate copies of the errors module, causing incompatibility issues.
cards.userImpact: Developers using Jest to test Temporal workflows encounter inconsistent shutdown errors when running multiple test files, preventing reliable integration testing.
cards.rootCause: Jest's module isolation creates separate copies of the Temporal module in different test files, causing one file's copy of the errors module to be incompatible with another file's copy, leading to Core shutdown errors.
cards.proposedFix: Export and handle errors consistently across module instances to prevent type mismatches caused by Jest's module duplication during test isolation.
cards.workaround: https://github.com/airhorns/sdk-typescript/commit/3955acdd638b2d0e5c2e7c736f1bbd19a8d4549e - manual fix by ensuring consistent error module references across test files.
cards.resolutionDetails: Fixed via PR that addressed the root cause of module duplication and error handling consistency across Jest test isolation boundaries.
cards.keyQuote: The root cause looks like one file's copy of the Temporal module is getting another file's copy of `errors`.

cards.summary: Calling `setHandler(signal, undefined)` to clear a signal handler while buffered signals exist causes a heap out of memory crash. The bug occurs because `setHandler` iterates over buffered signals and re-processes them, but when the handler is undefined, they get pushed back into the same buffer being iterated, creating an infinite loop.
cards.userImpact: Users implementing wait-for-single-signal patterns cannot safely clear handlers while signals are buffered, leading to application crashes.
cards.rootCause: setHandler iterates over buffered signals and calls signalWorkflow for each one. When handler is undefined, signalWorkflow pushes the signal back into the same buffer being iterated, creating an infinite loop.
cards.proposedFix: Move state.bufferedSignals.delete(def.name) before the for loop and skip processing buffered signals if the new handler is undefined: `if (bufferedSignals !== undefined && handler !== undefined)`
cards.workaround: Users can avoid clearing handlers from within signal handlers, or wait for the handler to be cleared from outside the signal context.
cards.resolutionDetails: The proposed fix was accepted and implemented to prevent buffer iteration issues when handlers are set to undefined.
cards.keyQuote: setHandler iterates over buffered signals and try to process each one. To do so, it calls signalWorkflow, which checks if a handler for that signal is actually defined. Now, since our handler is undefined, signalWorkflow instead push the signal occurence to the corresponding signal buffer. Turns out that this is the very same array over which setHandler is iterating.

cards.summary: Sink API creates circular JSON structures when passing data between workflow and sink threads via postMessage, causing JSON.stringify() to fail with circular reference error on the receiving end.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot serialize sink data with JSON.stringify() on the receiving end, limiting debugging and data processing capabilities.
cards.rootCause: The postMessage API used for communication between workflow worker thread and main thread creates circular structures in complex data objects during serialization/deserialization.
cards.workaround: Stringify the data on the sending end before passing it through the sink instead of stringifying on the receiving end.
cards.resolutionDetails: Acknowledged as a limitation of Node.js postMessage API used for thread communication; workaround suggested instead of fixing.
cards.keyQuote: This is a limitation of the postMessage API. We use this API because the workflow runs in a worker thread and the sink function runs on the main Node.js thread.

cards.summary: Worker threads in the TypeScript SDK use round-robin dispatch for workflows, which can lead to unbalanced load distribution. Implementing a least-loaded worker selection strategy would improve thread utilization and overall system balance.
cards.userImpact: Unbalanced worker threads can cause some threads to become overloaded while others remain underutilized, reducing throughput and increasing latency for workflow execution.
cards.rootCause: Current round-robin dispatcher does not account for workflow eviction, leading to unbalanced thread loads over time.
cards.proposedFix: Refactor dispatcher to select worker thread with least number of active workflows instead of using round-robin allocation.
cards.resolutionDetails: Implemented least-loaded worker selection strategy to replace round-robin dispatch mechanism.
cards.keyQuote: A simple refactoring of this dispatcher to choose the worker thread with least workflows would improve the overall balancing of work between the threads.

cards.summary: Update TypeScript SDK Connection to eagerly connect with getSystemInfo RPC call. Make Connection constructor private and add async Connection.create() factory method. Update WorkflowClient to require a Connection instance and add WorkflowClient.forLocalHost() helper.
cards.userImpact: Users will need to use async factory methods to create connections and clients, enabling proper system info discovery and metadata/timeout handling.
cards.proposedFix: Make Connection.create() an async factory, make Connection constructor private, require Connection in WorkflowClient constructor, add WorkflowClient.forLocalHost() helper, and expose connection via client.connection property.
cards.resolutionDetails: Feature was implemented as requested with Connection.create() factory and WorkflowClient updates.
cards.keyQuote: Connection constructor will become private and instead we'll expose an async factory: Connection.create().

cards.summary: Test environment tests fail intermittently on Windows with Node 14, causing CI failures during test execution. The issue appears to be environment-specific flakiness rather than a fundamental bug.
cards.userImpact: Developers on Windows encounter intermittent test failures in CI pipelines, reducing confidence in test results.
cards.workaround: Tests were skipped to work around the failures.
cards.resolutionDetails: No recent occurrences reported; maintainer indicated issue hasn't been seen in a while and appears to have resolved naturally.
cards.keyQuote: I haven't seen these in a while.

cards.summary: Custom logger passed to Runtime.install() wasn't being used by webpack for build-time logging. Webpack logs were emitted via console.error instead of flowing through the configured logger entry function.
cards.userImpact: Users unable to centralize webpack build logs through their custom logging infrastructure, breaking log aggregation and formatting consistency.
cards.rootCause: Webpack logger doesn't use the installed Runtime logger; logs are emitted directly via console.error instead of going through the configured entry function.
cards.workaround: Manually call bundleWorkflowCode instead of relying on Worker.create's automatic bundling, though this doesn't require instantiating the Runtime.
cards.resolutionDetails: Issue was confirmed to have been fixed in a later version; webpack output now routes through the custom logger when Worker.create initiates bundling.
cards.keyQuote: Logs are emitted using `console.error`, instead of the custom entry function passed to the `DefaultLogger` passed to `Runtime.install`

cards.summary: Automated security vulnerability scan detected 9 vulnerabilities in transitive dependencies of the core package beta 18, with the highest severity being 7.8 (CVE-2021-43138 in async library). The issue was automatically closed when the vulnerable dependencies were removed from the inventory.
cards.userImpact: Users of the SDK were potentially exposed to security vulnerabilities in transitive dependencies used in development and documentation builds.
cards.rootCause: Outdated transitive dependencies in webpack-dev-server, cli-table3, mdx-loader and other build/dev tools contained known CVEs including prototype pollution and ReDoS vulnerabilities.
cards.proposedFix: Upgrade vulnerable dependencies: async to 2.6.4 or 3.2.2, ansi-regex to 5.0.1 or 6.0.1, trim to latest, node-forge to patched version, minimist to 1.2.6+, nth-check to 2.0.1+, and got to 11.8.5+.
cards.resolutionDetails: Issue was automatically closed by Mend as the vulnerable libraries were no longer part of the inventory, indicating they were updated or removed from dependencies.
cards.keyQuote: This issue was automatically closed by Mend because the vulnerable library in the specific branch(es) was either marked as ignored or it is no longer part of the Mend inventory.

cards.summary: Request to ensure only a single version of @temporalio/workflow is loaded into the workflow runtime. Multiple library versions cause failures because workflow state is stored in module static variables.
cards.userImpact: Users with libraries depending on different versions of @temporalio/workflow encounter runtime failures due to incompatible state management.
cards.rootCause: Workflow state is stored in module static variables, making it incompatible with multiple versions loaded simultaneously
cards.keyQuote: We've seen cases where a library depends on a different version of our runtime which is not supported because we store workflow state in a module static variable.

cards.summary: Feature request to rename the 'codec' configuration option to 'codecs' in the TypeScript SDK for consistency and clarity.
cards.userImpact: Users would benefit from more intuitive naming that better reflects that multiple codecs can be used.
cards.proposedFix: Rename the 'codec' property to 'codecs' in the SDK configuration.
cards.resolutionDetails: The codec configuration was renamed to codecs to better represent multiple codec support.

cards.summary: Request to add UpsertSearchAttributes functionality to the TypeScript SDK for updating search attributes on running workflows.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot update search attributes on running workflows in TypeScript, limiting their ability to modify workflow metadata dynamically.
cards.resolutionDetails: Feature was implemented and issue closed

cards.summary: Transitive dependency minimist-1.2.5 has critical prototype pollution vulnerability (CVE-2021-44906) with CVSS 9.8 score. The vulnerability exists in swc-loader via loader-utils and json5 dependencies.
cards.userImpact: Applications using the TypeScript SDK are vulnerable to remote prototype pollution attacks through the minimist dependency chain.
cards.rootCause: minimist library version 1.2.5 vulnerable to prototype pollution via setKey() function in index.js (lines 69-95)
cards.proposedFix: Upgrade minimist to version 1.2.6 or higher
cards.resolutionDetails: Issue was automatically closed by WhiteSource as the vulnerable library was removed from the dependency tree or marked as ignored in inventory
cards.keyQuote: Minimist <=1.2.5 is vulnerable to Prototype Pollution via file index.js, function setKey() (lines 69-95).

cards.summary: Feature request to rename the `nonRetryable` boolean parameter to `retryable` with inverted default in SDK constructors for improved code readability. The request was rejected due to backwards compatibility concerns.
cards.userImpact: Rejected feature that would have simplified code readability but required users to update parameter usage during SDK upgrades.
cards.proposedFix: Rename `nonRetryable` parameter to `retryable` with default value changed from false to true
cards.resolutionDetails: Declined due to backwards compatibility concerns; maintainers determined the breaking change burden on users outweighs the readability improvement
cards.keyQuote: If we change this now it'd be a critical backwards incompatible change. I think it's too late at this point.

cards.summary: Parent workflow remains stuck in Running state when child workflow fails with WorkflowExecutionAlreadyStartedError, preventing the parent from exiting even after child completes and is restarted.
cards.userImpact: Workflows get stuck indefinitely when attempting to spawn child workflows with duplicate IDs, requiring manual intervention to recover.
cards.rootCause: WorkflowExecutionAlreadyStartedError is thrown as Error instead of TemporalFailure, causing the workflow task to fail without properly failing the workflow execution.
cards.proposedFix: Make WorkflowExecutionAlreadyStartedError extend TemporalFailure so it fails the workflow execution instead of just the task.
cards.resolutionDetails: WorkflowExecutionAlreadyStartedError was changed to extend TemporalFailure to properly fail the workflow instead of the workflow task.
cards.keyQuote: WorkflowExecutionAlreadyStartedError should extend TemporalFailure and fail the workflow.

cards.summary: TransportError exceptions lack detailed error information and stack traces, making it difficult to troubleshoot connection issues to Temporal clusters. Users need better diagnostics to identify root causes like missing CA certificates, incorrect server addresses, or missing/invalid TLS certificates.
cards.userImpact: Users struggle to diagnose and fix connection problems because TransportError provides insufficient context about the underlying cause.
cards.rootCause: TransportError exceptions mask lower-level connection errors without surfacing detailed error information or stack traces.
cards.proposedFix: Surface lower-level error information and stack traces in TransportError to help users identify the specific connection problem.
cards.workaround: Refer to documentation on CA certificate installation and valid server addresses (localhost:7233 vs host.docker.internal:7233).
cards.resolutionDetails: The issue was resolved by improving error details in TransportError reporting.
cards.keyQuote: It's hard to troubleshoot TransportErrors because they can be associated with any kind of problems when establishing a connection to a Temporal cluster.

cards.summary: Client process exits with status 0 when calling start() or execute() with an unresolvable DNS address, instead of rejecting the promise with an error.
cards.userImpact: Users experience silent process termination instead of proper error handling when DNS resolution fails, making debugging difficult.
cards.rootCause: Issue in makeGrpcRetryInterceptor, specifically at line 103 in grpc-retry.ts that causes improper error handling for unresolvable addresses.
cards.proposedFix: Fix the interceptor logic; connection constructor will be changed to async factory soon which will resolve this issue.
cards.workaround: Setting interceptors to an empty array causes the call to fail with a ServiceError as expected.
cards.resolutionDetails: Issue no longer occurs after upgrading grpc-js.
cards.keyQuote: Setting the Connection address to an address that won't resolve causes subsequent start and execute calls from the client to exit the process.

cards.summary: Feature request to return workflow status as a human-readable string instead of a gRPC enum number in WorkflowExecutionDescription. Currently users must build wrappers to translate numeric status codes to meaningful strings.
cards.userImpact: Users currently need to write wrapper code to convert numeric workflow status codes to human-readable strings when calling handle.describe().
cards.proposedFix: Change WorkflowExecutionDescription.status from a numeric enum to a string union type like 'Canceled' | 'Completed' | 'Continued_As_New' | 'Failed' | etc.
cards.workaround: Build a wrapper around handle.describe() response to manually translate gRPC codes to meaningful status strings.
cards.resolutionDetails: Feature was accepted and implemented to return workflow status as a string type instead of numeric gRPC enum.
cards.keyQuote: Return a string type to represent status in the WorkflowExecutionDescription.

cards.summary: Automated security report identifying 8 vulnerabilities in transitive dependencies of the core package, with the highest severity being 7.8 (CVE-2021-43138 in async library). The issue was automatically closed when the vulnerable dependencies were removed or updated.
cards.userImpact: Users are exposed to multiple high-severity security vulnerabilities through transitive dependencies in the SDK, potentially affecting the confidentiality, integrity, and availability of applications using this version.
cards.rootCause: Outdated transitive dependencies (async-2.6.3, node-forge-1.2.1, ansi-regex, trim, nth-check, shelljs) with known CVEs were included in the build.
cards.proposedFix: Upgrade vulnerable libraries: async to v3.2.2, ansi-regex to 5.0.1/6.0.1, node-forge to a patched version, and update other affected dependencies (trim, nth-check, shelljs).
cards.resolutionDetails: Automatically closed by WhiteSource when vulnerable dependencies were removed or updated in the inventory.
cards.keyQuote: Found 8 vulnerabilities (highest severity is: 7.8) - This issue was automatically closed by WhiteSource because the vulnerable library in the specific branch(es) was either marked as ignored or it is no longer part of the WhiteSource inventory.

cards.summary: Three transitive dependencies in the Rust core-bridge package contain security vulnerabilities (2 high severity DoS issues in rustls-webpki and 1 medium severity memory issue in rustix). This is an automated security alert that was repeatedly opened and closed as dependencies were updated.
cards.userImpact: Users of the TypeScript SDK are vulnerable to CPU denial of service attacks via crafted certificate paths and potential memory exhaustion through directory iteration.
cards.rootCause: Outdated transitive dependencies (rustls-webpki-0.100.1 and rustix-0.37.20) containing known security vulnerabilities in certificate validation and filesystem operations.
cards.proposedFix: Upgrade rustls-webpki to version 0.100.2 or 0.101.4, and rustix to a patched version. Update remove_dir_all to ^0.8.0 as mentioned in comments.
cards.resolutionDetails: Issue was resolved through dependency updates. The automated Mend scanner repeatedly confirmed closure as vulnerable libraries were removed from the inventory.
cards.keyQuote: Can the remove_dir_all be updated to ^0.8.0 as this will fix the vulnerability. Latest version of remove_dir_all has been updated a week ago

cards.summary: Transitive dependency vulnerability in json5 package exposes minimist-1.2.5 with CVE-2021-44906, a prototype pollution vulnerability with CVSS score of 9.8. The vulnerability was automatically closed after the library was removed from the dependency inventory.
cards.userImpact: Users are exposed to a critical prototype pollution vulnerability in a transitive dependency that could allow arbitrary code execution.
cards.rootCause: Minimist <=1.2.5 contains a prototype pollution vulnerability in the setKey() function (lines 69-95 in index.js) that allows network-based attacks without authentication.
cards.proposedFix: Upgrade minimist from 1.2.5 to 1.2.6 or later.
cards.resolutionDetails: Issue was automatically closed by WhiteSource after the vulnerable library was either marked as ignored or removed from the dependency inventory in the main branch.
cards.keyQuote: Minimist <=1.2.5 is vulnerable to Prototype Pollution via file index.js, function setKey() (lines 69-95).

cards.summary: TypeDoc 0.21.6 contains transitive vulnerability in marked library (CVE-2022-21681 and CVE-2022-21680) with CVSS score of 7.5, causing potential ReDoS attacks through malicious markdown input.
cards.userImpact: Users running untrusted markdown through the documentation toolchain are vulnerable to denial of service attacks via catastrophic backtracking in regular expressions.
cards.rootCause: Regular expressions `inline.reflinkSearch` and `block.def` in marked 2.1.3 exhibit catastrophic backtracking behavior against certain input strings.
cards.proposedFix: Upgrade typedoc to version 0.22.11 or marked to version 4.0.10
cards.workaround: Avoid running untrusted markdown through marked or run marked on a worker thread with a reasonable time limit to prevent resource exhaustion.
cards.resolutionDetails: Issue was automatically closed by WhiteSource as the vulnerable library was either ignored or is no longer part of the inventory, indicating the dependency has been updated or removed.
cards.keyQuote: Marked is a markdown parser and compiler. Prior to version 4.0.10, the regular expression may cause catastrophic backtracking and lead to a denial of service (DoS).

cards.summary: Transitive dependency vulnerability in css-what (CVE-2021-33587) with CVSS 7.5 severity affecting webpack build. The vulnerability allows ReDoS attacks through malformed CSS selectors with quadratic time complexity.
cards.userImpact: Users with the TypeScript SDK build tooling are exposed to a denial-of-service vulnerability through malformed CSS selector parsing.
cards.rootCause: css-what package versions 4.0.0-5.0.0 lack linear time complexity guarantees for attribute parsing, enabling ReDoS attacks.
cards.proposedFix: Upgrade @svgr/webpack to version 6.0.0-alpha.0 or later, which updates css-what to 5.0.1 or higher.
cards.resolutionDetails: Automatically resolved by WhiteSource; the vulnerable library was either marked as ignored or removed from inventory.
cards.keyQuote: The css-what package 4.0.0 through 5.0.0 for Node.js does not ensure that attribute parsing has Linear Time Complexity

cards.summary: Transitive dependency vulnerability in qs 6.5.3 (CVE-2021-44907) via lerna causes a Denial of Service risk due to insufficient property sanitization in query parsing. The issue was automatically closed after the vulnerable library was removed from inventory.
cards.userImpact: Users are exposed to a potential Denial of Service attack through a vulnerable transitive dependency in the query string parser.
cards.rootCause: Insufficient sanitization of properties in qs.parse() function allowing array property assignment to be converted to objects, potentially causing DoS.
cards.proposedFix: Upgrade qs from 6.5.3 to 6.8.1 or later to address CVE-2021-44907.
cards.resolutionDetails: The vulnerable library was removed from the WhiteSource inventory and the dependency chain was updated, eliminating the transitive dependency on the vulnerable qs version.
cards.keyQuote: A Denial of Service vulnerability exists in qs up to 6.8.0 due to insufficient sanitization of property in the gs.parse function.

cards.summary: Activity.heartbeat() in TypeScript SDK takes a single parameter but should accept an array of Payloads to match the Core SDK specification and be consistent with Go's varargs implementation.
cards.userImpact: Users may have incorrect heartbeat behavior if the API signature doesn't match the Core SDK specification, and SDK consistency is broken across languages.
cards.rootCause: TypeScript SDK copied Java's single-argument implementation instead of Go's varargs approach, while Core SDK explicitly defines heartbeat_details as repeated.
cards.proposedFix: Change Context.heartbeat() to accept an array of Payloads to match Core SDK specification and Go implementation.
cards.keyQuote: Core explicitly makes `coresdk.ActivityHeartbeat.details` a `repeated`. I think if we do want to limit to just one, we should do it in Core too.

cards.summary: Feature request to improve ApplicationFailure API by using an options object instead of positional parameters. The proposal suggests making the constructor accept a configuration object with optional message, type, retryable (instead of nonRetryable), and cause fields, along with a static helper method for creating non-retryable failures.
cards.userImpact: Improves code readability and reduces confusion when creating ApplicationFailure instances by using named parameters instead of positional arguments.
cards.proposedFix: Change ApplicationFailure constructor to accept an options object with message, type, retryable (positive boolean instead of negated nonRetryable), and cause fields. Add ApplicationFailure.nonRetryable() static helper method.
cards.resolutionDetails: Maintainer decided the API change was too late to implement due to backward compatibility concerns.
cards.keyQuote: It's way too late to change now IMO, can we close this?

cards.summary: Request to versionize documentation and API reference for the TypeScript SDK so that users can access documentation matching their installed version, rather than always seeing the latest development version.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot easily access documentation that matches the version of the SDK they are using, creating confusion when API differences exist between versions.
cards.rootCause: Current documentation is always built from the main branch and deployed as a single version, not tied to released versions of the SDK.
cards.proposedFix: Implement versioned documentation system where each release gets its own documentation version, potentially deployed from the release branch instead of main for API reference.
cards.workaround: Users can build and view documentation locally by cloning the repository, checking out a specific version tag, and running the build process locally.
cards.keyQuote: Relevant both for docs and API reference. And latest version of API ref could be deployed from `release` branch instead of `main`

cards.summary: WithWorkflowArgs type was removed from @temporalio/common and is not exported from @temporalio/client, breaking code that relies on this type for strong typing in SignalWithStart client calls.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot import WithWorkflowArgs from expected packages, forcing them to use internal imports as a workaround.
cards.rootCause: Type was removed from public API exports during refactoring without proper re-export or migration path
cards.proposedFix: Re-export WithWorkflowArgs from @temporalio/client as suggested in CHANGELOG instructions
cards.workaround: Import directly from @temporalio/internal-workflow-common
cards.resolutionDetails: Type was re-exported from the appropriate public package
cards.keyQuote: This type used to be exported under @temporalio/common, but no longer is. It's also not available in @temporalio/client

cards.summary: Move CI/CD builds from BuildKite to GitHub Actions for better public visibility and to work around a BuildKite docker-compose plugin bug affecting nightly jobs.
cards.userImpact: This improves build transparency and reliability for contributors and users following the project's CI status.
cards.rootCause: BuildKite docker-compose plugin bug causing nightly job failures
cards.proposedFix: Migrate both per-change and nightly build jobs from BuildKite to GitHub Actions once self-hosted runners are available
cards.resolutionDetails: The migration was completed as indicated by the author's comment 'This was done already'
cards.keyQuote: Once we get self hosted GH actions runners, we should move those jobs for better public visibility.

cards.summary: Request to implement a remote codec converter for TypeScript SDK, equivalent to the Go SDK's NewRemoteDataConverter functionality for encoding/decoding workflow data.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot use remote codec converters in TypeScript SDK, limiting their ability to implement centralized encoding/decoding strategies.
cards.proposedFix: Implement RemoteDataConverter equivalent matching Go SDK's NewRemoteDataConverter API and functionality.
cards.keyQuote: Add the equivalent of `NewRemoteDataConverter` in Go

cards.summary: Users get confusing error messages when using Workflow APIs (like condition or sleep) outside of the workflow VM context, such as in Activities. The error messages don't clearly indicate the underlying problem, causing confusion about what's wrong.
cards.userImpact: Users are unable to quickly identify why they're getting runtime errors when accidentally using Workflow APIs in Activities, leading to time wasted debugging.
cards.rootCause: Workflow APIs are only available within the workflow VM context. When called outside this context, the error message doesn't clearly explain that the API was used in the wrong execution context.
cards.proposedFix: Provide better error messages that explicitly indicate when Workflow APIs are being used outside of the VM context.
cards.resolutionDetails: Error messages were improved to provide clearer guidance when Workflow APIs are used outside the VM context.
cards.keyQuote: user using `import { sleep } from '@temporalio/workflow';` in an Activity, getting IllegalStateError, and not knowing what's wrong

cards.summary: Windows test suite intermittently exits with code 1 despite all tests passing, with missing test output suggesting a test timeout or pending test issue on that platform.
cards.userImpact: CI builds fail unexpectedly on Windows even when all tests pass, causing false negatives in the test suite.
cards.rootCause: Test framework timeout or pending test handling issue specific to Windows platform causing non-zero exit code despite successful test execution.
cards.resolutionDetails: Issue resolved through improvements to test handling; hasn't been observed in subsequent runs.
cards.keyQuote: Sometimes on Windows this happens, where no tests fail, but exit code is 1

cards.summary: Feature request to simplify protobuf payload converter usage by leveraging protobufjs's global module.roots field instead of requiring users to pass a root argument. This would reduce configuration complexity but requires compatible package manager setup and duplicate message name handling.
cards.userImpact: Users would have simpler protobuf integration without needing to pass root arguments to converters, but the feature was not completed due to bundle size concerns.
cards.rootCause: Bundle size bloat when importing protobufjs/light directly into the default payload converter (increasing from 0.25 to 0.5 MB).
cards.proposedFix: Use protobufjs global module.roots field to discover proto definitions instead of requiring explicit root argument, with requirements for package manager deduplication and pbjs code generation.
cards.resolutionDetails: Feature was not completed due to bundle size implications. Importing protobufjs/light would double bundle size, and webpack integration would require complex hacks to conditionally load the dependency.
cards.keyQuote: It requires importing `protobufjs/light`, which doubles the bundle size (.25 to .5 MB)

cards.summary: Snip comments are not displaying correctly in the generated API documentation, preventing documentation snippets from appearing as expected in the docusaurus-generated API docs.
cards.userImpact: Users viewing the API documentation see incomplete or missing code snippets and comments, reducing documentation clarity and usability.
cards.keyQuote: Snip comments don't show up in API docs

cards.summary: Worker starts successfully without any workflows or activities configured, making it difficult to debug. Request to either require at least one workflow/activity/workflowsPath option at type level or add warning logging.
cards.userImpact: Users can unknowingly deploy workers with no workflows/activities configured, causing silent failures that are difficult to debug.
cards.rootCause: Worker options make both workflowsPath and workflowBundle optional, allowing workers to start without any work available.
cards.proposedFix: Either enforce type-level requirement using RequireAtLeastOne utility type, or add warning logs when no workflows/activities are registered.
cards.workaround: Add logging output to show what activities or workflows the worker was able to find during startup.
cards.resolutionDetails: Warning messages for 'no workflows registered' and 'no activity registered' were implemented in PR #808.
cards.keyQuote: The worker happily starts up and does not pick up any work since it's not aware of any workflows it can run. This can be painful to debug.

cards.summary: Feature request to make the `create` command's post-installation instructions more intelligent by detecting the platform and checking if dependencies like docker-compose, Temporal Server, and Node.js are already installed before displaying setup instructions.
cards.userImpact: Users would see only relevant setup instructions for their specific platform and environment, reducing unnecessary output and confusion.
cards.proposedFix: Support templating in .post-create file (handlebars/ejs) or replace with .post-create.js script for conditional logic.
cards.resolutionDetails: Team decided the package initializer was already complex enough and that the custom template approach was sufficient for maintainability.
cards.keyQuote: I think our package initializer is complex enough as is. The custom template is more than enough imho.

cards.summary: The aarch64-unknown-linux-gnu binary release is 228 MB, significantly larger than other platform builds. The issue was resolved by automating the build process for this target in GitHub Actions instead of building on macOS.
cards.userImpact: Reduced download size for users installing the TypeScript SDK on aarch64 Linux systems.
cards.rootCause: Building the aarch64-unknown-linux-gnu target on macOS resulted in larger binary artifacts compared to building on the target platform.
cards.proposedFix: Automate the aarch64-unknown-linux-gnu build in GitHub Actions.
cards.resolutionDetails: Automated build for aarch64-unknown-linux-gnu target in GitHub Actions (GHA) instead of cross-compiling from macOS.
cards.keyQuote: 228 MB is too large... Increased size was due to us building for this target on MacOS. Need to automate this build.

cards.summary: Add a test for the TypeScript SDK that verifies heartbeat details are preserved across activity retries, similar to the existing Python test that checks heartbeat details are correctly carried forward through multiple retry attempts.
cards.userImpact: Ensures developers can rely on heartbeat details being preserved during activity retries, enabling proper state recovery and progress tracking.
cards.proposedFix: Implement a test similar to the Python version that sets heartbeat details, increments them on each retry, and verifies exact retry count and final value.
cards.resolutionDetails: Addressed in issue #523
cards.keyQuote: I just set the details and add 9 each time and have an expected count. It specifically tests multiple retries and makes sure that it does the _exact_ number of retries so a heartbeat isn't missed.

cards.summary: Feature request to allow customization of the webpack configuration used for bundling Temporal workflows in the TypeScript SDK. Users need flexibility to apply webpack plugins, overrides, and custom configurations for various use cases.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot customize webpack configuration for advanced bundling needs like using webpack plugins (e.g., DefinePlugin) or configuring absolute paths.
cards.rootCause: The SDK has a fixed webpack configuration with limited extensibility points, preventing users from applying custom webpack overrides or plugins.
cards.proposedFix: Add an optional webpackConfigOverrides property or override function to BundleOptions that allows users to merge with or modify the default webpack configuration, similar to how Gatsby handles custom webpack config.
cards.resolutionDetails: The issue was addressed by implementing webpack configuration customization capabilities in the SDK bundler.
cards.keyQuote: Allow users to apply more generic overrides to the Webpack config...merged with the default/calculated Webpack configuration

cards.summary: When using ts-node with swc-loader, the bundler sometimes includes regenerator-runtime in the webpack bundle even though it's not needed for Node 14+ target, causing module resolution failures. The issue was resolved by including swc-loader in the SDK.
cards.userImpact: Users experience webpack build failures when running workers with ts-node using @temporalio/create due to unresolved regenerator-runtime dependency.
cards.rootCause: swc-loader was transforming generators and async functions to include regenerator-runtime even when the build target (Node 14+) supports them natively; issue was in upstream swc project but workaround needed in SDK configuration.
cards.proposedFix: Set swc-loader target to at least ES2017 to prevent unnecessary regenerator-runtime inclusion, as demonstrated in swc playground.
cards.workaround: Add regenerator-runtime as a devDependency to resolve the module not found error.
cards.resolutionDetails: swc-loader was included in version 0.20.2 with proper configuration to prevent regenerator-runtime from being unnecessarily bundled.
cards.keyQuote: swc-loader included in 0.20.2

cards.summary: The test-npm-init test hangs during the 'Test run a workflow' step with no output, causing CI failures. The issue was resolved by PR #535.
cards.userImpact: Test suite hangs during workflow execution testing, blocking CI/CD pipelines and preventing release validation.
cards.resolutionDetails: Fixed by PR #535
cards.keyQuote: On step `Test run a workflow`, but there's no output

cards.summary: The test-worker-no-workflows test intermittently fails with a GracefulShutdownPeriodExpiredError timeout while waiting for the worker to shut down gracefully, occurring some of the time during integration test runs.
cards.userImpact: Developers experience flaky test runs due to intermittent worker shutdown timeouts, making test suite reliability uncertain.
cards.resolutionDetails: The worker shutdown process has changed significantly since initial report, and the error has not been observed recently, indicating the issue was resolved through architectural improvements.
cards.keyQuote: Haven't seen this error recently. Also, the Worker shutdown process has changed a lot since this was initially reported, so it seems very reasonable to think that this has already been fixed.

cards.summary: CI tests are being skipped with 'No tests found' errors in the TypeScript SDK build pipeline. The issue manifests in the Windows CI environment, particularly affecting integration and codec tests.
cards.userImpact: Developers cannot verify that their code changes work correctly because CI tests are silently skipped instead of running.
cards.rootCause: Issue with core build preventing tests from being found and executed in the CI environment
cards.resolutionDetails: Maintainer closed the issue indicating the root cause was no longer relevant or had been addressed separately
cards.keyQuote: I don't remember what this is anymore, closing.

cards.summary: Activity not found and activity argument conversion errors are currently marked as non-retryable in the TypeScript SDK, but should be retryable to align with behavior in other Temporal SDKs.
cards.userImpact: Activities fail permanently when encountering not-found or conversion errors instead of being retried according to the retry policy, inconsistent with other SDK implementations.
cards.rootCause: Activity not found and activity arg conversion errors are hardcoded as non-retryable in worker.ts lines 474 and 496, while other SDKs treat them as retryable.
cards.proposedFix: Reclassify activity not found and argument conversion errors as retryable to match behavior in other Temporal SDKs.
cards.resolutionDetails: Issue was addressed by making these error types retryable in the TypeScript SDK to align with other SDK implementations.
cards.keyQuote: this should be a retryable error

cards.summary: Webpack bundling of workflow code fails when transitive dependencies pull in Node.js built-in modules or native code. The bundler incorrectly tries to resolve these modules, causing build failures even when they're not actually used at runtime.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot bundle workflow code that transitively depends on packages that use Node.js built-ins or native code, blocking legitimate use cases with monorepos and certain dependencies.
cards.rootCause: Webpack defaults to browser target and tries to resolve all imported modules, including Node.js built-ins and native packages that aren't actually needed in the workflow sandbox context.
cards.proposedFix: Add `target: 'node'` to webpack config, allow users to specify ignored modules via `BundleOptions.ignoreModules`, or provide webpack config override hooks. Stub modules approach used successfully for `assert` could be extended.
cards.workaround: Import specific utilities directly rather than through barrel exports (e.g., import from `../api/models` instead of `../api/index`), though this is impractical at scale.
cards.resolutionDetails: Implemented ignoreModules configuration option in BundleOptions to allow users to exclude problematic transitive dependencies from bundling.
cards.keyQuote: Webpack is sometime unable to determine that the external package is not actually required at runtime, and will therefore try to load it, causing a build failure.

cards.summary: Feature request to allow codec/custom data converter to process headers, particularly OpenTelemetry baggage headers, with contextual information passed to encode/decode operations.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot currently route headers through custom codecs, limiting ability to apply custom serialization logic to header data like OpenTelemetry baggage.
cards.proposedFix: Allow codec to be run on headers with contextual information passed to Codec.encode/decode methods, with OTEL baggage as the default use case.
cards.keyQuote: by default, don't put headers through codec / custom data converter, except for otel baggage

cards.summary: Proto comments from the Temporal API are not included in the generated TypeScript API documentation, making protobufjs-generated classes lack explanatory text for their properties. Users want proto file comments to appear in the generated TypeScript API docs.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot find property descriptions when browsing the generated API documentation and must refer to proto source files instead.
cards.rootCause: protobufjs library does not extract and preserve proto comments during code generation process
cards.proposedFix: Modify protobufjs to properly translate proto comments (// or /* */) into JSDoc comments for the generated TypeScript classes
cards.resolutionDetails: protobufjs is no longer actively maintained (last commit May 2021) and the issue depends on upstream library changes
cards.keyQuote: protobufjs isn't really maintained unfortunately, last commit was May 2021

cards.summary: Failed activity heartbeat data conversion could crash the worker. The system didn't catch data conversion errors during heartbeats and should instead report them as activity cancellations to handle them gracefully.
cards.userImpact: Worker could crash when activity heartbeat data conversion fails, disrupting workflow execution.
cards.rootCause: Data conversion errors during activity heartbeat processing were not caught, causing unhandled exceptions.
cards.proposedFix: Catch data conversion errors during heartbeat and report them as activity cancellations instead of crashing.
cards.resolutionDetails: Issue was fixed and resolved in a previous update.
cards.keyQuote: We don't catch DC errors, we should instead report those back as activity cancellations.

cards.summary: Feature request to add WorkflowExecutionAlreadyTerminated error for handling attempts to terminate an already-terminated workflow with the same ID, similar to the existing WorkflowExecutionAlreadyStartedError.
cards.userImpact: Users need a specific exception to distinguish workflow already terminated scenarios from other errors when calling terminate on completed workflows.
cards.rootCause: Lack of specific exception type to differentiate WorkflowExecutionAlreadyTerminated from generic not found errors.
cards.proposedFix: Implement WorkflowExecutionAlreadyTerminated exception similar to WorkflowExecutionAlreadyStartedError pattern in the codebase.
cards.resolutionDetails: Comment indicates existing not-found exception already handles this case, making a new exception unnecessary.
cards.keyQuote: It'd just be not found and we already have that exception

cards.summary: Collection of transient CI test failures in the TypeScript SDK that require fixes rather than manual rebuilds. Includes failures with verdaccio registry path handling and 'channel closed' errors during replay tests.
cards.userImpact: Transient CI failures require manual rebuilds, reducing developer productivity and confidence in the test suite.
cards.rootCause: Registry path issues on Windows (D:\tmp vs /tmp), process cleanup failures, and race conditions in replay test execution.
cards.resolutionDetails: Team confirmed that all known flakes have been addressed. Future flakes should be tracked in separate, specific issues.
cards.keyQuote: There are a number of transient CI failures that we'd like to fix with code instead of the "rebuild" button

cards.summary: The CHANGELOG for version 0.18.0 doesn't document a breaking change in client error handling where users must now catch specific errors instead of relying on gRPC error codes.
cards.userImpact: Users upgrading to 0.18.0 may encounter unexpected errors if their code depends on gRPC error codes for error handling, with inadequate documentation of the change.
cards.rootCause: CHANGELOG was not updated to reflect the breaking change introduced in version 0.18.0 for client error handling
cards.resolutionDetails: Issue closed after CHANGELOG was updated to document the breaking change in error handling behavior
cards.keyQuote: Before 0.18.0 users could rely on grpc error code for handling errors, after the change they need to catch specific errors.

cards.summary: Feature request to encode baggage as part of trace context in the TypeScript SDK. User references issue #514 for additional details.
cards.userImpact: Users need better integration between baggage data and trace context for improved observability and context propagation.
cards.resolutionDetails: Issue was closed, likely resolved through implementation of baggage encoding in trace context.
cards.keyQuote: See #514, which has more info

cards.summary: Feature request to add a setDefaultDataConverter method to the TypeScript SDK for configuring a default data converter globally.
cards.userImpact: Users would be able to set a default data converter for all workflow and activity executions without manual configuration.
cards.resolutionDetails: Reviewer decided not to implement as this feature hasn't been requested by users.
cards.keyQuote: Let's drop this one, hasn't been requested

cards.summary: When using `npm i --production`, the TypeScript SDK's workflow bundler fails to resolve dependencies like `ms` because webpack's module resolution doesn't include `node_modules` in its search paths, causing production builds to fail.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot deploy TypeScript workflows to production using standard `npm i --production` installations, forcing them to install all dependencies including dev dependencies.
cards.rootCause: The webpack bundler's default `resolve.modules` configuration only includes absolute paths and doesn't include 'node_modules', making it incompatible with Node's module resolution algorithm when certain dependencies are hoisted differently during production installs.
cards.proposedFix: Add 'node_modules' to the `resolve.modules` array in the webpack bundler configuration to make webpack's dependency resolution compatible with Node's algorithm.
cards.workaround: Manually specify `nodeModulesPaths` in worker configuration and include 'node_modules' in the array, or use `npm i` instead of `npm i --production` (installs dev dependencies).
cards.resolutionDetails: The issue was resolved by updating webpack configuration to include 'node_modules' in the resolve.modules array, enabling production builds to properly resolve dependencies.
cards.keyQuote: To get webpack to resolve dependencies using an algorithm compatible with Node's algorithm, we must also include the string 'node_modules' in `resolve.modules`.

cards.summary: Feature request for all-method interceptors or middleware for the TypeScript SDK client. The user wants a simplified way to intercept all communication with the client/worker, similar to Apollo Client's Network Links, particularly for centralized error handling across all methods.
cards.userImpact: Users must currently implement all individual methods in WorkflowClientCallsInterceptor for centralized error handling instead of using a simpler all-method interceptor pattern.
cards.proposedFix: Implement all-method interceptors similar to Apollo Client's Network Links pattern to provide a simpler way to intercept all client/worker communication.
cards.workaround: Users can implement all methods in WorkflowClientCallsInterceptor, or use gRPC interceptors directly.
cards.resolutionDetails: Closed by maintainer (bergundy) with comment that gRPC interceptors can achieve the same result and no additional requests were received.
cards.keyQuote: gRPC interceptors can achieve this IIUC.

cards.summary: Feature request to expose the last workflow completion result directly in the workflow context, similar to Go and Java SDKs. Users currently need to use an activity and client to retrieve this information.
cards.userImpact: Users can now directly access the last workflow completion result within the workflow context without requiring an external activity and client.
cards.rootCause: The last_completion_result field from the Temporal API proto was not exposed in the TypeScript SDK's workflow context interfaces.
cards.proposedFix: Expose the last_completion_result proto field from temporal/api/history/v1/message.proto through the workflow context interfaces, similar to existing Go and Java implementations.
cards.workaround: Use an activity to call a Temporal client to fetch the last workflow execution result externally.
cards.resolutionDetails: Implemented in sdk-core and exposed in TypeScript SDK through PR #657.
cards.keyQuote: Would like to get the result of last Workflow Run without using an activity & client.

cards.summary: Request to create a NestJS integration/transport for the TypeScript SDK to enable decorator-based workflow and activity definitions following NestJS conventions. The requester explored a proof-of-concept and established design principles for supporting both monolithic and microservice architectures while avoiding non-deterministic code patterns.
cards.userImpact: NestJS developers cannot use familiar decorator-based patterns with Temporal SDK, requiring custom workarounds for dependency injection in activities.
cards.rootCause: The TypeScript SDK uses a functional paradigm rather than OOP/decorator-based approach that NestJS developers expect, limiting integration with NestJS's module system.
cards.proposedFix: Create a NestJS module that supports @Workflow() and @InjectActivities() decorators, with workflowsPath supporting both default export functions and object exports. Support for dependency injection through NestJS's container.
cards.workaround: Community members have built internal packages using higher-order functions for dependency injection, or used third-party packages like nestjs-temporal.
cards.keyQuote: The main problem for me I am not able to inject other services into my activities, for example if I have an activity interacts with the outside world so it needs the httpService

cards.summary: Wrap the output of WorkflowHandle.describe() in a JavaScript-friendly object instead of returning the raw gRPC response, improving usability for TypeScript/JavaScript developers.
cards.userImpact: Users currently receive raw gRPC protobuf responses from describe() that are difficult to work with in JavaScript; wrapping them in a friendly object makes the API more accessible.
cards.rootCause: The raw gRPC response from describe() uses protobuf serialization which is not naturally idiomatic for JavaScript developers.
cards.proposedFix: Wrap the output of describe in a JS-friendly object, similar to implementations already done in Java and Python SDKs.
cards.resolutionDetails: The team implemented wrapping of the describe output in a JavaScript-friendly object, following the pattern established in Java and Python SDKs.
cards.keyQuote: We're going to wrap the output of `describe` in a JS friendly object instead of returning the raw grpc response.

cards.summary: protobufjs's `.toJSON` method doesn't implement proto3-spec-compliant JSON encoding, causing incompatibility with other SDKs. The issue tracks whether to fix protobufjs or add alternative methods to make protobuf support easier for TypeScript SDK users.
cards.userImpact: Users must manually handle proto3-compliant JSON serialization, requiring extra setup code and workarounds like proto3-json-serializer instead of using protobufjs's native methods.
cards.rootCause: protobufjs library's `.toJSON` implementation does not follow Google's proto3 JSON specification, unlike Google's own protobuf libraries used by other SDKs.
cards.proposedFix: Either fix protobufjs's `toJSON` implementation or add a `toProto3JSON` method; alternatively support static generated messages for binary/protobuf encoding.
cards.workaround: Use proto3-json-serializer library as an external serialization workaround in the data converter.
cards.resolutionDetails: Closed as not an actionable issue for the SDK repo - it's an external protobufjs limitation. The current workaround using proto3-json-serializer is acceptable and handles serialization transparently for users.
cards.keyQuote: protobufjs's `.toJSON` doesn't do proto3-spec-compliant JSON encoding, which means that if we used it, it would either error or be incompatible with the other SDKs

cards.summary: Request for sleepUntil and UpdatableTimer utility functions to simplify common async patterns in workflows, particularly for recurring tasks like monthly operations.
cards.userImpact: Users currently must implement sleepUntil and updatable timers themselves, making workflows with monthly operations or dynamic timer modifications cumbersome.
cards.proposedFix: Implement sleepUntil and UpdatableTimer as utility functions that compose together, with sleepUntil handling absolute timestamp sleeping and UpdatableTimer allowing mid-flight timer modifications.
cards.resolutionDetails: Left as samples/documentation examples rather than building into the SDK, with possibility of making it an auxiliary library eventually.
cards.keyQuote: sleepuntil is needed because most users will probably have to write it themselves. especially when they try to do anything on a monthly basis

cards.summary: Feature request to add a Worker-level option to specify exception types that should fail the workflow instead of causing retry loops, similar to Java's setFailWorkflowExceptionTypes. The request was ultimately declined in favor of using interceptors for more flexible error handling.
cards.userImpact: Users need a way to distinguish between transient errors that should trigger retries and fatal errors that should fail the workflow immediately.
cards.proposedFix: Add WorkerOptions.failWorkflowErrorTypes: Function[] to allow users to specify error types that should fail workflows, with a special 'ALWAYS_FAIL' option for catching all errors including non-Error types.
cards.workaround: Use interceptors to wrap and handle errors with more flexibility, as documented in the failure handling guide.
cards.resolutionDetails: Team decided against implementing this feature, choosing instead to provide interceptors as a more powerful and flexible alternative for error handling.
cards.keyQuote: decided against an equivalent, instead providing interceptors as the more powerful/flexible (albeit more LoC) alternative

cards.summary: Request to create an ESLint plugin for the TypeScript SDK to catch determinism violations and other workflow-specific issues at compile time. The plugin would enforce workflow constraints like banned Node globals, proper async handling in signal handlers, and error throwing patterns.
