cards.userImpact: Users would be able to catch workflow determinism violations and other common mistakes at compile time rather than runtime, improving development experience and code quality.
cards.proposedFix: Create @temporalio/eslint-plugin with rules for detecting banned Node globals in workflows, async code in signal handlers, and improper error throwing patterns. Configuration would use src/workflows/.eslintrc.json with plugin:@temporalio/recommended preset.
cards.workaround: Currently users can use ESLint's no-restricted-imports rule as shown in temporalio/samples-typescript to prevent some issues, or manually review code for determinism violations.
cards.keyQuote: we will probably make an eslint rule eventually but ultimately we are limited by what we can do with static analysis - cant query a module to see if it uses one of the banned Node globals.

cards.summary: Worker should log an informational message when initialized with no workflows registered, to help users diagnose configuration issues where they accidentally skip workflow bundle initialization.
cards.userImpact: Users who accidentally skip workflow bundle initialization will see a confusing hung worker instead of a clear message explaining why no work is being polled.
cards.proposedFix: Log at INFO level: 'This worker has no workflows registered and will not poll for workflow tasks!'
cards.resolutionDetails: Implementation added logging in worker initialization to detect activity-only mode
cards.keyQuote: We should log at the `INFO` level something like "This worker has no workflows registered and will not poll for workflow tasks!"

cards.summary: The TerminatedFailure object is missing a 'details' field that is available on the WorkflowExecutionTerminatedEventAttributes and accepted by the terminate API. This inconsistency prevents users from accessing termination details.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot access termination details when a workflow is terminated, limiting their ability to understand and handle termination events properly.
cards.rootCause: The TerminatedFailureInfo proto definition in the core API is missing the details field that exists in WorkflowExecutionTerminatedEventAttributes.
cards.proposedFix: Add details field to TerminatedFailureInfo proto definition in temporalio/api repository and update WorkflowHandle.terminate to accept and pass through termination arguments.
cards.keyQuote: terminate accepts "details", which are present on WorkflowExecutionTerminatedEventAttributes even though they aren't present on TerminatedFailureInfo.

cards.summary: When registerErrors() is called multiple times on the TypeScript SDK bridge, it panics due to improper handling of the Neon Root handle. This occurs when worker code runs multiple times or in test scenarios with Jest mocking.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot run worker code multiple times or use Jest mocking in integration tests without encountering a panic.
cards.rootCause: The registerErrors function in the Neon bridge does not properly handle the Root handle cleanup when called multiple times, violating Neon's drop-safety requirements.
cards.proposedFix: Use OnceCell<bool> to make the initialization idempotent, doing nothing if already initialized instead of panicking.
cards.resolutionDetails: The function was modified to use OnceCell to make registerErrors() safely callable multiple times without panic.
cards.keyQuote: That function should probably just use a `OnceCell<bool>` to lift the restriction it imposes on callers, and just do nothing if initialization has already occurred.

cards.summary: The describeTaskQueue API was returning an empty pollers array because the taskQueueType parameter was not being specified in the request. Users needed to explicitly provide the task queue type to get the poller information.
cards.userImpact: Users were unable to retrieve poller information from describeTaskQueue until they discovered the undocumented requirement to specify taskQueueType.
cards.rootCause: The describeTaskQueue API requires the taskQueueType parameter to be explicitly set to return poller information, but this requirement was not clearly documented or enforced.
cards.proposedFix: Specify the taskQueueType parameter when calling describeTaskQueue with the appropriate TaskQueueType enum value.
cards.workaround: Pass taskQueueType parameter explicitly in the describeTaskQueue call, e.g., taskQueueType: temporal.api.enums.v1.TaskQueueType.TASK_QUEUE_TYPE_WORKFLOW
cards.resolutionDetails: Issue was resolved by documenting the required taskQueueType parameter and providing example code showing proper usage.
cards.keyQuote: You need to specify the task queue type to get the poller array back

cards.summary: During workflow result handling, the retry_state field from WorkflowExecutionFailedEventAttributes is hardcoded instead of being read from the actual event attributes.
cards.userImpact: Workflow retry state information is not correctly propagated, potentially causing incorrect retry behavior or loss of retry context information.
cards.rootCause: retry_state field is hardcoded in workflow result handling instead of being read from WorkflowExecutionFailedEventAttributes
cards.resolutionDetails: The retry_state field is now properly read from WorkflowExecutionFailedEventAttributes instead of being hardcoded
cards.keyQuote: Seems during workflow result, retry state is hardcoded instead of using that field

cards.summary: Workflow activation failures lack detailed debugging information. The error message, stack trace, and cause fields are often empty or unhelpful, making it difficult to diagnose issues thrown from workflows.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot effectively debug workflow errors because failure messages lack stack traces and proper formatting of thrown objects.
cards.rootCause: The workflow activation error reporting mechanism doesn't capture full error context (stack trace, cause chain) and doesn't handle non-Error throws properly.
cards.proposedFix: Fill in stack_trace when Error is thrown, handle non-Error throws with JSON.stringify, propagate error.cause property, and optionally make source field more specific.
cards.resolutionDetails: Most improvements were implemented: stack traces now captured, non-Error values JSON stringified with warning message, and error.cause property propagated. The source field enhancement was deferred as potentially breaking.
cards.keyQuote: Failing workflow activation... { message: "error in workflow", source: "TypeScriptSDK", stack_trace: "" }

cards.summary: Worker doesn't log errors when TemporalFailure instances are thrown in workflows, only logging standard Errors. User requests consistent error logging for all error types including ApplicationFailure and custom failures extending TemporalFailure.
cards.userImpact: Developers have difficulty debugging workflow failures when throwing TemporalFailure subclasses because errors are not logged to the console.
cards.rootCause: Worker only logs standard Error instances but not TemporalFailure subclasses, creating inconsistent debugging experience.
cards.proposedFix: Add logger for workflow activations and activity tasks to increase log level and ensure all failure types are logged.
cards.resolutionDetails: Issue resolved through improved logging implementation for failure types in worker.
cards.keyQuote: I would add a logger for activity tasks and workflow activations. We already have DEBUG logging, maybe we just need to increase the log level.

cards.summary: Documentation clarification about which error types cause WorkflowExecutionFailed vs WorkflowTaskFailed events. User was confused about when TemporalFailure and ApplicationFailure with different nonRetryable settings trigger which event types.
cards.userImpact: Developers may misunderstand which error types result in which workflow failure events and how retry policies apply.
cards.resolutionDetails: Issue author clarified their misunderstanding through discussion with maintainer - behavior is working as designed.
cards.keyQuote: Oh, retry policy is for `WorkflowExecutionFailed`s, not for `WorkflowTaskFailed`, got it. I misread TS docs.

cards.summary: Pre-built Rust bridge binaries are not being utilized on Windows during SDK installation, causing significantly longer installation times compared to Ubuntu and macOS.
cards.userImpact: Windows users experience substantially longer SDK installation times due to compilation of Rust bridge instead of using pre-built binaries.
cards.rootCause: Native Rust bridge binaries are not being properly detected or loaded on Windows platform during installation process.
cards.resolutionDetails: Issue was resolved through fixes to the build system to properly handle pre-built Rust bridge binaries on Windows.
cards.keyQuote: According to the build logs here it take a lot longer to install the SDK on Windows than Ubuntu / MacOS.

cards.summary: Feature request to add SAGA (Saga pattern) helpers to the TypeScript SDK for consistency with Java and PHP SDKs, which already include built-in SAGA implementations.
cards.userImpact: Users implementing SAGA patterns would have access to helper utilities similar to those in Java and PHP SDKs, reducing boilerplate code.
cards.proposedFix: Add SAGA helper utilities to the TypeScript SDK, similar to existing implementations in Java and PHP SDKs.
cards.workaround: Implement SAGA pattern manually in user code or reference sample implementations.
cards.resolutionDetails: Team decided not to implement built-in helpers, preferring to provide SAGA examples in samples instead. Will reconsider if demand increases.
cards.keyQuote: Decided not to do this for now, we'll reopen if we see demand.

cards.summary: The serverNameOverride configuration in tlsConfig does not properly set the gRPC authority header for SNI (Server Name Indication), unlike the Go SDK. Users must work around this by manually setting the grpc.default_authority channel argument.
cards.userImpact: Users connecting to gRPC servers with SNI requirements cannot properly configure the authority header through the standard serverNameOverride option, requiring manual channel argument configuration.
cards.rootCause: Rust Core requires extra parameters to add the authority header that are not exposed to the TypeScript SDK when serverNameOverride is set.
cards.proposedFix: Expose Rust Core's authority header parameters to the TypeScript SDK to properly handle serverNameOverride in tlsConfig.
cards.workaround: Set the grpc.default_authority channel argument manually when creating the Connection instead of using serverNameOverride.
cards.keyQuote: nodejs does not update the authority header when setting the serverNameOverride. This is visible from grpc verbose logging.

cards.summary: Feature request to add a default value (crypto.randomUUID()) to workflowId to reduce redundant code. Request was declined in favor of guiding users toward business-meaningful IDs instead of random IDs.
cards.userImpact: Users who want to use random UUIDs for workflow IDs must manually import crypto and set the value each time.
cards.proposedFix: Add crypto.randomUUID() as default value for workflowId parameter
cards.workaround: Manually import crypto package and set workflowId to crypto.randomUUID() in application code
cards.resolutionDetails: Rejected because users should use business-meaningful workflow IDs for production scenarios. Random UUIDs are discouraged to guide users toward better practices.
cards.keyQuote: You should always use meaningful business IDs for workflow IDs in real world scenarios and the API should lead users in that direction.

cards.summary: Add a simplified API to inject headers into the gRPC connection without requiring users to write custom interceptors. This is a common pattern that should be easier to accomplish.
cards.userImpact: Users currently need to write custom interceptors to inject headers, which is unnecessarily complex for a common use case.
cards.proposedFix: Expose a simpler API for header injection instead of requiring interceptor implementation
cards.workaround: Use gRPC interceptors to inject headers (current workaround mentioned in issue)
cards.keyQuote: This currently requires an interceptor, a simpler API should be exposed for this common pattern.

cards.summary: Windows path handling bug where project directories starting with 'n' have the characters '\n' incorrectly stripped from the path, causing workflows to fail to launch. The root cause is identified as the dedent library treating backslash-n as a newline escape sequence.
cards.userImpact: Windows users cannot run Temporal samples or projects with folder names starting with 'n' without renaming the directory.
cards.rootCause: The dedent library incorrectly treats the Windows path separator backslash followed by 'n' (\n) as a newline escape sequence and strips these characters from constructed paths.
cards.proposedFix: Replace the dedent dependency with an alternative like ts-dedent that properly handles Windows path separators.
cards.workaround: Rename project directories so they do not start with the letter 'n' (e.g., rename 'nextjs-ecommerce-oneclick' to 'ecommerce-nextjs-oneclick').
cards.resolutionDetails: Issue was resolved by replacing the dedent library with an alternative that properly handles Windows paths.
cards.keyQuote: This is an issue in dedent. I think the correct solution would be to replace dedent by some alternative (eg. ts-dedent).

cards.summary: Add parent workflow information to the WorkflowInfo object to enable child workflows to access details about their parent workflow context.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot currently access parent workflow information from child workflows, limiting the ability to track workflow lineage and implement parent-aware logic.
cards.resolutionDetails: Feature was implemented and merged to add parent workflow information to WorkflowInfo

cards.summary: User requests a warning when sending unregistered signals to workflows. Currently, handle.signal() succeeds silently even when the workflow has no handler for that signal, making debugging difficult. A warning message should be logged by the Worker to help users identify misspelled signals or missing handler registrations.
cards.userImpact: Users debugging signal handling issues spend time troubleshooting why their signal handlers aren't running when signals are silently ignored.
cards.proposedFix: Log a warning message when a workflow receives a signal without a registered handler, including common causes (misspelling, missing setHandler call, outdated worker code)
cards.keyQuote: They likely meant to send a registered signal and are wondering why their signal handler isn't running.

cards.summary: Users expect Date objects to be preserved when passed through Temporal workflows, but instead receive ISO strings due to JSON serialization. The feature request seeks to improve the default data converter to handle Dates and other types lost during JSON.parse.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot reliably use Date objects in TypeScript workflows without manual conversion, requiring workarounds and custom serialization logic.
cards.rootCause: JSON serialization converts Dates to ISO strings and there is no automatic deserialization back to Date objects in the default converter.
cards.proposedFix: Use EjsonCompositePayloadConverter or EjsonDataConverter for TypeScript-only projects to handle Dates, Uint8Array, special numbers, and RegExp; document this in the SDK guides and samples.
cards.workaround: Users can use EjsonCompositePayloadConverter or implement custom serialize/deserialize methods on their classes.
cards.resolutionDetails: The team decided not to implement this feature in the default converter, preferring to document the EJSON solution for TypeScript-only projects. Cross-language compatibility concerns and protobuf data converters were considered as future alternatives.
cards.keyQuote: Users expect that when they return or pass a `Date`, they'll receive a `Date`. Instead, they receive an ISO string.

cards.summary: Retry policy intervals specified in milliseconds (e.g., 500ms) are incorrectly rounded down to zero seconds when sent to the server. The SDK should round up durations like other SDKs do.
cards.userImpact: Activities configured with sub-second retry intervals fail to retry correctly, causing activities to not retry as intended.
cards.rootCause: Duration values are being rounded down to the nearest second instead of rounding up, resulting in zero-valued durations for millisecond intervals.
cards.proposedFix: Round up durations to the nearest second instead of rounding down, consistent with other SDK implementations.
cards.resolutionDetails: Issue was resolved on the server side via temporal PR #1681 and validated in SDK PR #1121.
cards.keyQuote: The SDK should probably round up the durations (first check what the other SDKs do here).

cards.summary: Activity retry policy was not using server-defined defaults as expected, causing workflows to fail with 'RetryPolicyNotSet' error when no explicit retry policy was provided. The issue was resolved after investigation confirmed that default policies are indeed being set correctly.
cards.userImpact: Users experienced workflow failures when activities lacked explicit retry policies, leading to confusion about default behavior across SDKs.
cards.rootCause: Misunderstanding about whether default retry policies were being applied; documentation was unclear about server-defined defaults.
cards.proposedFix: Align TypeScript SDK retry policy defaults with Go SDK and official Temporal documentation defaults.
cards.resolutionDetails: Investigation confirmed that default retry policies are being set correctly and match the expected behavior; issue was user misunderstanding rather than actual bug.
cards.keyQuote: A default policy is indeed being set, and it does match the default policy.

cards.summary: Add support for headers in signals and queries, matching the feature added to the Temporal Server. This aligns TypeScript SDK with Go and Java SDK implementations.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot attach metadata headers to signals and queries in TypeScript SDK, limiting communication capabilities compared to other SDK languages.
cards.proposedFix: Implement header support in signal and query APIs, following the pattern established in Go SDK PR #631 and referenced in Java SDK issue #940.
cards.resolutionDetails: Feature was implemented to support headers in signals and queries, bringing TypeScript SDK to feature parity with Go and Java SDKs.
cards.keyQuote: Headers were added to signals and queries in https://github.com/temporalio/temporal/pull/2149.

cards.summary: Server now supports headers in signal and query requests. The TypeScript SDK needs to expose this functionality through the various interceptors to allow developers to access and manipulate these headers.
cards.userImpact: Developers cannot currently access or manipulate headers in signal and query interceptors, limiting their ability to implement custom middleware and authentication patterns.
cards.proposedFix: Expose headers in the signal and query interceptor APIs to match the server-side support added in temporalio/temporal#2149.
cards.resolutionDetails: Marked as duplicate of issue #438
cards.keyQuote: Server support for headers in signal and query requests was added in temporalio/temporal#2149. The TypeScript SDK needs to expose this in the various interceptors.

cards.summary: Feature request to make binary the default protobuf data converter instead of JSON in the TypeScript SDK, prioritizing efficiency over human readability. This change should be coordinated across all SDKs simultaneously.
cards.userImpact: Users could benefit from reduced storage space and potentially faster serialization/network transfer times if binary became the default encoding.
cards.proposedFix: Change the default data converter encoding order to put binary protobuf first instead of JSON across all SDKs simultaneously.
cards.resolutionDetails: The change was rejected due to concerns that the clarity and debuggability benefits of JSON outweigh the marginal efficiency gains, and lack of demonstrated real-world performance problems.
cards.keyQuote: I disagree with this change as I find that the clarity of JSON outweighs the slight efficiency of it.

cards.summary: Proto3-json-serializer dependency added to common package increases workflow bundle size from 0.75MB to 0.86MB. Create a new shared package for code and dependencies not used in workflow package to reduce bundle size.
cards.userImpact: Users experience larger workflow bundles due to unnecessary dependencies being included, affecting deployment and runtime performance.
cards.rootCause: proto3-json-serializer dependency added to common package is not used in workflow but gets included in the bundle.
cards.proposedFix: Create a new shared package for code and dependencies not required by the workflow package.
cards.resolutionDetails: Issue was closed, indicating the shared package was created to separate workflow-specific and non-workflow code.
cards.keyQuote: Create a new package for shared code and deps that are not used in `workflow` package in order to reduce workflow bundle size.

cards.summary: pnpm package manager support is needed for the TypeScript SDK. Currently webpack builds fail with pnpm due to its hoisted module structure, requiring workaround using shamefully-hoist flag. Discussion concluded that users should install @temporalio/* packages directly instead of the temporalio package.
cards.userImpact: Users trying to use pnpm with the TypeScript SDK encounter webpack build failures and must use workarounds like shamefully-hoist flag.
cards.rootCause: pnpm's non-hoisted module structure (node_modules in workspace subdirectories) differs from npm/yarn, causing webpack configuration issues during builds.
cards.proposedFix: Document that users should install @temporalio/* packages directly rather than the temporalio package when using yarn or pnpm.
cards.workaround: Add shamefully-hoist=true option to pnpm configuration to revert to npm/yarn style module locations.
cards.resolutionDetails: Team decided not to modify the package structure but instead document that users should import from @temporalio/* packages directly when using yarn/pnpm, avoiding the monolithic temporalio package.
cards.keyQuote: Don't install the `temporalio` package if you're using yarn or pnpm. Instead, install the `@temporalio/*` packages that you import from.

cards.summary: Request to add a TypeScript DSL workflow example to match existing examples in Go and Java SDKs. This would provide TypeScript developers with a complete reference implementation of DSL patterns.
cards.userImpact: TypeScript developers lack a DSL example to understand workflow patterns that are already documented in other language SDKs.
cards.proposedFix: Add a TypeScript DSL workflow example similar to the Go and Java examples
cards.resolutionDetails: DSL example was added to the TypeScript SDK documentation/examples
cards.keyQuote: To do add a TS example for the DSL workflow similar to Go and Java.

cards.summary: Add generic default type parameter to WorkflowHandle interface to allow usage without specifying explicit workflow type. Currently requires T extends Workflow, but should support T extends Workflow = Workflow for more flexible handle creation.
cards.userImpact: Developers can create WorkflowHandle instances without explicitly specifying the workflow type parameter, reducing boilerplate in cases where type specifics aren't needed.
cards.proposedFix: Change WorkflowHandle interface definition from `WorkflowHandle<T extends Workflow>` to `WorkflowHandle<T extends Workflow = Workflow>`
cards.resolutionDetails: Generic default type parameter was added to WorkflowHandle interface to provide Workflow as the default type when not specified.
cards.keyQuote: WorkflowHandle requires an explicit T extends Workflow. It'd be nice to make it T extends Workflow = Workflow

cards.summary: Need an official, documented way to export the SDK version at runtime in the TypeScript SDK. Currently version can be accessed via internal import paths or package.json, but should have a blessed public API.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot easily access the SDK version at runtime through an official public API, forcing them to use internal imports or read package.json.
cards.proposedFix: Export SDK version from a blessed location, either the meta package or common package.
cards.workaround: Users can currently access version via `import pkg from '@temporalio/worker/lib/pkg'` and `pkg.version` or read package.json directly.
cards.keyQuote: Currently can get at a worker level via `import pkg from '@temporalio/worker/lib/pkg'` and `pkg.version` or by using the `package.json` directly, but should be in a more blessed/official place.

cards.summary: The `npx @temporalio/create` command fails to execute for some users on Node 14.15.0. The issue appears to be environment-specific with limited details provided in the bug report.
cards.userImpact: Users are unable to bootstrap new TypeScript Temporal projects using the official create command, blocking project setup.

cards.summary: User requested enhanced shell logging during workflow execution to provide visibility into workflow progress, activity execution, and failures without requiring the web console. This was addressed through logging interceptors added to the SDK.
cards.userImpact: Users had difficulty debugging workflow issues without access to the web console, leading to hanging processes with no visible error information.
cards.proposedFix: Add conditional logging (when NODE_ENV is not staging/production) to display task polling, workflow execution, activity invocation, and activity failures in the shell output.
cards.resolutionDetails: Addressed by adding logging interceptors to the SDK that provide more informative default logs.
cards.keyQuote: Give the user more information in the shell on what's happening.

cards.summary: When calling workflow API functions like sleep() outside of a workflow context (in a Node script), the error message is cryptic ("exports.storage.getStore is not a function") instead of clearly indicating the function must be run within a workflow.
cards.userImpact: Developers receive confusing stack traces when accidentally calling workflow APIs outside a workflow, making it difficult to diagnose the actual problem.
cards.rootCause: Workflow functions attempt to access async context storage that only exists within a workflow isolate, but the error propagates from the storage layer rather than being caught at the API boundary.
cards.proposedFix: Catch calls to workflow APIs outside of workflow context and throw a clear error message: 'This function is meant to be used inside Workflow code. Workflow code should only be run by the Worker (and is provided to the Worker via either the `workflowsPath` or `workflowBundle` option).'
cards.resolutionDetails: Issue was closed in favor of #553, indicating it was merged or consolidated with another issue addressing the same problem.
cards.keyQuote: This function is meant to be used inside Workflow code. Workflow code should only be run by the Worker

cards.summary: Feature request to help users debug the common issue of workflows not executing because no worker is polling the correct task queue. Proposes logging a helpful warning message when start/execute/signalWithStart is called and no workers are available on the specified queue.
cards.userImpact: Users frequently encounter silent failures when workflows don't execute due to missing or misconfigured workers, leading to confusion and debugging difficulty.
cards.rootCause: Lack of feedback when a workflow is started but no worker is available to process it on the specified task queue.
cards.proposedFix: Add a warning log message when start/execute/signalWithStart is called in development mode and no workers are polling the target task queue.
cards.resolutionDetails: Issue was resolved by the Temporal UI providing a banner to help users identify missing workers on task queues.
cards.keyQuote: There are no Workers polling on task queue 'my-queue'. In order to start running this workflow, run a Worker with `taskQueue: 'my-queue'`.

cards.summary: ContinueAsNew workflow transitions are incorrectly appearing as errors in OpenTelemetry traces, causing unnecessary noise and confusion in observability data.
cards.userImpact: Users see spurious error traces for normal ContinueAsNew workflow transitions, complicating debugging and increasing noise in monitoring systems.
cards.rootCause: ContinueAsNew completion is being treated as an error condition in the OpenTelemetry tracing instrumentation.
cards.resolutionDetails: ContinueAsNew is now properly handled as a normal workflow lifecycle event rather than an error in OTEL traces.
cards.keyQuote: It's quite irritating to see this error in my workflow traces

cards.summary: Node 14 and 18 support was disabled in CI for the npm init verdaccio test. This issue tracks re-enabling the broken test and adding these Node versions to the CI matrix.
cards.userImpact: Node 14 and 18 compatibility is not being tested in CI, potentially missing compatibility issues for SDK users.
cards.rootCause: Test was disabled in #385 and needs Node 14 and 18 added to the CI matrix to re-enable it.
cards.proposedFix: Add node 14 and 18 to the matrix for test-npm-init in .github/workflows/ci.yml
cards.resolutionDetails: Completed in #1003 which added the required Node versions to the CI matrix.
cards.keyQuote: Need to add node 14 and 18 to the matrix for test-npm-init

cards.summary: Workflow interceptors require double configuration: once for bundler inclusion and again in WorkerOptions. When workflows are pre-bundled, WorkerOptions.interceptors.workflowModules may become unavailable since require.resolve might not work in the pre-bundled worker process.
cards.userImpact: Users deploying pre-bundled workflows must maintain workflow interceptor paths in two places, or face runtime failures when require.resolve is unavailable.
cards.rootCause: require.resolve does not work in pre-bundled worker processes, requiring workflow modules to be specified separately at runtime despite already being bundled.
cards.proposedFix: Store the list of workflow interceptor modules at bundling time and automatically load them, or automatically load anything in the workflow bundle so paths only need to be specified once.
cards.keyQuote: The worker might not have the workflows available in the file system on startup (in case it is using a workflows bundle).

cards.summary: Add an integration test to verify that Workflows are automatically retried when experiencing multiple consecutive timeouts. This ensures the retry behavior works correctly end-to-end in the TypeScript SDK.
cards.userImpact: Ensures reliability of workflow retry behavior under timeout conditions, providing confidence that production workflows will retry correctly.
cards.proposedFix: Add an integration test to the TypeScript SDK that verifies workflows are retried when experiencing multiple consecutive timeouts.
cards.resolutionDetails: Integration test was implemented to verify retry behavior on consecutive timeouts
cards.keyQuote: WFT timeout is configurable and server behavior might change and make this test obsolete but this is good enough.

cards.summary: Feature request to add actual span time to spans created by workflow OpenTelemetry interceptors. Currently, spans use workflow task time which differs from actual processing time, limiting visibility into system behavior.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot accurately measure actual processing time of workflow spans, limiting their ability to diagnose system performance issues.
cards.rootCause: Spans in workflow isolate use workflow task time rather than real time because spans can span multiple workflow tasks running on different workers with replays, making reliable real start time unavailable.
cards.proposedFix: Use `workflowInfo().unsafe.now()` to access actual time for span timing.
cards.workaround: Use `workflowInfo().unsafe.now()` method as suggested in comments.
cards.keyQuote: Spans created in the workflow isolate use workflow task time which different than the actual processing time.

cards.summary: Package initializer fails on Node 14 due to incorrect tsconfig version being set based on Node version. The tool was replacing the tsconfig entry in package.json with an incompatible version for older Node versions.
cards.userImpact: Users trying to create new Temporal projects on Node 14 encounter initialization errors that prevent project setup.
cards.rootCause: The create-project tool was dynamically replacing the tsconfig version in package.json based on the Node version, setting an incompatible version for Node 14.
cards.proposedFix: Set tsconfig value to `^1.0.0` in sample package.json files or have create tool overwrite with `[version]@^1.0.0`.
cards.resolutionDetails: Issue was resolved by ensuring all samples have `^1.0.0` in their package.json files.
cards.keyQuote: We could just set the value to `^1.0.0`.

cards.summary: npm install fails on Windows with MSVC 2017 due to three cross-platform compatibility issues: non-cross-OS build script in core-bridge, OS-specific cargo artifact spawning, and isolated-vm compilation errors with Windows macro expansion.
cards.userImpact: Windows developers cannot install the TypeScript SDK, blocking adoption on Windows platforms.
cards.rootCause: Build scripts use OS-specific paths and spawning mechanisms; isolated-vm compilation fails due to Windows macro name collision with std::max.
cards.proposedFix: Refactor build scripts to be cross-platform compatible; fix macro collision in isolated-vm bindings.
cards.resolutionDetails: Author prepared fixes in fork and PR was welcomed by maintainers to address the outstanding Windows support issue #12.
cards.keyQuote: I have the required changes in my fork ready for a PR. This is great, we've had an outstanding issue to support windows build for a while now #12. PR will be very welcome.

cards.summary: Worker error message "Workflow executionsRow not found" is unclear and doesn't help users understand what went wrong. The message should provide higher-level context about the failure and suggest possible causes.
cards.userImpact: Users encounter cryptic database error messages that don't help them diagnose workflow execution problems.
cards.rootCause: Server returns low-level database error message ("Workflow executionsRow not found") that doesn't clearly indicate the underlying issue; message differs between Cassandra and PostgreSQL backends.
cards.proposedFix: Improve error message to explain the problem at a higher level and suggest possible reasons for the failure.
cards.keyQuote: Say what's going wrong in the Worker at a higher level and suggest possible reasons.

cards.summary: The gRPC DEADLINE_EXCEEDED error message is cryptic and doesn't help users troubleshoot. The request is to improve the error message to provide context and link to documentation about common causes and solutions.
cards.userImpact: Users encountering gRPC timeouts receive unhelpful error messages that don't guide them toward troubleshooting steps or solutions.
cards.rootCause: The raw gRPC error message 'context deadline exceeded' lacks context about why it occurred and how to resolve it.
cards.proposedFix: Wrap the gRPC deadline error with a more helpful message that explains common causes and links to documentation (https://docs.temporal.io/docs/typescript/troubleshooting/#grpc-call-timeouts-context-deadline-exceeded).
cards.resolutionDetails: Issue was closed in favor of #365, indicating it was merged with another related issue on the same topic.
cards.keyQuote: Log something like: Error: gRPC call timeout. This can happen for a number of reasons. Please see: https://docs.temporal.io/docs/typescript/troubleshooting/#grpc-call-timeouts-context-deadline-exceeded

cards.summary: Improve error messages when a Worker doesn't have the required Workflow function in its bundle. Instead of cryptic 'foo is not a function' errors, provide a helpful message that explains possible causes and links to documentation.
cards.userImpact: Users receive unclear error messages when workflow functions are missing, making it difficult to diagnose configuration issues.
cards.rootCause: Error messages don't clearly indicate that the Worker is missing a specific Workflow function from its bundle.
cards.proposedFix: Replace generic 'X is not a function' errors with a detailed message listing possible causes and linking to documentation. Optionally list exported functions.
cards.keyQuote: The Worker process that picked up this task doesn't have a Workflow function named 'foo' in its bundle.

cards.summary: Add support for aarch64-unknown-linux-gnu build target for Rust Core to enable building containers on M1 Macs. The aarch64-apple-darwin target is already supported, but users need the Linux ARM64 GNU target for cross-compilation to Linux containers.
cards.userImpact: Users building Docker containers on M1 Macs cannot target Linux ARM64 without this build target support.
cards.proposedFix: Add aarch64-unknown-linux-gnu to the list of supported Rust Core build targets
cards.resolutionDetails: The aarch64-unknown-linux-gnu target was added to the Rust Core build targets
cards.keyQuote: Mostly to support building containers on M1 macs

cards.summary: Remove the patch that was added for timer cancellation in condition workflows. This deprecation was a planned cleanup following the decision to not use a patch approach for this functionality.
cards.userImpact: No immediate user impact; this is a planned internal cleanup that removes unnecessary patching code.
cards.proposedFix: Remove the patch for timer cancellation in condition that was added in issue #372
cards.resolutionDetails: The team decided not to use a patch approach for timer cancellation in conditions, so the patch should be removed
cards.keyQuote: We decided not to use a patch in the end.

cards.summary: Feature request to provide official Docker images for building and running Temporal TypeScript workers, addressing user uncertainty about containerization practices. The request was closed as the team decided that VM support and pre-built binaries for major architectures made dedicated Docker images unnecessary.
cards.userImpact: Users lack clear guidance on containerizing and running Temporal TypeScript workers in production environments.
cards.proposedFix: Create official Docker build and runtime images and update documentation with containerization best practices.
cards.resolutionDetails: Closed as unnecessary given VM support and availability of pre-built binaries for all major architectures and OS targets.
cards.keyQuote: Now that we have `vm` support and pre-built binaries for all major architectures and os targets, I don't see a good reason to do this.

cards.summary: Users passing nameless/anonymous functions to infer workflow names receive unhelpful error messages. The SDK should validate function names at runtime and provide better error messages when functions aren't exported or named properly.
cards.userImpact: Users receive cryptic error messages when passing nameless functions or unexported workflows, making debugging difficult.
cards.rootCause: SDK lacks runtime validation for function names and doesn't wrap underlying ReferenceError with contextual information.
cards.proposedFix: Add validation to check that user-provided functions have names at registration time and wrap ReferenceError with more informative messaging.
cards.resolutionDetails: Issue closed - appears to have been addressed in subsequent SDK updates
cards.keyQuote: As for nameless function, I think the client should easily be able to check that at runtime. We could also wrap the ReferenceError in a more informative error.

cards.summary: gRPC errors thrown by the client lack meaningful context and have useless stack traces, making debugging difficult. The SDK should catch errors from WorkflowClient methods and rethrow them with better context about what operation failed.
cards.userImpact: Developers cannot effectively debug client failures because error messages lack context about which operation failed and why.
cards.rootCause: Errors are thrown asynchronously by gRPC-js, resulting in stack traces that point to internal gRPC code rather than user code, with insufficient context about the failed operation.
cards.proposedFix: Catch errors from WorkflowClient methods and rethrow with additional context about the operation that failed.
cards.resolutionDetails: The issue was resolved by implementing better error handling and context in the TypeScript SDK client.
cards.keyQuote: Right now client errors are thrown by grpc-js asynchronously and the stack trace is meaningless.

cards.summary: Rename the 'external dependencies' feature to 'sinks' to better reflect its actual functionality. The current name is misleading because this mechanism cannot be used to return values into the workflow.
cards.userImpact: Users will have a more accurate understanding of what the external dependencies/sinks feature can and cannot do based on its corrected name.
cards.rootCause: The original 'external dependencies' naming was inaccurate and did not reflect the actual capability constraints of the feature.
cards.proposedFix: Rename 'external dependencies' to 'sinks' throughout the SDK.
cards.resolutionDetails: Feature was renamed from 'external dependencies' to 'sinks' to accurately reflect its purpose.
cards.keyQuote: The name is no longer accurate because this mechanism cannot be used to return values into the workflow

cards.summary: Timer cancellation is not being properly cleaned up when a condition resolves, leading to unnecessary system load. The issue requests implementation of proper timer cancellation to reduce resource consumption.
cards.userImpact: Users experience unnecessary resource consumption due to timers not being properly cancelled when conditions are met.
cards.rootCause: Timer cancellation logic is not being invoked when a condition resolves, leaving timers active in the system.
cards.proposedFix: Implement proper timer cancellation when conditions resolve to reduce system load.
cards.keyQuote: It is better to cancel in order to reduce load on the system.

cards.summary: User requested support for applying patches at the top level of workflow code before the workflow function is required. The feature was later decided against due to confusion from patches at top level applying to all workflows.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot conditionally load workflow logic based on patches applied before the workflow function definition.
cards.rootCause: The workflow runtime required the workflow function to be available before patches could be applied, preventing top-level patch usage.
cards.proposedFix: Support patches at the top level of user code to conditionally enable/disable workflow features before workflow function execution.
cards.resolutionDetails: Feature was deliberately disallowed because patches at top level apply to all workflows, creating a confusing user experience.
cards.keyQuote: We decided to disallow this because patches at top level apply to all workflows and the experience is too confusing.

cards.summary: Tracing tags are inconsistent across different Temporal SDKs. This feature request asks for standardization of tracing tags across all SDKs (Go, Java, TypeScript, etc.) to ensure consistent observability across different language implementations.
cards.userImpact: Developers using multiple Temporal SDKs experience inconsistent tracing tag formats, making it difficult to correlate traces and build unified observability solutions.
cards.proposedFix: Standardize tracing tag naming and format across all SDK implementations (Go, Java, TypeScript, Python, etc.)
cards.keyQuote: Tracing tags are not consistent across SDKs.

cards.summary: Request to improve error messages when the wrong worker is polling the queue or when workflow functions are not found. Currently errors like 'Task not found' and 'is not a function' are cryptic; the request suggests more helpful messages that explain what went wrong and suggest possible causes.
cards.userImpact: Users spend significant time debugging cryptic error messages that don't clearly indicate what went wrong when the wrong worker polls a queue or workflow functions are missing.
cards.rootCause: Error messages lack context about underlying issues like mismatched workers, missing workflow functions, or configuration problems, making debugging difficult.
cards.proposedFix: Enhance error messages with: (1) Higher-level explanations of what went wrong in worker context, (2) Suggestions for common causes (typos, missing exports, incorrect entry points, multiple worker processes), (3) Links to documentation pages for reference and future updates.
cards.keyQuote: The Worker process that picked up this task doesn't have a Workflow function named 'progress' in its bundle. The issue might be...

cards.summary: Request to document SDK errors in API docs and enable type-safe error handling via error classes. Users need to discover which errors methods can throw and use instanceof for error type checking instead of runtime discovery.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot easily discover which errors SDK methods can throw or properly type-check errors at runtime, leading to incomplete error handling in applications.
cards.rootCause: SDK errors are not documented in API docs and lack proper error class hierarchy for isinstance checking.
cards.proposedFix: Add error classes for all SDK error codes and document which errors each method can throw in the API documentation.
cards.workaround: Manual runtime discovery of errors and string-based error classification in user code.
cards.resolutionDetails: Addressed through cross-SDK effort to add error classes (WorkflowExecutionAlreadyStartedError, WorkflowNotFoundError already added in PR #468) and document possible errors by method.
cards.keyQuote: Be able to see in a method's API docs which error types it can throw. Be able to use instanceof like this

cards.summary: Request to expose history event count and aggregated payload size through WorkflowInfo to help workflow authors make informed decisions about when to continue as new. Currently, developers must estimate history length using interceptors or arbitrary thresholds.
cards.userImpact: Users developing long-running workflows lack visibility into history size, forcing them to use unreliable estimation techniques or arbitrary thresholds for continue-as-new decisions.
cards.rootCause: WorkflowInfo does not expose history event count or payload size metrics that would enable informed continuation decisions.
cards.proposedFix: Expose history event length and aggregated payload size through WorkflowInfo; server-side provision of size metrics needed for complete solution.
cards.workaround: Use workflow interceptors to estimate history length by tracking activation jobs and workflow task events, though this may be inaccurate for uncommon event types.
cards.resolutionDetails: History length was exposed in the SDK; payload size awaited server-side implementation.
cards.keyQuote: we'd like to expose the number of history events and the aggregated payloads size to via WorkflowInfo so Workflow authors can make smarter decisions for when to continue as new

cards.summary: Algolia search integration is broken with a 403 API key error, preventing search functionality from working in the TypeScript SDK documentation.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot search the TypeScript SDK documentation due to authentication failures.
cards.rootCause: Algolia API key configuration lacks proper permissions for the search index.
cards.resolutionDetails: Issue was closed, likely resolved by updating API key permissions or configuration.
cards.keyQuote: 403 Error: `Index not allowed with this API key`

cards.summary: Add SIGUSR2 signal to the default list of worker shutdown signals. This signal is commonly used by nodemon for graceful shutdown and should be included by default.
cards.userImpact: Developers using nodemon for development will need to manually add SIGUSR2 to shutdown signals instead of having it included by default.
cards.proposedFix: Include SIGUSR2 in the default shutdownSignals list for workers.
cards.resolutionDetails: SIGUSR2 was added to the default worker shutdown signals.
cards.keyQuote: This is the signal nodemon uses for graceful shutdown, it should be in the default list.

cards.summary: Worker fails to reconnect when the Temporal server is initially down, throwing a transport error and stopping retry attempts. Unlike issue #290 which retries after server recovery, this addresses the case where the server is down when the worker starts.
cards.userImpact: Workers crash and stop attempting reconnection when the Temporal server is unavailable at startup, requiring manual intervention to restart the worker once the server is available.
cards.rootCause: Worker startup does not implement retry logic when server is initially down; retry logic was only added for cases where the server becomes unavailable after initial connection (issue #290).
cards.workaround: Implement custom retry logic by wrapping Worker.create or Core.install to handle initial connection failures.
cards.resolutionDetails: The maintainers decided the current behavior (failing fast on misconfiguration rather than leaving workers idle) is intentional and preferred, but remain open to discussion.
cards.keyQuote: We chose not to attempt to reconnect when worker starts to avoid a situation where workers are left idle in case of misconfiguration.

cards.summary: GitHub Actions CI workflow runs slowly, causing developers to wait for feedback on pull requests. The request is to optimize the workflow through parallelization, improved caching, or dedicated infrastructure.
cards.userImpact: Developers experience delays when waiting for CI workflow results on pull requests.
cards.rootCause: GitHub Actions workflow lacks sufficient parallelization and caching strategies.
cards.proposedFix: Increase parallelization, improve caching, use prebuilt Docker images, or implement dedicated runners.
cards.resolutionDetails: Completed through issue #1003 which likely implemented workflow optimizations.
cards.keyQuote: with several PRs I've found myself waiting and checking back on the status and it's usually still in progress

cards.summary: Feature request to add a built-in 'getHandlers' query method to the TypeScript SDK. This issue was closed as a duplicate of #1081, which provides more detailed discussion.
cards.userImpact: Users would be able to discover available query handlers on a workflow, improving debuggability and API discoverability.
cards.resolutionDetails: Closed in favor of #1081 which provides more detailed discussion of the same feature request.
cards.keyQuote: Closing in favor of duplicated #1081 (that other one provide more details).

cards.summary: The @temporalio/create package initializer fails with ENOENT errors when cloning sample projects, as the tar extraction doesn't properly validate that the package.json exists in the cloned folder before attempting to read it.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot successfully initialize new Temporal TypeScript projects using the create command, blocking project setup entirely.
cards.rootCause: The install script attempts to read package.json via readFileSync before validating that the tar extraction successfully produced the file, and lacks graceful error handling for missing sample files.
cards.proposedFix: Add validation to check for package.json existence after tar extraction and provide better error messages when samples are not found or invalid URLs are provided.
cards.resolutionDetails: Improved error handling and validation in the sample download and extraction process with clearer error messages when package.json is missing.
cards.keyQuote: the root cause is not the file read, it is the lack of package.json in the cloned folder

cards.summary: Multiple OpenTelemetry instrumentation bugs affecting span timing accuracy, service name propagation, trace hierarchy, and internal SDK traces visibility in the TypeScript SDK.
cards.userImpact: Users setting up OpenTelemetry tracing encounter incorrect span timings, missing service names in traces, unfiltered SDK-internal spans, and broken parent-child relationships in child workflows.
cards.rootCause: OTEL resource not being passed to makeWorkflowExporter; span hierarchy not properly maintained for child workflows; internal traces not filtered by default
cards.proposedFix: Make OTEL resource required in makeWorkflowExporter; implement proper span parent-child linking for child workflows; add filtering for SDK-internal traces; ensure ContinueAsNew is traced
cards.resolutionDetails: Issues were resolved locally by the maintainer and included in a PR addressing service name propagation, span hierarchy, and trace filtering
cards.keyQuote: Child workflows are not connected to root workflows (i.e. the child workflow span `workflow.execute` should be a child span of the root `workflow.schedule`)

cards.summary: Request to allow Workers to accept prebuilt bundles for improved deployment efficiency. Marked as duplicate of #310.
cards.userImpact: Users need more flexible options for bundling and deploying worker code to improve build and deployment workflows.
cards.resolutionDetails: This feature request is a duplicate of issue #310, which covers the same functionality.
cards.keyQuote: Accept prebuilt bundles in Workers

cards.summary: Request to add statsd metrics support to TypeScript SDK to track ScheduleToStart and other metrics for production deployments using statsd and Datadog integration.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot easily export SDK metrics like ScheduleToStart to statsd/Datadog without additional infrastructure overhead.
cards.rootCause: TypeScript SDK lacks native statsd exporter support, unlike Java/Go SDKs which use Tally libraries with statsd connectors.
cards.proposedFix: Provide metrics export capabilities from SDK with statsd connector support, potentially through OpenTelemetry collectors or direct statsd export.
cards.workaround: Deploy OpenTelemetry Collector as intermediate service to bridge metrics, though this adds operational complexity.
cards.resolutionDetails: Team decided metrics export through OpenTelemetry Collector is more flexible and sustainable than embedding direct statsd support across all SDKs.
cards.keyQuote: The big problem here is that we emit metrics from both Core and Lang. Every direct export we support it needs to exist in Core and all langs

cards.summary: User seeks guidance on proper client instantiation patterns when long-lived server connections frequently drop due to server redeployment. They question whether to reuse a single Connection/WorkflowClient or create new instances per request.
cards.userImpact: Users experiencing connection drop errors need to understand the correct client usage pattern to avoid redundant instance creation and ensure reliable operation across server redeployments.
cards.rootCause: Connection retry logic was not fully implemented in gRPC interceptors; individual calls may fail after retry limit is hit even though the connection can be reused.
cards.proposedFix: Reuse Connection and WorkflowClient instances for the lifetime of the application; the connection will automatically reconnect when dropped. Adjust retry policy based on expected server downtime duration.
cards.resolutionDetails: Confirmed that Connection/WorkflowClient can be safely reused across server redeployments; individual failed calls don't destroy the connection. Related fix in sdk-core PR #213 addresses worker persistence during server downtime.
cards.keyQuote: you can trust the Connection and WorkflowClient instance may be re-used though, depending on your retry policy, in-progress calls may eventually fail if the connection is lost for long enough

cards.summary: Unify WorkflowClient error handling by using a single Error type with Failure objects as causes, replacing the current approach of separate error classes for each workflow failure type.
cards.userImpact: Users would have a simpler and more consistent error handling pattern for WorkflowClient operations, aligned with the Java SDK implementation.
cards.rootCause: Separate error classes were implemented before failure classes were ported to the SDK, resulting in duplication of functionality.
cards.proposedFix: Replace multiple error classes with a single Error class that includes a Failure class in its `cause` attribute, matching the Java SDK pattern.
cards.resolutionDetails: Implemented unified error handling with single Error type and Failure cause attribute, aligning TypeScript SDK with Java SDK approach.
cards.keyQuote: Unify these errors into a single Error class and add a Failure class to its `cause` attribute.

cards.summary: Feature request to adopt the newer `Context.SetPromiseHooks` API for workflow isolate extensions. The new API is bound to a single context and uses faster JS functions compared to the current C++ implementation that redundantly overrides promise hooks per context.
cards.userImpact: Potential performance improvement and cleaner implementation for workflow isolation through more efficient promise hook management.
cards.proposedFix: Migrate to using `Context.SetPromiseHooks` API which is bound to a single context and uses JS functions instead of C++ functions.
cards.resolutionDetails: Implementation became irrelevant after transitioning to `vm` and using Node.js's native `AsyncLocalStorage` instead.
cards.keyQuote: Not relevant since we ended up using `AsyncLocalStorage`

cards.summary: Documentation for workflow ID generation was misleading, suggesting autogenerated IDs are suitable for most cases when business-meaningful IDs are often better. The docs needed to emphasize the importance of intentional workflow ID selection, especially for use cases like signalWithStart, and clarify the distinction between creating handles and creating new workflows.
cards.userImpact: Users were misled by documentation to use autogenerated workflow IDs in cases where business-meaningful IDs would be more appropriate, leading to issues with signalWithStart and workflow handle operations.
cards.rootCause: Documentation statement 'Most users should do just fine with the autogenerated workflowId' was statistically true but missed important edge cases and use patterns where intentional workflow IDs are necessary.
cards.proposedFix: Hint that workflow ID selection has important considerations beyond autogeneration and link to full Temporal concepts documentation on workflow IDs. Clarify the distinction between createHandle and creating new workflows.
cards.resolutionDetails: Made workflowId required in all WorkflowClient methods, eliminating the autogeneration path and forcing intentional ID selection.
cards.keyQuote: Most users should do just fine with the autogenerated workflowId. The problem with that statement is that while it is statistically true, there are a class of use cases where it is not suitable

cards.summary: WeakMap and WeakSet were deleted from the SDK but need to be restored to support private variables in TypeScript. The issue also flags FinalizationRegistry for deletion.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot use private variables in TypeScript workflows because required WeakMap and WeakSet functionality is missing from the SDK.
cards.rootCause: WeakMap and WeakSet were removed from the SDK polyfills, preventing TypeScript's private field implementation from working correctly.
cards.proposedFix: Restore WeakMap and WeakSet implementations; also remove FinalizationRegistry as suggested.
cards.resolutionDetails: WeakMap and WeakSet were restored to support private variables in TypeScript; FinalizationRegistry was deleted.
cards.keyQuote: need this to use private variables in typescript

cards.summary: Add the missing continuedAsNewExecutionRunId field to the WorkflowInfo interface to support accessing the run ID when a workflow continues as new. The request also suggests adding parentId and parentRunId for child workflow support.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot access the continued-as-new run ID or parent workflow information through the WorkflowInfo interface, limiting visibility into workflow relationships.
cards.proposedFix: Add continuedAsNewExecutionRunId, parentId, and parentRunId fields to the WorkflowInfo interface
cards.resolutionDetails: The issue was closed and referenced in documentation PR #696
cards.keyQuote: add parentId and parentRunId as well which is useful for child workflows if its possible

cards.summary: Users need a health check method on WorkflowClient or WorkflowServiceStubs to verify the underlying connection to the Temporal server is healthy. This was a common request across multiple SDKs.
cards.userImpact: Users can now verify their connection to the Temporal server is healthy before executing workflows.
cards.proposedFix: Expose health check method via WorkflowServiceStubs or WorkflowClient that wraps the gRPC health service.
cards.workaround: Use raw gRPC client health service via connection.healthService.check()
cards.resolutionDetails: Exposed via raw gRPC client through connection.healthService with HealthCheckResponse status
cards.keyQuote: import { Connection } from '@temporalio/client'; const health = await connection.healthService.check({});

cards.summary: Core bridge crashes with a panic when given invalid TLS certificate options instead of throwing an informative error. This affects JavaScript users who bypass TypeScript's type protection.
cards.userImpact: Users passing invalid TLS certificate options experience a cryptic internal crash instead of a clear error message, especially JavaScript users without TypeScript protection.
cards.rootCause: Core bridge calls `Option::unwrap()` on a `None` value in conversions.rs:108 when receiving invalid certificate pair data.
cards.resolutionDetails: Resolved by improving input validation and error handling in the core bridge to provide informative errors instead of panics.
cards.keyQuote: called `Option::unwrap()` on a `None` value - should provide good JS support with informative error messages

cards.summary: Users want to separate workflow code bundling from worker execution, allowing them to use custom bundlers (like esbuild) instead of the built-in webpack bundler and trigger only code execution on startup.
cards.userImpact: Users can now use their preferred bundling tools instead of being locked into the built-in bundler, enabling more flexible development workflows.
cards.rootCause: The worker entrypoint was tightly coupled to both bundling and execution logic, preventing users from customizing the bundling step.
cards.proposedFix: Export WorkflowCodeBundler class and add workflowCodeBundle parameter to WorkerOptions, accepting either bundled code string or path to bundle file.
cards.resolutionDetails: The feature was implemented by exporting bundling functionality separately and adding workflowCodeBundle parameter to Worker.create options.
cards.keyQuote: I'd like to take the responsibility of the bundling (and e.g. use something like esbuild instead of Webpack) and have my worker entrypoint only trigger the actual code execution

cards.summary: The `createWorkflowHandle` function has confusing overloaded behavior for both creating new workflows and retrieving existing ones. When users accidentally pass a workflow ID string instead of an object, they get an unclear error message. Request to split this into separate `createWorkflowHandle` and `getExistingWorkflowHandle` functions for better API clarity.
cards.userImpact: Developers encounter confusing error messages when accidentally misusing the overloaded `createWorkflowHandle` function, reducing API usability and causing confusion.
cards.rootCause: The function attempts to serve two distinct purposes (creating new workflows and retrieving existing ones) with overloaded signatures, making it prone to user error without clear guidance.
cards.proposedFix: Split `createWorkflowHandle` into two separate functions: `createWorkflowHandle` for creating new workflows and `getExistingWorkflowHandle` for retrieving existing workflows. Additionally, add validation in dev mode to detect when a workflowId string is passed instead of an object.
cards.resolutionDetails: Issue was resolved by splitting the functionality into separate functions as requested, implemented in PR #324.
cards.keyQuote: split the second behavior to another function, `getExistingWorkflowHandle`

cards.summary: Timer creation fails with "BadStartTimerAttributes" error when StartToFireTimeout is not properly set on the timer command, causing workers to crash with an unhandled gRPC error.
cards.userImpact: Users encounter worker crashes when using timers without proper timeout configuration, with an unclear error message.
cards.rootCause: StartToFireTimeout attribute is not being validated or set correctly when creating timer commands.
cards.resolutionDetails: Issue was addressed through proper validation and error handling in timer command creation.
cards.keyQuote: BadStartTimerAttributes: A valid StartToFireTimeout is not set on command.

cards.summary: The activity.Context.sleep method should accept time duration as a string (e.g., '1s', '100ms') in addition to milliseconds, similar to the existing behavior in issue #270.
cards.userImpact: Users must convert time durations to milliseconds manually instead of using convenient string formats like other Temporal APIs.
cards.rootCause: The sleep method only accepts numeric milliseconds, inconsistent with other Temporal SDK methods that support duration strings.
cards.proposedFix: Accept duration strings (e.g., '1s', '100ms') as an alternative to numeric milliseconds in activity.Context.sleep.
cards.resolutionDetails: Issue was addressed to align activity.Context.sleep API with other Temporal SDK methods for consistency.
cards.keyQuote: this should take a string too

cards.summary: Feature request to warn developers when multiple worker processes are running on the same machine with potentially different code versions, which can cause non-deterministic task execution in development environments.
cards.userImpact: Developers may experience confusing non-deterministic behavior when old worker processes interfere with new ones, making debugging difficult.
cards.rootCause: Multiple worker processes running simultaneously on the same machine can pick up tasks intended for the newer worker version.
cards.proposedFix: Add a development-time warning that searches for other worker processes on the machine and logs their PIDs with a suggestion to kill them, possibly integrated with task queue introspection via tctl API.
cards.workaround: Manually stop any other worker processes before starting development, or use worker versioning for deployments.
cards.resolutionDetails: Resolved as wontfix with suggestion to use worker versioning instead, which is the proper solution for managing multiple code versions.
cards.keyQuote: There is another worker process running on this machine. If it was started with an older version of your Worker and Activity code, we recommend stopping it

cards.summary: Queries are not properly registered when interceptors are involved and multiple jobs (start workflow, signal, query) are delivered in a single activation. The issue appears to be a race condition where async interceptor functions prevent the workflow function from being invoked before query handlers are needed.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot reliably use interceptors with workflow queries, as queries fail with INVALID_ARGUMENT when sent concurrently with signals and workflow start in a single activation.
cards.rootCause: Interceptors running async functions cause a race condition where the workflow function is not invoked before query handlers are registered, causing queries to fail when delivered in the same activation as start workflow and signal jobs.
cards.proposedFix: Buffer the query until the workflow function has been invoked to ensure handler registration completes before query processing.
cards.workaround: Ensure signals are awaited before sending queries to the workflow.
cards.keyQuote: I think the solution here is to buffer the query until workflow function has been invoked.

cards.summary: Feature request to support connecting to multiple server addresses from the Core API and optionally the Node gRPC client, similar to the Go SDK implementation.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot connect to multiple server addresses for failover or load-balancing scenarios.
cards.proposedFix: Implement support for multiple server addresses in Core API and Node gRPC client, potentially using custom gRPC resolvers.
cards.workaround: Custom gRPC resolvers can be used to achieve this, though they are marked as experimental in grpc-js.
cards.resolutionDetails: Closed due to lack of demand.
cards.keyQuote: Custom gRPC resolvers can be used to achieve this. Those are marked as experimental in grpc-js and not exposed in the Core API.

cards.summary: Request to automatically publish to npm with the 'next' tag on merge to main branch, allowing users to test new features and fixes before official releases without waiting for a release process.
cards.userImpact: Users can test new SDK features and fixes earlier by installing the 'next' tag version, improving feedback loops for samples and documentation updates.
cards.proposedFix: Implement automated npm publishing to 'next' tag on merge to main branch
cards.resolutionDetails: Merged into issue #170 which implemented the automated release workflow
cards.keyQuote: Automatically publish to npm with the `next` tag (`npm install temporalio@next`) on merge to `main`.

cards.summary: Discussion about whether the `condition` function should use strict boolean checks (=== true) instead of truthy checks. Users might expect `condition(() => array.length)` to work like an if statement, but truthy values could cause unexpected behavior.
cards.userImpact: Users may encounter unexpected behavior when using the condition function with truthy values that aren't strictly true, leading to confusing workflow execution.
cards.rootCause: The condition function uses truthy evaluation (if (cond.fn())) instead of strict boolean checking (if (cond.fn() === true)), which differs from standard if statement semantics.
cards.proposedFix: Use strict boolean check: `if (cond.fn() === true)`
cards.resolutionDetails: Acknowledged as too late to change at this point in the SDK's development without breaking changes.
cards.keyQuote: I think a lot of users would expect that condition behaves like an `if` statement. For example, one might expect `condition(() => array.length)` to resolve when there are new elements added to the array.

cards.summary: Worker crashes when Temporal server is down or goes offline, unable to reconnect. The TypeScript SDK should handle server unavailability gracefully like the Go SDK, allowing workers to be created before server is available and reconnect automatically when it comes back up.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot run workers independently of server availability, preventing parallel service operation and requiring manual worker restart when server recovers.
cards.rootCause: Worker enters FAILED state on transport errors during polling instead of attempting reconnection, with no retry mechanism for server unavailability.
cards.proposedFix: Implement automatic reconnection logic similar to Go SDK; allow worker creation before server is available; gracefully handle transport errors during polling with retry attempts.
cards.keyQuote: Worker should work like the Golang sdk, being able to create a worker even if the temporal server is down so I could have my other services running on parallel

cards.summary: The SDK is explicitly setting a default value for workflowIdReusePolicy, but the server already provides a default. This causes unnecessary duplication and potential inconsistency.
cards.userImpact: Users may experience unexpected behavior due to SDK-level defaults overriding server-level defaults, or confusion about which default applies.
cards.rootCause: The SDK explicitly sets a default value for workflowIdReusePolicy in workflow-options.ts instead of allowing the server to provide the default.
cards.proposedFix: Remove the SDK-level default for workflowIdReusePolicy and allow the server to provide the default value.
cards.resolutionDetails: The SDK-level default was removed to allow the server to handle the default value.
cards.keyQuote: The default is set by the server already.

cards.summary: WorkflowClient.execute() and WorkflowHandle.execute() have inconsistent parameter ordering - client takes options first while handle takes workflow type first. The request is to standardize the signatures for better API consistency.
cards.userImpact: Developers must remember different parameter orders when switching between WorkflowClient.execute() and WorkflowHandle.execute(), creating potential for confusion and errors.
cards.rootCause: Design decision to embed workflow type and options in WorkflowHandle led to different execute() signatures between client and handle.
cards.proposedFix: Two main proposals: (1) Pass arguments in an array: client.execute<T>('workflow', [arg1, arg2], options), or (2) Switch parameter order: client.execute<T>('workflow', options, arg1, arg2). Also suggested adding a variant that accepts a workflow function directly.
cards.resolutionDetails: Issue was addressed by standardizing the API to make WorkflowClient and WorkflowHandle signatures consistent.
cards.keyQuote: WorkflowClient should use the same signature as WorkflowHandle.

cards.summary: Feature request to make Worker.shutdown() return a Promise<void> instead of void, allowing cleaner async handling in test teardown code. After discussion, maintainers decided against this as shutdown is synchronous and returning the run promise would be confusing.
cards.userImpact: Users must manually await the run promise separately after shutdown instead of awaiting shutdown directly, requiring more boilerplate in test code.
cards.rootCause: Worker.shutdown() is a synchronous operation that only requests shutdown, making it inconsistent with async patterns.
cards.proposedFix: Return a Promise<void> from shutdown() or return the run promise from shutdown().
cards.workaround: Store the run promise separately and await it after calling shutdown().
cards.resolutionDetails: Maintainers decided against this because shutdown is a synchronous operation and returning the run promise would be confusing with weird stack traces. In production code, workers shut themselves down on signals rather than being explicitly shutdown.
cards.keyQuote: Shutdown ATM is a synchronous operation that only requests shutdown, making it return the run promise is a bit confusing especially because the stack trace would be weird.

cards.summary: Users can easily become confused by importing activity implementations directly instead of using registered activities, leading to unexpected behavior and potential webpack errors. The issue discusses whether to enforce stricter validation at registration time or improve documentation to guide proper activity usage.
cards.userImpact: Developers may accidentally import activity implementations directly, causing workflows to use unintended activity registrations or encounter webpack errors during bundling.
cards.rootCause: Workflows can only use activity type definitions at runtime, not implementations. TypeScript's type system is lost at runtime, making it impossible to enforce proper activity usage at compile time.
cards.proposedFix: Improve documentation with a FAQ entry explaining proper activity usage patterns and warning about webpack errors from incorrect imports.
cards.workaround: Use the same activities registered in the worker rather than importing implementations directly; rely on createActivityHandle's type inference for safety.
cards.resolutionDetails: Cannot be fixed due to TypeScript's type erasure at runtime. Solution is documentation-focused: help users understand proper activity patterns and troubleshoot webpack errors.
cards.keyQuote: Workflows can't import activity implementations, only type definitions, these types are lost at runtime. Due to this limitation it isn't possible to "fix" the issue.

cards.summary: Querying a complete workflow twice fails on the second query with an internal error about a nonexistent run ID. The first query succeeds but subsequent queries to the same completed workflow throw errors.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot reliably query completed workflows multiple times, limiting the ability to retrieve workflow results after completion.
cards.rootCause: The SDK core was not properly handling queries on completed workflows, causing cache invalidation issues with run IDs.
cards.resolutionDetails: Fixed in sdk-core via PR #199; issue was resolved in the main branch and addressed in the next Node SDK release.
cards.keyQuote: The second query should be successful otherwise better error message is expected.

cards.summary: SDK version was being read redundantly from package.json instead of using the already-loaded pkg module. The issue was that package.json was being accessed multiple times when the pkg module should have been reused for efficiency.
cards.userImpact: No direct user impact; this is an internal code quality issue where redundant file access could cause minor performance inefficiency.
cards.rootCause: package.json was being read directly in conversions.rs instead of reusing the already-loaded pkg module, causing redundant file access.
cards.proposedFix: Use the pkg module instead of reading package.json again to eliminate the redundant file access.
cards.resolutionDetails: Resolved by removing the redundant package.json access and using the pkg module instead, implemented in PR #288.
cards.keyQuote: I'd still change to use the `pkg` module instead of reading package.json again.

cards.summary: The SDK cannot currently use pure ESM npm modules like node-fetch@3 due to hardcoded CommonJS Webpack configuration. As the Node ecosystem increasingly adopts ESM, this limitation will become a growing problem requiring a bundling solution that supports both ESM and CommonJS.
cards.userImpact: Users are unable to use pure ESM npm modules in their Temporal applications and must downgrade to older CommonJS versions.
cards.rootCause: Webpack configuration is hardcoded to CommonJS, preventing import of pure ESM modules.
cards.proposedFix: Implement a smooth bundling solution that supports both ESM and CommonJS modules.
cards.workaround: Downgrade to older CommonJS versions of packages (e.g., node-fetch@2 instead of @3).
cards.resolutionDetails: A sample ESM solution was created and subsequently implemented in a subsequent release.
cards.keyQuote: over time, this will increasingly be a problem, as more and more of the Node ecosystem goes pure ESM

cards.summary: Feature request to add validation in createChildWorkflowHandle to ensure the child workflow is registered and exported, with the workflow function name matching the export name. This helps catch configuration errors early with better error messages.
cards.userImpact: Users get confusing errors when they mistakenly create child workflow handles for unregistered workflows, making debugging difficult.
