cards.proposedFix: Add a check in createChildWorkflowHandle that validates the workflow is registered (exported) and verify that the function name matches the export name, with validation scoped to the same Worker/task queue.
cards.resolutionDetails: Feature implemented with validation added to createChildWorkflowHandle for registered workflows on the same Worker.
cards.keyQuote: Add a check in createChildWorkflowHandle that it gets a registered workflow (e.g. exported) and verify that the function name matches the export name.

cards.summary: Feature request for signal total ordering - ensuring signals are processed in the exact order they're received globally across signal types in TypeScript workflows. The discussion explores various implementation approaches including object-based handlers, channel-based queuing, and serial processing utilities.
cards.userImpact: Users requiring strict signal ordering across multiple signal types must implement custom queuing logic rather than relying on native SDK support.
cards.rootCause: SDK does not provide built-in support for global signal ordering; only per-signal-type ordering is available.
cards.proposedFix: Multiple proposals discussed: (1) signals prop as object/function handler, (2) _globalHandler registration, (3) registerSignalHandler API, (4) channel-based user-space implementation with async-mutex.
cards.workaround: Implement channel-based queuing pattern locally; use async-mutex npm package for serial processing of signals.
cards.resolutionDetails: Closed as not planned - decision made to keep feature in user-space rather than add SDK support, with option to revisit if more requests received.
cards.keyQuote: this is all possible to implement in userspace. If we get enough requests for this we'll revisit.

cards.summary: Feature request to help catch use-before-define bugs when imperative APIs for signals and queries are defined after workflow start time. Proposes warning logs in development and/or buffering signals until handlers are registered.
cards.userImpact: Users may accidentally define signal or query handlers after workflow start, causing signals to be lost or queries to fail, but lack visibility into this bug.
cards.rootCause: Imperative dynamic API allows signals and queries to be defined after workflow start time, creating a window where messages arrive before handlers exist.
cards.proposedFix: Buffer signals until a listener is registered; queue them for delivery when the handler is defined. For queries, ensure they're registered before invocation or return an error.
cards.resolutionDetails: Implementation decided to buffer signals until listener is registered and require queries to be registered before invocation.
cards.keyQuote: We're buffering signals until a listener is registered. Queries must be registered before invoked or the caller will get an error.

cards.summary: Activity heartbeat options are duplicated in the API documentation, appearing twice on the same documentation page. This suggests a potential documentation generation or configuration issue.
cards.userImpact: Users are confused by redundant documentation entries for the same heartbeat functionality.
cards.rootCause: Documentation generation process may have a bug causing duplicate entries, or the source configuration has duplicate definitions.
cards.resolutionDetails: Documentation duplication issue was resolved through fix to documentation generation or source configuration.
cards.keyQuote: is this a symptom that something is wrong?

cards.summary: Request to make workflow.sleep() accept arguments in milliseconds (ms) for consistent API with timeout parameters throughout the SDK.
cards.userImpact: Users would have a more consistent API experience when working with sleep durations and timeouts across different Temporal SDK methods.
cards.proposedFix: Change workflow.sleep() arguments to pass through milliseconds to align with SDK timeout parameter conventions.
cards.resolutionDetails: Issue was closed, indicating the feature was implemented or resolved.
cards.keyQuote: for consistent api with our timeouts

cards.summary: Feature request to replace the workDir parameter with a utility function and switch to using nodeModulesPaths array for webpack configuration in the TypeScript SDK Worker. The discussion explores better approaches for resolving workflow and module paths.
cards.userImpact: Users need a clearer, more intuitive API for specifying workflow and node_modules paths when creating workers.
cards.rootCause: Current workDir and nodeModulesPath parameters are not intuitive; using require.resolve() would be more ergonomic
cards.proposedFix: Use require.resolve('./workflows') to resolve workflow paths instead of manual workDir specification
cards.workaround: Users can manually specify nodeModulesPath as an absolute path if the default resolution doesn't work
cards.resolutionDetails: The team converged on using require.resolve() for path resolution, which is simpler than adding utility functions
cards.keyQuote: even better IMHO: Worker.create({ workflowsPath: require.resolve('./workflows'), activities, taskQueue: 'test' })

cards.summary: User requests ability to specify a different task queue when using continueAsNew to transition a workflow to a new execution. The feature is already supported by ContinueAsNewOptions but is not properly exposed in the public API documentation.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot easily discover or use the existing task queue parameter when continuing workflows as new, requiring workarounds or external guidance.
cards.rootCause: ContinueAsNewOptions type was not exported from the public API, making it inaccessible to users despite the functionality being implemented.
cards.proposedFix: Export ContinueAsNewOptions from the public API and update documentation to show task queue parameter usage.
cards.workaround: Users can reference the internal definition and manually construct options, but this is not discoverable.
cards.resolutionDetails: ContinueAsNewOptions was exported and documentation was updated to properly expose the task queue parameter.
cards.keyQuote: ContinueAsNewOptions already does in fact allow setting a task queue, so this should work already.

cards.summary: The publish-to-verdaccio script fails with ECONNREFUSED when the local registry storage directory exists from a previous run, and also modifies package.json files on the first attempt, causing uncommitted changes on retry.
cards.userImpact: Developers cannot use the publish-to-verdaccio script without manually cleaning up registry state and handling lerna modifications to package.json files.
cards.rootCause: The registry storage directory persists between runs, causing connection failures. Lerna modifies package.json files during the publish attempt, leaving uncommitted changes.
cards.workaround: Remove the entire /tmp/registry directory instead of just /tmp/registry/storage before running the script.
cards.resolutionDetails: Changed cleanup command from 'rm /tmp/registry/storage' to 'rm /tmp/registry' to ensure registry state is completely reset.
cards.keyQuote: Fixed by changing `rm /tmp/registry/storage` to `rm /tmp/registry`

cards.summary: Feature request to add dynamic signal and query handler registration in TypeScript SDK workflows, enabling DSL creation and high-level abstractions like awaitable Signal objects during workflow execution.
cards.userImpact: Enables developers to build DSLs and high-level abstractions on top of Temporal by dynamically registering signal and query handlers during workflow execution.
cards.proposedFix: Expose registerSignalHandler and registerQueryHandler functions in the @temporalio/workflow module to allow dynamic handler registration.
cards.resolutionDetails: Feature implemented - dynamic handler registration is now supported in the SDK.
cards.keyQuote: This is useful for building DSLs on top of Temporal and can enable high level abstractions such as an awaitable Signal object

cards.summary: Update the server version-feature mapping to include Node.js SDK support for execution chain following. Also verify that SDK version info is being properly sent to the server.
cards.userImpact: Without the version mapping update, the execution chain following fix won't be utilized until the server recognizes the Node.js SDK version.
cards.rootCause: The execution chain following fix requires an updated version-feature mapping on the server side to recognize and use the capability from the Node.js SDK.
cards.proposedFix: Update the server version mapping to include Node.js SDK support, and consider sending client capabilities from the client instead of relying on version mapping.
cards.resolutionDetails: Issue closed; mapping was updated as a post-release task. Related sdk-features issue #142 opened to track SDKs sending client capabilities.
cards.keyQuote: The fix we made to follow execution chains under the new model won't be used until we add node to the version mapping

cards.summary: Support for single-file workflows path in Worker configuration. Currently workflowsPath only accepts directories, but users need the ability to specify a single workflow file (e.g., ./workflows.js) instead of requiring a directory structure.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot use simplified single-file workflow structures and must organize workflows in directories, limiting flexibility in project structure.
cards.rootCause: The isolate-builder module requires file extensions and only supports directory-based workflow loading, not individual files.
cards.proposedFix: Make workflowsPath flexible to accept both files and directories by adjusting module resolution logic and supporting require.resolve() patterns for both workflowsPath and interceptorModules.
cards.workaround: Use directory-based structure with workflows in a separate directory (e.g., ./workflows/ instead of ./workflows.js)
cards.resolutionDetails: Implementation made workflowsPath flexible to support both single files and directories through module resolution adjustments.
cards.keyQuote: The webpack module resolver should be able to work with an absolute or relative path that resolves to a folder or file

cards.summary: Feature request to add workflow history replay capability to the TypeScript SDK. This is a critical feature for debugging workflows by replaying exported history from tctl and Temporal web, similar to other SDKs.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot replay exported workflow histories for debugging purposes, limiting their ability to troubleshoot workflow behavior issues.
cards.proposedFix: Expose a convenient API in the TypeScript SDK to replay workflow history against a given Worker, leveraging mock pollers in the core.
cards.resolutionDetails: Implemented history replay capability in the TypeScript SDK by exposing a convenient API that uses core mock pollers.
cards.keyQuote: Other SDKs have the ability to replay exported Workflow history, this is a critical feature for Workflow debuggability.

cards.summary: When a new TypeScript SDK project is run without a local Temporal instance, users receive a cryptic [TransportError: transport error] message instead of helpful guidance. The request is for a more informative error message that explains what went wrong.
cards.userImpact: New users get a cryptic error message that doesn't explain why their worker failed to start, making it difficult to troubleshoot connection issues.
cards.rootCause: When Core cannot connect to a Temporal server, it propagates a generic TransportError that lacks context about the actual problem.
cards.resolutionDetails: Issue was resolved by implementing connection retry logic with warnings instead of immediate failure, as noted in issue #290.
cards.keyQuote: Not relevant anymore since we will log a warning and retry when Core cannot connect (#290)

cards.summary: A stack overflow error occurs when gathering forwarded logs from the core worker on shutdown, caused by conflicting `takeWhile` and `repeat` operators in the log collection logic.
cards.userImpact: Users see warning messages about failure to gather logs during worker shutdown, indicating incomplete log collection during graceful termination.
cards.rootCause: Conflicting `takeWhile` and `repeat` reactive operators causing infinite recursion in the log forwarding stream
cards.keyQuote: Error gathering forwarded logs from core RangeError: Maximum call stack size exceeded

cards.summary: Request to hide the isolateExecutionTimeout worker option and default to the workflow task timeout instead, as there are already many exposed options and isolates are entered multiple times during a single workflow task execution.
cards.userImpact: Simplifies worker configuration by reducing exposed options while maintaining sensible defaults based on workflow task timeout.
cards.proposedFix: Hide the isolateExecutionTimeout option and default to workflow task timeout
cards.resolutionDetails: Implemented in PR #264
cards.keyQuote: There are already a lot of exposed options, it'd be better to default to the workflow task timeout.

cards.summary: Request to add timestamps to the logger interface in the TypeScript SDK. This is a feature request to enhance logging capabilities by including timestamp information.
cards.userImpact: Users would be able to track timing information in logs for better debugging and monitoring of workflow execution.
cards.resolutionDetails: Issue was closed, indicating the feature was implemented or resolved.
cards.keyQuote: If you want I'll add that after this PR or just DIY

cards.summary: Integration tests are experiencing flakiness related to shutdown ordering in the Core component. The issue was identified and fixed in Core's shutdown sequencing logic.
cards.userImpact: Tests fail intermittently due to shutdown ordering issues, reducing test reliability and developer confidence in the test suite.
cards.rootCause: Problem with shutdown ordering in Core component causing race conditions during test execution
cards.proposedFix: Fixed shutdown ordering in Core
cards.resolutionDetails: Fixed by correcting shutdown ordering in Core component
cards.keyQuote: Pretty sure I fixed this actually. It was a problem with shutdown ordering in Core.

cards.summary: Lerna was not properly versioning the meta package according to its dependencies, resulting in breaking changes not being reflected in version bumps. The changelog generation was also broken, with commits being misclassified and duplicated across packages. The issue was resolved by adopting a single version for all packages in the monorepo.
cards.userImpact: Users were receiving misleading version numbers that didn't reflect the severity of breaking changes, making it difficult to understand compatibility between releases.
cards.rootCause: Lerna's automatic versioning algorithm did not understand that the meta package version should be incremented based on its dependencies, and the changelog generation was misinterpreting commit conventions.
cards.proposedFix: Implement a single version for all packages in the monorepo, replace automatic changelog generation with manual editing of a single CHANGELOG, and validate PR titles for conventional commit format instead of checking commits.
cards.resolutionDetails: Adopted a single version for all packages with a unified changelog. Removed automatic conventional commit checking in favor of PR title validation. Changelog is now manually edited before release.
cards.keyQuote: lerna does not understand that the meta package (`temporalio`) version should be incremented according to its dependencies.

cards.summary: Feature request to support asynchronous activity completion in TypeScript SDK, similar to Go SDK. Currently activities must return immediately even if work continues asynchronously, requiring workarounds with signals for long-running operations.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot elegantly handle long-running asynchronous activities without creating extra signals or resource leaks in the worker.
cards.rootCause: The TypeScript SDK lacks a mechanism to allow the worker to 'forget' about an activity so it can be completed asynchronously without worker tracking.
cards.proposedFix: Implement asynchronous activity completion support similar to the Go SDK, allowing the worker to release ownership of an activity so it can be completed independently via the service client.
cards.workaround: Use WorkflowService.respondActivityTaskCompleted directly, but this causes resource leaks as the worker continues tracking the activity.
cards.resolutionDetails: Core support was added and implementation was planned by bergundy to be done after beta release.
cards.keyQuote: In the Go SDK you can 'asynchronously complete an activity': we would like the same in node.

cards.summary: User proposes changing the parameter order for injected workflow functions so that `workflowInfo` is passed as the last optional parameter instead of first, arguing this is more intuitive and aligns better with the method signature defined in the interface.
cards.userImpact: Users find the current parameter order counter-intuitive and would prefer `workflowInfo` as the last parameter to match common patterns and better align with defined interfaces.
cards.proposedFix: Move `workflowInfo` from the first parameter position to the last optional parameter position in injected workflow functions.
cards.resolutionDetails: Acknowledged as probably too late for a breaking change, indicating the team decided not to implement this due to backwards compatibility concerns.
cards.keyQuote: Having it first clashes more in my mind with the interface than if it were last. In both cases, the signature doesn't match, but if it's last, at least my assumption that the first arg will be `message` holds.

cards.summary: Worker crashes intermittently during load tests with a V8 promise hook assertion failure. The crash occurs in native code during promise processing and is difficult to reproduce locally.
cards.userImpact: Workers crash unpredictably under load, causing workflow execution interruptions and requiring manual restarts.
cards.rootCause: V8 promise hook assertion failure in native code (workflow-isolate-extension.cc:47), indicating improper handling of promise state during high-concurrency scenarios.
cards.proposedFix: Merge PR #264 to address underlying promise handling; add detailed assertion messages per PR #268 for better diagnostics.
cards.resolutionDetails: Issue resolved through related PR #268 which added more informative assertion error messages. Root cause addressed by architectural changes in PR #264.
cards.keyQuote: node: ../workflow-isolate-extension.cc:47: void custom_promise_hook(v8::PromiseHookType, v8::Local<v8::Promise>, v8::Local<v8::Value>): Assertion `!result.IsEmpty()' failed.

cards.summary: Feature request to add default WorkflowOptions to WorkflowClient constructor, allowing users to specify task queue and other options once instead of repeatedly when creating workflow handles.
cards.userImpact: Reduces boilerplate code by allowing users to set common workflow options once at client creation instead of repeating them for each handle creation.
cards.proposedFix: Add a `defaults` or `workflowDefaults` attribute to `WorkflowClientOptions` interface containing default `WorkflowOptions` for new handles, making `createWorkflowHandle`'s options parameter optional.
cards.resolutionDetails: WorkflowClient now has a `workflowDefaults` option that allows users to set default workflow options at client creation time.
cards.keyQuote: It would be nice to provide the task queue once on `WorkflowClient` creation instead of every time when a WorkflowHandle is created.

cards.summary: Add support for protobuf payload converters (JSON and binary formats) to the TypeScript SDK to enable full cross-language interoperability. This requires implementing a payload converter and integrating it with the default data converter.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot fully support cross-language calls without protobuf payload converter support, limiting interoperability between Temporal SDKs.
cards.proposedFix: Implement a payload converter that supports reading and writing protobuf payloads (both JSON and binary formats) and add it to the default data converter.
cards.resolutionDetails: Protobuf payload converter support was implemented and added to the default data converter for TypeScript SDK.
cards.keyQuote: To fully support cross language calls we need to support the json and binary protobuf payload types.

cards.summary: Load tests fail intermittently due to DEADLINE EXCEEDED errors on query requests in the TypeScript SDK. Investigation revealed the root cause was a server-side query timeout issue, which was fixed upstream. Test stability was also improved by tuning down cached workflow limits.
cards.userImpact: Users running load tests experience intermittent failures due to query timeouts, making CI/CD pipelines unreliable.
cards.rootCause: Server-side bug in query implementation causing timeouts on sticky worker queries, fixed in temporalio/temporal#2033
cards.proposedFix: Tune down the number of cached workflows to stabilize builds; server-side fix applied upstream
cards.workaround: Retrying queries was attempted but proved unreliable as it could also result in timeouts
cards.resolutionDetails: Root cause fixed in upstream Temporal server (PR #2033). Stability improved by tuning cached workflow limits.
cards.keyQuote: The occasional DEADLINE EXCEEDED on query requests is a server issue which was fixed here: https://github.com/temporalio/temporal/pull/2033

cards.summary: Developer wants linting errors caught locally during development and commits, not just in CI. Currently commitlint runs only in GitHub workflows, missing issues that could be caught before pushing.
cards.userImpact: Developers must wait for CI feedback to catch commit message linting errors instead of catching them locally before pushing.
cards.rootCause: commitlint is only run as a GitHub workflow, not integrated into the local lint command or pre-commit hooks.
cards.proposedFix: Add commitlint to the local `npm run lint` command or as a pre-commit hook to catch errors before pushing.
cards.workaround: Run `npx commitlint --from origin/main` manually before pushing changes.
cards.resolutionDetails: Team decided to keep commitlint as a separate GH workflow rather than merging it with the lint command. Later removed commitlint from CI entirely.
cards.keyQuote: You can run commitlint yourself with: `npx commitlint --from origin/main`. Let's add that to `CONTRIBUTING.md`.

cards.summary: Activity registration changes broke external calling conventions. Documentation needed for how activities are called by type-string, and error messages should list available activities when a matching activity type isn't found.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot easily understand how to call activities externally and receive unclear errors when activity types are not found.
cards.rootCause: Activity registration changes altered how activities are called from outside the SDK without sufficient documentation or helpful error messages.
cards.proposedFix: Document the type-string calling convention and include available activities list in 'activity not found' error messages.
cards.resolutionDetails: Documentation was added at nodejs.temporal.io/api/namespaces/workflow#createactivityhandle and error messages improved.
cards.keyQuote: When we changed activity registration the way activities are called from outside of the SDK was broken/different. How that works should be documented and we should maintain compatibility going forward.

cards.summary: Documentation request to improve discoverability of the Context API by showing it as 'Context' instead of 'ContextImpl' in generated docs, and to list default activity options in a more accessible location.
cards.userImpact: Users have difficulty finding the Context API in documentation due to implementation class names being exposed instead of public interface names.
cards.rootCause: Documentation generation exposes internal implementation class names (ContextImpl) instead of public API interfaces.
cards.proposedFix: Update documentation generation to display 'Context' as the public API name, and consolidate default activity options documentation in a discoverable location.
cards.resolutionDetails: Resolved by issue #225 which redesigned the Context API implementation.
cards.keyQuote: Could this show up as `Context` instead of `ContextImpl`, so it's easier to find?

cards.summary: Feature request to support flexible workflow and method naming across language SDKs to enable seamless migration. Currently, the TypeScript SDK requires workflows to be named from filenames and use an `execute` method, creating incompatibilities with PHP and Java implementations that use custom method names.
cards.userImpact: Users migrating workflows from other languages like PHP or Java to TypeScript must rename methods and potentially restructure their code to comply with SDK conventions.
cards.rootCause: TypeScript SDK uses fixed naming conventions (file-based registration, `execute` method) whereas other language SDKs (PHP, Java) allow custom method names via decorators/annotations.
cards.proposedFix: Support custom method names using TypeScript decorators, or document a cross-language compatibility matrix showing naming restrictions and calling patterns.
cards.workaround: Define workflow interfaces in other languages with custom method names and call them from Node via stub interfaces that use the `execute` convention.
cards.resolutionDetails: The SDK team decided to maintain the `execute` method convention for consistency and rejected decorators to preserve JavaScript compatibility. Documentation of cross-language patterns was recommended instead.
cards.keyQuote: I think it would be a rude surprise for someone hoping to migrate to TypeScript to realize that they have to change a lot of legacy workflow interfaces.

cards.summary: Worker.create fails when activities is set to undefined, throwing MODULE_NOT_FOUND error instead of handling the undefined value gracefully. The SDK should either accept undefined activities or provide a clear error message.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot create workers with undefined activities parameter, preventing flexible worker initialization patterns.
cards.rootCause: The Worker.create method attempts to load activities module even when activities parameter is explicitly set to undefined, causing MODULE_NOT_FOUND error.
cards.workaround: Provide an activities object instead of leaving it undefined, or omit the activities parameter entirely.
cards.resolutionDetails: SDK was updated to handle undefined activities parameter gracefully without attempting module resolution.
cards.keyQuote: Worker.create with workDir and activities undefined does not work...it failed because of activities MODULE_NOT_FOUND

cards.summary: Feature request for official testing support in Node.js SDK, specifically for workflows and activities. Users need a TestWorkflowEnvironment similar to Java and Go SDKs, and better example projects with jest/eslint configuration.
cards.userImpact: Without proper testing infrastructure, developers cannot easily test workflows in the Node.js SDK, limiting its adoption despite testing being a major selling point of Temporal.
cards.rootCause: Core-based SDKs require a mocked server implementation for time-skipping support, which is a significant undertaking not yet completed for the Node.js SDK.
cards.proposedFix: Implement TestWorkflowEnvironment for Node.js SDK with time-skipping support and mocked activity context; include basic jest configuration and project references in example projects.
cards.workaround: Activities can be tested as async functions by mocking Context; workflows can be tested by running them with WorkflowClient, but this is not ideal.
cards.resolutionDetails: Closed as part of issue cleanup; test framework implementation was planned and subsequently completed for Core-based SDKs.
cards.keyQuote: Testability is a major selling point of Temporal but the Node SDK and its docs are currently lacking... There's no official support for testing Workflows and Activities.

cards.summary: TypeScript SDK needs to implement execution-chain following behavior that was fixed in the Go SDK (PR #527). This ensures proper handling of workflow execution chains in later server versions.
cards.userImpact: Workflows may not execute correctly with later server versions due to missing execution-chain following behavior.
cards.rootCause: TypeScript SDK lacks execution-chain following implementation that Go SDK implemented in PR #527.
cards.proposedFix: Implement the same execution-chain following behavior as the Go SDK fix (reference: https://github.com/temporalio/sdk-go/pull/527)
cards.resolutionDetails: Implementation aligned with Go SDK's execution-chain following behavior for later server version compatibility.
cards.keyQuote: See details from the Go fix here: https://github.com/temporalio/sdk-go/pull/527

cards.summary: Webpack compilation fails when importing built-in Node.js libraries like `fs` and `os` in the TypeScript SDK. The issue stems from webpack defaulting to 'web' target instead of 'node', causing it to require polyfills for core Node modules.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot use code that imports built-in Node.js libraries in workflows, blocking compilation and forcing workarounds through activities.
cards.rootCause: Webpack's default target is 'web' which doesn't support Node.js core modules; workflow isolation also prevents native node API usage.
cards.proposedFix: Set webpack target to 'node' in configuration to properly resolve built-in libraries.
cards.workaround: Use activities to access filesystem and other Node.js APIs instead of importing them directly in workflow code.
cards.resolutionDetails: Deterministic requirement: built-in Node APIs like `fs` cannot be used in workflows due to non-deterministic behavior. Users must use activities for filesystem access.
cards.keyQuote: `fs` is a native node API and cannot be imported in the Workflow isolate, you should use an activity to access the filesystem.

cards.summary: Request for OpenTracing support in the TypeScript SDK to enable distributed tracing across Node.js clients and Go workers. User needs traces to flow from workflow triggers through activities using existing OpenTracing infrastructure with Datadog backend.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot currently trace workflow execution end-to-end when using Node.js clients with existing OpenTracing infrastructure.
cards.proposedFix: Add OpenTracing support to the TypeScript SDK client, similar to Go SDK implementation, allowing tracers to be passed to client initialization and creating spans around workflow execution.
cards.keyQuote: I should be able to leverage my existing opentracing infrastructure to create spans when a workflow is triggered, and have this span encapsulate the entire workflow, including all activities.

cards.summary: Feature request to provide a method for accessing the worker's client instance from within activity code. Currently there's no easy way to get the same configured client from activities, which caused issues with activities using incorrect server URLs.
cards.userImpact: Activities cannot easily access the worker's configured client instance, forcing workarounds or incorrect client configurations.
cards.proposedFix: Add a method to activity.Context that returns the client instance used by the worker.
cards.workaround: Pass class instances as activities instead of using the client from context.
cards.resolutionDetails: Already supported by passing class instances as activities. Solution was documented in samples.
cards.keyQuote: Currently there's no easy way to get the *same* client that the worker/workflows use from inside an activity.

cards.summary: GitHub Actions tests occasionally fail with DEADLINE EXCEEDED errors due to reuse of the same client connection for concurrent tests. The issue only occurs on the weak GitHub Actions executors, not in local development environments.
cards.userImpact: Developers experience flaky test failures in CI/CD pipelines that don't reproduce locally, making it difficult to validate code quality.
cards.rootCause: Reuse of the same client connection for all concurrent tests causes deadline exceeded errors under resource constraints
cards.resolutionDetails: Resolved by updating GitHub Actions workflows to use the latest docker-compose tag from temporalio/temporal#2033
cards.keyQuote: Probably due to reuse of the same client connection for all concurrent tests. Does not happen in local dev environment, only on the weak GH actions executors

cards.summary: Enable the TypeScript SDK gRPC client to work in web browsers by leveraging gRPC-Web, with a client package free of non-proto core dependencies. This requires both client-side support and server-side infrastructure (proxy or HTTP/1.1 API).
cards.userImpact: Users can run the Temporal TypeScript SDK client in browser environments for web-based workflow interactions.
cards.proposedFix: Leverage gRPC-Web library and implement server-side proxy support (Envoy or built-in) or develop HTTP/1.1 API backend compatibility
cards.workaround: Use Envoy proxy or grpc-web proxy sidecar to translate browser requests to gRPC for server
cards.keyQuote: We're working on an HTTP/1.1 API that can be used to back running the TS SDK client in a browser.

cards.summary: The worker binary ID should be determined by the workflow bundle checksum rather than just the SDK version, to ensure consistent identification across deployments with the same code.
cards.userImpact: Workers may be incorrectly identified across deployments, making it difficult to track and manage workflow execution in production environments.
cards.rootCause: SDK version alone is insufficient as a binary ID; it doesn't reflect actual code changes and won't be consistent across deployments with identical code.
cards.proposedFix: Use SHA sum of the workflow bundle combined with SDK version as the binary ID, ensuring consistency across deployments while accounting for code changes.
cards.resolutionDetails: Implemented using SHA sum of the workflow bundle and SDK version as the binary ID, as documented in the worker.ts source code.
cards.keyQuote: I think what we do now is good enough (using sha sum of the workflow bundle and SDK version).

cards.summary: Remove the broken Worker suspend and resume polling methods from the TypeScript SDK. Core has moved WFT polling to background execution, making the current suspend/resume implementation incompatible. These methods should be disabled for now until properly reimplemented.
cards.userImpact: Users relying on suspend and resume methods for Worker control will have these features removed until properly reimplemented.
cards.rootCause: Core changed WFT polling to run in the background regardless of language-level polling requests, which breaks the suspend/resume implementation.
cards.proposedFix: Disable suspend and resume methods for now; reimplement properly in core at a later time.
cards.resolutionDetails: Feature was removed as part of the TypeScript SDK update to align with Core's background WFT polling approach.
cards.keyQuote: Since implemented we've decided to change WFT polling in Core to run in the background regardless of lang polling requests.

cards.summary: Review and optimize workflow activation logic in the TypeScript SDK, including handling of signals execution order, activation errors, and microtask synchronization requirements.
cards.userImpact: Users need clarity on how signals are processed in workflows and whether sequential delivery should be supported as an option.
cards.proposedFix: Maintain concurrent signal delivery (current behavior) and provide channel-based syntactic sugar for users who need sequential signal processing, rather than implementing framework-level sequential delivery options.
cards.workaround: Users can implement sequential signal processing using UnboundedChannel to buffer signals from signal handlers.
cards.resolutionDetails: Decision made to keep concurrent signal delivery model and document channel-based alternatives for sequential processing rather than add API complexity.
cards.keyQuote: As a Node dev, I'm used to the thought that my current function is going to be called non-sequentially, and program accordingly.

cards.summary: Feature request to make the deadline for workflow client and stub calls configurable. The issue was marked as completed, indicating the feature has been implemented.
cards.userImpact: Users can now configure deadlines for workflow client and stub calls, providing more control over execution timing.
cards.resolutionDetails: The feature was implemented to make deadlines configurable for workflow client and stub calls.
cards.keyQuote: This was done a while ago.

cards.summary: Module resolution error where the 'ms' package cannot be found when using @temporal/client in AWS Lambda environment. The error originates from @temporalio/workflow/lib/time.js but 'ms' is listed as a dependency in package.json.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot use @temporal/client library in AWS Lambda environments due to missing module dependency at runtime.
cards.rootCause: The 'ms' dependency may not be properly included in the Lambda deployment package or there's a bundling/installation issue specific to the Lambda environment.
cards.resolutionDetails: Could not be reproduced by maintainers in standard Node.js environment; dependency was confirmed to be present in package.json. Likely environment-specific issue.
cards.keyQuote: That's odd, I see it in the package.json for that release

cards.summary: API reference documentation shows repeated 'v1' namespace labels in the menu, appearing as a bug. User requests clarification by either showing both namespace and version (e.g., 'command.v1', 'common.v1') or omitting generated protobuf types from the reference.
cards.userImpact: Users find the API reference documentation confusing due to unclear labeling of namespace versions in the menu.
cards.rootCause: Generated protobuf types are displayed in the API reference menu without clear distinction between namespace and version labels.
cards.proposedFix: Either clarify menu items to show 'namespace.version' format (e.g., 'command.v1', 'common.v1') or omit generated protobuf types from the API reference entirely.
cards.resolutionDetails: Issue was addressed by considering whether to omit generated protobuf types from the API reference, related to issue #115.
cards.keyQuote: we might just want to omit the generated protobuf types from the API reference. Let's consider our options.

cards.summary: Documentation menu items are not in alphabetical order, forcing users to use search (Cmd-F) instead of scrolling. The author suggests sorting menu items to improve discoverability.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot easily find documentation items by scrolling and must resort to search functionality.
cards.proposedFix: Sort documentation menu items alphabetically.
cards.workaround: Use Cmd-F search to find desired documentation items.
cards.resolutionDetails: Maintainer indicated preference to exclude generated protobuf type definitions from API reference rather than implementing alphabetical sorting.
cards.keyQuote: Yeah, we might just want to not output any of the generated protobuf type defs in the API reference.

cards.summary: Mac developer encountered missing Rust/Cargo installation when following the Environment setup instructions. After discovering and following the building.md documentation and running lerna clean, the build succeeded. Clarification needed on whether all macOS developers need to follow building.md or just some.
cards.userImpact: macOS developers cannot build the SDK without discovering and following additional undocumented setup steps beyond the main contributing instructions.
cards.rootCause: The Environment setup instructions in the main documentation do not mention the Rust/Cargo requirement for building the core-bridge package on macOS.
cards.proposedFix: Add verification step 'which cargo' at the end of setup instructions and include a troubleshooting section mentioning 'npx lerna clean -- -f && npm ci' for environment resets.
cards.workaround: Follow the building.md instructions and run 'lerna clean -f' before building.
cards.resolutionDetails: Issue was clarified through discussion. Contributors should follow building.md for cross-compilation setup, but basic setup should be verified with 'which cargo' check. Troubleshooting section was suggested.
cards.keyQuote: Maybe we should conclude the setup part with a check `which cargo` to verify that everything was set up properly?

cards.summary: Proposal for a React-like API design for the TypeScript SDK that leverages the popularity and proven patterns of React to improve Temporal adoption and API design, while adapting for Temporal-specific concepts like Sagas, hook registration, and external invocations.
cards.userImpact: A React-like API could significantly improve developer adoption and experience for JavaScript developers familiar with React, while providing better type safety and more intuitive workflow definition patterns.
cards.proposedFix: Implement a class-based workflow API with decorator-like signal/query registration, activity registration as class properties, and factory functions for type-safe workflow instantiation, with optional factory pattern and function-style definitions.
cards.resolutionDetails: The strawman proposal was used to inform the actual TypeScript SDK API design, which incorporated many of these concepts including class-based workflows, signals, and queries.
cards.keyQuote: it might help solve some of our API design challenges (by starting from something already proven) and our adoption might be helped GREATLY since most JS people know React.

cards.summary: Implement incremental sequence numbers for correlation IDs between the TypeScript SDK and core runtime to improve tracing and debugging capabilities.
cards.userImpact: Users will have better ability to trace requests between the TypeScript SDK and core runtime through unique, sequential correlation IDs.
cards.resolutionDetails: Issue was resolved by implementing incremental sequence numbers for correlation IDs, dependent on the completion of sdk-core issue #164
cards.keyQuote: Depends on https://github.com/temporalio/sdk-core/issues/164

cards.summary: Remove the `CancelledError` class from the workflow library and replace it with `CancelledFailure` to maintain consistency with the Java SDK after porting the failure classes.
cards.userImpact: Users will need to update code that catches or handles CancelledError to use CancelledFailure instead, ensuring consistency across SDKs.
cards.rootCause: CancelledError existed before failure classes were ported from Java SDK; now redundant with CancelledFailure.
cards.proposedFix: Remove CancelledError and use CancelledFailure for all cancellation scope cancellations.
cards.resolutionDetails: CancelledError was removed and replaced with CancelledFailure to align with Java SDK implementation.
cards.keyQuote: Now that we've ported the failure classes from the Java SDK we should use them.

cards.summary: Build fails with TypeScript module resolution errors for @temporalio packages when running `npm run build` in the SDK monorepo. The issue was resolved by running `npx lerna clean -- -f && npm ci && npm run build` to properly clean and reinstall dependencies.
cards.userImpact: Developers cannot build the SDK from source without performing a full clean rebuild with specific command flags.
cards.rootCause: Stale or incomplete node_modules state from previous builds, requiring full cleanup and reinstallation via lerna clean and npm ci.
cards.proposedFix: Run `npx lerna clean -- -f && npm ci && npm run build` instead of just `npm run build`.
cards.workaround: Execute lerna clean with -f flag followed by npm ci before building: `npx lerna clean -- -f && npm ci && npm run build`
cards.resolutionDetails: Issue was resolved by running proper cleanup and reinstall commands; the solution was confirmed working by the issue reporter.
cards.keyQuote: Thank you, that worked! npx lerna clean -- -f && npm ci && npm run build

cards.summary: Worker fails to start when no workflows directory is configured, throwing an error about missing WorkerOptions. If the workflows directory exists but is empty, webpack fails with a file not found error.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot create a Worker without specifying workflows, blocking basic worker setup scenarios.
cards.rootCause: Worker initialization code requires either a workDir option or both workflowsPath and nodeModulesPath, and webpack fails when the workflows directory is empty or missing.
cards.proposedFix: Allow Worker to start with no configured workflowsPath or nodeModulesPath, and skip creating Workflow isolates in such cases.
cards.resolutionDetails: Worker initialization logic was modified to handle cases where no workflows are configured.
cards.keyQuote: Worker starts with no configured `workflowsPath` or `nodeModulesPath`, does not create Workflow isolates.

cards.summary: @temporalio/proto package had an unnecessary dependency on @temporalio/core-bridge, which was added only to work around a Lerna versioning issue. This caused clients to indirectly depend on core-bridge despite the Rust compilation overhead being irrelevant to proto consumers.
cards.userImpact: Clients consuming @temporalio/proto are forced to depend on core-bridge, introducing unnecessary Rust compilation overhead and build complexity.
cards.rootCause: Lerna doesn't increment a package's version unless something changes in git, so core-bridge was added as a dependency to @temporalio/proto to trigger version bumps.
cards.proposedFix: Move proto definitions into the proto package or create a separate package for the sdk-core submodule. The issue was resolved by using a single version for all SDK packages, allowing safe removal of the dependency.
cards.resolutionDetails: Adopted a single version numbering scheme for all SDK packages, eliminating the need for the artificial dependency on core-bridge.
cards.keyQuote: the client relies on the proto package while it shouldn't rely on core because of the Rust compilation dependency

cards.summary: Automate the SDK release process, including automated releases to the 'next' tag on merge to 'main' branch. Implementation was tracked in a separate issue.
cards.userImpact: Users would receive releases automatically without manual intervention, improving release velocity and consistency.
cards.proposedFix: Implement automated release pipeline triggered on merge to main branch
cards.resolutionDetails: Implementation was completed as part of issue #1003 which handled the automated release process
cards.keyQuote: Automated release to `next` tag on merge to `main`

cards.summary: Simplify TypeScript project structure by consolidating multiple tsconfig files into a single configuration now that workflow code is bundled with Webpack, trading some type safety for better developer experience and reduced complexity.
cards.userImpact: Developers benefit from a simpler single tsconfig setup while needing to be more careful about accidentally using non-deterministic APIs in workflows.
cards.rootCause: The composite project structure with multiple tsconfigs is unnecessarily complex now that Webpack handles workflow bundling and can output CommonJS.
cards.proposedFix: Consolidate the 4 tsconfig files into a single configuration, update samples and documentation to reflect the new structure.
cards.resolutionDetails: The project structure was simplified by consolidating multiple TypeScript configuration files into a single configuration as agreed upon in the discussion.
cards.keyQuote: instead of 4 tsconfig files we can now have a single config file. Doing this means sacrificing some type safety

cards.summary: Feature request to improve activity registration and import patterns in TypeScript SDK. Currently uses scoped imports (@activities/something) for implicit type safety, but community members suggest alternative approaches: Context.activities<ActivityInterface>() for flexible registration or enforcing a single entry point (@activities/index.ts) to prevent duplicates.
cards.userImpact: Users need clearer, more flexible patterns for activity registration that balance convenience with explicitness and type safety.
cards.proposedFix: Three options discussed: 1) Support imports from parent directories (../activities), 2) Use Context.activities<T>() with Worker registration for flexible DI, 3) Enforce single @activities/index.ts entry point to prevent duplicates and confusion.
cards.resolutionDetails: Issue was resolved as activity registration patterns were improved in subsequent SDK updates.
cards.keyQuote: The @activities idiom still strikes me as odd. I'd prefer if this were changed to something unambiguous and preferably explicit.

cards.summary: Request to implement a stack trace query feature for the TypeScript SDK that can retrieve all stack traces from a Workflow isolate.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot currently retrieve stack traces from running workflows for debugging and troubleshooting purposes.
cards.resolutionDetails: Feature was implemented to provide stack trace query capability for workflow isolates
cards.keyQuote: Need to figure out how to get all of the stack traces from the Workflow isolate

cards.summary: Jaeger export functionality is broken in the TypeScript SDK performance tests, with spans not appearing in Jaeger. The issue suggests either fixing the exporter or switching to the OpenTelemetry collector exporter.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot properly trace and debug performance issues as spans are missing from Jaeger after running performance tests.
cards.proposedFix: Fix the Jaeger exporter or switch to the OpenTelemetry collector exporter
cards.keyQuote: It's clear that spans are missing in jaeger after running perf.

cards.summary: Worker performance degrades significantly over time during high-concurrency workload execution, with throughput dropping from ~100 WFs/s to ~10 WFs/s. Investigation identified that the SDK was leaking isolate references, causing memory pressure and CPU overhead.
cards.userImpact: Users running high-throughput workflows experience dramatic performance degradation over time, making the SDK unsuitable for sustained workloads.
cards.rootCause: SDK was leaking isolate references during workflow activation, causing memory pressure and preventing proper garbage collection.
cards.proposedFix: Fix pending - requires proper cleanup and disposal of workflow isolate context references after activation.
cards.workaround: Use a larger pool of isolates (e.g., 8 instead of 1) to reduce degradation severity, though this doesn't eliminate the problem.
cards.resolutionDetails: Isolate reference leak was identified and fixed through proper lifecycle management of workflow isolate contexts.
cards.keyQuote: After further investigation, seems like the cause was the SDK leaking isolate references.

cards.summary: Request to implement WorkflowStub.signalWithStart method in the TypeScript SDK client package, which is currently missing.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot signal a workflow at the time of its creation in TypeScript, requiring workarounds or additional API calls.
cards.resolutionDetails: WorkflowStub.signalWithStart was implemented and added to the client package
cards.keyQuote: Missing from the client package

cards.summary: CI installation from verdaccio private registry fails silently with no error logs, making it difficult to diagnose the root cause. Logging was added to provide better diagnostic information.
cards.userImpact: Developers experience CI failures with no diagnostic information when installing from private registries.
cards.rootCause: Insufficient logging in the installation process from verdaccio private registry.
cards.proposedFix: Add logging for more information about the installation process.
cards.resolutionDetails: Fixed by adding improved logging to provide diagnostic information during installation failures.
cards.keyQuote: Add logging for more information the next time this happens.

cards.summary: Query handlers should not be async because they can create commands and mutate state, breaking workflow determinism. The SDK should enforce this by throwing a DeterminismViolationError when a query handler returns a Promise.
cards.userImpact: Users can accidentally create async query handlers that violate workflow determinism and break execution, but the SDK doesn't prevent this.
cards.rootCause: Query handler type signature allows Promise return values, but async functions that create commands or mutate state are not recorded in workflow history.
cards.proposedFix: Throw DeterminismViolationError if a query handler returns a Promise at runtime.
cards.resolutionDetails: Resolved via PR #149
cards.keyQuote: query methods should not create commands (e.g timers / activities) or mutate state because they are not recorded in the workflow history and thus will break determinism

cards.summary: Request to port error classes from Java SDK to TypeScript SDK, including activity failure errors with isRetryable attribute for better error handling and retry logic.
cards.userImpact: Users lack standardized error classes and retry indicators for activities, making error handling inconsistent between SDKs.
cards.proposedFix: Port error classes from Java SDK to TypeScript SDK with isRetryable attribute
cards.resolutionDetails: Error classes were ported from Java SDK to TypeScript SDK with appropriate retry attributes
cards.keyQuote: Errors should have an `isRetryable` attributes.

cards.summary: Feature request to implement search attributes in the TypeScript SDK once they are supported in sdk-core. This was later resolved by PR #657.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot search and filter workflows based on custom attributes until this feature is implemented.
cards.proposedFix: Implement search attributes support once sdk-core provides the necessary foundation.
cards.resolutionDetails: Implemented via PR #657
cards.keyQuote: Once they are supported in sdk-core

cards.summary: Feature request to implement child workflows in the TypeScript SDK once they are supported by sdk-core.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot compose workflows by executing child workflows from parent workflows, limiting workflow design flexibility.
cards.resolutionDetails: Child workflows were implemented in the TypeScript SDK after sdk-core added support.
cards.keyQuote: Once they are supported by sdk-core

cards.summary: Feature request to implement ContinueAsNew functionality in the TypeScript SDK, pending support in sdk-core.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot continue workflows as new, limiting their ability to manage long-running workflow chains and restart state.
cards.resolutionDetails: ContinueAsNew functionality was implemented once sdk-core support became available.
cards.keyQuote: Once it is supported by sdk-core

cards.summary: CI workflow isolation timeout was too short, causing failures on slow GitHub Actions worker nodes. The fix involved increasing the isolate timeout to provide more time for the test environment to initialize.
cards.userImpact: CI builds were failing intermittently on slow GitHub Actions runners, blocking development and causing unreliable test results.
cards.rootCause: Workflow isolate timeout was configured too aggressively for the variability in GitHub Actions worker node performance.
cards.proposedFix: Increase the workflow isolate timeout to accommodate slower worker nodes.
cards.resolutionDetails: Timeout was increased to handle slow GitHub Actions worker nodes. Subsequent comment indicates the issue hasn't been seen recently, confirming the fix.
cards.keyQuote: Haven't seen this recently

cards.summary: Webpack's default eval-based devtool causes EvalError when running workflows in isolated-vm context. The issue occurs when isolate memory is below a certain threshold (~65GB), triggering code generation restrictions in isolated-vm.
cards.userImpact: Developers cannot run workflows with default webpack development settings, requiring workarounds like switching to production mode or disabling eval-based devtools.
cards.rootCause: Webpack's eval devtool generates code that triggers isolated-vm's code generation restrictions when isolate memory is below a critical threshold.
cards.proposedFix: Revert changes in #145 once isolated-vm fixes the underlying issue causing the threshold behavior.
cards.workaround: Use production mode instead of development, or configure webpack devtool to use something other than eval (e.g., 'source-map').
cards.resolutionDetails: Fixed in isolated-vm, allowing revert of #145 workaround.
cards.keyQuote: If I increase `maxIsolateMemoryMB` to 66250, my hello world example works fine. If I only increase `maxIsolateMemoryMB` to 65000, I get the same error.

cards.summary: Request to reorganize samples in the SDK repository for better browsability and maintainability. Discussion centered on managing shared configuration files and reducing duplication while keeping samples easy for developers to copy and use independently.
cards.userImpact: Developers can more easily find, understand, and copy sample code from the repository, improving onboarding experience.
cards.proposedFix: Move samples to a top-level directory with shared configuration managed via precommit hook that copies root tsconfig to each sample, balancing code reuse with developer convenience.
cards.resolutionDetails: Samples were moved out of the main repo into a separate `samples-node` repository with improved organization.
cards.keyQuote: precommit hook that copies root tsconfig to each sample - best of both worlds

cards.summary: Request to support custom data converters in Workflow isolates. Currently, custom data converters work in worker and client contexts but cannot be passed to Workflows that run in isolation without access to node libraries. The interface should be made asynchronous to support network requests and non-blocking compression.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot implement custom serialization logic for their domain objects in Workflows, limiting flexibility for specialized data handling requirements.
cards.rootCause: Workflows run in isolation without access to node libraries, making it complex to pass and execute custom data converters in that context.
cards.proposedFix: Make the data converter interface asynchronous and implement a mechanism to pass custom data converters to the Workflow isolate, following a proper proposal process.
cards.resolutionDetails: Custom data converters interface was made async (#158), and the mechanism to pass custom converters to Workflow isolates was implemented.
cards.keyQuote: While we're tacking this problem we might want to make the data converter interface asynchronous to facilitate network requests and non-blocking compression.

cards.summary: Add the missing `ActivityCancellationType` enum to `ActivityOptions` in the TypeScript SDK to provide programmatic control over how activities handle cancellation requests.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot programmatically specify cancellation behavior for activities, limiting control over activity execution policies.
cards.rootCause: The `ActivityCancellationType` enum exists in the protobuf definition and other SDKs but is not exposed in the TypeScript SDK's `ActivityOptions` interface.
cards.proposedFix: Add `ActivityCancellationType` enum and expose it as a field in `ActivityOptions` to match the proto definition.
cards.resolutionDetails: The ActivityCancellationType was added to ActivityOptions in the TypeScript SDK.
cards.keyQuote: Add missing `ActivityCancellationType` to `ActivityOptions`

cards.summary: Hello World sample workflow doesn't return output message when executed. User follows the Node.js getting started guide but receives no "Hello, Temporal!" message output when running the scheduled workflow script, though the workflow appears to run in Temporal Web.
cards.userImpact: Users following the getting-started guide cannot see expected output, making it unclear if the sample is working correctly.
cards.rootCause: Package version issue - the temporalio package version 0.2.2 had a bug that was fixed in 0.2.4
cards.resolutionDetails: Fixed by publishing temporalio@0.2.4 with @temporalio/proto@0.2.2
cards.keyQuote: No message returned when i start the Workflow, running getting started (hello world sample app)

cards.summary: Worker initialization fails with 'TypeError: otel.setSpan is not a function' when running the hello world sample application. The error occurs in the tracing module during worker startup and is caused by an OpenTelemetry dependency version incompatibility.
cards.userImpact: Users following the getting started guide cannot run the hello world sample, blocking initial setup and evaluation of the SDK.
cards.rootCause: OpenTelemetry library broke semantic versioning, causing API incompatibility between @temporalio/worker and its otel dependency.
cards.proposedFix: Updated temporalio to 0.2.2 and @temporalio/worker to 0.4.0 which fix the issue.
cards.resolutionDetails: Patch releases (temporalio@0.2.2, @temporalio/worker@0.4.0) were cut to fix the OpenTelemetry semver breakage.
cards.keyQuote: This has already been fixed in the main branch. Looks like opentelemetry broke semver.

cards.summary: Add Clippy linting to the TypeScript SDK CI pipeline. Clippy should be run as part of the continuous integration process to catch code quality issues, similar to how it's implemented in the Core repository.
cards.userImpact: Improved code quality and consistency through automated linting checks, reducing manual review burden.
cards.proposedFix: Integrate Clippy into the CI pipeline following the same pattern used in the Core repository's Buildkite definition.
cards.resolutionDetails: Clippy was successfully added to the CI pipeline as requested.
cards.keyQuote: I just your pipeline doesn't run clippy which would be a nice thing to do.

cards.summary: Feature request to review and expose timeout, retries, and reconnection configuration for the TypeScript SDK client connection, similar to the Java SDK's gRPC-level and SDK-level retry mechanisms.
cards.userImpact: Users need better control over connection retry behavior and timeouts to handle network issues and service unavailability more robustly.
cards.rootCause: The TypeScript SDK lacked configurable retry and timeout settings at both gRPC and SDK levels, unlike the Java SDK implementation.
cards.proposedFix: Expose retry configuration with sensible defaults, and handle automatic deadline propagation (though grpc-js may not support this).
cards.resolutionDetails: Implemented a configurable retryer that does not retry deadline exceeded errors by default, addressing the core requirement.
cards.keyQuote: Closing this since the retryer exists, is configurable, and does not retry deadline exceeded errors by default which is the right thing to do.

cards.summary: gRPC connection to Temporal Cloud drops during RPC calls with '14 UNAVAILABLE: Connection dropped' error. The error persists even after reconnection attempts and keep-alive configuration. Resolved by switching from grpc.Credentials to TLSConfig for TLS certificate management.
cards.userImpact: Users connecting to Temporal Cloud experience intermittent connection drops that require manual reconnection and retry logic.
cards.rootCause: Improper TLS credential configuration using grpc.credentials.createSsl() instead of the SDK's TLSConfig API, which caused connection instability against Cloud deployments.
cards.proposedFix: Use TLSConfig object with serverRootCACertificate and clientCertPair instead of grpc.credentials.createSsl() for mTLS connections.
cards.workaround: Implement automatic reconnection and retry logic on connection drop errors, then switch to proper TLSConfig API.
cards.resolutionDetails: Issue was resolved by the reporter by switching from grpc.Credentials.createSsl() to TLSConfig API for TLS certificate configuration.
cards.keyQuote: I was eventually able to solve this by switching from using grpc.Credentials to use TLSConfig for specifying the TLS certs

cards.summary: Request to automatically compile TypeScript code when running a worker, eliminating the need for users to maintain a separate watch process. This would streamline local development by combining compilation and worker execution into a single command.
cards.userImpact: Users currently need to manage multiple terminal processes for development; automatic compilation would simplify the local development setup.
cards.proposedFix: Integrate TypeScript compilation into the worker startup process, potentially leveraging webpack for source map generation.
cards.workaround: Maintain a separate terminal process that watches for file changes and invokes the TypeScript compiler.
cards.resolutionDetails: Implemented as part of the SDK's development tooling improvements.
cards.keyQuote: It would be great if running a worker did the compilation too. That way I could only run the worker in some cases.

cards.summary: Users have difficulty finding information in the TypeScript SDK documentation. A search feature is needed to improve discoverability, potentially using Algolia or alternative solutions.
cards.userImpact: Users spend more time navigating SDK documentation to find relevant information without a search feature.
cards.proposedFix: Implement a search feature in SDK documentation, exploring solutions without Algolia dependency if possible.
cards.resolutionDetails: Search functionality was implemented in the SDK documentation.
cards.keyQuote: hard to find things in the SDK docs, search would be nice!

cards.summary: Worker crashes with "ValueError: Unknown Encoding" error when processing payloads from old task queue entries. The issue occurs when stale workflows from previous runs use incompatible encoding, causing the data converter to fail.
cards.userImpact: Users encounter worker crashes when running hello world samples if old task queue entries exist, requiring task queue name changes to work around the issue.
cards.rootCause: Payload metadata contains non-unicode characters from old workflow executions that the data converter cannot deserialize, causing the worker to fail.
cards.proposedFix: Improve error message handling and prevent malformed payloads from killing the entire worker process.
cards.workaround: Change task queue names to use a fresh queue without old entries.
cards.resolutionDetails: User identified the root cause as stale task queue entries; issue resolved by changing task queue names. Worker error handling was improved to be more resilient.
cards.keyQuote: This problem goes away when I change task queue names, so I think it may be due to an old entry in the task queue causing issues.

cards.summary: Activity identifiers in the TypeScript SDK include the module name using JSON.stringify([module, functionName]), but this is inconsistent with other SDKs. The fix should use only the function name as the identifier and have the Worker throw an error on duplicate activity names.
cards.userImpact: Users experience inconsistent activity naming behavior compared to other Temporal SDKs, and cannot easily refactor activities to different modules.
cards.rootCause: The TypeScript SDK uses JSON.stringify([module, functionName]) instead of just the function name for activity identifiers, creating a cross-SDK inconsistency.
cards.proposedFix: Use only the function name as the activity identifier and have the Worker throw an error if multiple activities are registered with the same name.
cards.resolutionDetails: Changed activity identifier generation to use only the function name instead of including the module, with duplicate name validation in the Worker.
cards.keyQuote: We should be consistent with the other SDKs and use only the function name.

cards.summary: Feature request to implement a configurable timeout for workflow activation to prevent workers from becoming unresponsive when workflows enter infinite loops. This would limit CPU usage and thread pool occupation caused by stuck workflows.
cards.userImpact: Workers can become unresponsive and consume excessive CPU when workflows get stuck in infinite loops, impacting application stability.
cards.rootCause: Workflows without execution time limits can run indefinitely, blocking worker threads and consuming resources.
cards.proposedFix: Use a configurable timeout parameter (similar to isolated-vm's timeout option) to limit workflow activation time.
cards.resolutionDetails: Implemented configurable workflow activation timeout to prevent unresponsive workers from stuck workflows.
cards.keyQuote: Use a configurable timeout to limit the WF activation time.

cards.summary: The `npm init @temporalio` command may fail when users run it a second time after a new version of `@temporalio/create` is released, because npm doesn't update the cached package which may contain an incompatible project template.
cards.userImpact: Users attempting to initialize new projects using the recommended command may encounter failures if they've previously used it with an older version of the create package.
cards.rootCause: npm init does not update cached packages, so @temporalio/create remains at the old version which may have incompatible project templates for newer temporalio versions.
cards.proposedFix: Hardcode the temporalio version in the published @temporalio/create package, or recommend using `npx @temporalio/create@latest` which forces package updates.
cards.workaround: Use `npx @temporalio/create@latest` instead of `npm init @temporalio` to ensure the latest version is used.
cards.resolutionDetails: The team stopped recommending `npm init @temporalio` in favor of the `npx @temporalio/create@latest` approach due to this npm limitation.
cards.keyQuote: We stopped recommending `npm init @temporalio` for the package initializer due to this limitation.

cards.summary: Add debugger support for Workflow code running in v8 isolates. Currently debugging workflows is not possible, which is a critical usability gap that needs comprehensive implementation and documentation.
cards.userImpact: Developers cannot debug workflow code, severely limiting their ability to troubleshoot and develop complex workflows.
cards.proposedFix: Implement v8 inspector integration for isolated workflow contexts, using isolated-vm inspector example as reference.
cards.resolutionDetails: Debugger support was implemented for workflows running in isolates.
cards.keyQuote: Debugging Workflows should be as seamless as possible (considering the limitations when working with multiple v8 contexts).

cards.summary: Workflow stack traces show compiled JavaScript line numbers instead of TypeScript source line numbers, making debugging difficult. The solution is to generate and use source maps similar to ts-node, which may require building the Workflow Isolate from TypeScript sources instead of compiled JS.
cards.userImpact: Developers cannot easily debug workflow code because stack traces point to compiled JavaScript files instead of original TypeScript sources.
cards.rootCause: Workflow Isolate is built from compiled JS files (./lib) instead of TypeScript sources (./src), losing source map information in the process.
cards.proposedFix: Build the Workflow Isolate from TypeScript sources with proper source map generation, similar to how ts-node handles source maps.
cards.workaround: Use ts-node to get workflow error stack traces with proper line numbers.
cards.resolutionDetails: Implemented source map support for workflow isolate stack traces to show TypeScript source locations instead of compiled JavaScript.
cards.keyQuote: Stack traces should include the source code the way they do in ts-node.

cards.summary: Proposal to create a shared dependency package that both the worker and client packages can depend on, reducing duplication and improving maintainability across the TypeScript SDK.
cards.userImpact: Reduces SDK complexity and improves long-term maintainability by eliminating shared dependency duplication between worker and client packages.
cards.proposedFix: Create a lower-level shared dependency package that both worker and client packages can depend on.
cards.resolutionDetails: Implemented shared dependency package for worker and client
cards.keyQuote: Any reason not to just make a lower dep they can share?

cards.summary: Refactor the native Rust bridge value extraction code by replacing a repetitive 3-line pattern with a reusable macro to improve code cleanliness and maintainability.
cards.userImpact: No direct user impact; improves developer experience by reducing code duplication in the native bridge implementation.
cards.proposedFix: Replace the 3-line repetitive value extraction pattern with a Rust macro that abstracts the get, downcast, and value operations.
cards.resolutionDetails: The enhancement was implemented to clean up the native bridge code using a macro pattern.
cards.keyQuote: Replace it with this... macro_rules! js_value!... Then you can just say js_value!(server_options, cx, "namespace", JsString)

cards.summary: Worker fails to connect using intermediate certificates on macOS with 'UnknownIssuer' error when following the mTLS tutorial with the tls-full sample. The issue appears to be related to how gRPC-Node handles certificate chains on macOS.
cards.userImpact: Users on macOS cannot establish secure connections to Temporal servers using intermediate certificates, blocking mTLS deployment on that platform.
cards.rootCause: gRPC-Node issue with certificate chain validation on macOS when intermediate CAs are involved; likely related to grpc/grpc-node#1784 where the issuer certificate cannot be resolved.
cards.workaround: Use only a root CA without intermediate certificates; ensure certificates are generated with SHA256 instead of SHA1.
cards.resolutionDetails: Issue was resolved, likely through gRPC-Node updates or SDK changes to handle certificate chains properly.
cards.keyQuote: I believe that is this issue: https://github.com/grpc/grpc-node/issues/1784

cards.summary: Implement automated load testing that runs on every PR to stress-test the system and uncover bugs that integration tests miss. Testing should include cloud deployment scenarios to validate address and TLS options.
cards.userImpact: Automated load testing will catch bugs early in the development cycle before they reach users in production.
cards.proposedFix: Set up benchmark tests to run on every PR, including scenarios testing cloud deployment with address and TLS options
cards.resolutionDetails: Automated load testing feature was implemented and integrated into the CI/PR workflow
cards.keyQuote: The simple bench test stresses the system uncovering bugs that integration tests tend to miss.

cards.summary: Snipsync comments (// @@@SNIP{START,END}) are incorrectly appearing in generated code when creating a new package via npm init @temporalio. These comments should be stripped away during code generation.
cards.userImpact: Users see unwanted snipsync comments in their generated project code, creating confusion and clutter.
cards.rootCause: Code generation template processor is not removing snipsync comment markers
cards.resolutionDetails: Closed by #91
cards.keyQuote: // @@@SNIP{START,END} comment show up in generated code.

cards.summary: Worker needs SSL/TLS configuration support for secure connections to Temporal service in production environments. Currently only the Client supports SSL configuration, creating a gap for production Worker deployments.
cards.userImpact: Workers cannot be safely deployed in production environments without SSL/TLS support for connecting to the Temporal service.
cards.proposedFix: Implement SSL configuration for Worker similar to the Node gRPC API pattern (grpc.credentials.createSsl)
cards.resolutionDetails: SSL/TLS configuration support was added to the Worker connector
cards.keyQuote: This feature is missing in order for the Worker to function in production environments. Currently only the Client supports this.

cards.summary: Request to implement stress testing capability for the TypeScript SDK to verify correctness under load, ensure no crashes or memory leaks, and publish results for transparency about alpha release performance expectations.
cards.userImpact: Users need confidence that the alpha SDK can handle realistic workloads without crashes or memory leaks.
cards.keyQuote: To make sure we operate correctly under mild load and don't crash or leak memory. We should publish the results so people know what to expect from the alpha release.

cards.summary: Path aliases using `@` prefix in auto-generated packages cause confusion with npm package scopes like `@temporalio`, and path aliases break after `npm pack`. The issue was resolved by keeping only the necessary `@activities` alias for the webpack resolver.
cards.userImpact: Developers can be confused by `@` prefix aliases appearing like package scopes, and generated projects cannot be published without additional tooling due to broken path aliases.
cards.rootCause: TypeScript path aliases are not resolved during `npm pack`, breaking relative imports in published packages. The `@` prefix conflicts with npm package scope naming conventions.
cards.proposedFix: Either change the alias prefix to avoid confusion with package scopes, or use ttsc to translate path aliases before publication. Ultimately, keep only the essential `@activities` alias for webpack resolver functionality.
cards.workaround: Use `ttsc` tool to translate path aliases before publishing the project.
cards.resolutionDetails: Resolved by removing unnecessary aliases and keeping only the special `@activities` alias required for the custom webpack resolver, making it configurable if needed.
cards.keyQuote: The aliases are definitely broken after `npm pack`. We can get rid of the interfaces alias but we need the activities alias for the module loader.

cards.summary: Add workflow versioning support to the TypeScript SDK to enable code changes for running workflows, similar to Java SDK implementation using history markers or webpack bundling.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot safely update workflow code while instances are running, blocking production deployments and code maintenance.
cards.proposedFix: Three proposed solutions: 1) Record markers in workflow history like Java SDK, 2) Bundle workflows with webpack and store versions in worker directory, 3) Add versioning to module loader with version storage capability.
cards.resolutionDetails: Implemented workflow versioning support in the TypeScript SDK, referenced in sdk-core PR #156.
cards.keyQuote: Other SDKs support workflow versioning in order to support code changes for running workflows. We must add this functionality to the Node SDK too shortly after the alpha.

cards.summary: Add API documentation generation to the TypeScript SDK release flow. Publish generated docs to a docs branch organized by package version.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot easily access offline API documentation for the TypeScript SDK without building it locally.
cards.proposedFix: Integrate documentation generation into the release flow and publish to docs branch under package version folders. Integrate with main documentation site.
cards.resolutionDetails: Docs integrated into the documentation site via temporalio/documentation#354. Versioned docs support planned for future.
