cards.keyQuote: Docs will be integrated into the docs site. We'll add versioned docs once the documentation repo supports it.

cards.summary: Implement snipsync integration to automatically test code snippets in TypeScript SDK documentation, preventing them from breaking due to code changes.
cards.userImpact: Users receive outdated or broken code examples in documentation, leading to confusion and failed implementation attempts.
cards.proposedFix: Use snipsync tool to automatically test and synchronize code snippets in documentation with actual codebase changes.
cards.resolutionDetails: Implemented snipsync integration for documentation code snippets to ensure they remain synchronized with codebase changes.
cards.keyQuote: We have quite a few code snippets in the docs, they're bound to break due to code changes, snipsync should help us test our snippets.

cards.summary: Add a warning to the TypeScript SDK API documentation and code about API instability during early development. The project's APIs are not yet stable and need more user feedback before reaching production-ready status.
cards.userImpact: Users should be made aware that the SDK APIs are unstable and may change based on feedback.
cards.proposedFix: Add warnings to API documentation and possibly in code about API instability
cards.resolutionDetails: The request was addressed by adding API stability warnings to the TypeScript SDK documentation
cards.keyQuote: The project's APIs are unstable until we have enough feedback and the project's more feature complete.

cards.summary: Worker times out when attempting graceful shutdown via Ctrl-C. This issue affects the shutdown process of the TypeScript SDK worker, making it difficult to cleanly stop workers.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot gracefully shut down workers via Ctrl-C without experiencing timeouts, affecting operational workflows.
cards.resolutionDetails: Resolved through implementation of proper shutdown handling in the worker (likely merged with #58 referenced in the issue).
cards.keyQuote: Easily reproducible via starting a worker and hitting Ctrl-C.

cards.summary: Request to migrate from the deprecated `grpc` package to `@grpc/grpc-js` for faster installations on Node 15+. Discussion reveals potential TLS/mTLS compatibility issues that were encountered in other Temporal projects.
cards.userImpact: Users could benefit from faster package installations on Node 15+, but potential TLS issues need verification.
cards.rootCause: Current dependency on deprecated `grpc` package; `@grpc/grpc-js` is pure JS alternative but has known TLS issues in some configurations
cards.proposedFix: Migrate from `grpc` to `@grpc/grpc-js` package with proper TLS/mTLS configuration handling
cards.workaround: Set GRPC_SSL_CIPHER_SUITES environment variable to address mTLS issues
cards.resolutionDetails: Feature was implemented; package migration was completed with TLS workaround documented
cards.keyQuote: It's implemented in pure JS which should make installations on node 15 faster.

cards.summary: Design a proper logging system for workflows that integrates with the worker logger instead of injecting console.log. Workflow internals need dedicated logging capabilities separate from user workflow code.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot properly capture and manage logs from both workflow internals and their own workflow code in a unified way.
cards.rootCause: Current console.log injection approach doesn't provide proper logging integration for workflow internals.
cards.proposedFix: Integrate workflow logging with the worker logger instead of using console.log injection.
cards.resolutionDetails: Implemented proper logging integration for workflows with worker logger.
cards.keyQuote: Workflow internals do not and should never use `console.log` for logging, instead we should integrate with the worker logger.

cards.summary: Define a clear strategy for handling different types of errors returned from core methods in the TypeScript SDK. This involves standardizing error handling across various core operations to ensure consistent and predictable error behavior.
cards.userImpact: Users need a consistent and well-defined way to handle errors from core operations to properly implement error handling in their workflows.
cards.resolutionDetails: Error handling strategy was implemented and standardized across core methods
cards.keyQuote: There are different types of errors that might be returned from the different core methods, define a clear strategy of handling these errors.

cards.summary: No method currently exists to cleanup a completed workflow. The issue discusses the need to define how workflow cleanup should be handled in terms of core and language-specific responsibilities.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot properly cleanup completed workflows, potentially leaving dangling resources or state.
cards.resolutionDetails: Resolved by #74 which implemented the workflow cleanup functionality.
cards.keyQuote: Currently there's no method to cleanup a completed workflow, decide how that works in terms of core<->lang responsibilities.

cards.summary: Complete API documentation for all public packages in the TypeScript SDK. This task involves documenting the worker, client, workflow, activity, proto, and create packages, with documentation to be published.
cards.userImpact: Users need complete and accessible API documentation to effectively use all public packages in the TypeScript SDK.
cards.resolutionDetails: All public packages (worker, client, workflow, activity, proto, create) were documented and published.
cards.keyQuote: Complete API documentation for all public packages

cards.summary: Implement missing worker concurrency and rate limiting options from WorkerOptions. Partial implementation exists for maxConcurrentActivityExecutions and maxConcurrentWorkflowTaskExecutions, with other limits pending Core SDK support.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot fully control worker resource consumption without complete implementation of all WorkerOptions limits.
cards.rootCause: Some rate limiting features not yet implemented in Core SDK; partial implementation existed in PR #71.
cards.proposedFix: Expose maxTaskQueueActivitiesPerSecond and implement remaining rate limits as Core SDK support becomes available.
cards.resolutionDetails: Implemented through phased approach starting with PR #71 for maxConcurrentActivityExecutions and maxConcurrentWorkflowTaskExecutions, with additional limits added as Core SDK support became available.
cards.keyQuote: Worker should respect the limits defined in WorkerOptions

cards.summary: Ensure all test activity cases are covered in integration tests, including all ActivityResult variants and heartbeat timeout scenarios on the workflow side.
cards.userImpact: Incomplete test coverage may leave activity functionality untested and undiscovered issues in production.
cards.resolutionDetails: Integration tests were completed covering all ActivityResult variants and heartbeat timeout scenarios.
cards.keyQuote: Get all of the cases from the test activities covered. Make sure to test all of the ActivityResult variants on the workflow side and heartbeat timeout on the workflow side.

cards.summary: User requests adding a roadmap to the TypeScript SDK README to clarify the project's current state and supported features. They want to contribute but the early-stage status and lack of clarity create uncertainty about what can be used.
cards.userImpact: Developers cannot easily understand the project's maturity level and supported features, making it difficult to decide whether to adopt and contribute to the SDK.
cards.proposedFix: Add a roadmap section to the README listing supported features and upcoming milestones, similar to the Cadence Python client example.
cards.resolutionDetails: Issue was closed by maintainer with note that discussions can continue if needed. A milestone was added to track alpha release planning, partially addressing the roadmap concern.
cards.keyQuote: This would really help to grasp in what state is the current project.

cards.summary: Worker constructor lacks connection options, forcing localhost-only connections. This issue requests adding connection options to the worker constructor and passing them to core initialization.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot connect workers to remote Temporal servers, limiting deployment flexibility to local development only.
cards.proposedFix: Add connection options parameter to worker constructor and pass them through to core initialization
cards.resolutionDetails: Connection options were added to worker constructor
cards.keyQuote: Currently can only connect to localhost.

cards.summary: Request to set up a logger for the worker package with support for popular Node.js loggers or custom logger injection, with fallback to console.error.
cards.userImpact: Users can integrate their own logging stack with the SDK instead of being limited to default logging behavior.
cards.proposedFix: Allow injecting a custom logger with fallback to console.error, or use a popular Node.js logger by default.
cards.resolutionDetails: Logger support was implemented for the worker package.
cards.keyQuote: I feel like usually developers have their own logging stack and I'd like to have the option to plug into any logger.

cards.summary: Add a utility function to convert exceptions into the standardized temporal.api.failure.v1.IFailure format for use throughout the TypeScript SDK codebase.
cards.userImpact: Provides a consistent and standardized way to handle exceptions across the SDK, ensuring proper error representation in the Temporal API.
cards.proposedFix: Create a utility function to convert exceptions into IFailure format and apply it throughout the codebase where TODO comments indicated the need.
cards.resolutionDetails: Exceptions are now expressed via coresdk.common.IUserCodeFailure with the utility applied to relevant occurrences throughout the codebase.
cards.keyQuote: Exceptions are now express via `coresdk.common.IUserCodeFailure`, updated the relevant occurrences.

cards.summary: The current implementation buffers poll results in a queue when polling in a separate thread, which can cause timing issues. Activities may be marked as started before the worker actually processes them, creating race conditions between polling and execution.
cards.userImpact: Activities may be incorrectly marked as started before they actually begin execution, causing timing issues and potential worker failures.
cards.rootCause: Poll results are buffered in a queue between the polling thread and JS thread, decoupling the actual start of activity execution from when it's reported as started.
cards.proposedFix: Replace the buffered queue with either a bounded blocking queue or poll only when JS is ready for the next result.
cards.resolutionDetails: Implemented on-demand polling mechanism to eliminate buffering of poll results.
cards.keyQuote: activities are automatically considered started when a poll request returns and if the worker is busy it might not actually start them in time

cards.summary: The TypeScript SDK loader hangs when cyclic module dependencies are detected. The issue requests detection and proper error throwing instead of hanging.
cards.userImpact: Users experience application hangs when their code has circular module dependencies, making the SDK unusable.
cards.rootCause: The module loader does not detect cyclic dependencies and enters an infinite loop
cards.proposedFix: Detect cyclic module dependencies and throw an error instead of hanging
cards.resolutionDetails: The loader now detects and throws on cyclic module dependencies
cards.keyQuote: the loader will hang when a cycle is found

cards.summary: Worker crashes with LoaderError when a referenced workflow file is not found. The node-side error handling needs improvement and core may not be handling the failure correctly.
cards.userImpact: Worker crashes when referencing non-existent workflow files, preventing graceful error handling and making the failure difficult to debug.
cards.rootCause: Worker does not handle missing workflow files gracefully; core is not properly handling the loader failure.
cards.proposedFix: Add error handling on the node side to catch and handle LoaderError appropriately; ensure core properly handles workflow load failures.
cards.resolutionDetails: Error handling added on the node side with test coverage; core updated to properly handle workflow file loading failures.
cards.keyQuote: LoaderError: Could not find file: /private/tmp/example/lib/workflows/not-found.js

cards.summary: Set up CI/CD pipeline to automatically publish TypeScript SDK packages to npm. Needs decisions on publish trigger, version bumping strategy, and changelog generation.
cards.userImpact: Without automated publishing, SDK releases require manual steps, slowing down release cycles and increasing error risk.
cards.proposedFix: Implement CI/CD workflow with decisions on: publish on main branch merge, version bump strategy (patch/minor/major), and auto-generated changelogs using lerna-changelog.
cards.resolutionDetails: Duplicate of issue #170
cards.keyQuote: Need to first consider: When to publish packages (on merge to main?), Which version to bump: patch, minor, major?

cards.summary: Add E2E testing for `npm init @temporalio` workflow to verify the project initialization functionality doesn't break with each PR. The test should verify the complete workflow from publishing packages to a temporary registry, initializing a project, building it, and running worker/tests.
cards.userImpact: Ensures that users can reliably initialize new Temporal TypeScript projects without regressions in the crucial `npm init` workflow.
cards.proposedFix: Implement E2E test workflow using temporary npm registry (verdaccio), Temporal docker-compose, and testing across multiple platforms (Windows, MacOS Intel/Apple, Linux).
cards.resolutionDetails: Closed with adequate coverage achieved through precompilation of packages and removal of node-gyp dependency, reducing risk. Intel Mac testing against Temporal Cloud currently sufficient.
cards.keyQuote: Closing for good enough coverage, the risk is not as high now that we precompile everything and don't have the node-gyp dependency.

cards.summary: Review and improve README.md files across the project to provide better explanations of what each package contains.
cards.userImpact: Users have difficulty understanding the purpose and contents of different packages in the project.
cards.keyQuote: We should provide better explanations for what the various packages in this project contain.

cards.summary: The worker's poll_task needs to drain remaining activations and properly detect the ShuttingDown signal during graceful shutdown. Currently, the promise from worker.run() never resolves because poll_task is blocked on a long poll and cannot see the shutdown flag.
cards.userImpact: Workers cannot shut down gracefully; the shutdown promise hangs indefinitely, requiring timeout-based termination.
cards.rootCause: poll_task is blocked on a long poll and never gets a chance to see that the shutdown flag is set, preventing it from detecting CoreError::ShuttingDown.
cards.proposedFix: Interrupt the long poll when the shutdown flag is set so poll_task can detect the shutdown signal and drain remaining activations.
cards.resolutionDetails: Fixed by sdk-core PR #59 which provided a mechanism to interrupt the long poll during shutdown.
cards.keyQuote: poll_task is stuck blocked on the long poll and never gets a chance to see that the shutdown flag is set. I need some way to interrupt the long poll when that happens.

cards.summary: README instructions fail because @temporalio/create package hasn't been published to npm yet. User encounters 404 error when trying to initialize a new project and requests documentation on how the package aliases are configured.
cards.userImpact: Users cannot follow the README instructions to get started with the SDK, creating a barrier to entry for new developers.
cards.rootCause: @temporalio/create package not yet published to npm registry
cards.proposedFix: Publish @temporalio/create to npm and document the package structure and aliases in the README
cards.resolutionDetails: Package was subsequently published to npm and documentation was updated
cards.keyQuote: This is because we haven't published anything to `npm` yet. I'll do that soon. I agree we should document the different packages in this repo.

cards.summary: Request to distribute pre-built binaries for native Rust code used in the TypeScript SDK worker and workflow-isolate-extension to simplify installation and avoid requiring node-gyp compilation.
cards.userImpact: Users currently need to compile native dependencies during SDK installation, which requires build tools like node-gyp to be installed.
cards.proposedFix: Distribute pre-built binaries for native worker code and workflow-isolate-extension similar to approaches used in Neon bindings
cards.workaround: Install node-gyp system dependency for compilation during installation
cards.resolutionDetails: Issue deprioritized after implementing precompilation of Rust code (#58). Determined that node-gyp is a common and simple enough dependency for SDK installation.
cards.keyQuote: Won't do, only system dependency to install the SDK is node-gyp which is quite common and simple to install.

cards.summary: Integration tests are currently disabled via environment variable in CI. This issue requests enabling them by running a server with Docker Compose as part of the continuous integration pipeline.
cards.userImpact: Integration tests remain disabled in CI, reducing confidence in SDK functionality against real server deployments.
cards.proposedFix: Run server with Docker Compose as part of CI pipeline to enable integration tests
cards.resolutionDetails: Integration tests were enabled and now run as part of the CI pipeline
cards.keyQuote: Run server with compose as part of CI.

cards.summary: CI build on Windows fails during compilation of the workflow-isolate-extension due to errors in the isolated-vm library dependency.
cards.userImpact: Windows users cannot build the SDK due to CI failures preventing the workflow-isolate-extension from compiling.
cards.rootCause: Errors in isolated-vm/lib dependency causing build failures on Windows platform during GitHub Actions workflow.
cards.resolutionDetails: Issue was addressed and resolved (closed status), though specific fix details are not documented in the issue.
cards.keyQuote: windows-latest failed during building of the workflow-isolate-extension due to errors that seem to originate in isolated-vm/lib

cards.summary: Design review needed for cancellation and scopes implementation in the TypeScript SDK. The previous design in PR#5 was not agreed upon and should be revisited after project restructuring.
cards.userImpact: Users need a well-designed cancellation and scopes mechanism to properly handle workflow and activity cancellation.
cards.resolutionDetails: Issue marked invalid, likely superseded by project restructuring or resolved through design review process.
cards.keyQuote: The design in https://github.com/temporalio/sdk-node/pull/5 was not agreed upon, we should revisit after the project restructuring.

cards.summary: Code style suggestions for the scheduler implementation: simplify complex conditional logic by breaking it into separate variables, and clarify the use of while(true) loop for handling event exhaustion.
cards.userImpact: No direct user impact; this is a code quality improvement suggestion for maintainability.
cards.rootCause: Complex conditional logic in scheduler.ts that makes debugging difficult
cards.proposedFix: Break up complex logic into separate variable assignments for better readability
cards.resolutionDetails: Scheduler was simplified and the first nit was addressed. The while(true) loop was explained as necessary for handling event exhaustion when waiting for completions.
cards.keyQuote: The scheduler might run out of events in case it's waiting for completions in which case it falls off the for loop and awaits the first completion.
